webTitle: Tories led by rabble rouser says Kennedy

fields.headline: Tories led by rabble rouser says Kennedy
fields.trailText: William Hague was last night condemned as an "irresponsible rabble rouser" by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, as the war of words intensified between the two parties over Tory hardline interventions on asylum and law and order.
fields.body:
William Hague was last night condemned as an "irresponsible rabble rouser" by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, as the war of words intensified between the two parties over Tory hardline interventions on asylum and law and order.

Mr Kennedy, who believes the distance he put between his party and the Conservatives helped the Lib Dems gain a surprise byelection victory in Romsey earlier this month, claimed that, by pursuing "kneejerk" solutions to complex problems, Mr Hague was "devaluing political life in Britain".

Delivering the Isaiah Berlin lecture at the National Liberal Club in London, Mr Kennedy dubbed the Tory leader "Sheriff Hague - the apologist for vigilantes - shooting from the hip and asking questions later".

His assault on Mr Hague's record took in the Tory leader's tax guarantee, his support for tougher sentencing, his backing for householders using violence against intruders and his tough stance on asylum-seekers.

Liberal Democrat strategists believe the uncompromising criticism will not only demonstrate clear distance between the party and the Conservatives, but will also differentiate the Lib Dems from Labour.

They argue Tony Blair's government has entered into a Dutch auction with the Tories on law and order issues, and believe they can position themselves as the clearest alternative for voters turned off by Mr Hague's stance.

The Conservatives, also confident they are on a winning streak after gaining almost 600 local council seats, dismissed Mr Kennedy as "Downing Street's lapdog".

The Lib Dem leader, who has now set his sights on taking a further 50 - mainly Conservative - seats at the next election in the wake of his party's Romsey success, insisted that Mr Hague was not fit to be leader of the opposition, let alone prime minister.

Attacking the Tory leader's policies on asylum and crime, he said: "By stirring up base instincts against asylum seekers and by seeking to change the law by kneejerk reaction, Mr Hague is devaluing political life in Britain.

"Issues like asylum and the trial of criminals are difficult. They have no easy answers. They require calm reflection, and it is shameful behaviour to pretend otherwise.

"Today's Conservative party is led by an irresponsible rabble rouser. A potential prime minister should never pander to prejudice nor cover up his record nor propose policies he rejected in government.

"But William Hague is no future prime minister - indeed he is not even fit to lead the opposition. People are sick of his glib soundbites and rhetorical gestures on crime."

Mr Kennedy also described Mr Hague's claim that low taxation was in itself morally good as "laughable".

Turning his fire on the government, he said that Labour had a "strong authoritarian streak" and accused it of being "increasingly unable to recognise pluralism", as shown in the elections in Wales and London.

A Conservative party spokesman said: "Charles Kennedy is no potential prime minister. It is hard to take him seriously in his laughable role as a Downing Street lapdog."

webTitle: Microsoft revives old ruling in effort to foil break-up

fields.headline: Microsoft revives old ruling in effort to foil break-up
fields.trailText: Microsoft made a last-ditch attempt to prevent the US government from pursuing its break-up of the company yesterday by publicising a five-year-old ruling in which the government said that such a move would be against the public interest.
fields.body:
Microsoft made a last-ditch attempt to prevent the US government from pursuing its break-up of the company yesterday by publicising a five-year-old ruling in which the government said that such a move would be against the public interest.

In an unscheduled filing in the competition case, the software company claimed that the government had gone on record to defend the company from break-up in a 1995 case.

The government statement contradicted its present stance and undermined the case against the company, a spokesman said. The filing, made two days before both sides are expected in court again, stated: "The government has already admitted that the break-up of Microsoft would be 'dangerous to the economy's welfare' and 'against the public interest'. "

The spokesman said the filing was made in response to the government's latest attack. "There is still no basis for [the break-up] in law, or precedent, or anything," he said.

The earlier case was heard two years before the US justice department and 19 states brought the anti-monopoly action against Microsoft alleging that it abused its stranglehold on the world's PC market.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who ruled in favour of the government last month, is due to hear both sides argue over an appropriate remedy to the monopoly, in a Washington courtroom tomorrow.

While the government has called for the company to be broken into two businesses, Microsoft has argued that behavioural constraints monitored by regulators would be a sufficient remedy. The gulf between the two could delay a final ruling for several months.

Microsoft has demanded a further trial to argue against a break-up - a remedy which it has characterised as being "unprecedented" and "unwarranted".

A source close to the justice department rejected Microsoft's tactic in comments to Reuters news agency yesterday. The agency reported the source as saying that the filing "relies on statements made before Microsoft's illegal actions in this case had taken place. That Microsoft repeatedly broke the law after those statements demonstrates why only structural relief can prevent Microsoft from violating the anti-trust laws in the future".

Wall Street analysts were surprised at yesterday's events, partly because Microsoft has argued that a fast-changing industry has made the government's case invalid. Shares in Microsoft fell more than $2 yesterday, having fallen by almost 40% since the judge first announced his negative verdict.

fields.headline: Börse fears for hi-tech market
fields.trailText: Plans to merge the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges face a crucial hurdle this evening when members of the Deutsche Börse board meet to endorse the deal formally amid signs of growing disquiet.
fields.body:
Plans to merge the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges face a crucial hurdle this evening when members of the Deutsche Börse board meet to endorse the deal formally amid signs of growing disquiet.

The extent of the crisis facing the exchanges' attempts to persuade their members to back the deal was underlined by Frankfurt board member Klaus Patig. "Before the merger fails, I am pleading for a pause for thought. A failure of the merger would be a disaster."

Though there is widespread support for the principle of a merger which would be a signficant step towards pan-European share trading, opposition to the way in which the merger would be implemented has been growing.

At the centre of concerns in both Frankfurt and London is the issue of which centre will control the Neuer Markt. Under the terms of the deal the hi-tech Neuer Markt will remain in Frankfurt but will be administered from London, leading members of both exchanges to fear they will miss out on a fast growing area.

Yesterday the Deutsche Börse chief executive Werner Seifert held talks with representatives of the government of the state of Hesse. Its economics ministry, which has to approve the deal, has tabled a series of questions about the merger.

Among its concerns are that the system of trading hi-tech stocks in Frankfurt but blue chip shares in London could prove unworkable over the longer term as cost pressures force the industry to concentrate on a single centre and whether German investors could face having to take action against German companies through the British courts.

In Britain the former chancellor of the exchequer, Lord Lamont, is expected to raise the issue of the merger in the Lords later this week.

Though the Deutsche Börse board has given the nod to the London-Frankfurt tie-up in outline, Mr Seifert is expected to face a rough ride at this evening's meeting.

At least three of the 21 members of the board have publicly announced concerns about the deal and, according to some reports, up to seven are unhappy with the terms.

"The opposition is serious. A lot of people are really concerned that there will be empty shelves in Frankfurt," said one observer.

However others suggest that the forceful Mr Seifert, with strong support from the börse's chairman Rolf Breuer, who is also chairman of the exchange's biggest shareholder Deutsche Bank, will be able to drive the deal through.

One concern will be that, unless Mr Seifert can satisfy the doubters on his own board, there will be a perception in London that its partner is going cool on the deal and that could undermine the London exchange's attempts to sell the merger to its members.

Both Mr Seifert - who will become the chief executive of the merged exchange - and London stock exchange chairman Don Cruickshank are understood to be planning a series of meetings designed to reassure their respective memberships about the deal.

The LSE is expected to produce a memorandum on the merger terms, either at the end of next month or early in July. To add to its difficulties the exchange needs to get a 75% vote in favour of the deal, rather than a simple majority.

webTitle: Putting the dot.com plunge in perspective

fields.headline: Putting the dot.com plunge in perspective
fields.standfirst:
Danger in a kneejerk reaction

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sell in May and go away? Not bad advice this year - provided you didn't wait too long beyond the bank holiday - though April would have been even better. For those not nursing heavy losses from plunging hi-tech stocks the recent correction to overblown stock markets is no doubt to be welcomed.
fields.body:
Sell in May and go away? Not bad advice this year - provided you didn't wait too long beyond the bank holiday - though April would have been even better. For those not nursing heavy losses from plunging hi-tech stocks the recent correction to overblown stock markets is no doubt to be welcomed.

The Dow Jones, at not much above 10,000 and falling, is likely to do at least as much to cool the US economy as any amount of interest rate raising by Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve.

Add in the effect on sentiment of the odd dot.com demise and before long we will be able to reassure ourselves that sanity has been restored.

But just as the irrational exuberance - to borrow a phrase - which sent stock markets soaring to giddy heights was to be deplored, there is danger, too in overdoing the reaction when they are on the way down. The rocket at least looks spectacular - the stick is neither use nor ornament.

Take a look at the telecoms sector. Deutsche Telekom - or rather its stakeholder KfW - said yesterday that it would sell off some 200m shares in the telecoms group. That is a chunky offering, the equivalent of some 6.6% of the company's share capital. But it is still some way smaller than analysts had been expecting and yet there are doubts that, in the prevailing market climate, it might yet be too much.

The recent volatility makes Vodafone AirTouch's decision on how to dispose of Orange trickier, too. A market flotation has been the official line but, in the circumstances, the temptation to take the cash from a trade buyer will have increased. Hence, presumably, Chris Gent's signal yesterday that Vodafone may be prepared to change course.

In the new, harsher, climate the dot.coms are likely to find life more difficult, too. Until recently the one problem they did not have was in raising money. If anything some at least have had too much. But, for those which now need to go back to investors made more wary by recent events, further financing may be difficult.

That may be no bad thing in general terms but it would be unfortunate if viable ventures were to fail because they were unable to secure financing as a result of their sector falling out of favour.

Merger snags

The members of the Deutsche Börse's supervisory board are between a rock and a hard place. Given the level of disquiet already expressed, not least within their own ranks, nodding the deal through will seem at best indifferent towards the worries which have surfaced about the future of Frankfurt as a finanzplatz in the wake of the merger.

But if they reverse their earlier stance and vote the deal down they will leave both London and Frankfurt with very large holes in their respective strategies. Even saying "yes, but" risks undermining the deal. The LSE is going to have a tough enough time persuading its members to back the merger without having to battle against the perception that its partner is an unwilling one.

To an extent they and the architects of the deal have only themselves to blame - though they are entitled to feel frustrated, too, that critics in both centres are claiming their exchange will lose out to the other. One set, after all, must be wrong.

The plan was put together in haste. Though it addressed the crucial issue of pan European trading - a facility on which many in both London and Frankfurt are keen - it left much undone. And while it is clear the two exchanges want to bring in others - Milan and Madrid to name but two - how that will be done is not. Nor has enough been done to address the concerns of those facing additional costs or who fear being marginalised but for whom the ability to deal easily and efficiently across European borders is not a central fact of daily commercial life.

Perhaps the strongest argument Deutsche Börse chief executive Werner Seifert will deploy will be the alternatives to acceptance. If the deal is voted down Frankfurt risks being isolated. London might be able to switch its attentions to Euronext - the alliance of Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels. Certainly Euronext would be keen enough.

The history of relations between Frankfurt and Paris, however, makes that option look unlikely for the German exchange. It could go it alone but that is risky. The London alliance will cement the position of Frankfurt's Xetra as Europe's leading trading system but it is unlikely to achieve that standing if the börse is forced to fly solo.

On balance the least worst option is for the board to back its executive this evening. That would allow both exchanges a breathing space during which they could do rather more thinking about the project than appears to have been the case to date and, equally importantly, work very hard at addressing the concerns of their members - and then do something about them.

fields.headline: Strengths to strengths
fields.standfirst:
Philadelphia Orchestra/ Wolfgang Sawallisch
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Philadelphia Orchestra/ Wolfgang Sawallisch
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: * * *
fields.body:
Wolfgang Sawallisch has been music director in Philadelphia now for seven years, and what seemed an unlikely appointment when he succeeded Riccardo Muti has matured into a fruitful relationship. The Philadelphia Orchestra established its international reputation under Stokowski and Ormandy as the epitome of the transatlantic orchestra, with highly coloured woodwind, assertive brass and silken strings; Sawallisch by contrast was rooted in the central European tradition, devoid of showmanship and with a total concentration on the musical essentials.

Yet conductor and orchestra have managed to find common ground - the Philadelphia has been encouraged to shed some of its star-spangled clothing, whereas Sawallisch, even in his 70s, has broadened his repertory and his approach too. Their concert together at the Festival Hall, part of an extensive European tour, was designed to play to the traditional strengths of both halves of the partnership, with Beethoven to begin, and Respighi and Stravinsky to follow after the interval.

Sawallisch's Beethoven is robust and warmly sonorous; it's a long time since the Fourth Symphony can have been played in the RFH with an orchestra built upon a foundation of eight double basses. Yet it moved lithely, and the still sharp focus of the Philadelphia's woodwind ensured that very little of the detail went missing.

The approach to Respighi's The Birds may have been a touch heavy-handed, but there was no holding back in The Firebird, given in Stravinsky's 1919 suite. The dynamic range was huge - the Philadelphia's quiet playing is just as vivid as its fortissimos - and the interweaving of the woodwind in the Princesses' Round Dance and in the Berceuse was perfectly done. Other conductors can screw up the tension a couple of notches more, but Sawallisch certainly made the finale weighty enough.

fields.headline: Jive and disarray
fields.standfirst:
Javier De Frutos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Javier De Frutos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * *
fields.body:
Javier De Frutos's latest work is a homage to Tennessee Williams, a writer who reflects his own obsession with love's seesaw axis of delusion and disillusion, and shares his own unusually bleak focus on human pain. Unlike Williams's best work however, which evoked human disarray in strong theatrical form, Montana's Winter seems without structure.

The piece breaks into two mismatched halves, beginning with a solo in which De Frutos performs a kind of cross- gendered, composite neurotic. Dressed in cowboy gear and a hula skirt, he fills 25 minutes with variations on a tight-hipped, mincing jive. At times the steps expand into vainglorious strutting, but mostly they're reduced to a fidgeting seizure of low-level agitation. This, as choreography, is outrageously repetitious, yet it's made watchable by its uncanny layering of personality, its tiny rhythmic nuances allowing us to see stud and spinster, Stanley and Blanche, within the same phrase.

Part two is completely different. De Frutos is joined by five dancers who veer between excruciating self exposure and obsessive mutual engagement. None of them boast hot-house bodies and as they strip off their clothes their bare bulging thighs and unheroic genitals show their (and our) fears of imperfection. They go on to flip be tween graceless need and psychopathic aggression in images ragged and raw. We might weep for their courage, only the material in this section has little argument or characterisation to engage us.

Apart from some beautifully crafted snippets of dance, the choreography is little more than a hail of disconnected shock tactics. Like crazy people shouting in the street, we see the dancers' anguish but can't make contact. De Frutos's best work has always drawn inside its circle of pain, but watching Montana's Winter we're like tourists on a visit to Bedlam.
At the Lowry Centre, Salford (0161-876 2000), tonight and tomorrow, and the Arnolifini, Bristol (0117-929 9191), on Thursday and Friday.

webTitle: Net Imperative joins dot.com casualty list

fields.headline: Net Imperative joins dot.com casualty list
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Net Imperative was forced to call in the liquidator after broker and net investment firm Durlacher pulled the plug on the information provider.
fields.body:
Net Imperative was forced to call in the liquidator after broker and net investment firm Durlacher pulled the plug on the information provider.

Durlacher shares, which have fallen more than 80% since February, fell 8p to 69.5p on the news. Chairman and chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain said it was the first time his company had been involved in a failure of this kind.

Lee Manning, a partner with liquidators Kroll Buchler Phillips, said the collapse could be the thin edge of the wedge. "I have just received a call from another internet company in trouble."

Mr Manning blamed the failure on stock market jitters. He said Net Imperative wanted to raise more cash but the shareholders, including Durlacher with 28.5%, refused to oblige.

Mr Chamberlain insisted there would be no change in the way Durlacher conducted its business.

Net Imperative had represented a good potential business but failed to meet its goals. "It is sad for everyone when this happens but we set strict targets, and if they are not achieved then we must accept it. But this is not a Boo.com situation. We are talking about a company capitalised at £2m."

The collapse of the east London firm came less than six months after its launch.

fields.headline: Boo liquidators make 220 staff redundant
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The bulk of the staff at Boo.com were made redundant yesterday as the liquidator struggled to find a buyer for the failed internet sportswear retailer.
fields.body:
The bulk of the staff at Boo.com were made redundant yesterday as the liquidator struggled to find a buyer for the failed internet sportswear retailer.

The liquidator, Mick McLoughlin of KPMG, said that to protect the company's remaining funds he had no option but to make 220 of the 250 staff redundant.

Those losing their jobs are unlikely to qualify for any redundancy payments because the business has been trading for only six months.

Mr McLoughlin, who had hoped to announce a buyer for the business yesterday, said he now expected negotiations with potential buyers to continue throughout the week.

"We are looking towards making a decision on a possible sale of the business in whole or in parts within days," he said.

"But there remains the possibility that a successful sale will not be achieved and the liquidation will continue to its conclusion."

Closure of the business and sale of its assets would raise little to repay creditors.

KPMG does not expect the former Boo staff to remain unemployed for long. "We are aware that a number of agencies and outside parties are making job offers to many of those made redundant," Mr McLoughlin said.

A KPMG spokesman denied that the departure of staff would make it harder to find a buyer for Boo, which was founded by Swedish duo Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander.

He said 30 staff including the directors had been retained by the liquidator to demonstrate Boo's system and answer questions from potential purchasers.

A lot of Boo staff, involved in developing the website and the advanced technology to run it, and negotiating deals with suppliers, were now no longer needed. A spokesman said: "You do not need 40 call centre staff if you are not trading."

KPMG has a 12-member team working round the clock on finding buyers for all or part of the business.

They are negotiating with six possible buyers, each of which has put down a £1m returnable deposit to take part in the talks.

Some are from outside Britain and not all are existing internet businesses.

Boo collapsed last Thursday after it failed to secure an injection of cash.

The company has been criticised for its lavish spending and lack of financial controls.

Industry experts also said its downfall was partly the result of developing a costly and complex website which enabled potential customers to rotate pictures of products and fit them on to figures.

Such technology worked well when viewed from office computers with fast connections to the internet but were too slow when viewed from home PCs.

webTitle: Bank that's just you and the web

fields.headline: Bank that's just you and the web
fields.standfirst:
Lloyds TSB wanted a new style of e-bank. They've got it

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB is relying on Jayne Almond to fulfil its pledge to create "the lowest cost bank in the world". Hired last year when Peter Ellwood, the chief executive was looking for "someone different" to launch his new internet bank, Ms Almond is no stranger to internet startups.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB is relying on Jayne Almond to fulfil its pledge to create "the lowest cost bank in the world". Hired last year when Peter Ellwood, the chief executive was looking for "someone different" to launch his new internet bank, Ms Almond is no stranger to internet startups.

As a consultant, she was a key player behind the scenes when Prudential launched Egg and the Cooperative Bank launched Smile last year. But, this time she is no longer a consultant but managing director of European internet banking.

She says Evolvebank.com, the name of Lloyds TSB's internet bank, is different too; unlike other internet banks Evolvebank.com will not have a heavily staffed call centre to conduct transactions for customers. It will just be the customer and the world wide web.

"If you want to create the lowest cost bank in the world then this is the model you have to develop," she says. A low cost bank should knock spots off its competitors by offering cheaper loans and better savings rates.

But, eight months before Evolvebank.com is launched in Britain and a few months before its October debut in Spain, her competitors are knocking her plan. They do not believe that the public is ready for a bank which purely operates on the internet, without a friendly voice on the end of a phone.

Ms Almond, dressed as an internet entrepreneur rather than a suit-clad banker, is undeterred. "It is stunningly low cost - this is what the banks don't appreciate - in comparison with a a telephone bank. We can save customers an awful lot of money." Without carrying the cost of employing hundreds of telephone staff like many of her competitors, her products should be the cheapest.

Based away from Lloyds TSB's stuffy head office in the City, she has chosen airy, bright offices near Victoria for her team, a contrast between the old and the new. Like all internet entrepreneurs, she is in the process of securing her close-knit team of 40 a new performance-related pay deal, essentially a shadow share options scheme.

But Evolvebank.com is just one prong of Lloyds TSB's internet strategy. Lloyds TSB, like all its rivals, is also launching it own-brand internet bank. Only a handful, such as Halifax and Abbey National, are also launching stand alone operations - Intelligent Finance for Halifax and Cahoot for Abbey - as well, though they appear to be internet and telephone ventures.

Barclays, which is to reveal further details of its internet strategy this morning, has so far chosen to develop under its own brand. All the banks face the criticism that they will erode their own customer bases with the new operations and Ms Almond admits that 30% of her customers might originate from Lloyds TSB.

According to her, Evolvebank.com has an international appeal and, to the surprise of many, it will be launched in Spain because customers there are "appallingly ripped off". By the end of the first year in Spain, she hopes to have 10,000 to 15,000 customers although she is already being frustrated in her marketing efforts by Spain which is refusing to let Evolvebank.com advertise comparative interest rates. The firm is considering taking its case to Europe's competition commission.

By the end of the second year, Evolvebank.com is aiming for 100,000 customers in Spain who will initially be offered current accounts, savings and credit cards.

Aware of the "reputational risk" for Lloyds TSB, it will not be launched in Britain until December or January. Ms Almond promises a "good pricing" pledge and a home page which will be personalised according to each customers' demand. She is cautious about offering products similar to Halifax's Intelligent Finance, which allows customers to optimise interest by temporarily moving money into and out of loans and savings accounts.

Other banks making big promises to customers - such as Prudential's Egg - have come unstuck when they underestimated demand for their product. This is why Ms Almond is trying to be realistic in her ambitions. The bank will be ready for launch on December 1 in Britain but may not be marketed until mid-January, after the Christmas rush, and wants to have 750,000 customers in three years.

Her break-even point, a key issue for all internet startups, is relatively low at 200,000 customers. Egg is yet to make money even with 1m customers.

With Egg preparing for a stock market flotation, Ms Almond insists that there are "no plans" for an Evolvebank.com share sale. However, as many internet firms have found, keeping and motivating staff is an issue, which is why she is installing short-term and long-term bonus schemes.

"We're setting an incentive structure for everyone to work as a team," she says. And, as a woman in what is often a man's world, she believes women are much better team players than men.

webTitle: Should you be paid for travelling time?

fields.headline: Should you be paid for travelling time?
fields.trailText: 23 May: My boss is sending me on a foreign trip but she refuses to pay me for the time it will take to get there.
fields.body:
The problem

I am working two days a week as a part time designer for a cloth manufacturer. My boss pays me over time whenever it is requested but recently I have been asked to go on a business trip to Austria.

She only wants to pay me overtime from the actual take off of the plane on Sunday and put the rest down to travelling time. Likewise she won't pay for the four hours I'm spending travelling from the mountain resort where the job is to the hotel in Vienna.

The solution

Working time rights are very complicated. The only (almost) certainties amongst all the complex issues surrounding working hours are that workers are entitled to regular breaks and cannot be sacked for refusing to work Sundays. However, even these rights vary in some circumstances. The bottom line then as far as your legal rights are concerned is that I would advise you to avoid resorting to asserting them at this stage since you could become embroiled in a messy wrangle.

I think you would do better negotiating with your boss in terms of what you and she can agree is reasonable. She really should pay you for any time you spend engaged in work activities and this includes travel above and beyond your normal route to work. However, she could argue that you could be doing other things on the plane, in your hotel etc., that are not work activities.

The problem is that you are both trying to apply a specific overtime rule to an unusual situation i.e. a trip abroad. I think that rather than work out payments by the hour you would do much better negotiating an overall fee for the whole trip based on not on some hourly rate, but on what you both consider reasonable for four days of your time. For instance, you could agree on your regular weekday rate if she will agree to pay fairly for the other two extra days.

Perhaps you won't get exactly the fee your hour-by-hour calculations suggest you should, but you could regard this sort of extra work activity as investment in your own career (oversees trips look good on the CV) as well as expressing company loyalty which might be rewarded in the future. The key is to give a little without being taken advantage of.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Kingston breaks out of Hull
fields.trailText: Kingston Communications is considering a £1bn national roll-out of the pay-television service which the telecoms business launched in its home city of Hull last year.
fields.body:
Kingston Communications is considering a £1bn national roll-out of the pay-television service which the telecoms business launched in its home city of Hull last year.

The plans emerged as Kingston announced it had joined forces with rival Colt Telecom to share the cost of building a £150m national fibre optic network. The agreement will provide the backbone for Kingston's ambition to break out of the Hull region in both the corporate telecoms market and ultimately in pay TV.

Kingston chief executive Steve Maine said the company was also considering a number of takeover targets to take advantage of the recent fall in telecoms stocks.

The deal with Colt, described as sensible by analysts, failed to halt the slide in Kingston's shares which reached a peak of around £15.92 at the beginning of March. They fell another 63p to close at 535p. Mr Maine said: "People forget how quickly the shares had risen. Relative to our sector we have still outperformed."

However, there was also some concern about the company's planned level of capital expenditure. Mr Maine said the company was considering plans for a £1bn investment in a national pay-TV business through deploying ADSL technology which upgrades traditional copper telephone wires for broadband use.

The Hull-based service offers multi-channel TV over Kingston's telephone network through a joint venture with BSkyB. It is not yet decided whether the pair will partner each other nationwide.

Kingston reported pre-tax profits for its first year as a quoted company of £7.9m, down from £36m due to increased investment but in line with analysts' expectations. Revenues were 22% higher at £181m.

Mr Maine said the prime reason for developing a national fibre optic network was to improve margins and capacity available to its Torch subsidiary which provides telecoms services to corporate clients. The company has introduced Torch in four regions and yesterday announced plans to add Thames Valley and Manchester.

The lock-in agreement which prevented Kingston-upon-Hull city council from selling any more of its 43% shareholding ended yesterday.

fields.headline: High hopes for hi-tech shares
fields.standfirst: Investors are praying for a rise in the fortunes of dot.com shares after the so-called 'hi-tech boom' has so far failed to materialise, writes Marianne Curphey
fields.trailText: Investors are praying for a rise in the fortunes of dot.com shares after the so-called 'hi-tech boom' has so far failed to materialise, writes Marianne Curphey
fields.body:
Dot.com investors will be watching the markets carefully today in the hope that some good news will come their way after so much recent volatility in the markets.

Some of the shares which rose so strongly at the end of last year and fuelled the so-called 'tech boom' have now fallen back almost to the level they started at last November.

Investors who bought then would now be looking at no net loss, but the majority of private investors did most of their buying in March just before the end of the tax year and at the top of the market. They will be feeling the pain of having seen their holdings plunge almost as soon as they bought them.

Hi-tech stocks in the UK are particularly affected by the movements of the Nasdaq, the US' own index of technology companies, and bad news in the States late in the day tends to adversely affect opening share prices the next morning in London.

Meanwhile, investors who still hold the so-called 'old economy' stocks have seen two of the most high-profile blue chip companies enjoy a small revival in the fortunes of their share prices. The share prices of both British Airways and Marks & Spencer rose this morning in early trading, even though BA unveiled losses and M&S announced it was cutting its dividend - a decision which no chief executive ever takes lightly.

As often in the City, the dividend cut had been trailed so widely in the press beforehand that when the results came out the shares actually rose.

The same was true of BA, which although it announced a £21m loss for the 12-month period rather than a £206m profit for the same time last year, losses were actually less than had been predicted by analysts in the City and so the shares rose.

fields.headline: The kids are all fright
fields.standfirst:
Korn
Wembley Arena, London
**
fields.trailText:
Korn
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: * *
fields.body:
Some bands keep their fans at a safe distance. Korn keep them in a cage on stage. And it's this heart-warming attitude to the kids that shifts thousands of T-shirts and sells millions of albums around the world. In America, Korn's first two albums - the self-titled Korn and Life is Peachy - went platinum with no radio airplay or MTV backing.

In Britain they've built a young and devoted following of teenagers whose parents don't understand them. It's an atmosphere of expectation and complete deference that fills Wembley Arena. Life sucks - but there's always singer Jonathan Davis and his screeching tales of child abuse and pleas to be left alone to get you through the odd bad day at school. Like Korn's new, fourth album says, it's all about the Issues, man.

Davis, dressed like Rasputin, voice full of rage, stands centre-stage surveying the crowd furiously throwing themselves at his feet as the band wring the life out of Good God. The sound at Wembley is uniquely terrible. Live favourite Blind is powerful but rock by numbers, all crashing symbols, powerchords and head-banging without a hint of irony.

Davis is a rock'n'roll ham in the Kiss tradition, part showbiz, part shockmeister. In the second of three costume changes, he walks on stage wearing a kilt and playing the bagpipes for Shoots and Ladders. The band's synchronised dance moves and the cheery singalong of "get the fuck out of my face" smack more of Hammer horror than intimidating rock rebels with a cause, but the kids down the front lap it up. And the ones in the cage keep smiling.

fields.headline: Trail of night wonders
fields.standfirst:
The Path
Glen Lyon, Perthshire
****
fields.trailText:
The Path
Glen Lyon, Perthshire
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
You assemble in a car park in a small Scottish town at 9pm. You are given a time slot for transport, a wristband, and a sheet of paper. The latter suggests that if you are prone to anxiety, you might want to think again. It's probably drizzling. It's all mysterious, edgy, like waiting for directions to a rave, except that the crowd is sorted for expensive waterproofs and cake instead of Es and wizz.

By midnight, 300 of us are scrambling across a big hill in the rain. We are not on an Endurance-style game show, but on The Path, the latest spectac ular installation-intervention in the Scottish landscape by the NVA organisation. Two years ago they brought a dramatic river gorge to life at twilight. The Path makes this look like child's play in scale and logistics. It makes U2's most bombastically ambitious stage show look a bit underwhelming.

A two-and-a-half hour walk along an old peat path through the hills, it is a physically exhilarating challenge not because of the tough terrain but because of the darkness that threatens to envelop you. The Path is also a sensual feast, with breathtaking light projections; the smell of peat fires; the sound of percussion bands and traditional Highland song; the taste of hot lemon served at the halfway point. Pagan, Buddhist, and Christian belief systems collide and co-exist in the show, so there are profound moments aplenty or, for cynics, moments of good old-fashioned spectacle.

While on The Path it holds you tight in its grip. When you come down it's a bit like Brigadoon: you can't believe it ever existed and feel a bit silly for having enjoyed the indulgent romance so much. But that's when you're back on the road, hungrily nibbling at the cake as the birds begin to sing. Until June 4. Information line: 0141 204 3346.

fields.headline: 'Most disappointing ever for Zimbabwe'
fields.trailText: England may not have beaten the world's best. But after the ordeals of recent years it would be a misanthrope who did not confess to a sense of satisfaction at a job well done.
fields.body:
One win against South Africa in a stage-managed finish with the series already lost; one win against a Zimbabwe team substantiating their reputation as the worst test side in the world.

As successive test wins go, those achieved by England are hardly cause to call an immediate public holiday, but after the ordeals of recent years it would be a misanthrope who did not confess to a sense of satisfaction at a job well done.

For England to follow up their winter's victory against South Africa in Pretoria by assembling their biggest winning margin for 26 years - since they overwhelmed India by an innings and 285 runs, also on this ground - perfectly answered Nasser Hussain's call for them to embrace Zimbabwe's traditional virtues of discipline and concentration.

One of Hussain's central tenets of captaincy is not to overreact to success, just as he refuses to become deflated by failure. He prefers the long game, taking pride in consistent excellence, not crushing one-off victories.

"That was one of our most complete and professional performances," he said. "But over the years we've beaten Australia in tests like this. The sign of a good side is to play well over a long period of time. We will enjoy our success but, if you start saying everything is sorted, cricket will hit back at you."

That India series in 1974 provides sound historical reasons for Hussain's caution. England followed up their win at Lord's with another innings win at Edgbaston, but that winter the batsmen who had been so supreme took a merciless pummelling in Australia from Dennis Lillee and Jeff Thomson. It was so bad that David Lloyd, one of those batsmen, was moved to write home: "Dear Mum, Things are looking up. Today I got a half-volley in the nets."

Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's captain, rated this test as "the most disappointing in Zimbabwe's history" although he did give England some credit, describing them as "a purposeful unit, probably more so than I have seen in the past".

It is Zimbabwe's wholesale deficiencies, though, which will most trouble him before next week's second test at Trent Bridge. The batting of Alistair Campbell and Trevor Gripper, the bowling of Bryan Strang and his own wicketkeeping will be among his chief concerns.

"We played such poor cricket," he bemoaned. "There were technical deficiencies in the batting and, other than Heath Streak, a lack of penetration in our bowling. That was also my worst wicketkeeping performance; there was hardly a ball hit the middle of the gloves, so we will have to rethink that as well.

"I think the occasion got to the players. We've played a lot of international cricket, so we shouldn't have been that nervous."

England, so often diffident at headquarters, ruthlessly pressed home their superiority. The three pace bowlers all impressed and even Graeme Hick wondered aloud after his hundred if this time he might even last out a summer.

webTitle: King takes gloss off Nazir's knock

fields.headline: King takes gloss off Nazir's knock
fields.trailText: The West Indies bowlers fought back against Pakistan yesterday in Bridgetown, Barbados, leaving the second test evenly balanced after the teenage batsman Imran Nazir had completed his maiden test century for the visitors.
fields.body:
The West Indies bowlers fought back against Pakistan yesterday in Bridgetown, Barbados, leaving the second test evenly balanced after the teenage batsman Imran Nazir had completed his maiden test century for the visitors.

Pakistan, 145 runs behind on first innings, had raced to 219 without loss but were slowed to 345 for seven when bad light forced play to be abandoned on the fourth day. With the tourists exactly 200 ahead a draw seems the most likely outcome today.

The day started with the 18-year-old Nazir, on 92 overnight and playing in only his second test, reaching his century in the sixth over. He eventually made 131, putting on 219 for the first wicket with Mohammad Wasim who made 82.

Then Reon King hit back for the West Indies with three wickets before lunch to put the game back in the balance.

webTitle: Trescothick hits the high notes to drown out Swann song

fields.headline: Trescothick hits the high notes to drown out Swann song
fields.standfirst:
Northants Steelbacks 240
Somerset Sabres 243-6
Somerset win by four wickets
fields.trailText: Runs may have been as thick on the ground in the National League this season as bons mots from Paul Gascoigne but two of the promoted clubs made amends with a vengeance here yesterday.
fields.body:
Runs may have been as thick on the ground in the National League this season as bons mots from Paul Gascoigne but two of the promoted clubs made amends with a vengeance here yesterday.

Better still, Graeme Swann and Marcus Trescothick emphasised their claims for England one-day contracts with batting to warm the most resistant cockles.

On a day when the visitors' long-leg Darren Cousins cost his side a couple of runs with an impromptu visit to the loo, Somerset made short work of a daunting target thanks to an unbroken seventh-wicket stand of 85 in 11 overs between Keith Parsons and Ian Blackwell, achieving their second success in two 45-over games with 17 balls to spare.

Northamptonshire, meanwhile, have still to get off the mark. Their innings, the highest of the National League season to date, leant on two muscular partnerships: 59 in 11 overs for the third wicket by Matthew Hayden and David Sales, 88 in 14 for the sixth by Swann and David Ripley.

Coming as it did after Sales, Hayden and Jeff Cook had all exited inside seven overs in a blaze of needless smears, the last alliance was as vital as it was stirring.

Slim and enviably self- assured, Swann is noted for neither false modesty nor punctuality. Oversleeping once on a maiden senior tour as he did in South Africa might be considered careless; to do so twice smacked of wonky focus at best, hence the resultant fine.

The likeliest path to restitution lies less with those unfashionable off-breaks - his four overs here cost 29 - than that supple bat. Setting off with a deceptively delicate nudge for four, Swann was soon taking the aerial route, the swing nonchalant, the timing sublime.

Racing to 50 off 35 balls with nine fours, he fell two overs later, missing a Trescothick long-hop, but the means will surely outlive the end.

The same could be said of Trescothick. Giving Somerset a flyer with a pair of fours in Devon Malcolm's opening over, this strapping opener survived the early loss of Jamie Cox and faltered thereafter only when Piran Holloway, responding to his call, was run out from short midwicket as the hefty Hayden swooped with the grace of a prima ballerina.

Dismissing good-length balls as if piqued by such temerity, Trescothick drove with effortless yet ferocious power. One Malcolm over brought him 14, including an imperious hooked six that would have turned Ian Botham green.

Memories of what might have been were kindled by a brief liaison with Mark Lathwell, warmly applauded to the middle for his first significant knock here since missing last season with a knee complaint, but after making 68 off 80 balls Trescothick flicked Michael Davies to midwicket and departed with a livid swish of that mighty blade.

webTitle: Graveney moves to prevent insider gambling

fields.headline: Graveney moves to prevent insider gambling
fields.trailText: A sweeping anti-betting code is about to be imposed throughout British first-class cricket in an attempt to rid the domestic game of all its links with bookmakers.
fields.body:
A sweeping anti-betting code is about to be imposed throughout British first-class cricket in an attempt to rid the domestic game of all its links with bookmakers.

Stringent restrictions will apply not only to players but to all involved in the first-class game, including umpires, groundsmen and committee members.

David Graveney, chief executive of the Professional Cricketers' Association, is drawing up the code in partnership with Gerard Elias QC, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board's disciplinary committee.

"We need a clear and easy-to-understand code which makes the responsibilities of players and employees entirely plain," he said. "One suggestion is a total ban on cricket betting, under any circumstances, for all those involved within the game. The game must not just be clean but be seen to be clean."

Graveney presented a damning paper nine months ago on the development in Britain of spread betting, which enables wagers to be struck not only on the result of a match but on isolated incidents within the game. "Many of my fears about spread betting have already come true," he said.

It is spread betting in Asia which is being held chiefly responsible for the spread of match-rigging, organised by mafia-like betting rings, in international cricket.

The International Cricket Council will also face pressure today to launch an urgent investigation into fresh allegations that one of its own officials has acted as an intermediary between illegal bookmakers and players allegedly involved in match-fixing.

A national Sunday newspaper has offered the ICC videotapes of what it claims is an undercover sting against the former Pakistan batsman Salim Malik, in which Malik allegedly claims that an ICC official is on his match-fixers' payroll.

The taped meetings with Malik are said to have taken place in the Kensington Hilton hotel late last month, a few days before the emergency ICC meeting at Lord's into cricket corruption decided upon a series of stiff punishments for players or officials involved in any betting conspiracy.

Malik is one of the central figures in the Justice Qayyum match-fixing investigation, the findings of which the ICC has demanded are released by Pakistan well in advance of its next meeting at Lord's, on June 20. Persistent leaks suggest that Qayyum has recommended that Malik be banned for life.

With the energies of the ICC's president Jagmohan Dalmiya entirely taken up by protecting his own reputation against charges of corruption, the onus will be on the chief executive David Richards, who has been absent from his desk for the past fortnight, to respond to the newspaper's charges.

Tim Lamb, chief executive of the ECB, responded: "If there is fresh evidence then we will welcome this being cleared up as soon as possible.

"But the ICC have still to appoint their head of the anti-corruption commission, and you can't have a trial without a judge."

fields.headline: Calamity ends the tedium
fields.standfirst: For neutrals the hero was David James whose mistake spared us extra-time
fields.trailText: Just as Americans have turkeys for Thanksgiving and Christmas, so the English have them for Christmas and FA Cup finals. To that extent at least the last final at Wembley before the old grey mare of a stadium goes to the knackers kept faith with tradition. Cranberry sauce again was the order of the day.
fields.body:
Just as Americans have turkeys for Thanksgiving and Christmas, so the English have them for Christmas and FA Cup finals. To that extent at least the last final at Wembley before the old grey mare of a stadium goes to the knackers kept faith with tradition. Cranberry sauce again was the order of the day.

The most fortunate person in Saturday's long-suffering crowd of 78,000 was five-month-old Henry Wise, son of Dennis, the Chelsea captain. He was taken up to the Royal Box by his father to collect the trophy after Aston Villa had been beaten by Roberto di Matteo's opportunist goal. Wise Jr will have a picture to treasure but none of the memories of what went on before.

Though this was not the worst of Wembley's 72 FA Cup finals it certainly finished in the bottom six. On Saturday the stadium of legends was the stadium of dog-ends, the pitch littered with bits and pieces of football which struggled to catch fire.

The drab spectacle was redeemed in part by the winners' greater enterprise after half-time, but for neutrals the hero of the afternoon was David James, the Villa goalkeeper, whose error presented Di Matteo with the chance to score and spared everybody extra-time.

Nevertheless this success at the end of a season of unfulfilment may make a significant difference to the way Chelsea are heading. After their vapid performance at Old Trafford on Easter Monday, when a 3-2 defeat by Manchester United all but ended their chances of finishing in the top three of the Premiership and re-entering the Champions League next season, the break-up of the present team was widely predicted. Now, though the cracks are still there, the process may be less painful.

Marcel Desailly was easily Chelsea's outstanding performer at Wembley, reducing the aerial threat of Dion Dublin to leaflet raids and consistently bringing the ball out from the back in an effort to instigate attacking movements. The Frenchman's excellence was matched by Gareth Southgate in the Villa defence and, when defenders are dominant, it will always be difficult for a game to develop a pleasing flow.

John Gregory, the Villa manager and nothing if not a pragmatist, had long realised that his team would get nowhere attempting to take on Chelsea in a passing game. So George Boateng and Ian Taylor played it tough and tight in midfield and the ball was hoisted high and long towards Dublin.

Chelsea's manager Gianluca Vialli started with Gustavo Poyet switched with Di Matteo on to the right flank to exploit his aerial advantage over Villa's left wing-back Alan Wright. Chelsea, therefore, began off-balance and, with Wise and Didier Deschamps equally obdurate in the central areas, the match was a stalemate from the outset.

With the midfield resembling a trawl of mackerel, all heaving bodies struggling for air, there was never going to be much chance for skilful individuals to give the final a touch of distinction.

Paul Merson provided the one half-decent moment of the first half, a well executed volley from 25 yards which dipped over the bar, and even then Ed de Goey had it covered. Otherwise Merson's principal role lay in trying to provide a decent service to Dublin from crosses and set pieces.

Villa might have created more opportunities had Benito Carbone been able to feed off Dublin to greater effect. But the diminutive Italian struggled to find space against Desailly and Mario Melchiot, the Dutch under-21 international who had replaced the unfit Albert Ferrer at right-back and seized his opportunity with athletic alacrity.

Villa's one chance to save the match fell to Carbone 15 minutes from the end after De Goey dropped a free-kick from Merson. With half the goal to aim at Carbone scuffed his shot and Frank Leboeuf easily cleared it off the line. Julian Joachim 's pace might have served Villa better had he arrived earlier than the 79th minute, by which time Chelsea were playing keep-ball as only they can.

Chelsea should have won the game earlier, as Poyet and Gianfranco Zola became greater influences and George Weah a greater threat. In the 50th minute the Liberian gathered a through-pass of typical shrewdness from Zola and beat James with a cross-shot which just rolled wide. In the 60th Zola's centre found Weah racing unmarked towards the far post but he wafted the ball over the bar.

Chelsea appeared to have taken the lead when James failed to hold a Di Matteo cross-shot, Wise poking home the rebound, but the Chelsea captain's celebrations were cut short when Weah was ruled marginally offside and James's suspect handling went unpunished, for the time being.

Yet a goal was not far distant. With 17 minutes remaining the persevering Melchiot was fouled by Taylor near the left-hand corner flag. As Zola swung the free-kick into a crowded goalmouth James lunged out to meet it with both fists but did not quite get there, pawing the ball on to Southgate; Di Matteo hooked the rebound into the roof of the net.

Three cup finals earlier Di Matteo had put Chelsea ahead against Middlesbrough after 43 seconds; it was a pity he left it so long this time.

James, meanwhile, had lived up to his Liverpool nickname of Calamity, leaving Wembley to hope that, if he is England's fourth-best goalkeeper, Kevin Keegan will never have to pick the fifth.

After their vapid performance at Old Trafford on Easter Monday, when a 3-2 defeat by Manchester United all but ended their chances of finishing in the top three of the Premiership and re-entering the Champions League next season, the break-up of the present team was widely predicted. Now, though the cracks are still there, the process may be less painful. Marcel Desailly was easily Chelsea's outstanding performer at Wembley, reducing the aerial threat of Dion Dublin to leaflet raids and consistently bringing the ball out from the back in an effort to instigate attacking movements. The Frenchman's excellence was matched by Gareth Southgate in the Villa defence and, when defenders are dominant, it will always be difficult for a game to develop a pleasing flow. John Gregory, the Villa manager and nothing if not a pragmatist, had long realised that his team would get nowhere attempting to take on Chelsea in a passing game. So George Boateng and Ian Taylor played it tough and tight in midfield and the ball was hoisted high and long towards Dublin. Chelsea's manager Gianluca Vialli started with Gustavo Poyet switched with Di Matteo on to the right flank to exploit his aerial advantage over Villa's left wing-back Alan Wright. Chelsea, therefore, began off-balance and, with Wise and Didier Deschamps equally obdurate in the central areas, the match was a stalemate from the outset. With the midfield resembling a trawl of mackerel, all heaving bodies struggling for air, there was never going to be much chance for skilful individuals to give the final a touch of distinction. Paul Merson provided the one half-decent moment of the first half, a well executed volley from 25 yards which dipped over the bar, and even then Ed de Goey had it covered. Otherwise Merson's principal role lay in trying to provide a decent service to Dublin from crosses and set pieces. Villa might have created more opportunities had Benito Carbone been able to feed off Dublin to greater effect. But the diminutive Italian struggled to find space against Desailly and Mario Melchiot, the Dutch under-21 international who had replaced the unfit Albert Ferrer at right-back and seized his opportunity with athletic alacrity. Villa's one chance to save the match fell to Carbone 15 minutes from the end after De Goey dropped a free-kick from Merson. With half the goal to aim at Carbone scuffed his shot and Frank Leboeuf easily cleared it off the line. Julian Joachim 's pace might have served Villa better had he arrived earlier than the 79th minute, by which time Chelsea were playing keep-ball as only they can. Chelsea should have won the game earlier, as Poyet and Gianfranco Zola became greater influences and George Weah a greater threat. In the 50th minute the Liberian gathered a through-pass of typical shrewdness from Zola and beat James with a cross-shot which just rolled wide. In the 60th Zola's centre found Weah racing unmarked towards the far post but he wafted the ball over the bar. Chelsea appeared to have taken the lead when James failed to hold a Di Matteo cross-shot, Wise poking home the rebound, but the Chelsea captain's celebrations were cut short when Weah was ruled marginally offside and James's suspect handling went unpunished, for the time being. Yet a goal was not far distant. With 17 minutes remaining the persevering Melchiot was fouled by Taylor near the left-hand corner flag. As Zola swung the free-kick into a crowded goalmouth James lunged out to meet it with both fists but did not quite get there, pawing the ball on to Southgate; Di Matteo hooked the rebound into the roof of the net. Three cup finals earlier Di Matteo had put Chelsea ahead against Middlesbrough after 43 seconds; it was a pity he left it so long this time. James, meanwhile, had lived up to his Liverpool nickname of Calamity, leaving Wembley to hope that, if he is England's fourth-best goalkeeper, Kevin Keegan will never have to pick the fifth.

webTitle: Vialli does little to clear up clear-out confusion

fields.headline: Vialli does little to clear up clear-out confusion
fields.standfirst: Chelsea are likely to prune their squad rather than butcher it
fields.trailText: Despite all the transfer speculation, Chelsea are more likely to prune their squad than butcher it.
fields.body:
Chelsea, despite all the foreigners in their squad, have yet to sign a Red Indian. Perhaps that is why the smoke signals coming out of Stamford Bridge are so confusing.

The club that added the term "rotating strikers" to English football's lexicon appear to be trading in rotating opinions.

Over the past few months, as Chelsea's season drained from hope to disappointment, Gianluca Vialli's post-match nudges and winks clearly pointed to a summer clear-out of his playing staff in order to trim the millionaire wage bill and make way for younger, preferably English legs in a renewed assault on the Premiership.

Even late last week Ken Bates was saying that "the aim is to have a smaller squad of more quality. Of course there are going to be changes this summer".

But after Saturday's Cup final victory the Chelsea manager started whistling a different tune. "Sure there's room for improvement but I would not expect any major change," Vialli insisted after Saturday's 1-0 win over Aston Villa. "I hope everyone wants to stay. Whoever is happy is welcome to stay."

And boy, are those rumoured to be leaving willing to stay. "Of course I'm staying," said Dan Petrescu despite not even being on the Cup final bench. "I'm happy with the manager."

Frank Leboeuf: "I definitely want to stay next season."

The scorer of Saturday's winner, Roberto Di Matteo: "I'm going to stay at Chelsea and finish my career here."

Tore Andre Flo: "I'm happy with things."

Gianfranco Zola: "It's important that I stay. I love the club."

Didier Deschamps: "I'm sure the club want to keep me. I enjoy it at Chelsea. There are no problems."

It is tempting to conclude that no one at Chelsea knows whether he is coming or going. Even the seemingly clear waters navigated by the on-loan George Weah - "I don't think I'm going to stay because I have to go back to Milan" - were later muddied when he added: "I'd love to stay but they have to make the decision whether they're going to keep me or not."

So what is going on? Well, it may be that not everyone is telling the truth, for diplomacy's sake. Even Chris Sutton, whose £10m move to Chelsea has turned to utter embarrassment, refused to comment rather than share his frustrations with the public.

But the feeling that Chelsea have abandoned their slash-and-burn tactics is supported by something else Vialli said: "Of course I want to improve the team but I had a meeting with Colin Hutchinson [who negotiates all Chelsea's transfers] and we concluded that this team is not too bad."

So a team who not long ago were too old, not British enough and did not like playing at Watford and Sheffield Wednesday are now "not too bad".

Market realities may also make it difficult for Chelsea to unload their baggage. Petrescu, for example, sitting on a juicy contract signed in January, has little incentive to agree to leave for what would almost certainly be a lesser club.

Di Matteo, Deschamps, Leboeuf, Zola: all are in similar positions. And prospective purchasers may find ageing players on huge salaries less than tempting.

On the other side of the equation, to improve his squad Vialli must buy better players than these. But in today's market that costs the sort of money Chelsea balked at when linked with the £19m Ruud van Nistelrooy. It is the same weakness which undermines recent speculation that Chelsea will sign the Lazio striker Marcelo Salas, valued at £13m.

And then Chelsea have the problem of luring players without the bait of Champions League football.

The likelihood is that Vialli will trim his squad rather than butcher it. Fringe players such as Jes Hogh, Bernard Lambourde and Gabriele Ambrosetti are likely to leave, plus Weah and Sutton, if they can get £4m for him. In will come a new striker, perhaps Bolton's £5m-rated Eidur Gudjohnsen, and a couple of other low-to-middle-range signings.

In the end Chelsea cannot hope to compete with Manchester United for the title and play in the Uefa Cup if they cut their squad too brutally. As Dennis Wise said: "We played 61 games this season and it took a toll on us. That's why you need a big squad like Man United. You've got to be able to do it like them."

webTitle: Hearts grab second Uefa Cup spot

fields.headline: Hearts grab second Uefa Cup spot
fields.trailText: Hearts secured Scotland's second Uefa Cup place yesterday with a 2-1 win over Hibernian to finish two points ahead of Motherwell, who nevertheless had the consolation of ending Rangers' 26-match undefeated run with a 2-0 victory.
fields.body:
Hearts secured Scotland's second Uefa Cup place yesterday with a 2-1 win over Hibernian to finish two points ahead of Motherwell, who nevertheless had the consolation of ending Rangers' 26-match undefeated run with a 2-0 victory.

Juanjo and Gary McSwegan got the goals for Hearts, although Mixu Paatelainen's equaliser did give hope to Motherwell and Hibs, who later had Martin McIntosh dismissed.

For Motherwell Kevin Twaddle and the former Rangers striker John Spencer both hit the target in five second-half minutes. "We got what we deserved. There was no commitment and no sharpness," said Dick Advocaat, the visiting manager. "Maybe it was due to the fact we have the cup final next week. You can expect Aberdeen to give the same commitment so that was a good exercise of how we are not intending to do it next week."

Motherwell's manager Billy Davies had mixed emotions. "The Hearts result was not in our hands," he said. "We heard it was 1-1 then got told it was 2-1, but it wasn't to be. I'm still very proud and very happy.

"Now we have to work on our consistency for next season, but fourth place is a real achievement."

Celtic, who have already qualified for the Uefa Cup, gave a run-out to Henrik Larsson for the final 25 minutes of their 2-0 win against Dundee United, the Swedish striker's first appearance since breaking a leg against Lyon last October.

"He looked quite sharp," said Kenny Dalglish, the interim manager, who gave six teenagers their first starts and brought two more on as substitutes. Simon Lynch and Mark Burchill got the goals.

"We were fortunate that Henrik has come off without any damage whatsoever. Credit to the Dundee United players as well: although they never got out of his way, they didn't go out of their way to try and be overphysical with him."

webTitle: Copenhagen 15 will be banished from Euro 2000

fields.headline: Copenhagen 15 will be banished from Euro 2000
fields.trailText: The Football Association yesterday welcomed the news that the 15 people arrested in the violence before the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen will be banished from this summer's European Championship.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday welcomed the news that the 15 people arrested in the violence before the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen will be banished from this summer's European Championship.

However, the FA is to press the government to widen the net so that anyone arrested on suspicion of being involved in criminal activity on the back of football is barred from travelling to the Low Countries for Euro 2000.

An FA spokesman said that "people under suspicion of football violence should not be allowed to travel to Euro 2000. That is an issue we will continue to take up with the government and the police authorities in coming weeks."

The Home Office minister Lord Bassam is confident steps being taken in Britain will result in the 15, and any others identified as being part of the riots before last Wednesday's Arsenal-Galatasaray final, being turned away from Euro 2000, which starts on June 10.

The minister said he had asked for the names of the 15 to be passed on not only to Belgian and Dutch police but also to the forces in Germany and France along with details of those identified as being involved in the disorder.

In addition, details of all 504 people currently subject to domestic football banning orders will also be forwarded to police forces on the continent.

Robbie Fowler played 63 minutes of a testimonial for Steve Staunton and Tony Cascarino yesterday, his fellow England squad members Michael Owen and Emile Heskey both getting on the scoresheet in Liverpool's 4-2 defeat by an Irish XI.

"Robbie looks sharper with every game he plays. But you don't come back after eight months out of top football and start where you left off," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier. "It will take time. But it was encouraging that Robbie made our first goal for Emile while, with one eye on Euro 2000, it was good that Owen scored."

Scotland's coach Craig Brown has turned down the chance to take Hong Kong to the next World Cup. He is contracted by the Scots until the end of 2002 World Cup qualifying.

Arsenal are due early this week to give Lauren, Real Mallorca's Cameroon international midfielder, a medical after the clubs agreed a £7.2m fee. The 23-year-old player had also been pursued by Real Madrid, Parma, Roma and Paris St-Germain.

webTitle: It's rusk or bust for Wise and friends in football's family affair

fields.headline: It's rusk or bust for Wise and friends in football's family affair
fields.trailText: After the White Horse final, the Matthews final and the one where the Crazy Gang beat the Culture Club, it was important for Wembley to sign off with something special. But the Farley's Rusk final?
fields.body:
After the White Horse final, the Matthews final and the one where the Crazy Gang beat the Culture Club, it was important for the old Empire stadium that its last hurrah was signified by something special. And thus it was that 77 years after the twin towers were initially graced by the conclusion of the FA Cup we were treated to the Farley's Rusk final. After perhaps the drabbest 90 minutes in Wembley memory Dennis Wise enlivened proceedings by becoming the first captain in the history of the world's senior club football competition to lift the trophy in one hand while the other was holding the baby.

Henry Wise, the Chelsea stalwart's infant boy, marked the moment by looking rather bemused. Sweet he may have been, in his Chelsea shirt with the word Daddy embossed across the shoulders, but clearly the boy Wise will look back on his first final like many a participant and claim it all passed him by. Logged deep in his memory bank, it will appear to be no more than routine: had bottle, filled nappy, dad lifted FA Cup.

Wise was not alone on Saturday. On the day the Prime Minister did his bit to expand the next generation, many of the Chelsea team turned their victory into a family affair, hauling offspring out of the crowd to join in the lap of honour. I know that Gianluca Vialli's side are characterised by their advanced years but some of the players' children out there looked older than Jody Morris. No wonder Frank Leboeuf wants to stay on at Stamford Bridge: he needs the money to pay the university fees.

So predominant was the fad for family that several of the less fecund members of the Chelsea squad must have been tempted to pull any old kid out of the stands simply not to feel left out. Roberto di Matteo, if he was not careful, was in danger of being told by a television interviewer that it was all very well scoring the winner in a Cup final but really, if he wanted to enter the spirit of the times, he needed a toddler in replica kit on his shoulders.

Intriguingly, like much of the preceding couple of hours - the fireworks, the PA announcer's tiresome histrionics, the way George Boateng attempted to kick anything that moved - there seemed little spontaneous about the gesture to family. It all had the gloss of orchestration.

As soon as the final whistle went, Wise was intent on getting his boy in on the action, pacing the touchline, scouring the crowd, pointing and gesticulating as if to put prearranged plans into operation.

At one stage he dispatched a television reporter to go from the pitch and collect the boy for him. In a text-book moment of Wembley obstruction, the reporter was prevented from entering the stand by a steward. Though it was not possible to lip-read from 40 yards, it was obvious that what was being said in the exchange included the phrase "it's more than my job's worth".

Wise, though, is nothing if not tenacious and the boy was there waiting in the arms of a more helping hand, those of Ken Bates's girlfriend Susannah, to be gathered up as his dad mounted the steps: a trophy child to go with the oldest of football pots. And so the skipper ensured Chelsea, the Cup winners, matched Manchester United, the league champions, for family celebration. It will be interesting to see who comes out on top in the Charity Shield.

But where did it all start, this rush for family involvement? Although this year Brooklyn Beckham may have become the first under-three in the history of sport to perform a lap of honour while securing his parents tens of thousands of pounds in sponsorship deals, snooker fans will recall its origin. Who can forget the sight of Alex "Hurricane" Higgins, lachrymose in victory, calling for his daughter as he lifted the world championship trophy back in the 80s? Well, probably Higgins himself a few drinks later, but that is another story.

Never mind that, the question is now: where will it all end? The overexcited man on the Wembley PA was full of emotional marker points in the build-up to Saturday's game. As the wrecking ball neared, he larded everything with extra significance. This, he reminded us all in tones more appropriate to signalling the end of the world, was the last time Abide With Me would ever be sung beneath the twin towers - though why Lesley Garrett had to mark the occasion by dressing in lime green combat trousers to lead the singing instead of the white overalls that sufficed for the old bloke who always used to do the job was unclear.

Thus, if everything takes on a new resonance because of the demise of this outdated pit of a stadium, what an opportunity to reside for ever in history is presented to the participants in the play-offs. Next Monday the captains of Barnsley and Ipswich will not simply be playing for the chance to lead their teams to the Premiership but to pip Dennis Wise and become the last skippers to mount the steps to the royal box carrying their kids.

And why stop at children? Why not invite everyone to the party? Wives, mums, dads, great Aunt Ada, the bloke from the corner shop who used to hand out free gobstoppers: the celebrations could go on for days, a vast Oscars-style thank-you for everyone any of the players has ever known.

Whatever happens, though, one thing will remain unchanged about the Wembley experience, even in these days of the Blairite family man. The towers may come and Lesley Garrett may go but the losers will always want to be left alone with their disappointment.

Which, after Saturday, is probably just as well. If, in an attempt to cheer him up, someone had handed David James a baby, he would probably have dropped it.

webTitle: Boateng hits at Wise and claims he was targeted

fields.headline: Boateng hits at Wise and claims he was targeted
fields.trailText: One person left cold, not warmed, by the image of Dennis Wise the cuddly daddy on Saturday was Aston Villa's George Boateng, who has accused the Chelsea captain of trying to injure him and get him sent off .
fields.body:
One person left cold, not warmed, by the image of Dennis Wise the cuddly daddy on Saturday was Aston Villa's George Boateng, who has accused the Chelsea captain of trying to injure him and get him sent off .

"I still have marks on me because there were so many challenges from Wise the referee didn't see," said the robust midfielder. "I play my football hard but I play it fair. I don't play to injure anybody or get them sent off.

"Wise literally tried to walk over my face while I was on the ground. Another time I walked away from Wise and he tried to flick my heels but I saw him coming. He was talking at me all the way through.

"I wouldn't shake [Marcel] Desailly's hand afterwards. I played the ball but he stepped on my feet once it had gone.

Wise, who was booked for a challenge on Boateng, responded succinctly: "He caught me at least three times but I'm not complaining or moaning. He's a cry baby."

Meanwhile Paul Merson says he is "90% certain" to leave Villa, though the club's Italian striker Benito Carbone is likely to stay.

Merson, 32, wants to extend his contract so that he can finish his career in the top flight with Villa at the age of 35. "I've offered to take a pay cut to stay, as well," he said. But he added: "I've had very negative feedback. I've got to see the boss [John Gregory] in the next couple of days but, if I want to stay at the top until I'm 35, I don't think I'll be doing it here."

With the Belgian internaional Luc Nilis, who like Merson is a forward, due to arrive in the summer from PSV Eindhoven, Villa may have decided to cash in on the former England player after an impressive season. Merson joined Villa from Middlesbrough for £6.75m early in the 1998/99 season.

Carbone is more confident of extending the short-term contract on which he has been playing since joining from Sheffield Wednesday.

"The club and I will talk this week," said the Italian, reported to be looking for £30,000 a week. "But I think it will be positive news because the club and the manager want me to stay and I want to stay. I think we can close the contract quickly."

If Carbone moves to any other club this summer it will be a Bosman transfer with no fee. But, because of the deal struck with Wednesday, if he signs permanently for Villa he will cost £1m, of which £250,000 has been paid.

Merson believes Villa still need a few more signings to become a major force. In what could be viewed as a farewell swipe he said: "Villa need to spend a lot of money. I think you're looking at three or four players. When I think who from our team would get in the top four sides, there are not many, including me.

"The class gap was evident last week against Manchester United and it showed again against Chelsea in the second half. The distance is massive at the moment."
