webTitle: Best Loved Violinist wins Cockney accent war

fields.headline: Best Loved Violinist wins Cockney accent war
fields.trailText: I got lucky. During the half-time commercials I switched over to BBC1 - don't ask me why, tradition I suppose - and was just in time for On The Street Where You Live, my favourite song from My Fair Lady, maybe the most felicitous marriage of music and lyric that Lerner and Loewe ever came up with, and such a contrast to the disjointed disharmonies being played out at Wembley on the other side.
fields.body:
I got lucky. During the half-time commercials I switched over to BBC1 - don't ask me why, tradition I suppose - and was just in time for On The Street Where You Live, my favourite song from My Fair Lady, maybe the most felicitous marriage of music and lyric that Lerner and Loewe ever came up with, and such a contrast to the disjointed disharmonies being played out at Wembley on the other side.

I was able to stay with the whole number, too, without missing any significant action. Mind you, had I stuck with the movie for the rest of the afternoon I should not have missed a great deal. It was just professional pride and a sense of duty, really, which drew me back to the football and kept me going through the second half. Not unlike Chelsea, in fact.

I have to confess, though, to being not fully engaged with the football. Having seen the celebrity Villa fan Nigel Kennedy join Des and Terry for a pre-match chat, I was busy trying to decide whose cockney accent was more unlikely, his or Audrey Hepburn's, which led to the subsidiary question of why Dick van Dyke is roundly and regularly ridiculed for his accent in Mary Poppins when Audrey's Eliza - Brussels crossed with Beverly Hills - mostly escapes criticism.

This in turn elided into utterly pointless speculation as to whether Janet Street-Porter might be the secret love child of Audrey Hepburn's Eliza and Dick van Dyke's chimney sweep.

It was that kind of match, like a hundred bread-and-butter Premiership fixtures that have you wondering whether £50 and your Saturday afternoon might not have been better spent. Most of the fun came before and after the football, and you have to applaud ITV and Sky for pulling out all the stops to create the sense of occasion I and many others feared would be missing from this year's final.

Sky kicked off in traditional fashion at 8am, with its reporter Frazer Robertson stationed outside Aston Villa's "exclusive country-house hotel at a secret location in north-west London", where the Villa players, it was exclusively revealed, "were in relaxed mood".

Good start. Is there a more traditional part of the Cup final ritual than the report from the teams' hotels which finds the combatants in relaxed mood? Do you ever recall a final when the reporter was asked about the mood of the players and replied, "Shitting bricks, actually, Brian"?

The delights of a country-house hotel, however, were deemed less than sufficient to relax Villa's highly tuned professionals, and Robertson reported that a marquee had been erected for them on the hotel lawns, stocked full of diversions to keep the little darlings occupied: Play- stations, pool tables and collections of the short stories of Guy de Maupassant (I may have imagined the Maupassant. It was very early in the morning and I was only half awake).

Back in the studio Andy Gray was envious. "There was nothing like that when I went to Wembley in the mid-80s," he grumbled. "You had to make your own playstation." "Some of you more successfully than others," said Richard Keys.

Gray also revealed that in his day, to lighten the mood, Freddie Starr was hired to wander around being wacky in a variety of costumes - clear evidence for those who put Everton's later decline down to disastrous misjudg ments by their management.

The banter on both sides was rather good all day. Nigel Kennedy was in an animated discussion with Des, Terry and Ally McCoist about whose was the fastest goal at Wembley. Des reckoned it was some bloke in the 60s who scored in 40 seconds. "Peter McParland's goal for Villa was earlier than that," said Britain's best-loved violinist. "What, earlier than 40 seconds?" asked Des. "Yeah, abaht four years earlier," replied Britain's BLV to general acclaim.

Des looked happier than he had done for ages. He is clearly not comfortable in the constricted atmosphere of Wednesday night European football but, with space to expand and in the company of Terry and Ally, with whom he clearly feels relaxed, he is beginning once more to look like an asset to ITV.

He still has to do things on the commercial channel that the BBC would never ask him to do, without irony. "We've seen one final and tonight there's another," he declared. He was referring to Stars In Their Eyes, where the make-up wizards transform shorthand typists into Barbra Streisand, although Saturday's winner, a mild-mannered computer programmer from Glasgow pretending to be Freddie Mercury, still came out looking more like Charles Hawtrey.

This was not typical. Mostly they work miracles and it is just a pity none of them was on hand to transform a visibly jaded Aston Villa, who seemed to regret being dragged away from their Playstations, into credible opponents for Chelsea.

webTitle: Day twelve: Truly, madly deeply in love

fields.headline: Day twelve: Truly, madly deeply in love
fields.trailText: The controversial director Lars von Trier last night won the Palm d'Or in Cannes in the most flamboyant circumstances, insulting the head of the festival and assuring his leading lady - whom he called a "mad woman" only a fortnight ago - that he "loved her very much".
fields.body:
The controversial director Lars von Trier last night won the Palm d'Or in Cannes in the most flamboyant circumstances, insulting the head of the festival and assuring his leading lady - whom he called a "mad woman" only a fortnight ago - that he "loved her very much".

Bjork, the Icelandic pop star whom he accused of eating her costume in a fit of rage on set, also won Best Actress for her portrayal of a blind woman who goes to the gallows for a crime she did not commit.

The bizarre musical, which climaxes with Bjork singing from the scaffold, had divided critics right down the middle, with Variety, the film industry bible, branding it "artistically bankrupt in every sense".

Von Trier, 44 - who previously insulted Roman Polanski and, on winning a minor prize in the past, kicked his scroll into the audience - immediately took on Cannes chief, Gilles Jacob.

"He is a very nice man. I don't know if he knows much about film, but he is a nice man," he said.

Then, in an attempt to heal the rift with Bjork, he said: "Thank you very much Bjork. I know she doesn't believe it, but if you ever meet her tell her I love her very much."

The pair had walked up the famous red steps before the ceremony in a show of unity reminiscent of Charles and Diana at their most glacial. Bjork, wearing a pink and black liquorice allsorts dress with a large gold penguin dangling from her neck, looked deeply uncomfortable while Von Trier sweated a few feet away.

The other big shocks of the ceremony were the three prizes that went to Iranian film makers.

After all the celebrity trivialities the Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf - the youngest ever in the main competition at Cannes - made an impassioned and, what could be for her, a dangerous speech to remind us that there was a real world outside.

Her voice quivering and her head wrapped in a black scarf, she said: "This is hope in my homeland. I accept this prize to honour the heroic efforts of the young generation who struggle for democracy and the promise of a better future in Iran."

Makhmalbaf, who shared the jury prize with Swedish veteran Roy Anderrson for her film The Blackboards, has never before been so open in her call for change in her homeland.

The other major winners were Wong Kar-Wai's I'm In The Mood For Love which won both best actor for Hong Kong star Tony Leung and the Grand Prix for artistic direction. Another surprise was the Grand Prix for the Chinese war epic Guizi Lai Le which some critics have condemned as dull and boring until its shocking final 20 minutes.

It was not a good night for Hollywood, with only Neil LaBute's comedy, Nurse Betty, winning Best Screen Play. Veteran James Caan told the night's best joke to a completely silenced auditorium: "Whoever named Cannes, the world's top film festival after me, thank you very much I am very grateful."

Away from last night's awards, a British film about a miner's son who dreams of being a ballet dancer became the expected audience hit of the festival.

Dancer is a tearjerker about a motherless boy from a Durham pit village who defies his father's wishes that he become a boxer only to win him back when he is accepted by the Royal Ballet.

Audiences sobbed and cheered when it was shown at the close the Director's Fortnight section of the festival. Although it was beaten to the main prize by Girlfight, an American film about women's boxing, last night it emerged as favourite for the audience award. Last year's winner was East Is East, the low-budget British comedy which became a box office sensation.

Dancer, written by Lee Hall, the award-winning playwright of Spoonface Steinberg fame, and starring Julie Walters as a razor-tongued ballet mistress, is a comedy of gender and class. That its debut director, Stephen Daldry, should have chosen to make such an obviously commercial crowd-pleaser caught many critics unawares.

Like East Is East, several British critics have been sniffy about how Dancer shamelessly milks every northern film cliche from Kes to Brassed Off for sentimental effect, but others could not get enough of it.

Festival prizewinners

Palm d'Or Dancer in the Dark by Lars von Trier

Grand Prix Guizi Lai Le by Jiang Wen (China)

Best Actress Bjork for Dancer in the Dark

Best Actor Tony Leung for In The Mood for Love

fields.bodyText: The controversial director Lars von Trier last night won the Palm d'Or in Cannes in the most flamboyant circumstances, insulting the head of the festival and assuring his leading lady - whom he called a "mad woman" only a fortnight ago - that he "loved her very much". Bjork, the Icelandic pop star whom he accused of eating her costume in a fit of rage on set, also won Best Actress for her portrayal of a blind woman who goes to the gallows for a crime she did not commit. The bizarre musical, which climaxes with Bjork singing from the scaffold, had divided critics right down the middle, with Variety, the film industry bible, branding it "artistically bankrupt in every sense". Von Trier, 44 - who previously insulted Roman Polanski and, on winning a minor prize in the past, kicked his scroll into the audience - immediately took on Cannes chief, Gilles Jacob. "He is a very nice man. I don't know if he knows much about film, but he is a nice man," he said. Then, in an attempt to heal the rift with Bjork, he said: "Thank you very much Bjork. I know she doesn't believe it, but if you ever meet her tell her I love her very much." The pair had walked up the famous red steps before the ceremony in a show of unity reminiscent of Charles and Diana at their most glacial. Bjork, wearing a pink and black liquorice allsorts dress with a large gold penguin dangling from her neck, looked deeply uncomfortable while Von Trier sweated a few feet away. The other big shocks of the ceremony were the three prizes that went to Iranian film makers. After all the celebrity trivialities the Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf - the youngest ever in the main competition at Cannes - made an impassioned and, what could be for her, a dangerous speech to remind us that there was a real world outside. Her voice quivering and her head wrapped in a black scarf, she said: "This is hope in my homeland. I accept this prize to honour the heroic efforts of the young generation who struggle for democracy and the promise of a better future in Iran." Makhmalbaf, who shared the jury prize with Swedish veteran Roy Anderrson for her film The Blackboards, has never before been so open in her call for change in her homeland. The other major winners were Wong Kar-Wai's I'm In The Mood For Love which won both best actor for Hong Kong star Tony Leung and the Grand Prix for artistic direction. Another surprise was the Grand Prix for the Chinese war epic Guizi Lai Le which some critics have condemned as dull and boring until its shocking final 20 minutes. It was not a good night for Hollywood, with only Neil LaBute's comedy, Nurse Betty, winning Best Screen Play. Veteran James Caan told the night's best joke to a completely silenced auditorium: "Whoever named Cannes, the world's top film festival after me, thank you very much I am very grateful." Away from last night's awards, a British film about a miner's son who dreams of being a ballet dancer became the expected audience hit of the festival. Dancer is a tearjerker about a motherless boy from a Durham pit village who defies his father's wishes that he become a boxer only to win him back when he is accepted by the Royal Ballet. Audiences sobbed and cheered when it was shown at the close the Director's Fortnight section of the festival. Although it was beaten to the main prize by Girlfight, an American film about women's boxing, last night it emerged as favourite for the audience award. Last year's winner was East Is East, the low-budget British comedy which became a box office sensation. Dancer, written by Lee Hall, the award-winning playwright of Spoonface Steinberg fame, and starring Julie Walters as a razor-tongued ballet mistress, is a comedy of gender and class. That its debut director, Stephen Daldry, should have chosen to make such an obviously commercial crowd-pleaser caught many critics unawares. Like East Is East, several British critics have been sniffy about how Dancer shamelessly milks every northern film cliche from Kes to Brassed Off for sentimental effect, but others could not get enough of it. fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Yorkshire are top of the First Division after their off- spinner James Middlebrook, playing in only his second National League game, took three for 16 in five overs to steer his side to a 35-run Duckworth-Lewis victory over Gloucestershire at Headingley.
fields.body:
Yorkshire are top of the First Division after their off- spinner James Middlebrook, playing in only his second National League game, took three for 16 in five overs to steer his side to a 35-run Duckworth-Lewis victory over Gloucestershire at Headingley.

Yorkshire reached 160 for three thanks to an opening stand of 77 between David Byas (48) and Gary Fellows (30). Richard Blakey made 43 not out from 50 balls.

After the early loss of Rob Cunliffe for a duck, Gloucestershire were temporarily revived by Tim Hancock and Matt Windows, who added 43 in 11 overs.

But Middlebrook took the important wickets of Mark Alleyne, Jeremy Snape and the Australian Ian Harvey, who had threatened to haul Gloucestershire back into the contest with 31 from 31 balls.

Elsewhere in the top division Trevor Ward smashed a 49-ball half-century to steer Leicestershire to their first league win of the season against his former county Kent at Grace Road. Chasing 142 for victory, Leicestershire slipped to 23 for four before easing home by three wickets with six overs to spare.

The left-arm seamer Kristian Adams, on his Kent debut, took the first four wickets for 19 runs in an opening five-over spell, but was then not used again as Chris Lewis and Jon Dakin saw the Foxes home with an eighth-wicket stand of 42.

In the Second Division Dougie Brown continued his purple patch with the bat and swept Warwickshire to their third successive win, over Hampshire at Edgbaston.

Brown, who scored a double century against Sussex earlier this month, hit an unbeaten 45 off 61 balls to clinch a five-wicket victory with more than five overs to spare.

Darren Bicknell and John Morris each hit a half-century to make it three wins out of three for Nottinghamshire. The winning blow was struck by yet another new winter signing, Giles Haywood, as the hosts passed Derbyshire's 187 with 22 balls to spare at Trent Bridge.

 On the final day of their championship game Sussex slipped to a fifth successive defeat at Hove after Elliott Wilson and Vikram Solanki shared in a stand of 80 to give Worcestershire a second successive victory in the Second Division.

The visitors, chasing a target of 96 in what turned out to be 26 overs, got home with 11 balls remaining to leave Sussex rooted to the bottom.

Chasing 142 for victory, Leicestershire slipped to 23 for four before easing home by three wickets with six overs to spare. The left-arm seamer Kristian Adams, on his Kent debut, took the first four wickets for 19 runs in an opening five-over spell, but was then not used again as Chris Lewis and Jon Dakin saw the Foxes home with an eighth-wicket stand of 42. In the Second Division Dougie Brown continued his purple patch with the bat and swept Warwickshire to their third successive win, over Hampshire at Edgbaston. Brown, who scored a double century against Sussex earlier this month, hit an unbeaten 45 off 61 balls to clinch a five-wicket victory with more than five overs to spare. Darren Bicknell and John Morris each hit a half-century to make it three wins out of three for Nottinghamshire. The winning blow was struck by yet another new winter signing, Giles Haywood, as the hosts passed Derbyshire's 187 with 22 balls to spare at Trent Bridge.  On the final day of their championship game Sussex slipped to a fifth successive defeat at Hove after Elliott Wilson and Vikram Solanki shared in a stand of 80 to give Worcestershire a second successive victory in the Second Division. The visitors, chasing a target of 96 in what turned out to be 26 overs, got home with 11 balls remaining to leave Sussex rooted to the bottom.

fields.headline: Net Imperative: what went wrong?
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran on the collapse of another high-profile internet start-up
fields.trailText: Mark Tran on the collapse of another high-profile internet start-up.
fields.body:
The sudden demise of the internet news service netimperative.com has surprised industry insiders and pierced another small puncture in the internet bubble. The service today fell victim to the backlash against dotcom companies and started liquidation proceedings just three months after its launch.

The company held discussions with its main shareholder Durlacher over the weekend and had been expected to secure more funds, but it appears Durlacher was unwilling to provide a second tranche of financing for the start-up. Durlacher, a stockbroking firm turned niche internet investor, holds a 28.5% stake in Net Imperative.

Last week the online fashion retailer boo.com collapsed, and at the weekend the video-on-demand provider Yes TV abandoned a stock market flotation planned for this morning. With the planned £600m offering undersubscribed in the recent freefall of technology stocks, Yes TV pulled the plug on its offering.

Netimperative.com described itself as the first in a planned international network of localised information and community service providers. It reported on sectors such as technology, investment, media and marketing and was a networking forum for entrepreneurs and investors.

The company was founded by Felicia Jackson, the former editor of New Media Investor, the UK's leading publication on investment in the UK internet industry. A highly regarded and respected authority on the sector, she also acts as an adviser for the Department of Trade and Industry's trade association and is a consultant to number of start-up internet businesses.

She has done stints as a stock analyst for newsletters such as Chart Breakout and Quantum Leap and a journalist for a number of publications including PFI report and Sports Marketing.

Net Imperative did not have the glitz and glamour of boo.com, with its attendant stories of extravagant spending plans. Amory Hall, chief executive of the web strategy firm Akasha Media said: "You can't just point the finger at management. You have to look at the people writing the cheques with unrealistic expectations. I'm convinced both boo.com and Net Imperative would have going concerns if given time."

The two collapses can only reinforce the view that the market is taking a more jaundiced look at internet startups with their sky-high valuations. Accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers have warned that many loss-making enterprises are gobbling up money so fast that one in four will run out of cash in less than six months.

A separate survey by FT.com found that the British public is turned off by internet industries, with only 7% saying they would like to be involved in a dotcom and just 3% prepared to give up their jobs if they had a good idea for an internet startup.

webTitle: City nights out never to be remembered

fields.headline: City nights out never to be remembered
fields.standfirst: Are young weekend drinkers causing anarchy and disorder as alleged by the Police Federation? Not in Newcastle, despite cheap booze
fields.trailText: Hard drinking begins around 7pm in a vast super-pub renowned for its cut-price cocktails. A range of "hot shots" are on offer at £2.99, ranging from "Viagra" - double Blue Bols and Red Bull - to a potent double of bourbon and mixers known as "Jumping Jack Flash".
fields.body:
Hard drinking begins around 7pm in a vast super-pub renowned for its cut-price cocktails. A range of "hot shots" are on offer at £2.99, ranging from "Viagra" - double Blue Bols and Red Bull - to a potent double of bourbon and mixers known as "Jumping Jack Flash".

Everyone says this is the place to hit the town running. "Great value, isn't it?" smiles a young girl, downing a £2.49 "TVR" - tequila, vodka and Red Bull - who swears she's just turned 18. "No one can match these prices. We'll have a few here and move on to the bright spots, won't we girls?"

Across the bar, a group of student maths teachers marvel at the cheap prices and the array of concoctions on special offer. "Girls drink more than you'd expect," says Brian, downing a £1.50 bottle of designer lager. "They come here before making for the flashy bars because it's so cheap. There's a circuit of six or seven bars and you have a couple of drinks in each - but I'm past it."

His friend, Catriona, adds: "A bit of escapism really. They just like a good time with their friends."

By 11pm, when the pubs and music bars close, tens of thousands spill into the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne, sometimes staggering for a quick pizza or a kebab before heading for a taxi. Others begin queuing for a nightclub and a second round of drinking into the small hours.

It doesn't come cheap. "Sets you back £50 sometimes, although I can get through a lot more," says a young office worker as police vans crawl through the heaving, screaming streets littered with the debris of party city. A few girls, semi-conscious, slump on benches and pavements while officers on foot occasionally break up a fight, bundling a protesting youngster into the back of a Transit. Inspector Kevin Wellden, in the nearby police station after patrolling the city centre in an unmarked car, said: "To someone who's not used to this - the noise level, for instance - the atmosphere might feel intimidating. But the reality is that not a lot is happening."

By that he means that while spirits are sky high, the incidence of law-breaking - as opposed to anti-social behaviour - is relatively low, thanks to high-tolerance policing, which generally manages to keep the lid on disorder. But, on the surface at least, an outsider might well conclude that night-time Newcastle is approaching the urban nightmare portrayed last week by the chairman of the Police Federation, Fred Broughton.

He provoked a storm of protest from chief constables by claiming that city centres - from Leeds and Liverpool to London and Manchester - had been taken over by "anarchy and disorder" at closing time, with some becoming no-go areas.

It's an image which Superintendent Graham Stafford, police commander of Newcastle's central division, cannot match with the reality of a one-square mile city centre which boasts 300 licensed premises, including 160 pubs and 15 nightclubs - with a further 20 on the cards, including a big new nightspot and a leisure centre with 11 individual licences and capacity for 6,000 more "drinking spaces".

"This is a relaxed, enjoyable, safe city. No doubt there is violence - when you get that number of people together and have drink involved there are obviously at times going to be situations of conflict. It would be naive to suggest that does not happen."

With up to 100,000 people coming into the centre on any weekend night, he says the 800 recorded offences for violent crime over the past 12 months - "from the minor to more serious assault" - indicate that the vast majority of party-goers are law-abiding.

But there is clearly concern among police, and some licensees, that cut-price liquor, often promoted by national chains, is pushing some youngsters over the edge. "It does sort of encourage people to overindulge in a short period of time as opposed to pacing themselves over an evening."

According to a new report by the pressure group, Alcohol Concern, 13,000 violent incidents now occur in, or near, licensed premises every week. Eric Appleby, the group's chief executive, is in no doubt that some of the violence is fuelled by cheap drink offers. "Certain types of bar are designed to get young people in and drinking quickly."

Not surprisingly, some rival licensees are outraged. Bob Senior, managing director of a Newcastle company which owns a string of bars and nightspots on Tyneside, says cheap drink cannot be defended. His cocktail prices are more than double some cut-price outlets. "It gets dangerous when some operators sell discounted drink on Fridays and Saturdays. At the end of the day we are licensed to sell a drug called alcohol and certain restrictions come with that right."

Figures from the Office of National Statistics show that young people are increasingly heavy drinkers. Almost 40% of men, and a quarter of women aged 16 to 24 now regularly drink more than eight and six units of alcohol respectively in one sitting (a unit is equal to a bottle of beer, or a glass of wine). Problem drinking is rising fastest among affluent young women. Leanne, a young Newcastle barmaid, said: "Cheap booze is definitely making things worse. I get kids in very early on, with a lot of money, who are well away."

With the Department of Health preparing to release a consultation paper on alcohol misuse this summer, Eric Appleby says police should be given greater powers to temporarily close down bars or clubs which promote cheap drinking.

He believes proposals from the home secretary, Jack Straw, to give selected pubs and clubs 24-hour licences will make matters worse.
fields.bodyText: Hard drinking begins around 7pm in a vast super-pub renowned for its cut-price cocktails. A range of "hot shots" are on offer at £2.99, ranging from "Viagra" - double Blue Bols and Red Bull - to a potent double of bourbon and mixers known as "Jumping Jack Flash". Everyone says this is the place to hit the town running. "Great value, isn't it?" smiles a young girl, downing a £2.49 "TVR" - tequila, vodka and Red Bull - who swears she's just turned 18. "No one can match these prices. We'll have a few here and move on to the bright spots, won't we girls?" Across the bar, a group of student maths teachers marvel at the cheap prices and the array of concoctions on special offer. "Girls drink more than you'd expect," says Brian, downing a £1.50 bottle of designer lager. "They come here before making for the flashy bars because it's so cheap. There's a circuit of six or seven bars and you have a couple of drinks in each - but I'm past it." His friend, Catriona, adds: "A bit of escapism really. They just like a good time with their friends." By 11pm, when the pubs and music bars close, tens of thousands spill into the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne, sometimes staggering for a quick pizza or a kebab before heading for a taxi. Others begin queuing for a nightclub and a second round of drinking into the small hours. It doesn't come cheap. "Sets you back £50 sometimes, although I can get through a lot more," says a young office worker as police vans crawl through the heaving, screaming streets littered with the debris of party city. A few girls, semi-conscious, slump on benches and pavements while officers on foot occasionally break up a fight, bundling a protesting youngster into the back of a Transit. Inspector Kevin Wellden, in the nearby police station after patrolling the city centre in an unmarked car, said: "To someone who's not used to this - the noise level, for instance - the atmosphere might feel intimidating. But the reality is that not a lot is happening." By that he means that while spirits are sky high, the incidence of law-breaking - as opposed to anti-social behaviour - is relatively low, thanks to high-tolerance policing, which generally manages to keep the lid on disorder. But, on the surface at least, an outsider might well conclude that night-time Newcastle is approaching the urban nightmare portrayed last week by the chairman of the Police Federation, Fred Broughton. He provoked a storm of protest from chief constables by claiming that city centres - from Leeds and Liverpool to London and Manchester - had been taken over by "anarchy and disorder" at closing time, with some becoming no-go areas. It's an image which Superintendent Graham Stafford, police commander of Newcastle's central division, cannot match with the reality of a one-square mile city centre which boasts 300 licensed premises, including 160 pubs and 15 nightclubs - with a further 20 on the cards, including a big new nightspot and a leisure centre with 11 individual licences and capacity for 6,000 more "drinking spaces". "This is a relaxed, enjoyable, safe city. No doubt there is violence - when you get that number of people together and have drink involved there are obviously at times going to be situations of conflict. It would be naive to suggest that does not happen." With up to 100,000 people coming into the centre on any weekend night, he says the 800 recorded offences for violent crime over the past 12 months - "from the minor to more serious assault" - indicate that the vast majority of party-goers are law-abiding. But there is clearly concern among police, and some licensees, that cut-price liquor, often promoted by national chains, is pushing some youngsters over the edge. His cocktail prices are more than double some cut-price outlets. "It gets dangerous when some operators sell discounted drink on Fridays and Saturdays. At the end of the day we are licensed to sell a drug called alcohol and certain restrictions come with that right." Figures from the Office of National Statistics show that young people are increasingly heavy drinkers. Almost 40% of men, and a quarter of women aged 16 to 24 now regularly drink more than eight and six units of alcohol respectively in one sitting (a unit is equal to a bottle of beer, or a glass of wine). Problem drinking is rising fastest among affluent young women. Leanne, a young Newcastle barmaid, said: "Cheap booze is definitely making things worse. I get kids in very early on, with a lot of money, who are well away." fields.headline: Dot.com pain continues
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited editor Marianne Curphey looks at how the liquidation of netimperative.com will affect the markets
Net Imperative goes into liquidation
fields.trailText:
Money Unlimited editor Marianne Curphey looks at how the liquidation of netimperative.com will affect the markets.

Net Imperative goes into liquidation
fields.body:
The news that netimperative.com has begun liquidation proceedings is the second shock for dot.com investors in a matter of days. Only last week Boo.com, the UK e-tailer, announced it was facing collapse after failing to secure future funding.

The warm glow that investors felt as they watched their internet and technology shares soar in February and March has given way to horror as valuations have plummeted.

Even good quality shares with real earnings rather than deepening losses have been hit by the change in sentiment.

The technology, media and telecoms (TMT) sector is not just focused on e-tailers, but each new announcement that a dot.com company is struggling has a knock-on effect on new economy shares in general.

After a report last week suggesting that many ecommerce companies were burning cash so quickly that they would run out of money within six months, there was more bad news today with the release of a report claiming that Britons had shown less interest than forecast in buying online.

The problem for the dot.com companies, particularly those which are selling to the consumer rather than business, is the high cost of building a brand in a short timescale.

The marketing costs are huge, and many ecommerce sites do not expect to make money for four or more years.

Until now, this had not been a problem, as investors and venture capitalists were willing to tolerate large initial losses in the hope of owning a part of a new company which would one day dominate online retailing.

But the fall in the price of technology shares and fears about how much profit the e-tailers can hope to make means the City is becoming much more cautious about providing more money when the first batch of funding runs out.

There will be more e-casualties, and some will fail not because they are failing to stick to their business plan or meet their targets, but simply because venture capitalists are becoming far more selective about where they spend their money, and the City has lost its appetite for providing loss-making companies with second-round funding.

Coupled with the continuing gyrations in the Nasdaq, the technology index in the US, there is likely to be more pain ahead for TMT investors.

fields.headline: Seizing criminals' assets
fields.standfirst: The government is proposing new powers to seize the assets of drug barons and other criminals. James Meikle explains why they are necessary
fields.trailText:
What's the current situation?
Police and customs officials in England and Wales already have the power to take court action to seize the cash profits of criminals, particularly drug traffickers, under laws dating back to the late 1980s.
fields.body:
What's the current situation?
Police and customs officials in England and Wales already have the power to take court action to seize the cash profits of criminals, particularly drug traffickers, under laws dating back to the late 1980s.

Why are more powers needed?
Criminals are getting even better at squirreling away their ill-gotten gains. The lucrative trappings of drug-related crime can include mansions, yachts, powerful cars and expensive jewellery. Only 20% of all drug prosecutions result in confiscation orders, which could be seen as embarrassing when the illicit drug trade is costing the UK economy £1bn a year. In Ireland, similar laws have allowed 12 times as much money to be recovered from each criminal as in the UK.

How much has been confiscated?
Proceeds recovered from drug-related crimes amounted to just over £37m between 1987 and 1996, but that was only a third of the amount ordered to be confiscated. £7.4m was retrieved in 1996 and the amount has fallen since, to around £3m. Tracking down other crime-related profits brought in just £4.5m between 1991 and 1996.

What can be done?
A new confiscation agency will be created to co-ordinate the new measures against money laundering, although no date has been mentioned.

How much money could be raised?
Around £40m, if the rate of confiscation is increased significantly. Much of the money could be used to fund treatment for drug abusers and run education and prevention programmes.

How might that sum be achieved?
By insisting confiscation was the norm not the exception and being more successful tracking down criminals' assets.

Why has this been announced now?
The Conservatives have been seen to make the running on law and order in recent weeks, but ministers insist they have been considering these moves for months. A Home Office working group called for criminals to forfeit more of their profits in November 1998 and a cabinet office think-tank was commissioned to draw up further proposals.

webTitle: Cash alone won't cure the ailing NHS

fields.headline: Cash alone won't cure the ailing NHS
fields.standfirst: Onlya radical agenda for NHS change will convince the nation that Labour is serious about improving the NHS.
fields.trailText: The extra billions promised for the NHS may relieve the symptoms, but they won't cure the disease, argues David Brindle.
fields.body:
Health is the basic humanitarian yardstick by which any society is judged. In Britain, New Labour is not doing nearly enough to improve the lot of the sick and vulnerable nor to convince the nation that the ravages of the 1980s are being put behind us.

There is, indeed, a crisis of confidence in the government's handling of health and social care - and only a radical agenda will address it. The extra billions promised for the NHS may relieve the symptoms, but they won't cure the disease.

That may seem churlish, perverse even, when ministers have not only given the health service unprecedented funding guarantees - worth more than 6% above inflation for the next four years - but when they have launched a wide-ranging professional and public consultation on a new NHS plan to be published in July. In the words of Alan Milburn, the health secretary, the aim is nothing less than to "start transforming the NHS into an organisation where the patient comes first and... where the consumer is king".

Yet this responds only to part of the problem: the short term need to be seen to be modernising a service still steeped in the values of 1948. Yes, people today want walk-in, helpline and online health care. Yes, Dr Finlay has long since had his day. But the problems of our health and social care system run far deeper: there is a pressing need to shift the whole focus of care towards older people and chronic disease; there is a mounting anger at the secrecy of the system and its so-called democratic deficit; and there is, above all, a stark and shameful failure to tackle the health inequalities that blight this land.

To square up to these challenges, Labour must take a bolder, longer term perspective. It must also let go. In its 1997 manifesto, it declared that "there can be no return to top down management". Yet the running of the NHS and social services is now more centralised than it has been for a decade - arguably longer. At the heart of the next term should be a commitment to a new Beveridge plan for not just the NHS, but health and social care as a whole.

Such a plan would set down the fundamental principles of state-funded care, perhaps making the consumer king but at the same time serving to manage his or her expectations. It would require compromise from all. In particular, it could be the prompt for completing the unfinished business of the 1948 NHS settlement: the part-time status enjoyed by 43% of hospital consultants, enabling them to work on the side in the lucrative private sector.

One way of arriving at such a plan would be to designate one or more localities as test beds, freeing them of national performance targets and controls. There all parties could work together, forging local solutions that might ultimately be replicated nationally. Idealistic? Perhaps.

A second task for the second term should be the removal of the public health function from the Department of Health. Britain's present approach is almost unique in Europe and it has patently failed.

The poor remain by far the hardest hit by disease and illness; messages about healthier lifestyles are simply not getting home. For all Labour's brave talk on public health, the discipline has been trampled in the stampede to shore up acute hospital care. Symbolically, the relevant ministerial post was last year downgraded to junior rank.

Lead responsibility for public health could pass to the Cabinet Office, where it could sit within the social exclusion unit. The health department would be freed to concentrate on care delivery.

Down the line, the lead should go to local government or perhaps the emerging regional tier, freeing health authorities to assume a more assertive role in care. Ever since the demise of regional health authorities in the mid-1990s, such oversight has been lacking.

It was about that time, too, that concern began to grow at the secrecy of the NHS. Today barely one in three people considers the NHS to be run in an open way that involves the public. Moreover, the Shipman, Bristol and Alder Hey scandals have dealt fatal blows to the once-blind faith in doctors. In the new consumer era, patients want - and expect - full access to information about their own health and the competence of those to whom they entrust it.

There is no way round this. Labour must promise new patient rights, including free availability of performance data on hospitals, units and individual clinicians. Which doctor, after all, would not want to know whether the surgeon about to operate on their child had previously done one such procedure or 1,000? Labour must also address the democratic deficit of the NHS structure, if not through election of health bodies then through far greater transparency.

That will take courage. But it will take still more to acknowledge, as the government surely must, that the most pressing health and social care issue is not the "third world wards" of the tabloid imagination, not even a shortage of cancer doctors and nurses, but our ageing population. Over the next dozen years, by far the biggest challenge will be the need to switch care resources from young to old, from communicable to chronic disease.

For a start, ministers should stop their desperate search for a cheap way out of the dilemma over long-term care. Instead of struggling to find a watertight definition of nursing care, to be free wherever delivered, they should accept the recent royal commission's call for free "personal" care. Even at an initial cost of £1.1bn a year, rising to £2.6bn by 2021, this is surely affordable for an administration heading for a surplus of £20bn in its public finances.

By promising to pay up, Labour would be sending the clearest and bravest signal about its understanding of the real health and social care agenda - and about society's debt to its elders.

Social care: rescuing a tainted service

Labour should propose to abolish social workers. The idea would win easy headlines and pander to popular prejudice, but also make much sense.

Rightly or wrongly, the term "social worker" is irredeemably tainted. Associated with political correctness, the failings of municipal socialism and 20 years of care scandals, it is a real deterrent to recruitment into the social care sector. By redefining and renaming the role, the profession could make a fresh start.

The move should be coupled with the extension of care management - as designed for work with elderly people - into children's services. Vulnerable children would in effect have a personal champion, holding a budget and able to commission the services best suited for the individual. For "interfering social worker", read "enabling care manager."

Elsewhere, Labour should drop its resistance to the creation in England of a children's commissioner. Wales is going ahead with the idea, as recommended by the Waterhouse inquiry into abuse in children's homes in north Wales. Ministers have failed to make a convincing case for not following suit.

Giving children their own ombudsman would be a popular and low cost measure, as experience in other countries suggests. It would also draw a welcome line under the horrors of the past.

What happens next...

Do you think David Brindle has got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? Send your thoughts to our letters page, or join the debate on our talkboards by going to our special report.

 Next week: Home affairs

fields.headline: Millions more for the Dome
fields.standfirst:
New Millennium Experience Company
Millennium Commission
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome is to receive an extra £29 million grant from National Lottery funds subject to "stringent conditions", the Millennium Commission said tonight.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is to receive an extra £29 million grant from National Lottery funds subject to "stringent conditions", the Millennium Commission said tonight.

The money is in addition to £509 million the New Millennium Experience Company has already received from the commission for the ailing attraction in Greenwich, south London

The commission revealed tonight that the NMEC has requested a grant of £38.6 million following worse-than-expected attendance figures at the Dome.

The commission said it had "serious reservations about providing further support without substantial change in the governance of NMEC".

But it went on: "The commission decided it would be foolish to withdraw support when the best of the year is yet to come and that the value of the Dome as the centrepiece of the nation's millennium celebrations should be recognised and continued."

The commission said the extra grant would not affect its wider programme of work. The money was provided on three key conditions:
 The strengthening and restructuring of NMEC's management and governance;
 A revised business plan showing substantial additional cost savings and enhanced marketing plans;
 An enhanced financial team at NMEC, including a dedicated member of the commission's own financial staff joining the team.

Visitors to the Dome today insisted no further money should be spent on the attraction.

Doreen Berry, 66, who made a day trip from Corby, in Northamptonshire, said the application for a further £30 million to finance the Dome was "an awful lot of money for this".

"Was it such a good idea in the first place? It's half empty. I don't think they deserve any more money," she said.

Michael Beale, a coach driver from Ledbury, Hertfordshire who regularly takes visitors to the Dome, said: "Look at the state of it. People are just wandering around looking for something to do. They shouldn't put more money into this. It's a rip-off."

Richard and Ann Pugh, from Malvern in Worcestershire, were "disappointed" after their visit and felt that enough money had already been spent on the Dome.

Mr Pugh said: "If they could spend the money on sports facilities and such things it would be far better spent than pouring money into this. The general public isn't responding. If you take away the children there wouldn't be any people at all."

But teacher Ian MacKenzie, who brought pupils from Colneis Junior School in Felixstowe, said: "I think it should get more money. It is educational. It's given the children a chance to see things put to them in a more interesting way. Because they have spent so much money now I think it has got to be built up on a more permanent basis."

fields.headline: The history
fields.trailText: 1960
fields.body:
1960

After qualifying stages that featured 16 European nations, four eventually made their way to France to play the final rounds of the inaugural European Championship tournament.

In the first semi-final, France lost 5-4 to Yugoslavia despite leading 4-2 with 15 minutes left. Three goals in three minutes, including two from Drazen Jerkovic, accounted for the hosts.

The other semi was a far more straightforward affair with the USSR defeating Czechoslovakia 3-0 in Marseille.

After the Czechs made sure of third place by beating France 2-0 in a play-off, the stage was set for the Paris final in which the Russians triumphed 2-1 over Yugoslavia thanks to Victor Ponedelnik's extra-time winner.

1964

Spain became the first hosts to win the tournament when they defeated the Soviet Union in front of nearly 80,000 fans at the Bernabeu stadium in Madrid.

In a competition in which all the Home Nations, apart from Scotland, took part for the first time, England crashed out to the French 5-2 in Paris under the guidance of Alf Ramsey for the first time.

The Russians coasted into the final courtesy of a 3-0 win over Denmark while Spain had to rely on an extra-time winner from Amancio to seal a 2-1 success over Hungary.

The final saw two goals in the first eight minutes, Galimzian Khusainov cancelling out Jesus Maria Pereda's opener for the hosts. Then, six minutes from time, Marcelino Martinez won the game for his country to the delight of the home crowd.

1968

World Champions England reached the last four of the competition for the first time.

The Championship finals were staged in Italy and after overcoming Spain over two legs in the quarter-finals, England were eliminated by Yugoslavia by a single goal in a tense semi-final.

In the other semi, Italy were held to a goalless draw by the Soviet Union but made it through to the final by winning the ensuing toss of a coin.

And the Italians became the second hosts in succession to be crowned European Champions when goals from Luigi Riva and Pietro Anastasi gave them a 2-0 win over the Yugoslavians, who had lost in the final for the second time in three tournaments.

1972

Hosts Belgium gave the home fans something to cheer about by reaching the semi-finals but they were dumped out by the Gerd Muller-inspired Germans, who had also accounted for England in the quarter-finals.

The German side also featured the likes of Franz Beckenbauer, Uli Hoeness and Gunter Netzer and were justifiably clear favourites to win their first European crown.

In the other semi-final the ever-reliable Russians defeated Hungary to reach their third final in four attempts.

The final in Brussels saw Germany romp to victory and Muller did not disappoint by scoring twice in a 3-0 win with Herbert Wimmer also on target.

1976

Wales progressed to the quarter-finals for the first time in their history before being eliminated by hosts Yugoslavia, who then suffered defeat in front of their own supporters at the hands of the holders Germany in the semi-finals.

The little-fancied Czechs were making waves and when they defeated the highly-rated Dutch 3-1 in the other semi-final, which denied Holland a chance to take revenge for their 1974 World Cup final defeat by Germany.

And in a tournament of shocks and late drama, the final did not disappoint as the Czechs raced into a two-goal lead.

But the Germans hit back with Bernd Holzenbein's equaliser arriving in the last minute.

Extra-time produced no further goals to set up the first penalty-shoot-out in a major international final and when Uli Hoeness missed his spot-kick, Antonin Panenka stepped up to win the tournament for Czechoslovakia.

1980

Italy hosted the first enlarged tournament, which saw eight teams competing in the final stages in two groups of four with the group winners meeting in the final.

England had qualified impressively with twice European footballer of the year Kevin Keegan firing on all cylinders but defeat to Italy in the group stages cost them dear and a win over Spain in their last game was not enough.

Italy could not beat Belgium in their final group game which cost them a place in the final while in the other group, Germany had cantered into their third successive final.

Horst Hrubesch put Germany ahead in the final but a Rene Vandereycken penalty drew Belgium level only for Hrubesch to snatch a last-gasp winner and give the Germans their second European crown.

1984

Hosts France entertained the best sides in Europe and had no qualms about beating them all.

Inspired by the midfield trio of Platini, Giresse and Tigana, les Bleus scored a total of 14 goals, including a 5-0 defeat of Belgium.

Denmark also put five past Yugoslavia on their way to a semi-final date with Spain, who had reached the finals by beating Malta 12-1.

The dark horses of Group Two were Portugal, whose striker Jardao scored twice in a roller coaster semi-final with France that was decided by a late, late Platini strike.

Spain booked their place in the final on penalties, but it was there that heroic keeper Arkonada turned villain, allowing a Platini free-kick to slip agonisingly through his grasp before Bruno Bellone's late goal handed the hosts the title.

1988

Germany hosted the European Championships for the first time, thirsting for success on home soil and a third title.

They reckoned without a Netherlands side boasting the glorious triumvirate of Frank Rijkaard, Ruud Gullit and Marco van Basten.

The USSR had experience, class and eight Dynamo Kiev players. They humiliated England, beat the Netherlands and ended Italy's dreams in the semi-final.

Meanwhile, the Dutch masters knocked out the hosts to set up a rematch for the Henri Delaunay trophy.

The final was an orange triumph, as captain Gullit nodded home the opener and van Basten volleyed perhaps the greatest ever goal to grace a final to send the USSR packing.

1992

Sweden hosted the first major Championships in Scandinavia since the 1958 World Cup and the last eight-team tournament format.

Denmark replaced war-torn Yugoslavia in the competition at the last minute and belied their underdog status, edging out favourites Germany in a fascinating final.

John Jensen scored a rare thunderbolt and Kim Vilfort finished the job. It was a far cry from the low scoring group games, with Group One yielding only nine goals in six games.

In the semis, goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel saw Denmark through a penalty shoot-out after a pulsating 2-2 draw with the Netherlands.

In Solna, a magical Thomas Hassler free-kick and two goals from Karlheinz Riedle helped Germany beat the hosts 3-2, but in the final they were to meet their match.

1996

An international tournament finally returned to England 30 years after the famous summer of '66, with none of the off-field problems predicted.

The hosts' dreams collapsed in the semi-finals, as Gareth Southgate's weak shoot-out spot-kick allowed Andreas Moeller to fire Germany into the final.

A Davor Suker-inspired Croatia impressed, reaching the last eight in their first tournament, but a late Vladimir Scimer goal took the unfancied Czech Republic through.

Both semis went to the dreaded penalties, and as England bowed out, the Czechs sneaked past France and into the Wembley final.

Patrick Berger's penalty put the Czechs in front, but then Oliver Bierhoff's header and deflected 'golden goal' made a forgettable final memorable as the Germans took revenge for their 1976 defeat at the hands of the Czechs.

fields.headline: Dorset's King Vyv
fields.standfirst: Vyvian Pike, 30, is a legspinner for Dorset who works for WS Atkins, a  civil engineering firm, during the week. On May 16, he took 5-10 against  Norfolk in the NatWest Trophy, the best figures of the second round. In the Minor Counties Championship last season he took 68 wickets, the best haul in the competition since 1974. He has  also played for Gloucestershire. Since he was interviewed, Vyv has been named in the England Board XI (the highest level an amateur in England can reach) to play matches against Zimbabwe and MCC in June
fields.trailText: "It was only the third game I'd played this year, partly because of the rain and partly because I'm only playing for Dorset this season, not any other teams. I'd played against Norfolk once before in what used to be the MCC trophy, and on paper they are probably the stronger side. We didn't really have a specific game plan, it was just a matter of trying to get a good total on what was a slow wicket. A good total would have been something around 200ish, but we lost a few early and managed to get out for 180. So then we had to try to get them worrying early, which our opening bowlers achieved, and then press home the advantage.
fields.body:
"It was only the third game I'd played this year, partly because of the rain and partly because I'm only playing for Dorset this season, not any other teams. I'd played against Norfolk once before in what used to be the MCC trophy, and on paper they are probably the stronger side. We didn't really have a specific game plan, it was just a matter of trying to get a good total on what was a slow wicket. A good total would have been something around 200ish, but we lost a few early and managed to get out for 180. So then we had to try to get them worrying early, which our opening bowlers achieved, and then press home the advantage.

"I bowled all my ten overs from one end straight through, and it came out OK. I feel like I'm bowling all right, certainly not too bad early doors. My first wicket came from a rank long hop; after that I got one to leave the bat which was nicked to the keeper; the third was a googly through the gate; the fourth one a spinning leg-break and the fifth the googly again. I bowled seven maidens in my ten overs, partly because they felt under pressure as they had wickets down and partly because I was trying hard to keep it tight. They were my best figures in the NatWest, though I got an 8-for in a match last year [8-89 against Berkshire at Finchampstead].

"I got a medal and £350 for winning the Man of the Match award. No, I haven't shared it out with the rest of the side. Don't write that or the others will get ideas! I've got a ten-week-old son, Sam, so most of the money will probably go on nappies and stuff.

"We are playing against Glamorgan in the next round, and obviously they are a far superior side on paper but we'll do our best to try to keep it tight. We've got about a one in a thousand chance, but we'll see how it goes. I'm probably the most experienced bowler in the Dorset side, and I played against Glamorgan when I was with Gloucestershire, so the pressure's on - the boys will be looking for me to take some wickets.

webTitle: Government and industry promote ethnic talent in film

fields.headline: Government and industry promote ethnic talent in film
fields.trailText: The government today announced a joint venture with the British Screen Advisory Council to promote ethnic talent in film
fields.body:
The government today announced a joint venture with the British Screen Advisory Council (BSAC) to promote ethnic talent in film. The new Committee for Ethnic Minority Employment in Film will seek out ethnic minority talent in the UK film industry, and encourage more multicultural productions, such as the phenomenally successful East is East.

Culture secretary Chris Smith said: "It is only right that today's multi-cultural society should be reflected both in front of and behind the camera East is East is an example of what can be achieved - a highly successful film, enjoyed by a multiracial audience."

It is hoped the committee will serve as a catalyst for change within the industry, helping to develop proposals that will lead to fairer levels of employment for ethnic minority film talent in the UK, in front of and behind the cameras.

The 16-strong committee will look at distribution and all aspects of production.

fields.headline: Staying at home, Staying put and Staying away
fields.trailText: LEFT AT HOME
fields.body:
LEFT AT HOME

When Jason Wilcox pulled out of England's provisional Euro 2000 squad last night, an unshaven Kelvin Koogan stared grimly at the 27 players remaining and asked them to kick a ball with their left foot. Only one, a hobbling Robbie Fowler, could manage it - and that was with the aid of crutches.

England were on the verge of entering Euro 2000 with no left-footed, left-sided players. Koogan knew he had to do something, but what? Then, while sleeping, came a masterstroke. Why not play Beckham, Parlour, Dyer, Redknapp, Gerrard and both Nevilles all on the right-hand side of the pitch, thus keeping the ball away from more tricky areas of the field? It would sure stop those fat, whining, gelatinous tabloid hacks from claiming he was tactically naive.

Sadly, when Koogan awoke, that dream had dissipated into a rare moment of logic, and he replaced Wilcox with a left-footed, left-sided midfielder instead. Sort of. "With Jason pulling out, it had to be Gareth Barry because he is a left-footed player," Koogan said of the Villa central defender this afternoon. "He is used to playing in big games now." And also losing them, the Fiver notes - so he should have no problem fitting in with this England squad.

LAUREN F*** ALL

"The deal will be officially signed by Arsenal when Lauren passes his medical exam in the next days." That's what Mallorca's vice-president Mateo Alemany said of his Cameroon international Lauren Bisan-Etame Mayer on Friday night. "It's a great opportunity for Mallorca to get a lot of money," Alemany went on, wondering why the sun-blessed citizens of the Balearic island were standing around rubbing their chins. They were rubbing their chins, you see, because what he was saying wasn't true.

Alright, not strictly not true in the 'Gazza: no more drinking for me' sense of the word, but still rather naughty. Because 48 hours after Mallorca announced the £7m transfer of Lauren to Arsenal, the London club have yet to acknowledge they are interested in the player. In fact, the only remarks to have emanated from Highbury suggest that Mallorca are talking up a move to Arsenal in order to prompt Real Madrid or Valencia into making a (presumably bigger) bid.

This could in turn mean that Arsenal are playing the move down in order to force Mallorca to speed it up. Or even that Mallorca are slowing it down in order to keep their name in the British press and sell more holidays to the sun-drenched island before using the profits to buy real Gunners target Robert Pires. Could be. All we really know, however, is that the season has barely finished and the Fiver has already lost faith in the new improved rumour mill. What next: "Rivaldo to sign for Charlton - God"?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF CUP FINAL DAY

"That's a very intelligent question" - A straight-talking Roberto di Matteo responds to a Sky reporter who asked if it felt good to score the winning goal at Wembley.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TOTALLY CHRISSED OFF

Poor old Chris Sutton. Instead of spending the first day of his holidays shivering on an open-top bus in the pouring rain being stared at by a load of people who don't like him very much, he suffered the pain of boarding a luxury aircraft bound for sunny Florida with his family. Not everything's going wrong for him, however - it looks as though the £10m failure will soon be free of his Stamford Bridge hell.

Reports suggest Chelsea are prepared to cut their losses and accept £6m for the lanky loser, still a lot of money when you consider Sutton only scored one Premiership goal last season. Not that Leicester are overly bothered - they're prepared to meet the price to land yet another striker Martin O'Neill may live to regret taking a chance on. Spurs are also considering fronting the cash for the one-goal wonder, as they revert to type after the momentary madness of buying a world-class player.

Meanwhile, as Sutton prepares to use Chelsea's revolving transfer door to leave, the likes of Marcelo Salas and Jamie Redknapp are rumoured to be sizing it up in order to arrive. Sadly, they won't get anywhere if, upon exiting, Sutton trips over his own feet, sprawls uselessly onto the floor, and jams the door stuck with his head. But what are the chances of that happening?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Tottenham have warned Neil Sullivan that his agent may ruin his prospects of sealing a move to White Hart Lane. "The club has enquired about Sullivan... and has made its maximum offer, but fears that the agent may ruin the club's chances by pushing their luck too hard," a club statement read.

There will be a mass exodus from Barcelona this summer following Louis Van Gaal's departure - and many of their players will end up in the Premiership. Liverpool are set to make a £3m move for veteran left-back Sergi, while Middlesbrough are close to signing Winston Bogarde for £3m.

Millwall's 15-year-old striker Cherno Samba is expected to sign for Liverpool in the next few days for £1.5m.

Newcastle are close to agreeing a £3m fee for Velez Sarsfield midfielder Christian Bassedas.

Rangers are rumoured to have made Hibernian a £2m offer for young striker Kenny Miller. The Hibees have denied the speculation but have said another unnamed club have approached them about the player.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Koogan knew he had to do something, but what? Then, while sleeping, came a masterstroke. Why not play Beckham, Parlour, Dyer, Redknapp, Gerrard and both Nevilles all on the right-hand side of the pitch, thus keeping the ball away from more tricky areas of the field? It would sure stop those fat, whining, gelatinous tabloid hacks from claiming he was tactically naive. fields.headline: Peter Pringle
fields.standfirst: Peter Pringle, journalist and author of a controversial new study of violence in Ulster, answered questions on Bloody Sunday live online on Monday April 10 2000. He discussed his views on the aims and abilities of the Saville Inquiry, the alleged role of Martin McGuinness and the mystery of missing evidence. This is an edited transcript of the debate, but you can click here to read the full version and have your say.
fields.body:
grover: What qualifies you to answer these questions about Bloody Sunday? Were you there? Do you have access to "privileged" information or is your controversial position a personal interpretation of existing facts?

Peter Pringle: Dear grover, the answer is I was not there on the day but arrived the next day and spent the following two and a half months investigating the day for the Sunday Times. I have also seen many of the new submissions to the Saville Inquiry. Our original report was published on April 23, 1972 in the Sunday Times.


Morcheeba: Dear Peter, sorry but I've not read your book. What's your new take in a nutshell?

Morcheeba: Dear Morcheeba, unlike the Saville Inquiry, which is a legal investigation, our book tells the human story: the lives of those who took part in the march, why they marched, and how the 13 were killed and the 14 wounded. It also goes into the background of the military operation, using the new material that has come to light since 1972. In that sense it is a continuation of the story, not the definitive account which is the aim of the Saville inquiry at the end of its next two years of hearings.


ppgm1953: It has been admitted recently that there was a shoot to kill policy in NI (although perhaps later than Bloody Sunday). Do you feel that this may have been the case earlier? If so, was it a contributary factor to that Sunday?

PP: Dear ppgm1953, this is one of the key avenues for the inquiry to follow. It was the conclusion of army high command in Northern Ireland at the time, that perhaps the only way of dealing with the regular Derry rioters -the Derry Young Hooligans, as the army called them - was to shoot selected ringleaders. A secret report to this effect was made to the officer commanding the Ulster-based forces three weeks before Bloody Sunday. The question is how far down the ranks had this attitude gone?


Jonifame: Peter, do you think that the Saville inquiry will actually help the peace process? What impact could it have? Is it better not to dwell on the past so much, tragic though it is?

PP: Dear Jonifame, anything that clears up the inconsistencies and gaps in the Widgery inquiry could help the peace process by creating an atmosphere more conducive to talks. But there are minefields, obviously. One of them was identified last week when Saville's counsel introduced the MoD intelligence report about Martin McGuinness. Where that goes is anyone's guess.


grover: Peter, families of the dead already have their truth. The paras and their families already have their truth. How do you think the truth commission is going to be able to reconcile these diametrically opposed positions with a third version of the "true truth". Do you see it as an exercise in compromise to lay bones to rest, or a concerted effort to unearth facts buried through years of complicity on the part of those involved?

PP: Dear grover, you're right in one sense. The families know who died and who was wounded; the paratroopers know who they shot. But in the previous Widgery inquiry many of the civilian eyewitnesses were never heard, and many MoD documents secret. In other words, the "real" truth is not known. Given the resources of the Saville inquiry, also the time interval and a new pile of declassified documents, we are bound to know more.


Canselin: What do you make of the allegations that Martin McGuinness was the IRA man who fired the first shot? Are they nonsense?

PP: Dear Canselin, we will have to wait and see. The MoD by producing an unsourced, unattributable secret agent report has opened a new debate. McGuinness has denied the allegations. one secret agent report does not prove anything.


SiKing: 1. If Mr. McGuinness accepted an offer to give evidence to the Saville Inquiry, is it possible that he could be asked, under oath, to reveal details of his involvement in IRA activity not related to Bloody Sunday?

2. Is it realistic to expect a truthful outcome to the inquiry rather than something between a politically expedient compromise and the Widgery report?

PP: Dear SiKing, 1. McGuinness could be asked those questions but he is under no obligation to answer them. None of the information he gives can be used to prosecute him in a different forum. 2. The obstacle to finding out the truth is more likely, in my view, to be the impossibility of making a single judgement from the great variety of the evidence now being presented than from the restrictions of political expediency. Everyone, on both sides, is now interested in closure of this event.


fmk: Now that the UK govt is undertaking a proper inquiry into what went down in Derry, do you think the terrorists themselves can ever be convinced to undertake a proper public enquiry into the likes of Birmingham, Enniskillen or Omagh? Or does justice have several versions?

PP: Dear fmk, I understand your point but of course a public inquiry must be started by the government.


wh52: How significant is the report that the Army has recently destroyed or disposed of rifles used that day? Apart from the simple loss of evidence can it also be read that the Army authorities still feel there are tracks to be covered?

PP: Dear wh52, the SLR rifles that were used to fire the fatal shots on that day could have been used to match at least two of the bullets found in the bodies of those who were killed. In addition, it was possible that some of the rifles used on that day were re-bored from 7.62mm down to .22in. Without the rifles that mystery cannot be cleared up.

wh52: May seem to be overly technical but how do you rebore a hole to a smaller diameter? Was it really fitting new barrels, in which case even if the rifles were available they might not have the actual barrels used.

PP: Dear wh52, good point. Actually what you do, as I understand it, is put a sleeve into the barrel to downsize, as it were. You are right, if you can put a new sleeve in, you can surely take it out. Thus, it is possible that any downsized rifle could be upgraded before being handed over to the Saville inquiry. As you say, perhaps we are getting too technical here. But the issue remains - were any of the rifles downsized?


PP: Dear all, thanks for all your questions. Sorry but I have to leave now. Hope you can get the book.

fields.headline: Racism in the ring
fields.standfirst:
Tyson should not be allowed entry because he is famous when we deny others with more pressing claims

Boxing: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Tyson should not be allowed entry because he is famous when we deny others with more pressing claims
fields.body:
Here we go again. In the House of Commons, motions are being passed and questions being asked. On the airwaves, boxing fans are squaring up against feminists. Demonstrations are being organised, placards painted and defensive positions taken on the moral high ground. The home secretary is allowing Mike Tyson to come into Britain once more. And intellectually, we are no better prepared for his arrival than we were three months ago. We are about to lose ourselves in the Bermuda triangle of sex, race and class. Steel yourselves, Iron Mike is coming.

This time around there are a few things we would do well to remember in the run-up to his proposed visit. First, Tyson is a human being. He is not a "monster", a "beast" or an "animal" as he was described in January. The rhetorical value of such descriptions is clear. They cast Tyson as a race apart. He is the ultimate "other". And since he does not follow our moral code, we do not have to apply it when referring to him. It is the opening salvo in the broadside of white supremacy. First dehumanise, then demonise - a perfect formula for promoting the bestial and relegating the cerebral, not just in Tyson in particular, but black men in general.

Second he is a boxer. He makes his money by punching people in the head so hard that they fall over and are rendered unconscious. He delivers brain damage for a living. We may not like this (I certainly don't), but our dispute on that score is with boxing, not with Tyson. The one thing we can be certain of, if he does come to this country, is that he will beat at least one person up because that is the whole point of him being here. So to describe his physicality (big, muscular, scary) or his personality (crude, swaggering, tough) as evidence of his brutality is as absurd as criticising ballerinas for being delicate and dainty or professors for being bookish and well-read.

Finally, he is a former criminal and, most pertinently, a rapist. In 1991 he raped Desiree Washington at a Miss Black America beauty pageant, a crime for which he was sentenced to six years in jail. Unlike the well-connected member of the Kennedy clan, who was in court facing the same charge at the same time, Tyson was not acquitted. He was punished. It is intriguing to hear liberals, whose views on criminal justice are generally underpinned by the idea that criminals can and should be rehabilitated, waive that argument in the case of Tyson as though his soul itself is irredeemable. In a fit of illogic they claim that he has shown no remorse, but conveniently forget his insistence that he was innocent. It is difficult to apologise for something you say you didn't do.

So, if Tyson does come he will not be travelling light. As well as his entourage of minders he will be journeying from, in and to a context. He will leave a country where 40% of black children grow up below the poverty line - just as he did - and where incarcerating black people is a boom industry. One-third of all young black men are either in jail, on probation or awaiting trial. He travels as part of a sport, boxing, which has turned that poverty into profit by exploiting those who take it up to within an inch of their lives. And he will arrive in a country which has pursued an immigration "policy" for the past 30 years of keeping black people out and asylum laws designed to criminalise the most vulnerable.

How many of those MPs who will voice their opposition to Straw's decision in the Commons next week lost their voice when it came to the asylum bill, which offends the dignity of so many survivors of state-sponsored rape throughout the world? They are rightly attentive to the plight of Desiree Washington; but if she were Rwandan they would be thinking of detaining her in an army camp.

His reception, both positive and negative, also shows the limits of identity politics. He arrives in a country where two women are killed every week by their current or former partner and reported rape has risen by 165% in the past decade. His arrival reduces the entire issue into the hierarchies of oppression. People who use their blackness or femaleness as the end, rather than the starting point, of their ideology are destined to cut themselves off from the needs of others. "I'll see your race and raise your gender," said the feminist to the black, male activist as both ignored the racism in the women's movement and sexism in the black community, as though there was only a strategic and no ethical response to the event.

None of these points answer whether Tyson should be allowed in the country a second time, but relate to the blatantly racist, hypocritical manner in which the question was put the first time and the inadequacy of the response to it. Jack Straw's decision to bend the rules to allow Tyson into the country because he is famous and a few individuals are going to make money out of him is wrong.

It is an insult to those who have suffered domestic violence, for by waiving the rules on financial grounds Straw puts a price on rape. It suggests that if Tyson were a less successful boxer, a car salesman or a computer engineer he would be kept out of the country because it would cost us less. If he prevented Tyson entering the country he might (although it is unlikely) make a few people bankrupt. By allowing him in he makes the entire government morally bankrupt.

Those who ask how consistently applied is the rule that keeps those who have been convicted of serious crimes out of the country have a good point. General Pinochet, who bore responsibility for the rape of hundreds if not thousands in Chile, was until recently welcomed with open arms. Laws such as these are often implemented with far more rigour against black people than they are against others. There are almost certainly hundreds of people who commit similar crimes arriving every day. The price Tyson pays for his fame is that we know what he has done and since we know it we cannot, with any integrity, ignore it.

Nor is it any mystery why hundreds of black people, and some whites, packed the streets of Brixton to greet him. A community that has been criminalised by the state and vilified by the press is likely to look with leniency and forgiveness on those who have fallen foul of the criminal justice system and are attacked by the media. But the collective denial which underpinned the notion that a rapist - whose victim was a black woman at that - can be transformed into a poster-boy for anti-racism was entirely wrong-headed. Like Straw, it signals that misogyny is forgivable so long as it is coupled with fame.

Tyson should be denied entry to Britain because it is wrong to base the rule of law on the power of the purse. But for every placard at Hampden demanding that he should be kept out, there must be another at the Home Office calling for other black people to be allowed in.

 gary.younge@theguardian.com
