None of these points answer whether Tyson should be allowed in the country a second time, but relate to the blatantly racist, hypocritical manner in which the question was put the first time and the inadequacy of the response to it. Jack Straw's decision to bend the rules to allow Tyson into the country because he is famous and a few individuals are going to make money out of him is wrong. It is an insult to those who have suffered domestic violence, for by waiving the rules on financial grounds Straw puts a price on rape. It suggests that if Tyson were a less successful boxer, a car salesman or a computer engineer he would be kept out of the country because it would cost us less. If he prevented Tyson entering the country he might (although it is unlikely) make a few people bankrupt. By allowing him in he makes the entire government morally bankrupt. Those who ask how consistently applied is the rule that keeps those who have been convicted of serious crimes out of the country have a good point. General Pinochet, who bore responsibility for the rape of hundreds if not thousands in Chile, was until recently welcomed with open arms. Laws such as these are often implemented with far more rigour against black people than they are against others. There are almost certainly hundreds of people who commit similar crimes arriving every day. The price Tyson pays for his fame is that we know what he has done and since we know it we cannot, with any integrity, ignore it. Nor is it any mystery why hundreds of black people, and some whites, packed the streets of Brixton to greet him. A community that has been criminalised by the state and vilified by the press is likely to look with leniency and forgiveness on those who have fallen foul of the criminal justice system and are attacked by the media. But the collective denial which underpinned the notion that a rapist - whose victim was a black woman at that - can be transformed into a poster-boy for anti-racism was entirely wrong-headed. Like Straw, it signals that misogyny is forgivable so long as it is coupled with fame. Tyson should be denied entry to Britain because it is wrong to base the rule of law on the power of the purse. But for every placard at Hampden demanding that he should be kept out, there must be another at the Home Office calling for other black people to be allowed in.  gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Tigers in a prize fight
fields.standfirst:
An increasing number of channels are vying for Asian TV viewers in Britain. Palan Barakrishnan introduces the contestants in this cut-throat battle

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: An increasing number of channels are vying for Asian TV viewers in Britain. Palan Barakrishnan introduces the contestants in this cut-throat battle
fields.body:
Britain's newest television channel is belting out music around the clock and it isn't playing Bon Jovi, the Beatles or Beethoven. B4U Music, launched this month, is filling its slots with the latest chart-toppers from Bollywood, complete with video clips of athletic heroes chasing coy heroines around trees.

How times have changed. Back in the 1980s, British Asians had to programme their videos for the occasional Bollywood movie that aired in the late night slots on BBC and ITV. Now, they're spoiled for choice. There are 14 UK channels broadcasting in south Asian languages such as Hindi, Bengali and Urdu. More are on the way.

A colourful cast has already assembled for the battle of the Asian small screen. It includes two billionaires and the Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp. Even Star TV, the jewel in the crown of Rupert Murdoch's eastern empire, is considering starting a Hindi channel for Britain and Europe.

The defending champion is the media mogul Subhash Chandra who heads Zee TV, the Indian entertainment powerhouse which is also the biggest player on Asian TV screens in Britain. He is worth about $5bn.

Then there is the steel baron Lakshmi Mittal, Britain's fourth richest tycoon, who is worth £2.2 bn according to the Sunday Times Rich List. Last year, Mittal threw his weight behind B4U (Bollywood for You), a movie channel showing five Hindi films a day.

Zee is fighting back by starting more niche channels. In October, it started the all-singing, all-dancing music channel Music Asia. A few days later, it kicked off the Bengali language channel Alpha Bangla.

But the Mittal-backed consortium is also moving quickly with the launch of its second channel, B4U Music, aimed at challenging Zee's Music Asia. In four months' time, it plans to launch a third, B4U South, which will broadcast south Indian screen hits.

Also in the fray is Zee's arch-enemy, Sony Entertainment Television which was launched two years ago in Britain. It has struck a marketing alliance with B4U to outmanoeuvre the market leader.

What's the prize these channels are fighting over? There are about 500,000 Asian households in Britain and Zee has around 150,000 subscribers. That may seem like small potatoes compared to a channel like Sky Movies, which reaches more than 2m households. But profit margins can be high because programmes are made cheaply and imported from India. "Asian channels are serving a niche market and you've got to treat it like that. It shouldn't be compared with a giant like Sky," says Ash Jaswal, marketing executive with Sony Entertainment.

What's the programming formula that makes Asians reach for the remote control and switch on their sets? For a start Bollywood is the world's second largest film industry and its blockbuster melodramas are crowd-pullers around the world. But Bollywood's starring role doesn't stop there. Its song and dance sequences are better than any music video and they are turned into Hindi Top of the Pops-style programmes.

Then there are the serials produced on the Indian subcontinent. Back in the 1980s, serials such as Mahabharata, based on the Hindu epic, brought India to a standstill when they were broadcast.

But what about second and third-generation British Asians who don't have fond childhood memories of the Indian subcontinent? For them, there are channels like the ambitious Channel East and Birmingham-based Asia 1 which broadcast in a mix of English and the main south Asian languages.

The advent of digital broadcasting has changed the rules of the game completely, slashing costs. The transmission cost of putting a channel on air is now around £50,000 per month, compared with about £400,000 before digital. Saad Saraf, of Media Reach, which follows the Asian television industry, says: "Digital has made it that much easier. It needs roughly 25,000 subscribers to break even. That's why you see this explosion of channels."

For the bigger players like Zee, a bouquet of channels brings in more revenue and can be broadcast for less than the price of putting out one analogue channel. Zee, which says it reaches around 150,000 households, charges around £12 for a monthly subscription. About 60% of its revenue comes from subscriptions and the rest from advertising.

But the economics of Asian broadcasting also depend on cheap programming from the Indian subcontinent. Zee started out by making some programmes in Britain but has cut back over the years. Most of its key rivals like Sony aren't yet contemplating local programming. Most companies reckon programmes can be made for a fifth of the price in India or Pakistan. And each channel is playing the same game.

One station that doesn't have to worry about programming is B4U. Kishore Lulla, one of B4U's backers owns the international rights to around 1,700 Bollywood movies and is snapping up more all the time.

Of course, south Asians aren't the only ones rushing to start channels. The ITC, which regulates the television industry in Britain, reckons about 400 stations have permission to broadcast. There are channels aimed at the Chinese community and Arabic speakers. But the south Asians from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are ahead of all other ethnic minority groups and one reason is language. India has more than 20 official languages.

Television is a cut-throat business and there may not be many winners in this multi-cornered battle. But it is certain that more Asian channels will be arriving on the crowded battlefield and it will be a long time before the victors emerge.

fields.headline: Alan Rusbridger
fields.standfirst: Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger battled with readers live online on Wednesday 29 March 2000. He responded on issues from populist journalism to Jonathan Aitken, Murdoch money and the rise of the electronic newspaper. This is an edited transcript of the live discussion. Click here to read the full debate and have your say.
fields.body:
Ms.Borg: I like this website. In fact I like it so much, I don't really buy the paper any more. The site is better to navigate around rather than flip pages, and you get to argue with Guardian readers which is an enjoyable pursuit now fox-hunting appears to be facing a ban. I was wondering if you think newspapers might ultimately all go out of business because of the greater perfection attached to online surfing, or do you think that there's some quality about newspapers which means they will be around forever?

Alan Rusbridger: Will newspapers disappear? Difficult to say. There is something irreplaceable and valuable about print on paper. Is that very different from, say, electronic ink on plastic paper? We're slightly at the mercy of technology; which is why we're attempting to put the Guardian on every platform so that you can read it on paper, TV, palm pilot, WAP phone or wherever. Currently we put out at least five different versions of the paper every night (including one version for the blind). So we're ready (we hope) for anything the future holds...


tomwilde99: Have to agree with Ms Borg... The online version of the Guardian is far too good. The Guardian does appear to be streaks ahead of the competition with online news. The problem however is, as always, money. What happens once your readership gravitates from paper to bytes, as it will surely do?

AR: tomwilde99; glad you like it all. The economic model of newspapers will change; thankfully, we have an enlightened Trust behind us who have a long-term vision for the newspaper and its electronic development. So we do have a bit of time to get it right.


ABC123: Mr Rusbridger, what do you think about Peter Stothard and his "other projects". Will his demise affect the Times? Who do you think will be the new editor? And how much money would Murdoch have to offer you to entice you away from the Guardian?

AR: ABC123: I'm a fan of Peter Stothard: nice, serious man and a good editor. I've no idea what's going on at the Times or what his "sabbatical" means. But he's a good journalist, and I hope he's back running something or other soon. And no amount of Murdoch money could lure me from the Guardian. Honestly.


Meatloaf: Do you feel that the Guardian's news coverage has become more populist in the last couple of years (the faces of Martha LF, Robbie Williams and that Ali G fellow appear to turn up in the first five pages quite a lot). Do you think this is a bad thing?

AR: Meatloaf: more populist? Don't think so. The Times had a Great Debate circa 1967 as to whether the august paper could mention a personage such as John Lennon. I think we've gone beyond that kind of soul-searching now, accepting that you can be interested in Martha Lane Fox or Robbie Williams and debt relief or asylum policy. Papers are much bigger than they were even five years ago: I think there's room for both.


pommiebill: Dear Editor, what have you got for readers who are fed up with articles and news about pop and sports "stars", have managed to sort out their sex lives and don't feel the need for constant titillation via the Guardian, think much of the e-world is so far a waste of time, and who just want good writing about serious topics? You are forcing me to follow numerous acquaintances (of different ages) who have gone elsewhere.

AR: pommiebill. See my reply to meatloaf. Not sure you're being entirely fair. Think about: Saturday Review (most upmarket cultural section of any paper in UK); Weekend (most serious colour mag); Society, Education, Media, Friday Review. Two full broadsheet pages of comment and analysis every day. All this is serious, good writing on serious topics.


Mpotter: Did you have many sleepless nights over the Aitken affair? What kept you going with the case? Were you ever tempted to settle out of court in order to protect the paper and its employees?

AR: MPotter: Sleepless nights over Aitken? One or two. These big libel clashes are unnerving, whichever side you're on and however much confidence you have in your own case. We did try to get Aitken to see that he would be destroyed by the case because it was so obvious he was lying about the Ritz weekend. But he is - or was - a gambler and (as I think he now realises) was recklessly driven to take the ultimate risk.


jrwilliams: What is the plan now with Jonathan Aitken? Do you believe he truly is a reformed (should I say "born again") character? Keep up the excellent work.

AR: jrwilliams: Aitken reformed? Difficult to say. He's still finding one or two problems getting his story straight and seems slightly over keen to settle scores for one who has supposedly forgiven us all and moved on. But it would be good to see him putting it behind him and doing something with his undoubted intelligence and ability: something in the field of prison reform?


Messiah666: Do you, on reflection, regret the early Guardian coverage of the GM issue? Taking Dr Pusztai too much on his own valuation? It was a great victory for your newspaper, but...

AR: Messiah666: GM? I think we were pretty balanced from the start. Jury still out on Pusztai. My own views are that GM has great potential for good and great potential for danger. So I'd like the paper to be pretty straight down the middle on the subject - neither Monsanto nor Greenpeace.


Messiah666: And do you have any views on the LM/ITN affair? And more generally, of the extent of the threat that the LM/RCP grouping pose, to (relatively..:-) honest journalism?

AR: LM/ITN: I'm not a huge admirer of LM's journalistic standards, and I think it's dangerous querying the authenticity of war crimes - why should we admire LM and not David Irving? Also, I know Ed Vulliamy. He's a great and brave reporter. And he doesn't make things up.


nqeditor: AR - how do you maintain all that quality writing when you're writing for a screen the size of your watch face? That is, how can the Guardian adapt to media that favour the superficial - or should it even try?

AR: nqeditor: different writing for different platforms. Of course there's no point in trying to read Martin Woollacott or Hugo Young on a WAP phone. But some people like headline news and subbed-down Guardian stories as they move about. It's easy to do, but I agree one can't be allowed to replace the other.


AR: All: thanks for all constructive input. Have to go now.

webTitle: Mowlam unveils plan to strip criminals of assets

fields.headline: Mowlam unveils plan to strip criminals of assets
fields.trailText: Criminals could have their ill-gotten gains seized by the government under sweeping new powers proposed by cabinet office minister Mo Mowlam today.
fields.body:
Criminals could have their ill-gotten gains seized by the government under sweeping new powers proposed by cabinet office minister Mo Mowlam today.

Extending the powers of courts to recover cash from all criminals, rather than just drug traffickers, could bring in around £40m a year if current collection rates were continued.

But officials hope to increase the number of cases that result in confiscation orders, which is currently only 20% of drug prosecutions.

Much of the cash recovered could be used to fund "socially inclusive" programmes such as combating homelessness, Ms Mowlam said at the launch of the Safe in the City report, which is part of a six-year programme to prevent youth homelessness.

"Why should millions of law-abiding people work hard for a living, whilst a few criminals live a life of luxury built on the misery of others?" Ms Mowlam, who is also minister for social exclusion, said.

"Arresting and convicting criminals is not enough - we must also take away their profits. In every court case, we should be looking to confiscate the unlawful assets that have built up. That should be the norm, not the exception."

Under present laws, only fortunes amassed by drug traffickers can be recovered by the courts. And with only around £3m recovered annually from an illicit industry thought to drain £1bn a year from the UK economy, there is government concern at the low level of recovery.

Although there is no timetable for the introduction of the new laws which would allow courts to claw back cash from all convicted criminals, Ms Mowlam said there would be immediate action to increase funds recovered from drug traffickers.

A high proportion of drug proceeds are ring-fenced to help provide treatment for abusers. When the new laws come into effect, the Treasury is likely to take a slice but, similarly, a proportion is expected to be reserved for initiatives aimed at social projects.

The proposals, which are likely to be put at the heart of Labour's next election campaign, were not an attempt to out-tough the Conservatives on crime, she insisted.

"What the Tories are trying to do is tough, tough, tough and that doesn't work," she said. Those on the margins of society who could be more easily drawn into a life of crime have to be embraced both literally and figuratively, she added.

webTitle: News: Cannes jurors recognise Asian talent

fields.headline: News: Cannes jurors recognise Asian talent
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm reports on last night's awards at the close of the Cannes film festival
fields.body:
A bug-eyed jury who had to slog their way through a set of films among the longest ever to be seen in the Cannes competition awarded Bjork the Best Actress prize and Lars Von Trier's semi-musical Dancer In The Dark the Palme D'Or. Some were delighted. Others couldn't believe their ears. The film which has Bjork playing a young girl going blind and unjustly charged with murder, was loved and hated in equal measure.

Having done that, the jury led by French director Luc Besson proceeded to leave out altogether Liv Ullman's Faithless, scripted by Ingmar Bergman and one of the best films in the entire festival.

Otherwise, they did a creditable job. They recognised the strength and originality of the Asian films in the competition by giving their film-makers several of the top prizes.

The Grand Prize of Cannes 2000, which is in effect the runners-up award, went to the Chinese Devils At The Doorstep, the Best Director prize was given to Edward Yang, the Taiwanese director, for A One And A Two, and Best Actor was Hong Kong star Tony Leung for Wong Kar-wei's In The Mood For Love.

These films and others enlivened a competition which, if it had relied on Europe and America would have been infinitely less rewarding.

As is usual with international juries these days, almost everything that moved across the screen from Iran was given a prize, but at least one of them was deserved - twenty-year-old Samira Makhmalbaf's (pictured) The Blackboard which won the minor jury prize.

The Camera D'or for best first film was shared by two rather less good Iranian films - Djomeh and A Time For Drunken Horses.

Poor old Britain represented in the competition by Ken Loach's Bread And Roses and James Ivory's The Golden Bowl got nothing, though many thought Ivory's adaptation of the Henry James' novel the best thing he had done for some time.

webTitle: Come on BBC, play fair with sites

fields.headline: Come on BBC, play fair with sites
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: I like BBC News Online. Unlike Noel Edmonds, Esther Rantzen and Changing Rooms, I think it an excellent use of the licence fee.
fields.body:
I like BBC News Online. Unlike Noel Edmonds, Esther Rantzen and Changing Rooms, I think it an excellent use of the licence fee. It is also a vital investment in the future of the corporation and great proof that there is more to the net than Martha Lane Fox, teenage millionaires and that case-history in bad business known as boo.com.

True, you can ask whether the BBC's news site should really be a bit better given its resources, or the traffic a bit higher given the endless on-air promotion it receives. You can also point out that CNN.com has three times the traffic (because it dominates the US domestic market), but that is being churlish. On the whole it does a pretty good job.

However, it entered a new arena last week, when it announced a news distribution deal with Yahoo!. This may be the start of something very exciting, or something very worrying - either way, it is not to be ignored.

Deals such as this are done all the time on the net (Guardian Unlimited has a similar arrangement with Yahoo! and many other portals). Often money does not change hands, but Yahoo! gets content and traffic, and the content provider gets a presence on a major platform and links back to its site. However, once the BBC gets involved, it takes on a different dimension. Like it or not, it has been drawn into a commercial battlefield and, as a public-service broadcaster, has to be extremely careful about how it behaves.

Richard Deverell, head of new media at BBC news, told the FT that this "was not a commercial deal, but simply part of efforts to make our online service more accessible". No money is involved and in order to protect the BBC's integrity there are no banner ads on BBC stories. (There are ads on the menu pages where its stories are featured, but maybe it's being fussy to mention it).

Now, this may not appear to be "a commercial deal" for the BBC, but it does have a commercial impact for both content providers and portals. First, the BBC is such a strong name that it is likely to get top billing on any platform at which it arrives, shoving out other commercial partners. This is not true of the Yahoo! deal, it has to be said, where it gets equal billing with PA and Reuters, but it is understandable that commercial rivals might be unhappy about the BBC's arrival on the scene.

Second, whether or not the BBC likes it, whoever it becomes partners with is commercially advantaged - if not in terms of cash, then certainly in kudos. Yahoo! can now go out into the market with the BBC name attached to it, seeking other partners and advertisers. It can now tell its users that they can go to its site and get all the BBC's news. It is the sort of endorsement that money cannot buy (ironic given that Yahoo! has got so much of the stuff).

This cannot be right. If the BBC wants to hand its content in this way to Yahoo!, it has to be willing to hand it on exactly the same terms to any other site. I mentioned this to Deverell, and he agreed ultimately that BBC news would be willing to partner with anyone who could meet its "technological and branding requirements".

But it should not stop with the likes of Freeserve and MSN - by the same logic, Guardian Unlimited should be allowed to have it. As should the Times Online or the Independent.

Again, I suggested this to Deverell and while he appreciated the logic, he was rather hesitant about handing content to us as "a rival news organisation". In my dreams! I like the idea that we as a network of sites with 12m or so page impressions a month and the off-shoot of a paper that sells 400,000 copies a day are a real rival to the BBC with its 77m page impressions, the offshoot of a broadcaster with a daily audience in the tens of millions, but somehow it doesn't quite ring true.

If anything, Yahoo!, which sees itself as a media company not simply a portal or search engine (hence talks and rumoured talks with the likes of Emap, News International and Disney), is a much greater rival - which, of course, is why the BBC wanted to partner with it.

The deal with Yahoo! is a trial. Hopefully, it is a step in the right direction. It would be good for the BBC, good for the industry and good for the BBC's image within that industry if it was a blueprint for a global BBC distribution policy, where any site that passed the BBC's branding and technical requirements could take its content.

This could be the only way the BBC achieves the sort of global presence it is after, and the only way it could start to challenge its rivals, CNN.com and MSNBC.

For the BBC to fudge around with preferential treatment for some sites and not others is illogical, unfair and - the greatest sin of all - deeply unimaginative.

webTitle: The voice of the nation that can't answer back

fields.headline: The voice of the nation that can't answer back
fields.standfirst:
A general election has to be fought and the BBC is target practice

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: A general election has to be fought and the BBC is target practice
fields.body:
When Mrs Thatcher wanted to win her first general election (as John Campbell's brilliant new biography reminds us) she fawned around Fleet Street. She flirted with the Telegraph, spooned with the Mail and wooed Larry Lamb's Sun. But she threatened the BBC.

It was "the very heart of the defeatist pinko-liberal conspiracy which was dragging Britain down". She arrived at Broadcasting House "with all guns blazing: she showed scant interest in, let alone tolerance of, the editors' problems and berated them on their failings over a wide area..." She came to office "determined to bring the BBC to heel".

So what, you may ask, is new? Another general election hovers balefully over the horizon and the BBC is target practice again. Its approval ratings are on the slide (according to Mori for the Mail). The press that used to love Mrs T is doing its memorial duty.

And can the corporation look for succour or even neutrality from Labour? Hardly: Mr Blair ducks for cover behind the Queen Mum while Gerald Kaufman empties his reservoir of bile. An instructive reaction. Politicians facing a potentially life-changing vote don't defend public service broadcasting: they seek to intimidate it. And that should give us all pause.

Yet what, exactly, is the charge sheet here? A curious ragbag of random offences. The detail of the Mail's "damning" poll provides a convenient checklist.

There is the hiring of Andrew Marr to replace Robin Oakley as BBC political editor - when Marr (see the precise formulation of the question Mori put) "has in the past written articles sympathetic towards Labour". He's said "he will be impartial in his new role, but should he have been appointed?" Thirty-six per cent of the populace say aye to that and 36% say nay, whilst a prudent 28%, perhaps a little hazy about Mr Marr's career from the Economist on, have no opinion.

But it's very silly stuff. Practically the only BBC political editor anyone remembers is my friend and former Guardian colleague, John Cole. John was (and is) a free-thinking follower of old Labour, if such categorisations have any meaning: but on air he was the shrewdest, most human and yet most dispassionate of commentators. Like the departing Robin Oakley, he's a professional; and Andrew Marr is a professional, too.

Charge two is, of course, a related one. "Were you aware that Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, gave £50,000 to the Labour party in the past?" Only 27% were so aware but, having been informed, some 30% thought he shouldn't have been appointed.

Were you equally aware that Ian Trethowan, the director general Mrs Thatcher thought ran this "pinko- liberal conspiracy", was - in Campbell's words - a "good friend of Ted Heath", a genteel Conservative who never hid his political beliefs? No, cancel that one. It wasn't on the Mori list.

Has the standard of the BBC's news and current affairs generally improved/stayed the same/got worse? Here a lid drops on this whole tendentious area. Forty-two per cent say improved, 43% can see no change; a mere 12% think things have got worse. Set a general context to enclose the specific, needling questions and you can see the mountains as well as the mists.

So it is, also, with another great gripe of the week: sport and the supposed shame of a Saturday afternoon without Grandstand. Thirty-five per cent "strongly agree" that the BBC hasn't kept up with ITV and Sky in covering live sport - but on the "too much/too little/just about right" multiple choice, the biggest vote (37%, mainly from women) is that there's too much sport on the Beeb anyway. And would anyone like to go the Sky way and fund the sporting fightback from subscription charges? Only a hardy 12% say yes to that.

The sole sensible conclusion at the end of a rather protracted questionnaire is that if you ring up 1,003 people over the age of 18 and ask them whether they like the BBC's decision not to show the Queen Mother's birthday pageant live, then a non-thunderous majority will disapprove: but, thanks to a little ITV opportunism, we shall soon have the actual viewing figures to see whether Jonathan Dimbleby is right when he sees his dad Richard "turning in his grave" at this abdication of responsibility. The rest, faithfully tabulated, is the flim-flam of polls at particular times in particular circumstances.

Nevertheless, the yoking together of the BBC and the Queen Mum does boast a certain bizarre symmetry - a conjunction of whipping lads and lasses. The royal family, when attacked, has no direct means of answering back. It has an array of courtiers and press officers, but only silence at the heart (unless the Duke of Edinburgh briefly decides otherwise).

The corporation, too, is similarly constrained. Greg Dyke may be kicked all over the park by the Telegraph and Mail - but his lips stay sealed. To reply would play straight into the hands of his enemies, confirming them in their cries of bias. "Embattled Dyke lashes out". It's a no-win game. Only losing, as the years go by, comes easier.

We ought to be clear-eyed about the reasons for that, and its consequences. Commercially, the BBC has no natural allies. Its expanding, proliferating competitors find its position privileged and offensive - not just on television and radio, secured by licence fee, but increasingly on the internet, where its dotcombustion engine threatens to become a juggernaut which crushes other web ventures run by a press that sees its own future at stake. Vulnerability.

Ideologically, see the Dimbleby charge, it must speak as "voice of the nation" for a nation which has changed beyond imagining in its multiculturalism and defining passions. Politically, it remains "most trusted" - but prey to those who, by their threats or their silences, wish to make use of that trust. Only 10%, on that Mori poll, thought the licence fee very good value. More vulnerability.

When Mrs T took on the Beeb, 20 years ago, she had to retire hurt in the close. The scaffolding of Birt bureaucracy was the price paid for seeing her off. Joe Public still thought of the enterprise as his own, a member of the family to be cherished against assault.

But how many times can you take a pasting without losing your place in the sun? The lesson of the rough week that was is that constant assaults on all imaginable fronts take their toll of a corporation which can't answer back. That's no way to win a war as the election nears. Just remember, amidst the turmoil, that it is a war. Just remember (pace the Lady) that everyone has an agenda.

webTitle: Britain must clarify Sierra Leone mission, say Tories

fields.headline: Britain must clarify Sierra Leone mission, say Tories
fields.standfirst: UK may offer 'long-term commitment' to help Sierra Leone army fight rebels
fields.trailText: The Conservatives today called on the government to clarify the British mission in Sierra Leone amid indications that the government may arm government forces there.
fields.body:
The Conservatives today called on the government to clarify the British mission in Sierra Leone amid indications that the government may arm government forces there.

Shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan Smith said his party continued to support British troops but added: "There now appears to be frustration in the military over the lack of clarity of their aims... The government must now clarify its mission and set clear objectives to give British troops the flexibility to operate in the way they feel best suited to achieving their mission."

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon yesterday signalled that the UK could give a long-term commitment to help the Sierra Leone army take on rebel forces. Mr Hoon said military help and advice would continue even after British paratroopers withdrew.

"For some time we have had advisers present," he said yesterday. "That is something we will continue. Obviously we have to have regard for the safety of anyone who goes there to train the army of Sierra Leone and when the situation is safe, we can take that forward."

According to the Daily Telegraph, British paratroopers could leave within 10 days under an exit strategy being considered by the government. The paper reported that British commanders plan to arm the Sierra Leone army and train up their troops to be capable of attacking the rebels. The move, which could be seen an escalation of British involvement, came as news emerged about a missing British aid worker.

Major Andrew Harrison, the British UN observer taken hostage in Sierra Leone, has sent an email to his wife saying he is safe and well. He was released nine days ago after being held captive for 11 days in the jungle by RUF rebels. However, he remains trapped behind rebel lines in a UN compound at Kailahun, in the north of the country, along with 10 other former observers. The rebels are still thought to be holding almost 300 of the 500 UN personnel they originally seized - most of them Zambians.

During the past week, former hostages have been steadily returning to Sierra Leone after being released through neighbouring Liberia in a deal brokered by Liberian President Charles Taylor. Fifty-four more UN hostages were freed yesterday, but the government said it will not compromise on its handling of detained rebel leader Foday Sankoh in order to secure the releases of nearly 300 additional captives.

"There is no connection," said information minister Julius Spencer. A government investigation to decide whether to prosecute Mr Sankoh, who was captured last week, had not yet been completed, he added.

The peacekeepers were flown by helicopter to Monrovia, Liberia, and then taken a few hours later by plane to Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown. A UN official said on Monday that the world body believed that more hostages could be released soon. But David Wimhurst, the spokesman for the UN peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone, said there was no definite word of impending releases.

UN officials have expressed concerns for the health of the remaining captives. Many in the group that was released looked thin and weak as they walked off the plane. Three injured Kenyans were taken away in an ambulance. Officials did not say how they were hurt. Mr Wimhurst said several of the freed hostages were suffering from malaria.

The release of the UN troops came as pro-government forces advanced yesterday toward the rebel-held town of Lunsar, 50 miles north east of Freetown, military officials said. If they take the town, it would position them to make a push against the key rebel stronghold of Makeni. The government counter attack followed a rebel offensive that brought them within 40 miles of Freetown, in a flare-up of Sierra Leone's civil conflict which has seen RUF rebels kill or mutilate thousands of civilians.

fields.headline: Net Imperative goes into liquidation
fields.standfirst:
How Net Imperative reported its own demise
Net Imperative
fields.trailText: The internet news service Net Imperative became the second big casualty of the slump in the start-up economy when it went into liquidation today.
fields.body:
The internet news service Net Imperative became the second big casualty of the slump in the start-up economy when it went into liquidation today.

Net Imperative appointed Kroll Buchler Phillips as provisional liquidators after a board meeting this morning, the service's editor, Niki Panourgias, announced on its website.

"It is work as usual," Mr Panourgias said, as the site endeavours "to provide as impartial coverage of the story as would be the case with any company in the same situation".

Net Imperative was founded eight months ago with a staff of 24 to provide specialist news for the UK internet industry. It went live in February from its office in Shoreditch, London.

It appointed Albert Scardino, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist in the 1980s, as non-executive chairman, and was primarily funded by the British stockbroker and niche internet investor Durlacher Plc, which holds a 28.5% stake.

webTitle: Do we want to go large?

fields.headline: Do we want to go large?
fields.standfirst: The rush to merge in the regions could end in a risky redrawing of our local newspaper landscape, argues  Roy Greenslade, while Tim Bowdler  disagrees
fields.trailText: The rush to merge in the regions could end in a risky redrawing of our local newspaper landscape, argues Roy Greenslade, while Tim Bowdler disagrees
fields.body:
Every week there is another takeover or merger of regional newspapers. A fortnight ago, after a competition commission report cleared the way for three large chains to offer bids, Newsquest snaffled Newscom. So Newsquest, which already owns 130 titles, added a further 60 papers based in the south of England and South Wales with a stock market value of more than £400m.

Newsquest is itself a subsidiary of the USA's largest newspaper corpoartion, Gannett, with 74 newspapers across America selling 6.6m a day. Last week it was the turn of Johnston Press, owner of 168 titles, to buy 14 more papers from Southnews, which were an unwanted part of a package of 33 titles it acquired in March.

But these latest moves towards greater consolidation in the regional newspaper industry will not satisfy the appetites of the leading companies. It isn't happening fast enough, or smoothly enough, for them.

They are calling on the government to do away with all competition regulations in order to speed the process of mergers and acquisitions.

My understanding is that ministers are beginning to bend to the owners' wishes, and before the government gets close to making that mistake, it is imperative that everyone wakes up to the dangers that lie ahead.

Previously, I have been relatively relaxed about the gradual formation of regional chains in Britain. Those in charge of the main groups have good track records, care about newspapers and in most cases have invested wisely.

It's fair to say that they have saved many titles which might well have gone to the wall under previous owners who failed to take the right decisions. There is no denying that most of the groups in the chart have done well.

But the alarm bells began to sound when Newsquest was forced by its venture capital backers to sell to Gannett. Was it in our interest, I asked myself, for an American company which has attracted opprobrium from journalists in its own country for cost-cutting and squeezing editorial resources to own the Brighton Evening Argus or the Bradford Telegraph and Argus?

Now the sound of those bells is deafening. In an important recent speech Tim Bowdler, chief executive of Johnston Press, argued that the time had come to do away with the regulations which have been in force for almost 40 years - though many times amended - to prevent too great a concentration of ownership. Similarly, he wishes to set aside rules inhibiting cross-media ownership.

He was not speaking just for himself but for all the large owners who have been lobbying hard through their organisation, the Newspaper Society, to bring about these changes.

It has to be said that there is some merit in their arguments. As Bowdler rightly pointed out, it is plainly ridiculous that his company had to seek prior approval to acquire the Arbroath Herald and the Broughty Ferry, Carnoustie and Monifieth Guide and Gazette with a combined circulation of approximately 10,000 copies. Yet Johnston Press itself, with 168 titles, could be acquired by a foreign conglomerate tomorrow.

That kind of absurdity obviously requires a reform of the competition rules, just as the criteria for a referral - which usually hinge on an outdated concept of competition for advertising revenue - need amendment.

But that doesn't mean that we should have a free-for-all, allowing the formation of huge media combines or, worse, creating the conditions for the wholesale purchase of our regional newspapers by US-based global media cartels which have made a fetish of driving up profit margins.

Bowdler and the others are consumed with the idea that they are too small and weak to compete with the world's multi-media players. Not only must they be big, but huge, enormous, gigantic. Smallness and local-ness, to coin a word, are no longer economically viable. Size is everything.

Small companies in mature industries are considered largely irrelevant. If they want a decent future they must combine into ever-expanding chains. Big is beautiful.

This may make life interesting, even fun, for businessmen, but is it good for the future of our local weekly papers?

Bowdler argues that "specialist newspaper provisions are unnecessary" and that "newspapers should be subject only to general competition law". In other words, papers should be regarded as a product like any other.

Now forgive me if I sound a little romantic, but I happen to believe that papers are different and special. They cannot be seen in the same light as other goods, such as cars or (with apologies to Tony O'Reilly's past occupation) baked beans. Papers may be commercial operations but they have a public purpose. That's why they must be treated as different and special. That was the view of three royal commissions. It's also the view, I suspect, of most MPs and of governments, of whatever hue, in the past. I also fondly imagine it to be the view of the people who buy papers too.

I see no genuine reason to change our minds about the fundamental point: papers require a different regulatory regime from other forms of business.

In truth, there is only one reason to wipe out the regulatory framework and that, of course, is profit.

Papers have always straddled the line between public service and private profit, finding a way to make them mutually compatible for the benefit of both the reader and the owner. The balance between the two is delicate. What I fear is that the tearing asunder of all regulations will create an imbalance which could, in the long run, destroy our national network of local and regional papers. In the long term, profit will eclipse all sense of public purpose.

I agree that we have reason to praise Bowdler and his fellow chief executives. But they are not the only good owners. Lots of much smaller companies, from the vibrant Kent Messenger group with several sales-winning successes to Joan Trimble's wonderful single title, the Impartial Reporter of Enniskillen, have fine records too.

They keep close to their communities and to their readers. So far, our bigger companies have succeeded in doing so too. But if we remove regulations, or fail to get to grips with the encroachment of foreign ownership (which many other countries restrict), I foresee an unwholesome scenario.

Imagine a future in which an accountant in Atlanta decides that the Giggleswick Guardian's editor must make do with one part-time reporter in place of his two full-time staff because the Yorkshire United Press division of its UK-based Anglo-Georgia Newspapers plc, a subsidiary of the US-owned Internet Corporation of America, is required to improve its profit margin by a full 1% in the next financial year. Far-fetched? Maybe. After all, what earthly sense is there in a company squeezing a little paper to death in order to make a fast buck?

 Roy Greenslade, abridged from a speech made to the Newspaper Society's annual meeting

Change the game

When Johnston Press agreed to buy the Broughty Ferry, Carnoustie and Monifieth Guide and Gazette, with a circulation of around 2,000 copies and no overlap with any of its newspaper titles, it required consent from the Department of Trade and Industry under the special merger provisions to which regional newspaper publishers are subject. Yet virtually every other industry sector, including other media, is subject only to general competition law.

In a large number of cases, prior approval has extended to the statutory requirement for a full competition commission inquiry. But while the UK's regional press is subject to these onerous constraints, foreign newspaper publishers are freely able to acquire newspapers in this country.

Similarly, venture capitalists have been active buyers of regional papers, because they see the opportunity for a quick profit. It's their good fortune that regional publishers have been unable to compete on a level playing field.

The process of consolidation in the media, telecoms and entertainment industries continues apace. Mega deals seem not to raise a regulatory eyebrow and increasing concentration of ownership looks inevitable in commercial television and radio. And yet the regulatory mindset presumes that consolidation of the regional press should be strictly and arbitrarily controlled.

The regulations which govern newspaper mergers are based on a royal commission which reported in 1962. While there have been modifications since then, the special newspaper merger controls have remained largely unchanged. The dramatic changes to the media landscape since 1962 have resulted in a proliferation of media choice.

There are no longer static geographic monopolies of information. Regional papers now face a vast array of competition for the attention of their communities and for the advertising revenues which represent the lifeblood of the business.

The current regulations greatly disadvantage the regional press in the face of this intensifying competition. The ability to achieve efficiencies through consolidation is essential if the industry is to defend its market position. There is also a need for continued investment in systems and printing capacity, in improving editorial content and presentation, and to embrace the opportunities presented by the new media. However, the industry's ability to invest in these areas will also be a function of the extent to which further consolidation takes place.

Roy Greenslade's view that consolidation threatens editorial independence and quality is misguided. Firstly, neither the DTI nor the competition commission has ever found that regional publishers are pursuing editorial policies which are contrary to the public interest. The reason is simple: newspapers which fail to retain readers will struggle to maintain advertising revenues. Secondly, the larger players have invested heavily to meet market needs and indeed where acquisitions have been made, they have provided much-needed investment for those businesses.

And finally, Mr Greenslade fails to recognise the intensity of competition faced by regional newspapers. Make no mistake, the ability to produce good newspapers is fundamentally dependent upon healthy advertising revenues.

Newspapers should not be ring-fenced in a manner which subjects them to greater regulation than their competitors. The industry should be permitted to consolidate subject only to general competition law, just as its competitors are increasingly free to do.

What is more, a failure to remove discriminatory controls will put in jeopardy the industry's ability to provide the local editorial voices which the current regulations were originally put in place to protect.

Mr Greenslade's concerns about multinational media conglomerates are best regulated by general EU and UK competition law.

A feature in the Guardian more than a year ago concluded: "This government needs to reconsider competition policy in relation to newspapers, especially at regional level, and ask whether the public interest is really being served at present. In a rapidly developing multimedia world, the nature of competition from non-print sources needs to be built into the criteria too."

It was written by Mr Greenslade. I tend to agree with him. We both want regional and local newspapers to flourish. The current ownership regulations need to change radically and quickly if this is to happen.

 Tim Bowdler, chief executive of Johnston Press plc.

fields.headline: As seen on TV
fields.standfirst: Meet the man who gave Mother Teresa a condom. By  Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: Meet the man who gave Mother Teresa a condom. By Rory Carroll
fields.body:
Every night he is at the heart of the action. War, political upheaval, transport strikes, mafia killings, papal audiences, the World Cup, whatever it is, wherever it is, he's there. Tall and intense, he gazes into the camera and without his uttering a word millions of Italians know they are watching the day's big news story.

His name is Gabriele Paolini but he prefers to be called the Condom Prophet, and he is a uniquely dedicated, shameless and successful media gatecrasher. Paolini has singlehandedly breached just about every media sanctum. No broadcast is safe, no interview secure, no celebrity immune from his assaults. Every Italian journalist knows him, most fear and loathe him, but almost all agree on one thing: he is very, very good.

The 25-year-old's mission in life is to hog the limelight. Six years of doing nothing else has forged his razor-sharp news judgment. After a scan of the morning agency wires, off he goes, leaving his parents' house in a Rome suburb and setting off for what is almost certain to end up as the day's lead news item.

"I pollute information, I am a media virus," he says. Newscasters have learned to keep a poker face when he bursts into studios brandishing condoms under their noses. Television crews filing breaking stories have long given up trying to shoo him away. He is relentless.

Tales of celebrity come no emptier than this. Rome is the city of La Dolce Vita, Federico Fellini's classic 1960 film which portrayed paparazzi chasing movie stars in a world of shallow glamour and hedonism. Paolini has gone one step further, for he chases paparazzi. Publicity is an end, not a means.

In the land where television is king he has become a star of sorts. "This is my choice in life. I have found my vocation and I will be doing this forever," he says, not taking his eyes off the latest news flash. Camera crews will probably assemble outside Palazzo Chigi for a parliamentary crisis within the hour. Time is short and he talks quickly.

"It started in 1994 when a close friend died of Aids. I decided to warn people to protect themselves, by publicising condoms." Armed with brass neck, he started his ambushes - at first local news bulletins, but soon the nationals. A protest here, a press conference there, condoms everywhere. The moment he handed one to Mother Teresa of Calcutta is recorded in a photograph. The fury of her aides moments later is not.

Another photo records him clutching the hand and whispering in the ear of Pope John Paul II. He says he slipped him a condom and asked: "Did you ever have an erection?" The Pope allegedly replied with a smile: "I, too, was young once." Paolini is known for fibbing and there is no corroborating evidence.

But there is no doubt whatsoever about his condom-waving encounter with Paolo Frajese, an anchor for state broadcaster RAI, during a 1998 World Cup broadcast in Marseilles. Six million watched Frajese lose it. He turned on the prophet and kicked him repeatedly in the crotch and stomach. "Here," says Paolini, unbuttoning his shirt to reveal a red weal around the navel. "That's where they had to operate." He smiles. He was there for the "trial of the century" when the former prime minister Giulio Andreotti was acquitted on murder charges, for Luciano Pavarotti's performance at Spoleto, for John McEnroe's press conference, for a porn star's birthday.

For the Kosovo war he was at Nato's huge base at Aviano. "I didn't eat or sleep, it was so busy. But the BBC and CNN are more aggressive than the average Italian. Hands pushing you everywhere. I don't go near them anymore. I stick to Italian TV. It's much more democratic and, let's admit it, less professional."

It was the necklace of condoms he habitually wears that pushed his parents, a retired army general and housewife, over the edge. "He said he wanted to be a journalist," his mother sighed to Italy Daily. His three older sisters avoid being seen with him in public.

Paolini, who doesn't speak English but made it on to Channel 4, no longer waves the condoms during his on-air interruptions. "Now I'm into phase two. It's not about Aids anymore, it's about me. My persona has been built, when people see my face they automatically think of condoms so I only wear the necklace."

Journalists accept him but have not warmed to him. "He's an idiot, an egotist with nothing to offer," says one. Paolo Dal Donno, of Radio Dimensione Suono, disagrees: "I feel reassured when I see him because I know I'm covering the right stuff."

Paolini is bullish. He has no girlfriend - "no time, it wouldn't be fair on her, though I sleep with loads of people" - and claims to earn income from giving pep talks at sex clubs. He has four fan clubs, two acolytes who join his gatecrashing and an imminent autobiography.

Odium and ridicule assail him each day but he ploughs on. Persistence has revealed a paradox of the media. "They hate me, but they use me. I get asked for interviews all the time. RAI have persecuted me, yet some of their producers call me up for interviews."

But now, time's up. Cameras are possibly already whirring at Palazzo Chigi. Paolini bounds away for another performance. The media is a voracious monster which craves feeding. Even from him.

fields.headline: Secrecy - the feelgood factor
fields.trailText: Five months ago at the start of a new century, in an office three floors above London's most luxurious table dancing club, I was sharing a desk, a phone, and a Mac with a man I barely knew. I was the editor of an untitled film magazine, and the man sitting uncomfortably close to me was Paul Henderson, who had come from GQ to act as deputy editor. The magazine would be the first launch for IFeelGood, James Brown's fledgling publishing empire.
fields.body:
Five months ago at the start of a new century, in an office three floors above London's most luxurious table dancing club, I was sharing a desk, a phone, and a Mac with a man I barely knew. I was the editor of an untitled film magazine, and the man sitting uncomfortably close to me was Paul Henderson, who had come from GQ to act as deputy editor. The magazine would be the first launch for IFeelGood, James Brown's fledgling publishing empire.

The content had already been broadly planned: we wanted a film magazine that would be informative without being dry, that would be populist without falling for every over-hyped new release, and we also wanted a magazine that would make us laugh. Above all, it was going to be a magazine we wanted to read. It was going to be fantastic. Unfortunately nobody - not friends or family - was to know what we were working on.

The cone of silence under which we were working made dealing with PRs difficult, and it made talking with friends and ex-colleagues treacherous. But it became positively surreal when we began to do interviews with potential writers and editors. James had placed a small, general call-out for staff in the Guardian, and a flood of applications had come back. Interviews are difficult for both sides at the best of times, but we found ourselves in the unique position of asking people to come in to discuss an unspecified job on a magazine about which we were able to tell them nothing - not content, nor title, not even the launch date. Perhaps unsurprisingly we kept these interviews brief, but each one shuddered to the same inevitable point at which we asked the candidate if there was anything more they'd like to know about the job - bearing in mind that we could tell them nothing.

Amazingly, we found some great staff despite this awkward process. While the new recruits worked out their notice, Paul and I worked with James, IFG creative director Jon Link and his assistant Simon Brown (no relation) on a dummy. And by the time production manager David Gyseman arrived from Condé Nast we had a dummy pretty much ready to send to the printers.

If that sounds simple, it really shouldn't. At the same time as producing the dummy, we also had to research the magazine, for which we needed layouts on boards and lots and lots of titles. We had loads - some were stupid, and a few inspired, so don't expect to read them here. And armed with these glorified print-outs we embarked on the focus group circuit.

Although there was some trepidation on our part, the focus groups turned out to be a lot of fun. The potential punters seemed to get what we were trying to do, they laughed at the jokes, got the references, and mostly bought in to the idea of a movie magazine that's about great films, not just every new release. They also yielded a surprise bonus when one guy in Manchester unwittingly gave us our tag line, when he told the guy he was engaged in a heated debate with: "You've been watching too many movies."

Buoyed up by this extraordinarily positive research, and now with a dummy to show, the ad team went off to work, and we settled down to our first issue.

With the title, subject matter and launch date still a mystery, we stealthily approached writers and PRs and started to figure out how best to fill the pages. For the people working on the magazine, it was a little hard to believe that in eight weeks' time we'd actually be holding a copy of the magazine - for the contributors, none of whom we'd told more than the sketchiest details, it must have been almost impossible. But they all came through for us. And finally, very tired, somewhat emotional, and slightly late we sent the last page.

Now here it is: 132 pages of Hotdog, near as dammit the magazine James and I first discussed last autumn. It's been a fraught and frantic few months, but more than that it's been the most exciting project I think any of us have ever worked on. And now I even have my own desk, and a phone and a brand-new Mac.

fields.headline: Brown in motion
fields.standfirst: The publishing world has been waiting for him to fail, instead he's now worth £5m thanks to the flotation of his new company which hasn't yet printed a word.  Imogen O'Rorke  talks to James Brown
fields.trailText: The publishing world has been waiting for him to fail, instead he's now worth £5m thanks to the flotation of his new company which hasn't yet printed a word. Imogen O'Rorke talks to James Brown
fields.body:
There was probably only one man in the wild west of UK publishing who could have pulled it off. Last week James Brown, the maverick editor who gave the world Loaded and new men the freedom to be lads, successfully floated his publishing company IFG on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) at a valuation of £10m, before so much as a single national title or website had been launched.

Down at the offices of the newly-christened IFeelGood Holdings plc, in Clerkenwell, central London, it's impossible not to catch the feelgood bug. The 24 hours since the company raised the £3.6m that it needed to launch its first three titles have been ecstatic, frenetic, surreal. There's been no time to celebrate in the traditional manner of an all-night bender - that's not the reason why Brown has a pair of dark glasses strapped to his face - but the goggle-eyed expressions of IFG staff say it all.

Brown was up at 6am to talk on the Money Channel about his flotation strategy. The phone has been going all day. Felix Dennis, the millionaire publisher who owns a 10% stake in the company as non-executive chairman, called to offer another £500,000, then there was a meeting with a top Hollywood fixer for Hotdog (IFG's first big launch, a magazine for movie fanatics, out on Friday) and there was just time to go home, change, "listen to Lou Reed and the Beastie Boys" and come back in.

Cavorting around his retro orange, green and purple offices ("Come on, let me show you around!") like Willy Wonka in his chocolate factory (his own analogy), Brown introduces his team of "geniuses" or "oompa-loompas" who are eating their way through a gift box of muffins. There's Paul Henderson, aka "the grunge", the art director who came with him from GQ; there's Ben Olins, the "mod", editor of Hotdog, formerly Guardian Guide editor; Neil Jeffries, contributing editor, aka "the rocker", and Brown himself is of course "the godfather of soul".

His role as CEO, editorial director and honorary "idiot savant" - a title bestowed upon him by Dennis who believes Brown has the Midas touch - will be "to give the company direction", to use those instincts which made IPC a lot of money back in 1994 when they took on a 26-year-old football fanatic with an idea for a fantasy men's mag, and just to "be James Brown", as he puts it.

"The general opinion is that to launch anything you need 99% straight guys and one maverick - well, I think it's the other way round," says Brown contentiously. Mavericks maybe, but his non-executive directors and financial advisers Chris Akers and Rodger Sargent knew exactly what they were doing when they advised Brown to go for an early float.

It looked like a huge gamble. Premature flotation proved a disaster for new media companies such as Lastminute.com and YesTV and if the shares had bottomed out, IFG would be in an untenable position right now. But to the chagrin of many rivals in the industry who were hoping Brown might get his comeuppance, it paid off - with a PR windfall.

"It wasn't just my reputation it was floated on," says Brown. "It was the reputations of Dennis, myself and Chris Akers" (who recently sold his Sports Internet Group to Sky for millions). "The beauty of IFG is that we have strong editorial talent and we can apply that to anything - content is king." The invitation to join the founding editor of Loaded and the publisher of Maxim around the table at a game of Risk proved irresistible to many City brokers, who were after all Brown's most loyal readership in his Loaded days.

With Hotdog, the magazine for men who've "been watching too many movies", Brown hopes to use his in-joke magic to give what is otherwise a highly commercial, tightly-niched film and DVD industry driver the feel of a national fanzine. Digital Home Video is the hottest spot in publishing this month with four launches in the sector. Hotdog is meat and sauce between two wedges of carbohydrate for the "staying in" generation.

The cover promises "Scandals, Starlets and Car Chases" and carries a drawing of Robert De Niro as Travis Bickle, the anti-hero of Taxi Driver and movie buffs' favourite loony after Norman Bates. Inside there is a centre spread on the film - including a spoof interview with Travis - sizzler du jour Angelina Jolie in a surprisingly tasteful fashion shoot, and an investigation into the paranoia surrounding the Church of Scientology and its links to John Travolta's new movie.

"Travis said he'd only do the interview if he got the cover," quips Brown, explaining that "we wanted an icon. A character from a film that came out 15 years ago means more to me than a publicity stunt." It makes a change from the slavish PR agendas that mainstream movie mags follow. Hotdogmagazine.com, launched simultaneously, will have its own identity. Adam Porter, who as editor of UpLoaded brought in 1m visitors a month and also edits his own fan ezine, Year Zero, on the side, has been busy signing deals with cult short film production companies. And with columnists like Ivan Narge, better known as Hollywood madam Heidi Fleiss's "minder", and Kerri Sharpem, who was head of Virgin's "exotic" publishing arm, the site could become Hotdog's red light zone.

The next two titles, a lifestyle magazine (target date December 2000 - Brown will not be more specific) and a leisure title (mid-2001), will be launched with sister websites alongside. The company's AIM admission brochure emphasises the increasing importance of online revenue streams.

Another central plank of the Brownian strategy is creative consultancy and content syndication. "I started IFG in the first place to harness my alternative revenue stream, I was earning money from talking to ad agencies about cheese and tomato sauce - and I needed a bank account."

There were other motivations, he says: "IFG was actually a mood. I didn't think about the James Brown thing until afterwards. It sounds a bit disingenuous now, but I was just feeling very good..." Last January he was offered the editorship of American GQ, which was hit by the laddish invasion force of US editions of FHM and Maxim. He was flown over and tempted with large amounts of money but turned it down because "it just didn't feel right".

Five weeks later came the infamous "Rommel incident", when Brown published a piece in GQ including the Nazi field marshal in a list of the 200 "style icons" of the 20th century. Si Newhouse, the Jewish boss of Condé Nast, was not amused. Brown resigned, having increased the readership by 20% but messed with the magazine's identity ("GQ didn't know what it was, anyway").

"I thought, 'that's it, then, I'll get on and do me own thing'," he recalls. "I got on the tube, went to Oxford Circus and instead of turning right into Hanover Square, I walked left down Regent Street" - away from Condé Nast's HQ and into the offices of the Leeds United fanzine. Within a couple of months he had ideas for three magazines and was putting together a team. Olins was one of the first on board. Brown was considering nominating him for a best editor award, and instead took him out to lunch and made him a proposal. ("Everyone I've hired, I've promoted. And it's a clean slate - they can do what they want.") Akers came next: "I knew then that it would happen. Chris is a smart guy."

The real clincher was getting Felix Dennis's backing: "Felix started as a maverick like us. We just went to see him, really. We showed Alistair Ramsay [Dennis's number two] the layouts for magazines, he really liked them, he said, 'let's do it'. Akers had a chat with Felix. That was that." He makes it sound like taking candy from a baby.

Allied to Dennis Publishing, IFG is more likely to be able to withstand the pressure from big publishers such as IPC, which showed in taking on Cabal that it has the financial muscle to smother independent launches with temporary "spoiler" magazines. IPC has just poured millions into revamping its music and sport department, to be led by Mike Soutar, and there are plans for several new men's lifestyle and leisure launches this year.

Brown is "not intimidated" but reluctant to criticise his old employers, although he admits he is "not exactly friends" with IPC, which took Loaded - the publishing sensation of the decade - off his hands in return for a mere salary. "Our policy has always been magazines produced by fans for fans. We haven't done this to take on the multinationals," he insists. He has so far resisted offers to sell off parts of IFG to companies who wanted the controlling share. "The way I see it, they are the Americans and we are the Vietcong."

The days of sleeping hungover under the desk and dropping "big tits" into every other sentence are gone - anecdotes for the historians of laddism. "I'm now trying to unite the disciplines I learned at Condé Nast with the editorial freedom of Loaded. And if you can bring those two things together you've got a very attractive proposition."

Later, down at a favourite King's Cross pub where he knows everyone from the barman to the guy at the door selling Locked In, a fanzine for heavy drinkers, Brown relaxes - over a bottle of water - and finally takes his shades off. He talks amusingly about his quasi-voyeuristic new-found friendship with celebrity club owner Piers Adam ("he reminds me of me at my worst. I watch him behaving at a splendid level of debauchery") and what keeps driving him back to men's magazines, especially when he has stopped reading them now they are all "identical, stale, boring".

"I like being positive about things and being inspired. Whether it's Johnny Vaughan, the Beastie Boys, or the Chapman Brothers, people making good art, good films - whatever. I like watching things where people have had fun producing them. And I'm good at it - the vision and the team-building."

He has spent the last six years of his life making money for other people ("Loaded was my life on paper"). Now, at 34, with a 47% share in his own company, Brown is taking orders from no one but himself. "In the words of the Beastie Boys, it's time to set the record straight."
