fields.headline: A question of timing
fields.standfirst: Is ITV's row with the regulator over when the news should be shown about more than just News at Ten?  Maggie Brown and Matt Wells  report
fields.trailText: Is ITV's row with the regulator over when the news should be shown about more than just News at Ten? Maggie Brown and Matt Wells report
fields.body:
It was with some trepidation that a delegation of ITV chiefs embarked on the taxi ride from their swanky network headquarters, across central London to the slightly less salubrious home of the independent television commission on Wednesday evening. Their nervousness during the journey was understandable: the following morning, the commission would meet formally to discuss ITV's justification for sweeping News at Ten from the evening schedules to make way for ratings-boosting drama and entertainment. Given the regulator's immoderate pronouncements about the issue a month earlier, it would be a tense meeting.

Despite the initial coolness, the smooth-talking ITV director of programmes, David Liddiment gave a polished presentation, with moral support from ITV chairman Leslie Hill. He told commission members, led by chairman Sir Robin Biggam and chief executive Peter Rogers, that ITV would invest up to £20m in new programmes for the 9-11pm slot to boost audiences in the run-up to the problematic Nightly News, and a new soap would help to stem the decline in the early evening schedule. News audiences were already looking better than when the ITC blew its top a few weeks earlier, and the rot was in retreat, he said.

The commission members were impressed with Liddiment's positive tone. They liked the promise of more money, and some had begun to be won over to the argument that ratings for news bulletins largely depend on the popularity of the shows that precede them. The ITV delegation left the meeting feeling more relaxed than when it arrived.

So it was a surprise when the call came at about 2pm the following day to say that the commission had unanimously rejected the plan. Anger was fuelled when the press release arrived an hour later: "This will be ITV's last opportunity to present proposals, since the uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue," thundered Biggam. It was a bit rich, said ITV bosses, given that it was the commission itself that was perpetuating the uncertainty. After declaring May 18 the deadline, it now gave ITV another two weeks to produce a new plan. Like errant schoolboys, ITV executives were told to come up with a "final set of proposals" by June 9, in time for the next ITC meeting on June 22.

The chasm between regulator and broadcaster is as wide as ever; rarely has such a breakdown in the way British TV is run been exposed in public. "Even if they are in dialogue, communication has broken down: the two sides keep missing each other," says one informed insider.

It is clear there are different shades of opinion within the regulator. Officials, led by outgoing ITC chief executive Peter Rogers, are sympathetic to the pressures of the free market, and keen not to be presented as overbearing. Yet commission members unanimously voted down ITV's plans.

Over at the network, executives are still misreading the ITC's signals on this most sensitive of issues. Since last autumn when pressure for the news review mounted, ITV has consistently been wrong-footed. It should have been obvious that the ITC, given its stated views last month on the fall in news audiences (regional news shows were down 22%), would not be satisfied with the status quo. The ITC expected a significant gesture, to address its conviction that the news experiment has not worked: crucially, 6.30pm for national news is a bit too early, and 11pm, with regional news tacked on, a bit too late.

But Liddiment and his ITV colleagues could not bring themselves to give commission members what they really wanted: a change in the news schedule. There is little doubt that had ITV offered to move the 11pm bulletin to 10.30pm, the ITC would have been placated. But the ITV chiefs - angered that an under-pressure regulator has apparently moved the goalpoasts since first giving permission for the schedule change in March last year - had rallied round the network line. A 10.30pm news would be the worst of all possible worlds. There would be no place for current affairs such as Tonight and John Pilger's work, no place for late-night drama, and no place for the regional programmes that are often shown at 10.30pm, they threatened. Viewing figures would increase in the short term, but ITV's overall share of the evening audience would soon start to drop off. Given that ITV is not even on course to meet current targets this year, such a move would be suicidal. They thought the ITC would give way: instead, the network is back on the rack.

"We were surprised," says Hill. "We thought we had offered a substantial set of changes. But jaw jaw is better than war war. We shall strive to produce acceptable measures." Would such an "acceptable measure" mean ITV, against its better judgement, opting to head off a damaging row by giving in to the commission's demand for a News at 10.30pm? On that, Hill is silent.

Before last week, the ITV companies had stood firm. During a two-hour debate on the issue at ITV's ruling council meeting on May 8, all the companies stuck to their guns, some more solidly than others, united behind the current schedule, which Liddiment argues is working well, and bringing in the crucial younger viewers. The "honourable compromise" of a 10.30pm bulletin was rejected, but with Carlton and Granada said to be more hawkish than United News & Media. Now, the ball is back in ITV's court. Urgent meetings have already been held, and Liddiment will be in constant contact over the next week from Los Angeles, where he is viewing up-and-coming US shows.

Paul Bonner, who is writing the official history of independent television in Britain - authorised by the ITC - is amazed that it has gone this far. "It is bizarre. Both sides are in a position of confrontation most would seek to avoid. But people do back themselves into situations."

Should ITV refuse to compromise, arguing that technically it is meeting licence requirements to provide high-quality news in peak time, the ITC could use two regulatory weapons. First, it could cancel the variation in the ITV licences it granted in November 1998, which allowed ITV to move News at Ten. This is something of a blunt instrument, however, and the ITC does not see this as a viable option, even though it would delight government ministers, who believe 10.30pm is still too late for news.

As a back-up, the ITC is looking to the catch-all wording in the broadcasting act which requires ITV to provide "such services which taken as a whole are of high quality". This would allow the ITC to order a judicial review in the high court.

But does it dare go to law? The high court option would be the equivalent of pressing the nuclear button. A judicial review would throw the spotlight on the ITC's very purpose: a forensic examination of which would be highly damaging just at the time when the government is considering the whole future of regulation. (The government chose a squad of experts last week to come up with ideas in advance of the communications white paper, expected in the autumn.) The ITC is under threat: there are well-sourced reports that the commission is heading for the axe.

In this light, it is easier to understand the commission's delicate position. Politicians want the return of News at Ten, yet the ITC knows that if it attempts seriously to stand up to ITV, it could precipitate its own demise. In so many ways this is an old-fashioned dispute, with politicians on the one side, a modern television network facing the pressures of a multi-media explosion on another, and a nervous and indecisive regulator in the middle.

That certainly is the view of advertisers. Graham Duff, chief executive of Zenith Media, says: "I find it remarkable that the regulator is putting this amount of pressure on ITV. It should be allowed to operate as it sees fit. And as for ordinary people to be told what's good for them to watch, it is deeply insulting."

Even if ITV, supported by appalled advertisers, is right in its commercial interests in trying to stick with its new schedules, delivering an extra £70m of revenue a year, the timing of the row could not be worse. The growing debate about ITV's public service and regional duties is becoming bound up with a broader debate about media ownership, the consolidation of ITV and future regulation.

Sir George Russell, the former chairman of the ITC and the architect of the current detailed licences who gave evidence to the media select committee urging great caution in ending News at Ten, says: "The ITC must insist they get the local news right. The fundamental thing is that the change in news is undermining the regional news provision. ITV is designed as a federal organisation. We always knew takeovers would take place but the 15 franchises would remain. Anyone involved in a takeover would be stuck with honouring those commitments. I know from my contacts that the regional news services are in disarray."

That is why developments are being watched, open-mouthed, with a mix of enjoyment and horror by the BBC and Channel 4. There is a degree of sympathy for Liddiment - they know how hard it is to change back, or change at all, and that new schedules need time to bed in. But as the white paper approaches, time is running out for ITV.

Hill met the culture secretary, Chris Smith, earlier this month to assure him that ITV, despite the defiance over News at Ten, wants to remain a key public service broadcaster, with all the protection that provides. But, as an observer says: "They are losing credibility, and are coming to be regarded cynically by the government. In normal times, you'd expect the ITC to edge them into a sensible debate. This time, it's combustion. The ITV companies have mishandled it horribly. They have been so defiant in public. They have riled everyone." (The decision last week to screen the Queen Mother's 100th birthday pageant, a PR coup handed on a plate by the BBC, was in part seen as an opportunity to ingratiate the network with conservative-minded politicians.)

It has become fashionable to allege - though it is disputed as "rubbish" by Hill - that ITV lacks leadership. Without a chief executive since Richard Eyre quit last autumn, it has certainly lacked a diplomatic spokesman to finesse its case.

But another evident truth is that Granada, Carlton and United News & Media, the three power players, have been distracted by something much bigger and more vital to their interests: merger mania and who will emerge dominant. Last Friday, United was back at the competition commission, which is in the final stages of preparing its report over the United/Carlton merger in which Granada, itself in the throes of demerger, hopes to intervene. Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, receives the report on June 16, a few days before the ITC meets to discuss the news issue again.

The competition commission is not concerned, as the ITC must be, about regional news, or News at Ten, but the government is. This is why the messy compromise of a 10.30pm bulletin may yet win through. The main ITV players, at the end of the day, have much bigger things on their plate. And, like it not, they need a benign government to nod things through.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Thora Hird
fields.trailText: Thora Hird
fields.body:
Newspapers: I get my paper delivered by my neighbour down the mews. Most times it's the Daily Mail. Lynda Lee-Potter sometimes has opinions I agree with. Sometimes it's the Express. With my arthritis, they're a better size for me to hold than the broadsheets. At the weekend, the Mail on Sunday. But if I'm with my daughter, it's the only time I get to discuss politics because she gets the Times and Telegraph.

Magazines: The only one I get is Country Living, because it has photographs of the life I dream of. But as I'm so busy, some months it doesn't get opened.

Books: I love all Dirk Bogarde's books - especially the autobiographical ones. I've just finished Jeffrey Archer's As the Crow Flies - he's a terrific page-turner.

Film: My all-time favourite is Citizen Kane. The film I've seen most - upwards of 15 times - is Jour de Fete with Jacques Tati. The last film I saw in a cinema was Titanic. I did enjoy it but I remember it best because I dropped my bucket of popcorn. Favourite director is John Schlesinger. When I was young, I loved Eddie G Robinson and Ronald Colman. I don't like violence or creepy-crawlies.

Television: My favourite programme is Countryfile on a Sunday. I try not to miss it. I watch many more soaps than I used to and I watch Wheel of Fortune every day when I'm not working. This is Your Life is a long-time favourite of mine.

Radio: When I'm being driven to my country place, I like to listen to Radio 2 - Jimmy Young and so forth. But none of them play songs I can sing along with like they used to. Classic FM is sometimes pleasant as an alternative.

Ads: The tea ads with the chimps make me laugh every time.

Multimedia: I know nothing. I can't even work my own video machine, and this morning I picked up the wrong handset to phone my daughter and opened the front door by mistake.

 Last week Thora Hird won the Best Actress Bafta for Lost for Words. Her latest book, Not in the Diary, has just sold its 8000th copy.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's Diary
fields.trailText: • Fearing that M, the Mirror's supplement for women, is too full of raunchy sex, Mirror managing director Roger Eastoe ordered research into its first six months - apparently the poor flower is offended by its tone. He will be even more discomfited to know that the research revealed a wide readership from teens to 40s, with male readers particularly fond of the regular Sex Clinic slot - known for its ability to make hoary Mirror subs blush. So jealous is the Daily Mail that it has tried to poach key M staff to ginger up its middle-aged Femail, gaining the response: "Why quit to write about pashminas?" Precisely. Where's the male G-spot? is far more Y2K.
fields.body:
 Fearing that M, the Mirror's supplement for women, is too full of raunchy sex, Mirror managing director Roger Eastoe ordered research into its first six months - apparently the poor flower is offended by its tone. He will be even more discomfited to know that the research revealed a wide readership from teens to 40s, with male readers particularly fond of the regular Sex Clinic slot - known for its ability to make hoary Mirror subs blush. So jealous is the Daily Mail that it has tried to poach key M staff to ginger up its middle-aged Femail, gaining the response: "Why quit to write about pashminas?" Precisely. Where's the male G-spot? is far more Y2K.

 The top brass at Zenith Media, who dash out caustic reports each quarter on the state of television which they, bless 'em, believe should be organised for the benefit of advertisers, are feeling more than a little nervous. Their deputy managing director, Tim Greatrex, is about to marry one Jennie Biggam, from rival Carat. As the stiffie reveals, Jennie is the daughter of Sir Robin Biggam, chairman of the independent television commission, whose latest demands that ITV bring back news at a sensible time have had Zenith frothing with indignation. Graham Duff, the Zenith chief executive, says: "I had a real dilemma as I looked at the wedding invite from Sir Robin. How dare we go after what we've written about him?" Step forward the first thin-skinned ad man I've ever met.

 The current issue of Ariel brings historic news. The official dismantling of the internal market at the BBC has begun. Under an announcement, "change with immediate effect", the finance director John Smith says all loans of video tapes, films, sound recordings, CDs, sheet music and pictures will be free. "The famous £12 to borrow a CD is no more. It has, you might say, gone for a song." See, now Birt has gone, even the suits feel free to crack jokes.

 Congratulations to the Daily Mail for its triumphant campaign last week to force the BBC to screen the Queen Mum's birthday pageant. Mail readers, the paper told us, completed thousands of cutout petition slips which executives biked over to those damned republicans at the BBC. But something must have gone awry, for when the bags arrived they were stuffed with samples of Associated Newspapers' postbag. Including, we can reveal, the following: two cheques, one for £152.75, another for £1031.06; letters to Mail editor Paul Dacre and his political editor; a complaint about the quality of printing of the Northern Ireland edition; 10 entries for a caption competition; "urgent news copy" from a London news agency; nine letters which appear to have been posted by Daily Mail staff; and a reader's letter complaining about a Mail columnist. Only lack of space prevents us from... Still, at least the campaign worked - on ITV.

 Further congratulations from the Diary to Jim Moir, the rotund controller of Radio 2. It's little known that he is also the BBC's royal liaison officer, charged with ensuring relations with the palace are sweet. So well done Jim for smoothing over what could have been an embarrassing situation for the corporation - may we suggest you stick to radio?

 Last words about Andrew Marr, the new political editor of the BBC. He's not got a job for life, only a three to five year deal. And as for a deputy, well he's learnt the Sergeant lesson, there won't be one, though News 24's Nick Robinson is on the rise. As for why the BBC doesn't produce its own political editors - obvious. All its political creatures take their crafted skills into management.

fields.headline: A shameful decision
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The entire This Week production team wrote to the Times in the 70s to protest at the IBA's decision to allow LWT to cut back the run of Weekend World to barely 30 editions a year.
fields.body:
The entire This Week production team wrote to the Times in the 70s to protest at the IBA's decision to allow LWT to cut back the run of Weekend World to barely 30 editions a year. We were all threatened with disciplinary action by our employer, Thames, for discussing in public sensitive regulatory issues, and the IBA ignored us.

Eventually, LWT abandoned Weekend World. Since 1992, ITV has also dropped This Week, First Tuesday and even World in Action (not to mention News at Ten), claiming they were either outmoded, irrelevant to the audience, or inhibiting ITV's commercial success. Since 1992, ITV's audience share has diminished from 41% to 30% despite the addition to the schedule of more soap episodes and Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?

But that is commercial television. How can a publicly funded broadcaster take the axe to its own current affairs flagship without provoking more than a smidgeon of protest? Yet 10 days ago, the editor of Panorama went public with the news that the run of the series would be reduced from 38 to 30, with the justification that "the same amount of programme budget will be targeted on a reduced number of higher profile films".

Peter Horrocks is a talented editor, and - I am sure - an honourable man. He must surely have argued to his own superiors that there was another course of action open to them. That if the diagnosis was that Panorama editions were under-funded and under-researched (as Monday's feeble effort on football TV rights suggested), then surely the correct response was to bring all 38 editions up to the new budget level for 30 editions. That the cost of this injection of funds into the BBC's single most important programme would be less than £1m. That there could be few other ways of spending £1m - even the coverage planned for the Queen Mother's birthday - that would more vividly demonstrate the case for public funding of television, the licence fee and the BBC. That this £1m represented 0.0004% of the BBC's public funding. That a current affairs series on air for only 30 weeks of the year was crucially undermined in its ability to manage a mix of topical and long-range stories. That in the age of "always-on" broadband and 24-hour news, such a downsizing for Panorama - after previously having its length cut and its slot twice shunted down the schedule - was a dangerous step towards final extinction.

One can only assume that Horrocks's superiors heard and discounted these arguments. Perhaps the grant of an extra £300,000 for the overall Panorama budget - the equivalent of one episode of the journalistically vapid MacIntyre Undercover - was deemed a price worth paying to buy off staff hostility and eliminate eight ratings dips in the BBC1 Monday schedule.

No doubt the director-general (the man who axed Weekend World when he was at ITV) and perhaps even the governors were kept informed. It is even possible that the word "dinosaur" was uttered - though Horrocks would surely have riposted that the dinosaurs actually lasted far longer than homo sapiens have so far managed.

Sadly, most media attention relating to the BBC last week was concentrated on its withdrawal from covering the Queen Mother's parade and on its failure to offer an edition of Grandstand on Saturday. With so many newspapers competing to bash the BBC, it is remarkable how little attention was paid to the crucial Panorama announcement. Perhaps those enemies of publicly funded broadcasting so relished such a dismal retreat from the corporation's duties that they preferred not to drive the BBC into making good its error.

In the 70s and 80s, the main current affairs series were on for up to 46 weeks a year. This kept their journalism sharp and maximised the flexibility for slotting long-range investigations into the run. The old Panorama - or World in Action - would surely last Monday have covered the story of the Unionist response to the IRA's arms initiative.

It is not the job of current affairs series to win ratings, but to keep the audience informed. If Peter Salmon is worried about his Monday audience levels, it is his 9.30pm drama, not Panorama at 10pm, that he needs to fix. Whoever took that shameful decision, it should not be Peter Horrocks who has to justify it with weasel words and transparently inadequate logic.

 David Elstein is chief executive of Channel 5.

How can a publicly funded broadcaster take the axe to its own current affairs flagship without provoking more than a smidgeon of protest? Yet 10 days ago, the editor of Panorama went public with the news that the run of the series would be reduced from 38 to 30, with the justification that "the same amount of programme budget will be targeted on a reduced number of higher profile films". Peter Horrocks is a talented editor, and - I am sure - an honourable man. He must surely have argued to his own superiors that there was another course of action open to them. That if the diagnosis was that Panorama editions were under-funded and under-researched (as Monday's feeble effort on football TV rights suggested), then surely the correct response was to bring all 38 editions up to the new budget level for 30 editions. That the cost of this injection of funds into the BBC's single most important programme would be less than £1m. That there could be few other ways of spending £1m - even the coverage planned for the Queen Mother's birthday - that would more vividly demonstrate the case for public funding of television, the licence fee and the BBC. That this £1m represented 0.0004% of the BBC's public funding. That a current affairs series on air for only 30 weeks of the year was crucially undermined in its ability to manage a mix of topical and long-range stories. That in the age of "always-on" broadband and 24-hour news, such a downsizing for Panorama - after previously having its length cut and its slot twice shunted down the schedule - was a dangerous step towards final extinction. One can only assume that Horrocks's superiors heard and discounted these arguments. Perhaps the grant of an extra £300,000 for the overall Panorama budget - the equivalent of one episode of the journalistically vapid MacIntyre Undercover - was deemed a price worth paying to buy off staff hostility and eliminate eight ratings dips in the BBC1 Monday schedule. No doubt the director-general (the man who axed Weekend World when he was at ITV) and perhaps even the governors were kept informed. It is even possible that the word "dinosaur" was uttered - though Horrocks would surely have riposted that the dinosaurs actually lasted far longer than homo sapiens have so far managed. Sadly, most media attention relating to the BBC last week was concentrated on its withdrawal from covering the Queen Mother's parade and on its failure to offer an edition of Grandstand on Saturday. With so many newspapers competing to bash the BBC, it is remarkable how little attention was paid to the crucial Panorama announcement. Perhaps those enemies of publicly funded broadcasting so relished such a dismal retreat from the corporation's duties that they preferred not to drive the BBC into making good its error. In the 70s and 80s, the main current affairs series were on for up to 46 weeks a year. This kept their journalism sharp and maximised the flexibility for slotting long-range investigations into the run. The old Panorama - or World in Action - would surely last Monday have covered the story of the Unionist response to the IRA's arms initiative. It is not the job of current affairs series to win ratings, but to keep the audience informed. If Peter Salmon is worried about his Monday audience levels, it is his 9.30pm drama, not Panorama at 10pm, that he needs to fix. Whoever took that shameful decision, it should not be Peter Horrocks who has to justify it with weasel words and transparently inadequate logic.  David Elstein is chief executive of Channel 5.

fields.headline: Sir John Gielgud dies aged 96
fields.standfirst:
 Obituary by Nicholas de Jongh

• Michael Billington: Walking a tightrope to great acting

• Tributes from the theatrical world

 Useful links
fields.trailText: Sir John Gielgud, one of the greatest British actors of his generation, has died at the age of 96, his former agent Laurence Evans announced this morning. The actor, who was a master of Shakespearean roles, died yesterday at his home near Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire.
fields.body:
Sir John Gielgud, one of the greatest British actors of his generation, has died at the age of 96, his former agent Laurence Evans announced this morning. The actor, who was a master of Shakespearean roles, died yesterday at his home near Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire.

Sir John's official biographer Sheridan Morley said today: "He was the greatest actor and his life was exactly the history of British theatre in the last century. He was the last of a classic generation of actors with Olivier, Redgrave, Richardson and Dame Peggy Ashcroft. Theirs was an amazing single generation of classical actors and he was the final survivor."

Born in 1904, Gielgud was the great-nephew of celebrated British actress Ellen Terry. He was on stage by 1917, with an appearance - with a single line as a herald - in Henry V, at the Old Vic Theatre.

His film debut came in 1924, in Who is That Man?. He has since appeared in over 60 feature films and television productions. He won an Academy Award as Best Supporting Actor for his role as Hobson, Dudley Moore's valet, in Arthur; and was Academy Award-nominated for Becketin which he starred with Richard Burton and Peter O'Toole.

His television credits include Brideshead Revisited, The Scarlet and the Black, and Gulliver's Travels.

His many feature film roles include Julius Caesar with Marlon Brando, Laurence Olivier's Richard III, The Elephant Man, Chariots of Fire, and Gandhi. In 1991, he received much acclaim for his role in Prospero's Books, Peter Greenaway's surreal adaptation of Shakespeare's The Tempest.

Sir John Gielgud's most recent films include Shine, The Portrait of the Lady, and he continued working well into his 90s with roles recently in The Tichborne Claimant and Elizabeth in 1998. The actor was knighted in 1953, and appointed to the Order of Merit in 1996. His companion for more than 40 years was Martin Hensler, who died last year.

"He died peacefully at home," said Evans. He said the cause of death was thought to be simply old age.

fields.headline: John Vidal
fields.standfirst: John Vidal, the Guardian's environment editor, was live online on Tuesday 4 April to talk about food waste in Britain. He gave his views on giving out of date groceries to the homeless and hungry. Is it our responsibility? Is it patronising? This is an edited transcript; click here to read the full debate and have your say.
fields.trailText:
imogen: Giving the homeless our out of date groceries seems to me patronising and insulting, and just reinforces the perception that they are an underclass. This is only a short-term remedy. What can be done long term?

John Vidal: Imogen. Youêre right. It is patronising. But I think there is a real emergency out there. The scale of the need for good food is huge now. The food the supermarkets and others are chucking out is not bad. Its just wasted. The problem is do we give the food out or let it rot? That's a hard one. Ideally the government would address the issue of food poverty and the shops would get their act together and waste less. But until they do, we have this crazy situation.
fields.body:
imogen: Giving the homeless our out of date groceries seems to me patronising and insulting, and just reinforces the perception that they are an underclass. This is only a short-term remedy. What can be done long term?

John Vidal: Imogen. Youêre right. It is patronising. But I think there is a real emergency out there. The scale of the need for good food is huge now. The food the supermarkets and others are chucking out is not bad. Its just wasted. The problem is do we give the food out or let it rot? That's a hard one. Ideally the government would address the issue of food poverty and the shops would get their act together and waste less. But until they do, we have this crazy situation.


Morcheeba: Why should M&S give food to beggars? It's hardly their responsibility. Let's face it, stores give them a doorway to beg in all day and once they've earned some cash it wouldn't hurt them to buy a sandwich.

JV: Good point but these are not beggars. There are only about 600 people thought to be living rough in London. Theyêre the tip of the iceberg. There are hundreds of thousands of people who are too poor to buy good nutritious food. Theyêre not beggars; theyêre just poor. The poor often canêt get to the supermarkets which are increasingly out of town and inaccessible to people without cars. Besides, there are beggars and there are beggars. Some beg becauses they really need to. I donêt have great problems giving to some beggars.


parasite: Why don't supermarkets just leave their bins open so homeless/foodless people can help themselves???

JV: Getting round the back of a supermarket these days - where they keep the waste food - is like getting into a bank. I found it really outrageous to see people at the front desperate for food and all this stuff being chucked out the back. I heard of a restaurateur in Devon who gives his leftover stuff away. He was taken to court and fined (though I gather he's going to carry on).


larry1000: Dear John, isn't it the point that we shouldn't be over-producing food in the first place - which raises prices and creates waste - but distributing it better and making it more affordable to everyone instead?

JV: Larry 1000. Yes, yes, yes. Were madly overproducing - because of farm subsidies  and then we wonder why we have all this waste. The US is the classic. It overproduces massively and then dumps its waste on developing countries, building up food dependency and effectively not helping people become more self-sufficient. For US farmers, itês good business. The supermarkets there are the same. They now buy in extra food just so that they can give it away, earning PR points. Itês sick, really. I think the supermarkets have a lot of points to answer. They demand that the farmers produce huge amounts, beat their prices down, then sell at high prices to the consumer and make them pay (through the high prices) for the waste.

anomaly2: Sorry JohnVidal, I must disagree with your last point... Food is not expensive in the USA! It is over production that allows food prices to remain low. A shortage of food would make food prices rise. This is simple economics.

JV: Dead right. But we have a really weird system here where almost 70 per cent of all our food is sold through four or five chains which also control (to a large extent) what the farmers grow. Food is dead cheap in the US because there's more genuine competition and because it's industrially farmed on a scale that is unimaginable here (biggest pig farm here about 10,000 animals, in the US 1 million or more). But if, say, Walmart managed to get a semi monopoly going in the US - just as our chums have here - than you can bet your dollars the prices would rise. It's a not a normal market situation here.


Jonifame: What exactly are the hygiene regulations that stop companies giving their food away? Is it a law or just companies who are worried they might get sued for passing on sarnies past their sell-by date?

JV: Jonifame, these government hygiene regulations make it illegal for licensed food premises - supermarkets, restaurants and so on - to give food away to individuals or organisations that cannot prove they can store and handle it properly. Theyêre pretty draconian and well policed. The trouble is that charities often donêt have the money to invest in huge refrigeration units or refrigerated vans to cart the food around in. So there are very few who are trying to do it.


kevinroper2000: Increasing the cost of waste disposal to the company would surely lead to a reduction in the amount of waste produced. As landfill tax is set to only increase in the future, will this not be a problem that will eventually sort itself out?

JV: Greetings kevinroper. The theory's fine. The supermarkets and others are finding the landfill tax is painful, so they are genuinely looking for alternatives to dumping. Two or three are testing - or setting up - huge composting experiments, which makes real sense. The landfill tax, I think, partly explains why they are all becoming more interested in giving food away, too. There will always be some waste, though. The trouble is, itês repeated all the way down the food chain. So the farmer wastes a lot, the wholesaler wastes a lot, the supermarket does, so do the restaurants, canteens and householders. It seems that on average 20% of all food is wasted.

Meatloaf: Let them eat (slightly mouldy) cake!


JV: Thatês it from me, for the moment. Thanks for the messages. This food debate will run and run and I donêt actually know what the solution is. Seems like we're closer to seeing what the problem is, though, and at least thatês a start to sorting it out.

webTitle: Wilcox out, Barry in for Keegan

fields.headline: Wilcox out, Barry in for Keegan
fields.trailText: Jason Wilcox has pulled out of England's squad for Euro 2000 and will been replaced by Aston Villa defender Gareth Barry.
fields.body:
Jason Wilcox has pulled out of England's squad for Euro 2000 and will been replaced by Aston Villa defender Gareth Barry.

Wilcox has failed to recover from a knee injury and England coach Kevin Keegan has ruled him out of his plans for the European Championships.

Keegan said: "Jason has had a knee injury for the last two or three weeks at Leeds. I had him down yesterday, the medical people have checked him out and have sent him back to Leeds.

"We don't feel he had any chance of getting back for a place in the 22. I'm disappointed, he was devastated - I think that's the second time that had happened to him."

Barry, 19, was due to report for England duty tonight along with the three other squad members who appeared in the FA Cup final - club team-mates Gareth Southgate and David James, as well as Chelsea's Dennis Wise.

The left-sided defender had been placed on standby along with midfielder Frank Lampard last week when coach Kevin Keegan announced his provisional 28-man squad for the tournament.

"He was probably unlucky not be in the 28," said the England coach. "With Jason pulling out, it had to be Gareth because he is a left-footed player. He is used to playing in big games now."

webTitle: First photo of Leo Blair released

fields.headline: First photo of Leo Blair released
fields.standfirst: See the photo
fields.trailText: The first photograph of Tony and Cherie Blair's new baby Leo was   released today. It shows the sleeping baby in the arms of his mother, while the prime minister has an arm around his wife.
fields.body:
The first photograph of Tony and Cherie Blair's new baby Leo was released today. It shows the sleeping baby in the arms of his mother, while the prime minister has an arm around his wife.

The picture was taken yesterday in a Downing Street photo session with Sir Paul McCartney's daughter Mary. Mrs Blair chose the photographer, whom she got to know through her work with breast cancer charities after the death from cancer of Sir Paul's wife Linda McCartney.

Another 14 photos of Leo will be sold through a photographic agency and the proceeds split between two cancer charities of which Mrs Blair is patron - Breast Cancer Care and the Sargent Cancer Care for Children charity.

The prime minister's spokesman Alastair Campbell said Mr Blair had cancelled his public appearances for this week to spend more time with his wife and their new baby, the couple's fourth child who was born on Saturday.

When the family leave Downing Street for the prime minister's official country residence of Chequers, in Buckinghamshire, "probably later this week sometime", Mr Blair's spokesman said No 10 "would be happy for broadcasters for that day only to film the prime minister, Cherie and the baby when they leave".

He added: "Then we would hope we can get back to normal in terms of people being camped out in Downing Street."

fields.headline: Les dot.coms
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about France's newfound internet supremacy
fields.trailText: All you need to know about France's newfound internet supremacy
fields.body:
1. Hell, the froggies are at it again: e-commerce that is, as it emerges that the UK has lost its position of Europe's e-commerce leader to its Gallic neighbour.

2. The findings of a study by the CMG eCom index suggest that the French are taking to "les dot.coms" en masse.

3. This may be down to schools such as Epita, an IT and communications college whose intake has trebled in the last three years.

4. It could also be because of Minitel, a widely used online telephone service which for years has allowed the French to satisfy all their daily needs, from travel bookings to grocery shopping, via a keyboard plugged into the phone.

5. So France, far from facing a technical Waterloo, is heading for a glorious Austerlitz on the e-commerce front.

6. French fans of la Net économie now total between four and eight million "internautes" - depending on who you believe - nearly a fifth of the population.

7. Bien sûr, "le commerce électronique" is not the only thing the French are good at: there's food, l'amour (toujours), luxury goods, the list is endless

8. Not all is luxe, calme et volupté on the French "toile" however: you have only to look at sites such as degueulasse.com (revolting.com) to see that.

9. Thanks to the internet, you can keep up with what's happening Gaulside by listening to the radio with "le direct"

10and for more joie de vivre, try Radio Grenouille, a Marseille radio station.

fields.headline: Dome-ing down
fields.standfirst: As the Millennium Dome struggles to make ends meet, arts and heritage correspondent Maev Kennedy argues that the public should be let in for free
fields.trailText: Monday, 1.30pm: As the Millennium Dome struggles to make ends meet, arts and heritage correspondent Maev Kennedy argues that the public should be let in for free
fields.body:
The dome, surely, has missed a trick in asking today for £30m. Any of those starry-eyed strangers who pin you down in Waterloo station know the trick. You must combine a ludicrous demand for money with a bizarrely precise sum.

It should be a request for £2,999,997 - and 38p - guv, just to tide the dome over until 10.23am on Tuesday June 6, when it is expecting a surge of visitors in the post and all its problems will be history. The ritual is then as set as a corrida: you ask, mildly, "but what did you do with the last £60m I gave you?" and the supplicant responds with a torrent of abuse.

The dome is a basket case. The good bit is that unlike the poor, it will not be with us always: we only have to find a way to cope with it for another seven months.

The thinking now is that it was a mistake to let all those school children in free, and then go back to other schools demanding they pay for class visits - particularly since the ungrateful little pups who got in free didn't even empty their piggy banks into the souvenir shop as expected. Now everybody must pay, even if that means nobody comes.

There have been two recent arts phenomena in London. Seeing Salvation at the National Gallery in London, an exhibition teasing out profound issues of art and religious history through objects of high beauty and seriousness, had crowds queuing into Trafalgar Square.

And Tate Modern, give or take the odd performance artist taking the piss, is churning through crowds in an hour which the dome would often be grateful for in a day. People came for an hour, or a day, came and looked at something interesting, went away, and came back to look at something else. They didn't feel they had to slog around the whole exhausting thing in One Amazing Day.

There is indeed a mystical connection between the two events, a factor so abstruse that the government, with all its moaning about access, seems quite incapable of getting its head around it. I'm going to say this loudly, because when a lot of us said it quietly, nobody seemed to be listening: THEY WERE FREE!

So here's my modest proposal. The dome was supposed to be, Lord help us, the people's millennium celebration. The people have already paid for the dome once, through lottery tickets, and are now in the process of paying for it again. Open the doors. Let them in. It will do nothing to mend the books, but nothing can. What it will do is fill the yawning spaces, and leave everyone feeling less sick at heart about the whole thing.

The ritual is then as set as a corrida: you ask, mildly, "but what did you do with the last £60m I gave you?" and the supplicant responds with a torrent of abuse. The dome is a basket case. The good bit is that unlike the poor, it will not be with us always: we only have to find a way to cope with it for another seven months. The thinking now is that it was a mistake to let all those school children in free, and then go back to other schools demanding they pay for class visits - particularly since the ungrateful little pups who got in free didn't even empty their piggy banks into the souvenir shop as expected. Now everybody must pay, even if that means nobody comes. There have been two recent arts phenomena in London. Seeing Salvation at the National Gallery in London, an exhibition teasing out profound issues of art and religious history through objects of high beauty and seriousness, had crowds queuing into Trafalgar Square. And Tate Modern, give or take the odd performance artist taking the piss, is churning through crowds in an hour which the dome would often be grateful for in a day. People came for an hour, or a day, came and looked at something interesting, went away, and came back to look at something else. They didn't feel they had to slog around the whole exhausting thing in One Amazing Day. There is indeed a mystical connection between the two events, a factor so abstruse that the government, with all its moaning about access, seems quite incapable of getting its head around it. I'm going to say this loudly, because when a lot of us said it quietly, nobody seemed to be listening: THEY WERE FREE! So here's my modest proposal. The dome was supposed to be, Lord help us, the people's millennium celebration. The people have already paid for the dome once, through lottery tickets, and are now in the process of paying for it again. Open the doors. Let them in. It will do nothing to mend the books, but nothing can. What it will do is fill the yawning spaces, and leave everyone feeling less sick at heart about the whole thing.

webTitle: Shuttle astronauts complete six hour spacewalk

fields.headline: Shuttle astronauts complete six hour spacewalk
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
International Space Station homepage
fields.trailText: Spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis made short work of a wobbly crane, a broken antenna and a half-finished construction boom on Monday, marking a successful first day of maintenance work on the International Space Station.
fields.body:
Spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis made short work of a wobbly crane, a broken antenna and a half-finished construction boom on Monday, marking a successful first day of maintenance work on the International Space Station.

Working quickly, astronauts Jeffery Williams and James Voss were able to add a few extra tasks to their agenda, wrapping up their work in six hours, 44 minutes.

The astronauts worked so feverishly that at one point Atlantis pilot Scott Horowitz, directing their activities from inside the orbiter, urged them to slow down and enjoy the view.

"Look down. I think you can see London," he said.

Atlantis docked with the unfinished $60 billion outpost early on Sunday to do five days of badly needed maintenance both inside and outside the station, which should be completed in 2005.

Williams and Voss performed the riskiest and most physically challenging portion of the docked operations, working in the deadly vacuum of space in suits so bulky that even the simplest tasks can prove exhausting.

Their first job was to fix a 209-pound crane installed on an earlier mission. The base of the crane, designed for moving cargo during station construction, had come loose in the year since it was installed.

The astronauts quickly secured it then moved on to their other tasks, which included completing assembly of a 45-foot telescoping construction boom that was half finished on an earlier flight. That was the most difficult and time-consuming job.

After that, the astronauts replaced a faulty communications antenna, which should restore the station's video-conferencing capabilities. The remainder of their work involved installing cables and handrails for future spacewalkers. Building the space station will take about 45 spacewalks.

"This spacewalk is a good example of what future spacewalks will look like where we need to do maintenance to the station," said Scott Bleisath, the mission's top spacewalk official at Mission Control.

Williams, the lone rookie aboard Atlantis, scampered up and down the 70-foot station under his own power, while Voss, with one previous spacewalk under his belt, rode the shuttle's 90-foot (27-metre) robot arm, operated by mission specialist Mary Ellen Weber and Halsell from inside the shuttle.

Having wrapped up the outside work, the crew of seven plan to open the hatches connecting the shuttle and station and start the inside work on Monday afternoon.

The top priority will be replacing four of six solar-charged batteries that have begun to fail since the first two space-station components were linked in orbit in December 1998.

The shuttle and station have been orbiting at about 208 miles above Earth. Mission commander James Halsell and Horowitz will use the shuttle's thrusters to boost that orbit to about 235 miles. The station has been losing about 1.5 miles of orbit each week as it is dragged down by Earth's atmosphere.

For three Atlantis crew mates, their first look at the inside of the fledgling station will also be a peek at their future home. Voss, Susan Helms and Yuri Usachev, a Russian cosmonaut, are scheduled to become the second long-duration crew to take up residence aboard the station.

One reason they were added to this crew was the experience Usachev has living aboard the Russian Mir space station - more than a year - where he became familiar with electrical systems similar to those now malfunctioning on the Russian-built Zarya module of the International Space Station.

By that time they return to the space station early next year, the Russian Space Agency is scheduled to add a third major component, a service module with living quarters and life-support that will be needed to make the station inhabitable.

Mission Control reported just a handful of minor problems with spacecraft operations. Most significant was the failure of a power converter that allows the station to operate on the shuttle's power supply. The problem poses no immediate threat to the mission because a second identical unit can do the job on its own.

webTitle: Should the UN get out of Sierra Leone?

fields.headline: Should the UN get out of Sierra Leone?
fields.standfirst: Is the military involvement of the UN in conflicts such as Sierra Leone a basic moral responsibility of the international community? Or does the attempt to keep peaces that don't exist carry the risk of exacerbating the very problems the peacekeepers are supposed to help resolve? In this week's Saturday Review debate, Alex Ramsbotham of the United Nations Association and Professor Christopher Clapham of Lancaster University assess the fraught past and controversial future of UN peacekeeping. Read the debate and tell us what you think.
fields.trailText:
Is the military involvement of the UN in conflicts such as Sierra Leone a basic moral responsibility of the international community? 
Or does the attempt to keep peaces that don't exist carry the risk of exacerbating the very problems the peacekeepers are supposed to help resolve? 
In this week's Saturday Review debate, Alex Ramsbotham of the United Nations Association and Professor Christopher Clapham of
Lancaster University assess the fraught past and controversial future of UN peacekeeping. Read the debate and tell us what you think.
fields.body:
Dear Alex,
The Sierra Leone fiasco reinforces a lesson the UN should have learned years ago but is still shamefully reluctant to accept: if there isn't a peace, you can't keep it - and the attempt to keep non-existent peaces is not merely a waste of time, but carries a huge risk of exacerbating the very conflicts the peacekeepers were meant to help resolve. There is a place for UN monitoring, where the parties to a conflict have reached a genuine settlement, backed by their dispositions on the ground, which the intervening force can help guarantee. Sierra Leone had no more than a bogus settlement, reminiscent of Angola in 1991-92, or worse, Rwanda in 1993-94: paper agreements between bitterly hostile adversaries. UN peacekeepers were sent in, though neither side had disarmed, and one side had accepted the agreement mostly to gain a breathing space in which to strengthen its position. Providing such a space only makes things worse. In Rwanda, the Arusha accords gave hardliners in the government the opportunity to organise genocide. Sierra Leone is similar: the Lom* agreement of May 1999, into which the Kabbah government was pressured by the UN and others, ostensibly established a coalition between an ineffectual elected government and a ruthless armed opposition with a record of reneging on agreements. The peacekeepers sent in to police it were so poorly armed that hundreds could be rounded up as soon as the war resumed. It is open to the UN to send real fighting forces into situations like Sierra Leone, to kill and be killed, if the states concerned allow it. That would be a very hazardous enterprise, and unlikely to lead to the reconstruction of Sierra Leone. But at least the UN would have some idea of what it was supposed to be doing. Peacekeeping as seen in recent conflicts is a farce fuelled by wishful thinking. We'd be better off without it. Yours sincerely,
Christopher Clapham
Professor of politics and International relations, Lancaster University

Dear Christopher,

I acknowledge your reservations about fragile peace agreements: the Lom* agreement was seriously flawed. But the UK and US were primary influences in initiating Lom*; the UN was fully aware of its weaknesses. Traditional peace-keeping is often inapplicable to internal wars, but the UN has been trying to develop appropriate responses to such emergencies. It is the unwillingness of the more powerful UN member states, not least the five permanent members of the Security Council, to provide sufficient resources for an operation's effectiveness that is the problem. Perhaps a lesson can be learned from East Timor last year, where the May agreement providing for a referendum to decide the province's future status was deeply flawed: the Indonesian authorities insisted upon guaranteeing security. It was inadequate UN involvement that allowed gross human rights abuses against the East Timorese people before, and especially after, the vote. Only then was the international community convinced to provide a proper input. No one can pretend that the referendum process was an unqualified success, nor that UN involvement has been smooth. But there at least appears to have been progress, which could not have occurred without the UN. Peace processes are delicate, dynamic and risky. It is difficult to persuade the international community to prepare effective contingencies until it is too late. Meanwhile, people continue to live (or die) in misery while the international community prevaricates. The responsibility lies with UN member states, particularly those in the Security Council, to provide operations with sufficient resources to reduce the risks, including strengthening peace agreements in the first place.

Yours sincerely,
Alex Ramsbotham
Head, UN and conflict unit, United Nations Association, UK

Dear Alex,

I do not agree the failings of the UN can be separated from those of its member states, least of all the permanent members of the Security Council. The UN is an assembly of states; its strengths and weaknesses are reflected in those of its leading members. Their reluctance to provide resources for peacekeeping, most of all to risk troops, is a reality derived from bitter experience, notably that of the US in Somalia. I do not believe that many conflicts can be resolved through external intervention. East Timor, like Namibia a decade earlier, was a crisis to which a clear, acceptable solution could be found, through the simple mechanism of independence validated by an internationally supervised election. Crises like those in Somalia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone or Congo are not like that. These are fundamentally internal wars which can only be resolved internally: either by one combatant securing supremacy, or through a compromise in which each party recognises a settlement. Bodged settlements only delay, and often prevent, this resolution. Either the force brought in to monitor them packs up at the first sign of trouble, or it gets dragged into a long-term commitment in which its own role is compromised, and its costs escalate - not least in lives. The UN must acknowledge its limitations, and avoid getting dragged into conflicts it cannot resolve and in which its involvement can only damage its credibility and the welfare of those it is trying to help.

Yours sincerely,
Christopher

Dear Christopher,

I cannot agree that external intervention is inappropriate to internal wars; nor are they ever really internal for very long. It cannot be assumed that a lack of intervention will accelerate resolution. In Sudan, a highly destructive war has been continuing despite international involvement being limited to diplomacy, non-military humanitarian aid and development assistance; Somalia, since the UN's withdrawal, is no nearer stability. Military victory does not guarantee peace: in Afghanistan, the Taliban is not renowned for respecting human rights. This does not assume that forcible military intervention is desirable: it is costly in human and financial terms and ineffective. Some of the UN's best (but least public) achievements have been through preventive action, such as the pre-emptive deployment in Macedonia. I accept that bodged peace agreements are unsatisfactory and urge the international community to increase preventive efforts, especially through the UN. But where military intervention is necessary to protect life and promote stability, it must be undertaken, even if it requires a long-term commitment by the international community.

Yours sincerely,
Alex

Dear Alex,

I feel we are on similar ground: we both recognise and support the obligation of the international community, acting through the UN, to do what it can to resolve conflicts in which internal and external elements are often impossible to distinguish. There is a role for peacekeeping forces and preventive action. But we differ over something more important. You believe that the world is ultimately controllable: that the UN, backed by the leading members of the Security Council, can, with sufficient goodwill and determination, police an international system in which viable states are maintained, governments are stabilised, and basic respect for human rights is assured. Sadly, I cannot agree, and the cases that you cite - including Afghanistan and Somalia - make it clear why not. The long-term commitment by the international community would involve the imposition of a new colonialism enforced by the armies of industrial states. It would also be impossible: no amount of commitment (which in practice translates into "no number of dead soldiers") is going to protect life and promote stability. It can only promote further instability, as it did when the Russians intervened in Afghanistan and the Americans in Somalia. No matter how tragic the loss of life, and how appalling the abuse of rights, the UN and its leading states must recognise the limitations on their capacities, and come to terms as best they can with a world that they cannot control. They must resist the temptation to send peacekeepers into situations where they add to the number of victims of the UN's naivety and overambition.

Sincerely,
Christopher

Dear Christopher,

I'm pleased we agree on the need for increasing the focus on preventive action. But the fact that conflict prevention is at present so inadequate suggests there are situations where more emergency measures are required. I think we can distinguish between the neo-imperialist imposition of western ideals and the obligations of richer, more stable countries to uphold their responsibilities to poorer or less stable states, whose predicament we have often had a significant role in creating. One would hope local people would lead the way in designing models for governance. I agree that attempts by the UN, or anyone else, to intervene in evidently unsuitable circumstances are likely to be counterproductive. The UN has been very cautious in its approach to the Congo, although much greater (not necessarily military) international assistance might help to ameliorate the situation. In Sierra Leone, much more could have been done much earlier to address the grotesque behaviour of the RUF and improve the circumstances surrounding Lom*. But while acknowledging the input of UN peacekeepers, the improved circumstances since the arrival of highly efficient, well-resourced British troops demonstrates the effect such support can have. It's precisely the uncontrollable nature of the world that warrants some forum for global management, not only in security terms. The UN was established in the wake of two world wars to counter the massive destruction that accompanied such inter-state conflicts. The changing nature of war can be seen as a consequence of some success in the UN*s original raison d'etre. The problems that it is experiencing with internal conflict is a reason to make stronger efforts rather than to disengage.

Sincerely,
Alex

UK United Nations Association
Christopher Clapham's page
Guardian special report on Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Confessions of a 40-year addict
fields.standfirst: As tobacco manufacturers take legal action to stave off a proposed advertising ban, our smoker-in-chief explains how a teenage Derek Brown chose his first cigarette
fields.trailText: As tobacco manufacturers take legal action to stave off a proposed advertising ban, our smoker-in-chief explains how a teenage Derek Brown chose his first cigarette
fields.body:
My first cigarette was filched from my mother's handbag around 1960, when I was 13 years old. It was, I think, a Bristol.

"A Bristol, a Bristol, today's cigarette is a Bristol!" trilled the telly advert, and who was I to disagree? In truth, I don't think I was much influenced in my decision to smoke, or in my choice of brand, by the torrent of advertising which was then perfectly normal.

I certainly wasn't put off by the notorious advert featuring a sad no-hoper who was "never alone with a Strand". If my mum bought Strands, I stole them.

It may have been a Strand which made me violently sick, circa 1961, after a vigorous bout of deep inhalation in the lav, accompanied by the traditional blowing of smoke from the window. That didn't put me off either. Nor did the 1962 Bike Shed Incident, when I was caught in mid-ciggie by a sadistic chemistry master and flogged on the bum with a length of bunsen-burner tubing.

We knew about the cancer risk, even then, but we were inclined to pooh-pooh it. My mother smoked, my father smoked, and my big brother and sister both dabbled with it for a time. I was the one who persevered, moving in a couple of years from furtive toilet-puffer to full-fledged addict, complete with a rather fetching pigskin cigarette case.

That was the point, you see. Smoking was stylish, grown-up, adult. We didn't know the word macho, but it was that too. The few girls who smoked did so guiltily, and never in the street. We chaps smoked with a swagger.

A packet of 20 cost around half a crown (12.5p), which was affordable, even then. We vied with each other with our discriminating choice of brands. Some went for the untipped vigour of Player's Navy Cut or Senior Service; others for the exciting new kingsize brands in their innovative flip-top packs. Woodbines and Park Drives were the cheap and cheerful choice, being available in packs of five for under a shilling (5p). But it was generally agreed that they would never impress the girls.

Forty years on, I am a hopeless addict. I have twice kicked the habit, each time for a year, only to be seduced back into it by a sweet-smelling tobacco shop, or a foolish fancy that I could manage on a pipe. Maybe I will succeed a third time, like my father, who died at the age of 82, or my mother, happily flourishing at 85.

Meanwhile, I will continue to serve a useful social function, propping up the fortunes of my very distant cousin the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and providing an acceptable outlet for the bottled up frustration of a society which is prevented by political correctness from attacking black people, cripples, lunatics and other minorities, but which is encouraged to treat smokers with monstrous contempt.

To hell with the intolerance of bans and rules and smoke-free environments. I work from home, which is a compulsory smoking zone, and where working and smoking are synonymous. I reach for the keyboard with one hand, and for the ciggies with the other. I have consumed at least four during the composition of this piece and - this is the hard thing for non-smokers to understand - thoroughly enjoyed each of them.

Some went for the untipped vigour of Player's Navy Cut or Senior Service; others for the exciting new kingsize brands in their innovative flip-top packs. Woodbines and Park Drives were the cheap and cheerful choice, being available in packs of five for under a shilling (5p). But it was generally agreed that they would never impress the girls. Forty years on, I am a hopeless addict. I have twice kicked the habit, each time for a year, only to be seduced back into it by a sweet-smelling tobacco shop, or a foolish fancy that I could manage on a pipe. Maybe I will succeed a third time, like my father, who died at the age of 82, or my mother, happily flourishing at 85. Meanwhile, I will continue to serve a useful social function, propping up the fortunes of my very distant cousin the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and providing an acceptable outlet for the bottled up frustration of a society which is prevented by political correctness from attacking black people, cripples, lunatics and other minorities, but which is encouraged to treat smokers with monstrous contempt. To hell with the intolerance of bans and rules and smoke-free environments. I work from home, which is a compulsory smoking zone, and where working and smoking are synonymous. I reach for the keyboard with one hand, and for the ciggies with the other. I have consumed at least four during the composition of this piece and - this is the hard thing for non-smokers to understand - thoroughly enjoyed each of them. fields.standfirst: Actor with a voice 'like a silver trumpet muffled in silk'
