fields.headline: The nuclear non-proliferation treaty
fields.trailText: The five official nuclear powers, including Britain, have agreed to eliminate their atomic arsenals after a month of negotiations at a UN conference in New York. Mark Tran explains the significance of their decision.
fields.body:
What did the nuclear club say it would do? The five agreed to "an unequivocal undertaking by the nuclear weapon states to accomplish the total elimimation of their nuclear arsenals, leading to nuclear disarmament to which all parties are committed" under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty (NPT).

That sounds like a breakthrough, doesn't it? Sort of. Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, called it a significant step, but anti-nuclear groups point out that the five left themselves a huge loophole by omitting any timetable that would have put real teeth to their commitment. For the five, it was a way of deflecting international pressure on them to get rid of atomic weapons, without being pinned down.

What is the NPT? Signed in 1968, the NPT is a landmark international treaty designed to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and weapons technology, to foster the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and to further the goal of complete disarmament. When the treaty was first negotiated, only five nations had nuclear weapons - the US, the then Soviet Union, Britain, France, and China. There were fears that nuclear weapons would soon spread to dozens of countries, but the treaty stifled this threat. Today only three other countries (India, Pakistan, and Israel) have nuclear weapons, and they remain outside the treaty.

What are the main elements of the NPT? The treaty, which has 187 signatories, has three basic elements. First, states without nuclear weapons agree not to acquire them, and those with nuclear weapons cannot transfer them, or help any non-nuclear state in their manufacture or acquisition. Second, countries wishing to use nuclear power for peaceful purposes must agree to international inspections. Finally, the nuclear states promise to undertake good-faith negotiations to eliminate nuclear weapons entirely. The declaration of the five came at the end of a month-long review conference in New York.

What is the review conference? Five years ago, the countries party to the NPT agreed to make the treaty permanent after four weeks of sometimes bitter debate. While most countries favoured a permanent treaty, some feared such a move would take the pressure off the nuclear club to get rid of their atomic weapons. The delegates in New York met to discuss what progress has been made towards nuclear disarmament.

What progress has been made in the last five years? The treaty is in trouble. In 1998, Indian and Pakistan conducted tit-for-tat nuclear tests. The US has yet to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty. In preparatory meetings, participants could not agree on the pace of disarmament. Above all, the biggest threat to the treaty comes from US plans to develop a national missile defence (NMD). The US says NMD would offer protection from "rogue" states such as Iraq and North Korea, but few experts believe that such a system will work and they fear that America's quest for absolute security will chip away at the concept of deterrence and make "limited" nuclear war more acceptable. NMD is the "ghost at the wedding", according to Rebecca Johnson of Acronym Institute, a London disarmament think tank.

Any bright spots? On the eve of the conference, Russia's parliament ratified the Start II arms reduction treaty, which commits the US and Russia to slash their strategic warheads from 6,000 to 3,500 by 2007. The Russian parliament also ratified the comprehensive test ban treaty, which the US senate has failed to ratify so far. The US and Russia are preparing to begin talks on Start 3 with the Russians wanting to go below 1,500, but the Americans do not want to go below 2,000 or 2,500. On the downside, the US is reportedly upgrading and stockpiling warheads which it was expected to destroy under Start.

webTitle: Disney's Dinosaur tops Gladiator at US box office

fields.headline: Disney's Dinosaur tops Gladiator at US box office
fields.trailText: The Disney-animated adventure Dinosaur registered the highest opening of the year as it eclipsed last week's number one, Gladiator, at the American weekend box office
fields.body:
The Disney-animated adventure Dinosaur registered the highest opening of the year as it eclipsed last week's number one, Gladiator, at the American weekend box office. Meanwhile, John Travolta's sci-fi flick Battlefield Earth lost two-thirds of its opening weekend audience, with bad press and word of mouth reviews repelling audiences.

Dinosaur tells the story of a genial iguanodon called Aladar and his search for somewhere to live after a meteorite shower lays waste to his home. The film opened, according to estimates, with a take of some $38.6 million, while Gladiator pulled in $19.1 million in its third weekend. Dinosaur therefore surpasses the Russell Crowe epic as the best debut of 2000, and also ranks no 20 on the all time openings, according to a Disney spokeswoman. It marks Disney's third best opening ever, behind 1999's Toy Story 2 ($57.4 million) and The Lion King ($40.9 million) in 1994.

fields.headline: American Beauty in video row
fields.trailText: American Beauty in video row
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg's movie house DreamWorks SKG is locked in a row with video giant Blockbuster over distribution of the Oscar-winning American Beauty . Blockbuster is reported to have demanded a bigger-than-usual cut of the rental revenues from the black comedy. When DreamWorks resisted the shop's efforts, Blockbuster exercised its right to undersell American Beauty in its outlets nationwide.

According to Blockbuster spokesperson Liz Greene, "we were not able to reach a satisfactory agreement to secure the number of copies which Blockbuster is
typically known for." In other words, the United States' largest video chain
opted not to buy the hundreds of thousands of extra copies of American
Beauty that would make it a "guaranteed title" on its release on May 9.
Blockbuster also banished the Sam Mendes-directed film to behind the counter: would-be renters now have to specifically request the title.

The row has had an immediate impact on American Beauty's sales: the figures for its first week of release were eclipsed by those for Fight
Club , a far less popular movie at the cinema. DreamWorks are playing down the spat, averring that "we have a great relationship with Blockbuster," before adding "it's just that if you want to rent it at Blockbuster, you might have to ask them for it."

webTitle: Loss-making Dome needs £30 million to stay alive

fields.headline: Loss-making Dome needs £30 million to stay alive
fields.trailText:
The Millennium Dome is seeking up to £30 million from the National Lottery to save the jobs of 5,000 staff and stave off
bankruptcy.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is seeking up to £30 million from the National Lottery to save the jobs of 5,000 staff and stave off bankruptcy.

The Greenwich attraction's chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is due to tell the Millennium Commission that he needs the money to meets its outstanding debts and carry on operating.

Ministers are understood to have accepted that the £509 million of lottery money already given to the Dome will never be recovered and that the beleaguered exhibition will make huge losses.

According to the Dome management's own figures, it is now expecting between only six and seven million visitors this year, compared with the 12 million it had expected.

It was uncertain whether the nine-member commission would be willing to bail the Dome out again, having already topped up the original £399 million with further repayable grants of £50 and £60 million.

It is believed that the commission is divided, with some members against expending further money on the Dome at the expense of less controversial projects.

Others, however, believe that pulling the plug could be even more costly. They are expected to tell Mr Gerbeau to dismiss some of his staff and make cuts worth more than £10 million in return for more lottery cash.

Another option being floated was that the Government could sell the Dome early to either Nomura or Legacy - the two consortia competing to take over the site at the end of the year.

Supporters of an early sell-off believe it would at least enable the Government to get the loss-making and politically-damaging project off its hands well ahead of the election.

But Lord Falconer of Thoroton, the Cabinet Office minister with responsibility for the Dome, denied reports that it could be sold off early in September.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth argued that drastic action was needed to address the Dome's problems. "There's no guarantee that the money that they are seeking now will be the end of the story," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"We are talking about the peak period for the Dome when they should be getting their maximum amount of income. Frankly, they have got a monumental hill to climb if they are going to achieve anything like the visitor numbers that they need.

"The best option is to try and seek a private buyer at a decent price to take the thing out of its misery, or to close it at the end of the summer." And Stephen Bayley, a former creative director of the Dome turned prominent critic, said the Dome was paying the price for patronising the public.

"I'm afraid this is 'I told you so'. One of the reasons I walked was because of the determination of the management and their political sponsors to patronise the public with a version of Disney.

"In PR terms the thing is a disaster, it's a national disgrace, and it's probably best to let it die quietly.

"The success of the Tate Modern in recent weeks has shown that the public isn't a moron, the public expect a higher standard," he said.

fields.headline: Lottery bail-out for sinking Dome
fields.standfirst:
Ministers forced to take extra £30m from fund intended for small health and education schemes
The Millennium Experience
fields.trailText: The government is about to cause new controversy by letting the cash-strapped Millennium Dome draw on money from the New Opportunities Fund, which was set up to give lottery proceeds to the poor.
fields.body:
The government is about to cause new controversy by letting the cash-strapped Millennium Dome draw on money from the New Opportunities Fund, which was set up to give lottery proceeds to the poor.

A Millennium Commission meeting today will be asked for an extra £30m, on top of the Dome's original £399m and loans of £50m and £60m.

The commission has already allocated its entire £2bn budget and could only provide extra cash by cutting back on some of its other projects.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, decided that if the Dome could not repay its earlier loans the money would come from the National Lottery. The cash would have to be taken from the New Opportunities Fund, which Labour set up to help fund smaller scale health and education projects.

If the government does provide the cash - and it has little option if bankruptcy is to be avoided - ministers will demand big cuts in staffing in return.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat spokesman on the Dome, condemned the plan. He said: "It's time the government stopped pouring money into the Dome. When you are putting your money on the wrong horse, you stop betting on it. The Dome has had more than enough money and it would be terrible if it started draining cash away from other, much better, causes.

"There is no point closing the thing down, but the government needs to look to see if the assets are being managed properly and its overheads. The drawbridge has got to come up."

Mr Smith will tell the New Millennium Experience company, which runs the Dome, that cash savings must be possible if the number of visitors is lower than forecast. The Dome now expects 6-7m visitors, around half the organisers' original 12m forecast.

The government has been forced to admit that Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the Frenchman imported from Disneyland in Paris, has been unable to turn the Dome's fortunes around. They admit he has made improvements, but believe the word of mouth effect, the only way of salvaging the Dome after its disastrous launch, has not been as strong as expected.

The organisers admit it was a strategic blunder to let so many schoolchildren visit the Dome free of charge, since they have become its single biggest target.

Some commissioners are considering selling the Dome off in late September to help cut the losses. It is due to be sold at the end of the year in any case, to either Dome Europe, part of the Japanese investment bank Nomura International, or to Legacy.

Nomura International specialises in buying troubled companies and assets and turning them around with a new management or an injection of extra cash where it is needed. It is planning a revamped pleasure park, and is bidding around £150m.

The aim of Legacy is to create a space which would nurture the Bill Gateses of the future. In an interview in March, its chief executive, Robert Bourne, described it as "the space to build the hi-tech campus of the 21st century".

"It will be the spiritual home of the web; the actual home of e-commerce. Hi-tech businesses do not have appropriate premises in which to work. This will accommodate the hi-tech industrial revolution that is going on."

Ministers are due to decide between the two bids in the summer. They admit that the continuing bad publicity for the Dome leads to a vicious circle of lower sales, lower revenue and more stories of financial bail-outs.

It is not considered possible to close the Dome early, after the summer tourist boom, since business sponsors who backed it on the understanding that it would be open for 12 months would make crippling financial claims.

webTitle: Next big step should allow us to straddle continent

fields.headline: Next big step should allow us to straddle continent
fields.trailText: Things have been moving at an incredibly fast pace since we completed our major funding round, and we took another important step last week with the opening of a Rools office in Paris.
fields.body:
Things have been moving at an incredibly fast pace since we completed our major funding round, and we took another important step last week with the opening of a Rools office in Paris.

We have great ambitions for Rools and operating an effective service throughout Europe is a priority, not least because many of our retail and strategic partners have pan-European businesses and are looking for us to work with them in each country where they operate.

In addition, although Britain represents a sizeable potential market for our services - teenagers spend around £3bn each year in the UK - the business is likely to attain a value that will provide our investors with a great return only if Rools becomes pan-European.

But it is not going to be easy. Europe is a complicated mixture of languages and cultures, and the commercial environment varies. Of particular pertinence to us are differences in take-up of the internet across Europe - penetration varying from under 8% in some southern regions to over 50% in Scandinavia - and consumers' shopping habits, such as their preferred methods of payment for goods and services. Britain's fondness for credit cards is not replicated throughout Europe, for example, and such differences should have an impact on how we market a service that effectively acts as a secure online debit facility.

The challenges involved in obtaining scale in Europe contrasts with the United States. You would need to operate in Germany, France, the UK, Italy and Spain to reach the same number of potential consumers as you would by operating one online service in the more culturally homogenous US.

fields.headline: Decisions, decisions
fields.standfirst:
Every choice the Blairs make about bringing up Leo will be political as well as critical. Lucy Ward looks into the issues - from buggies to babyfood - which will come under the closest scrutiny

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: The Blairs can't say they weren't warned: the nappy debate gave the game away even before baby Leo arrived. Every decision they make over their fourth child's first year will have instant political significance - from choice of nappy (we already know their preference is for terry towelling rather than easy but landfill-clogging disposables) to childcare.
fields.body:
The Blairs can't say they weren't warned: the nappy debate gave the game away even before baby Leo arrived. Every decision they make over their fourth child's first year will have instant political significance - from choice of nappy (we already know their preference is for terry towelling rather than easy but landfill-clogging disposables) to childcare. In a spin-doctored world where the personal is political and vice versa, such details will be headline news, reported and chewed over by a string of columnists in more depth than Britain's dilemmas over Euro entry. Below, we detail some of the critical decisions facing the Blairs, like any parents, over the first 12 months, and gauge the significance of their preferences in buggies and babyfood for a fickle electorate.

Breastfeeding

Always a hot topic, and now more political than ever due to the row over breastfeeding in the House of Commons (despite requests from MPs nursing newborns, the speaker's office has banned the taking of "refreshment" in committee rooms). A new government Breast is Best campaign launched only days before Mrs Blair entered the labour ward is intended to boost UK breastfeeding rates from among the lowest in Europe, and the Department of Health would doubtless welcome such a high-profile example.

On the basis of current statistics, she is almost certain to nurse, assuming all goes smoothly: figures show that middle-class, educated, older mothers are far more likely than their less well-off counterparts to prefer breast to bottle.

However, if the lure of a return to the courtroom proves irresistible within weeks, she may choose to switch wholly or partly to formula - potentially incurring the wrath of the breast-is-best lobby. The choice of brand is a minefield - an ethical foreign policy would not approve of manufacturers who foist formula on poor women in developing countries.

Father's role

Tony Blair has already encountered the politics of paternity leave (a right which does not exist in the UK, though a new entitlement to unpaid parental leave has just been introduced) and has opted for a typically New Labour third way. To the disappointment of campaigners for better balance between home and work, he will not take time off , but hop up and down the Downing Street staircase between his No 10 office and the first family's appartment above No 11.

But while the prime minister clearly did not feel he could be as radical as Finnish prime minister Paavo Lipponen, who took a week's leave on the birth of his baby last February, he is known to value greatly the time spent with his older children and is certain to be an involved father. Visitors to Chequers report that the Blair children and their father can often be found playing football in the gardens, and Mr Blair frequently refers in interviews to "Cherie and the kids".

A key influence on the prime minister is likely to be the memory of the severe stroke which hit his own father, Leo, at just 40. The illness, though devastating, meant he benefited by seeing much more of the once workaholic barrister, Mr Blair has said. However, as prime minister, the battle for work-life balance is one he is unlikely to win. If the polls dip for Labour, critics will accuse him of devoting too much time to fatherhood; while leaving childcare duties to Mrs Blair and the nanny will mean bowing to the forces of Conservatism he claims to despise.

Childcare

Another contentious issue - Mrs Blair has already disclosed that, initially at least, she will spurn paid help in favour of her mother, Gale Booth, who will move into the Downing Street flat. In doing so, she will buck the trend among professional parents, only 18% of whom rely on relatives to look after their children, compared with 44% of lower-income groups.

Later on, the Blairs may well turn to a live-in nanny which would highlight the fact that, for the vast majority of parents, finding good childcare is costly, with neither tax relief nor employer incentives.

The Blairs will also have to address the problem of isolation for the Downing Street baby, particularly since friends their own age are likely to have children much older than the new arrival. If they choose a toddler group, nursery or playgroup, it will have to be a public or voluntary-sector facility to avoid Tory jibes over going private.

Clothing

A tough dilemma now that political style so often triumphs over substance. Despite New Labour's professed passion for football, the Blairs are unlikely to opt for the miniature football boots à la Anaïs, daughter of Oasis's Noel Gallagher, nor the Brooklyn Beckham-style football shirt. Perhaps Ronit Zilkha, Mrs Blair's favourite designer, could be persuaded to knock up a few outfits for special occasions, though that could leave Worcester woman feeling outclassed. Buying British would mean sturdy but dull M&S or Mothercare standbys, whereas Baby Gap, Middle England's favourite yet, sadly, American, could provide stylish mini combat trousers for that Islington look.

Toys

How much to spend, and what to buy, now that manufacturers so effectively persuade small consumers to fleece their parents? Leo should at least be too young for Pokémon cards, but will the Blairs succumb to garish plastic teethers that play Old Macdonald - hardly in keeping with Georgian Downing Street - or go for stylish wooden alternatives favoured by parents but ignored by their offspring? Either way, the child is certain to be given footballs galore, with the soccer vote in mind.

Transport

The Blairs famously pile their brood into a people-carrier, but Leo's personal transport will require some tough decisions. The options have multiplied since the births of Euan, 16, Nicky, 14 and Kathryn, 12, as has the style subtext lurking behind the most innocent buggy. The old-fashioned carriage pram would hark back to the Mary Poppins era but the trendy, all-terrain three-wheeler could come in handy for the Downing Street roadhumps.

The practical Blairs, whose hall was reported by their former nanny to be jammed with pushchairs and toys, will probably go for a prudent but purposeful "travel system" combining car seat, buggy and carrycot. Maybe Uncle Gordon who lives next door will even be allowed to push the buggy occasionally.

Vaccinations

Every parent faces a dilemma over immunisation, but the vast majority weigh up the relative risks and opt to have it done. Babies are vaccinated against polio, diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough and the Hib form of meningitis at two months, three months and four months; at a year or a little more they have the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine, claimed to be linked controversially with autism.

Since immunisation is part of a government programme, the Blairs are almost certain to have Leo vaccinated. There may be criticism from campaigners who argue that doctors put too much pressure on parents to agree to immunisation.

Food

Mrs Blair is opting for recycled nappies; will she buy organic baby food? Or will she set the best example and make her own? The trendiest babies are green ones, and the Blairs may choose to raise Leo on costly but pesticide-free organic meals - now taking 25% of the British market after a recent dramatic boom. Critics would make snide references to puréed polenta and grumble that only high-flying lawyers can afford such things. More risky for Tony Blair is the question of GM food? The PM has indicated that he is happy to eat GM himself, but the spectacle of former Tory minister John Gummer stuffing a burger down his daughter's throat to prove the safety of British beef should warn him off using his children as guineapigs.

Back to work

As a hotshot employment lawyer, Mrs Blair has already attracted criticism from some quarters by working so close to the birth, setting an example beyond the energy - or will - of most expectant mothers. Although 45, she is widely expected to follow the pattern she set with her older children and return to work relatively quickly. Work-life balance campaigners, however, will be watching to see whether the prime minister's wife, who recently moved to new legal chambers, cuts down her office hours and works at home, in line with the government's promotion of family-friendly working.

Publicity

The Blairs have always made much of shielding their children and family life from the public eye and insist they want to continue that policy with Leo. Downing Street has promised one photo session, after which he will disappear behind the security gates of Downing Street, emerging for the cameras only for the family's traditional Tuscan summer holiday snap.

With a general election possibly under a year away, however, the temptation to wheel out the new arrival from time to time could prove too great, leading to a curious synchronicity between the little one's outings and William Hague's keynote speeches. The Blairs will have to be careful, though - any hint of exploitation and the strategy will backfire with the voters.

fields.headline: 2.5m reasons for radical regional policies
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: As everyone is aware, the government is awash with cash. Treasury coffers are brimming over, even before the £22.5bn from the sale of the next generation of mobile phone licences rolls in.
fields.body:
As everyone is aware, the government is awash with cash. Treasury coffers are brimming over, even before the £22.5bn from the sale of the next generation of mobile phone licences rolls in. For a Labour administration this is unusual, since by this stage it is normally scrabbling around for the last brass farthing.

So, trebles all round then? Not exactly. Rather like a lottery winner, the government has no real idea what to do with its new found wealth but insists that it still wants to go on living in the same old way. This is curious. After all, Labour spent almost 20 years moaning about how Britain was being impoverished by Conservative public spending cuts and now has the financial muscle to do something about all those issues that symbolised Thatcherite wickedness in the 80s and 90s - the shoddy state of publicly owned housing, the lack of a decent transport infrastructure, the raw deal given to pensioners.

But now that Labour is in power and has the money, all it can think of is to use the money paying off the national debt. Not only is this needless when the national debt is shrinking anyway, it also shows a crashing lack of imagination.

Of course, there are good reasons why the money should not be spent now. The economy does not need a sudden injection of demand, and the fact that the mobile phone licences are for 20 years means that the dosh should be spent over 20 years as well, rather than blown in one great splurge.

That said, it is not hard to think of using £22.5bn in ways that are both progressive and long-termist - home insulation to cut energy use, for example, or a scheme to make Britain the most wired country in the world. It can only be hoped that, in the event that Labour does win a second term, it can try a bit harder.

Regional policy is a case in point. There were two big post-war attempts at regenerating Britain's regions by spreading economic growth more evenly, first in the late 40s, then in the 60s - but the idea went out of fashion a quarter of a century ago. Labour in the 70s ran out of money, while the Conservatives believed in letting market forces do the job. To the extent that there was a regional policy, it was to use tax breaks and grants to attract inward investment.

It does not take much scratching below the surface of modern Britain to show that this strategy has not worked. Twenty years of mass unemployment have left the country pockmarked with deprivation, untouched by the recent recovery.

In some cases, these communities live cheek by jowl with affluent areas; in others - the pit villages of Nottinghamshire, the Welsh valleys - geographical isolation adds to the sense of living in a different world.

The government is doing some worthwhile things. The new deal for communities - £2bn over 10 years - aims to provide a comprehensive package embracing health, education, business start-ups and jobs, rather than rely on a piecemeal approach in which each government agency operates in an uncoordinated fashion. It is important that all pupils leave school withbasic educational and interpersonal skills, and it is a good idea to help with transport costs - encouraging people to travel to find jobs.

But the scale of the problem requires a more ambitious solution. Last week's claimant count figures show that unemployment is coming down in every region, with the south-east having the lowest unemployment at 2.1% and the north-east the highest at 6.6%. Sadly, however, the claimant count only tells part of the story, as Christina Beatty and Stephen Fothergill of Sheffield Hallam University have documented.

Put bluntly, Beatty and Fothergill say that Britain has become a nation "on the sick". Relatively low claimant counts disguise a hidden iceberg of unemployment, concentrated in Britain's old industrial heartlands.

In April 1981, 574,000 people had been claiming sickness or invalidity benefit for more than six months. By April 1998, this figure had climbed to 1,932,000. Add 300,000 receiving Severe Disablement Allowance and another 300,000 on Incapacity Benefit to reach a total of just over 2.5m. These are people of working age without jobs and claiming sickness-related benefits - more than double the number of unemployed on the claimant count.

As Beatty and Fothergill point out, there are two reasons why this trend suggests a pool of hidden unemployment.

The first is the scale of the increase, which took place at a time when the general standard of health was rising.

The second was the geographical distribution of sickness claimants, which showed the highest numbers in South Wales, Merseyside, Manchester, South Yorkshire, north-east England and Clydeside. In many of these places, more than 15% of the male population of working age is claiming sickness benefit. In some, such as the Welsh valleys, the figure exceeds 20%.

There is no doubt that unemployment - particularly in the long term - breeds ill-health. But this cannot be the whole story. Large numbers of unemployed people have been diverted on to sickness-related benefits, which are not means tested, and quietly forgotten about. In more ways than one, they no longer count. Many of those on sickness benefits would be eager to take a job, provided that one was available and that there was an escape route if the job did not work out. This point is currently being looked at by ministers, but the provision of jobs can only be tackled by a more vigorous interventionist policy.

The fact that regional policy has been out of vogue for the past quarter of a century is neither here nor there, given that the current state of the economy is nothing like it was in the 80s or 90s, when it was like spitting into a hurricane. There is no case for a general reflation, but there is an overwhelming case for intervention locally. Far from spitting into the hurricane, this would be going with the prevailing wind, because many companies find it hard to expand in the overheating economy of southern England.

The main problem in the most rundown parts of Britain is deficient demand. A pit closure or the loss of a factory leads to unemployment. Those that are able to migrate to other parts of the country do so, while those left behind spend less. The skills base is eroded, the physical infrastructure deteriorates. A downward spiral ensues.

Breaking this vicious cycle will take more than supply-side policies. Ideally, rather than have one currency for the whole of Europe it would make sense for the worst-affected regions to have their own currencies to allow them to become more competitive.

This will, of course, not happen, but as Frank Field recently demonstrated there are other means of local reflation - abolishing employers' national insurance contributions, improving transport links, targeting government purchasing, rebuilding social capital - that could and should be considered.

In the US, the price of the Federal Reserve's agreement for a bank takeover like that of NatWest by Royal Bank of Scotland would have been a hefty payment for regeneration under the Community Reinvestment Act, something that Britain sorely lacks.

Labour says that its second term will be as radical as Mrs Thatcher's: its ability to repair her handiwork will show whether there is any substance to this boast.

The main problem in the most rundown parts of Britain is deficient demand. A pit closure or the loss of a factory leads to unemployment. Those that are able to migrate to other parts of the country do so, while those left behind spend less. The skills base is eroded, the physical infrastructure deteriorates. A downward spiral ensues. Breaking this vicious cycle will take more than supply-side policies. Ideally, rather than have one currency for the whole of Europe it would make sense for the worst-affected regions to have their own currencies to allow them to become more competitive. This will, of course, not happen, but as Frank Field recently demonstrated there are other means of local reflation - abolishing employers' national insurance contributions, improving transport links, targeting government purchasing, rebuilding social capital - that could and should be considered. In the US, the price of the Federal Reserve's agreement for a bank takeover like that of NatWest by Royal Bank of Scotland would have been a hefty payment for regeneration under the Community Reinvestment Act, something that Britain sorely lacks. Labour says that its second term will be as radical as Mrs Thatcher's: its ability to repair her handiwork will show whether there is any substance to this boast.

fields.headline: Terrorism bill
fields.standfirst: New definition puts direct action and protest groups at risk
fields.trailText: In the past six months, the Guardian has talked to human rights activists, anti-arms trade campaigners, exiles fighting fearsome regimes, people chucking bottles at McDonald's, animal rights groups, GM crop destroyers, pro-democracy activists, and demonstrators against global capitalism.
fields.body:
In the past six months, the Guardian has talked to human rights activists, anti-arms trade campaigners, exiles fighting fearsome regimes, people chucking bottles at McDonald's, animal rights groups, GM crop destroyers, pro-democracy activists, and demonstrators against global capitalism.

Under the new prevention of terrorism bill making its way through parliament with barely any dissent, all these people could be branded terrorists and be held and interrogated for a week without being charged or given access to lawyers - lesser rights than someone who sets out to murder or maim.

Under the bill, the Guardian, or any journalist or member of the public who has information about anyone redefined as a terrorist, would be obliged to report information to the police. Anyone suspected of contributing money to the cause of terrorism must be reported. Failure to comply could mean five years in jail.

The bill makes it an offence to support, by word or deed, an armed struggle or violence against any person or property inside or outside the UK. Had such a law been in place before 1990, it would have made it illegal to support Nelson Mandela in South Africa, or the Zapatistas in Mexico, the Tamils in Sri Lanka, or the Burmese opposition and Tibetan freedom fighters today.

Many of the Newbury bypass protesters, those involved in the miners' strike, or people digging up Parliament Square to plant vegetables could be theoretically defined as terrorists.

According to Liberty, the civil rights group, the bill also means that if you so much as talk at a meeting that you know will be addressed by someone from a proscribed organisation, you could face 10 years in prison.

The many peaceful people who tried to establish a dialogue between the warring factions in Northern Ireland would have been outlawed.

The bill, say civil rights and environment groups, hinges on the catch-all definition of terrorism. Because it is so wide, it will be left to police and courts to decide who are terrorists and who are activists.

But as well as the threat to those involved in direct action and protest movements, the bill also endangers people's right to know about such organisations and activities. Already suspicious of the motives of many journalists and angry at the coverage they receive, such groups will be even more reluctant to talk to the press if they fear reporters and photographers will be forced to hand over notes and film to the police.

webTitle: How a Tory Lady made my day

fields.headline: How a Tory Lady made my day
fields.standfirst:
Comprehensives are superior to grammar schools: official

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Comprehensives are superior to grammar schools: official
fields.body:
No doubt the campaign for state education - which includes amongst its aims an end to secondary selection - will properly acknowledge the contribution made to its cause by the Baroness Blatch, the Tory party's education "shadow" in the House of Lords. Nothing more than an invitation to be Patron would be appropriate. In five minutes of intellectual inquiry, she did more to improve the reputation of the comprehensive system than most have us have done in a lifetime of passionate support. Only natural reticence can have prevented Her Ladyship from publicising her triumph. I set out her achievement in detail as a mark of gratitude.

Baroness Blatch won her battle against formidable odds. For months opponents of selection had tried to obtain figures which compared the performance of grammar schools with schools which welcome children of all abilities. In Ripon - where the first of the phoney "parental ballots" was held in March - opponents of the 11-plus asked the Department of Education to provide exactly that information. They were told that it was not available. Baroness Blatch gamely battled on.

Loath as I am to diminish Lady Blatch's achievement, honesty requires me to admit that her brilliant initiative owed something to what often looks like personal dislike of Baroness Blackstone, the minister of state for education. As they face each other across the Despatch Box, the two Noble Ladies rarely exhibit signs of affection. I have no doubt that the Tory spokesLady welcomed the chance to exploit what she believed to be a chink in her opposite number's usually impenetrable armour. On March 15, Lady Blackstone claimed that genuine comprehensive schools were producing better results than grammar schools. Prove it, demanded Lady Blatch - in suitable parliamentary language.

The answer was provided by Lord Bach, Lady Blackstone's junior. As it appears in the House of Lords Hansard, it was complicated enough without the reader having to concentrate on where Bach began and Blatch ended. It was, however, entirely conclusive. In grammar schools - accommodating something like the most "academically gifted" 25% of pupils sitting the 11-plus examination - 96.4% of 15-year-olds achieve five or more grades A* to C in GCSE/ BNVQ, 99.6% achieve one or more grades at that level and their average point score is 60.7. For the 25% most academic pupils in comprehensive schools, the comparative figures are 100%, 100% and 60.9.

Grammar school apologists may claim that the difference is minimal - though an improvement of 3.6% in the number of pupils gaining five or more good GCSEs is a considerable achievement. But Baroness Blatch would have become a heroine of the comprehensive campaign had the superiority - as revealed by the result of her persistence - been measured in the second point of decimals. For the grammar school lobby has always argued that only selective education can bring out the best in academically gifted students. The truth, as revealed by Lord Bach's parliamentary answer, is that the grammar schools - with all the advantages of superior facilities and the encouragement that "passing" the 11-plus provides - fail, on average, one pupil in each of their enviably small classes.

The Bach revelation raises a couple of questions which we can be sure that the government will not answer. Why, if on March 15, Baroness Blackstone was so certain that the comprehensive sector was doing so well, did the Department for Education and Employment refuse to give that information to the Ripon Campaign for State Education before the "parents' ballot" of March 10? The statistics, "based on data collected for the secondary performance tests, published in November 1999", were certainly available. I would ask the supplementary question, "Which side is the government on?", if I did not already know the answer.

The second question raises a more fundamental issue. If all that concerns the government is "standards", why does it tolerate the existence of 160-odd schools in which results could be improved by the abolition of selection? Comprehensive campaigners have historically based their argument on the damage that grammar schools do to the schools which surround them - primary schools required to prepare children for "the exam" rather than educate them and secondary modern schools whose pupils are stigmatised as failures. Thanks to Baroness Blatch, the arguments for all-ability intakes have moved up a notch. Grammar school pupils must be protected against the grammar schools.

When next I meet Baroness Blatch I shall have to resist the strong temptation to lock her in a grateful embrace. Thanks to her, the campaign for comprehensive schools can go onto the offence. It is the government, in its protection of the grammar schools, which is obsessed with "structures". "Down with selection and up with standards!" can become the cry. No need to read David Blunkett's lips. All we have to do is quote the statistics. And the statistics cannot lie.

webTitle: Puttnam urges teachers to take lead in changes

fields.headline: Puttnam urges teachers to take lead in changes
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers should be allowed to be the "architects" of wide-ranging change in schools and not the victims, the government education adviser, Lord Puttnam, will tell ministers today.
fields.body:
Teachers should be allowed to be the "architects" of wide-ranging change in schools and not the victims, the government education adviser, Lord Puttnam, will tell ministers today.

As chairman of the fledgling general teaching council, the Oscar-winning film producer will insist that teachers must be given "time and space" to make a contribution as professionals to raising standards.

He will address a conference in London organised by the helpline Teacherline, which today publishes a survey of calls showing that in the last two years an estimated 200,000 teachers reported stress through an excessive workload.

The research also says that 85,000 teachers claimed to have been physically assaulted or to have experienced aggression from pupils, while 58,000 were threatened by parents. A separate survey, also published today, claims teachers feel under pressure as a result of an increased workload.

The survey, carried out by the centre for economic performance, a research unit of the London School of Economics, also reveals that most teachers remain opposed to performance-related pay.

Lord Puttnam will say stress among teachers results "as often as not from feeling disempowered". Change was inevitable, but . "the challenge is to avoid seeing oneself and being seen as a figure on whom change is imposed and instead, to take on a pro-active role as architect of that change".

webTitle: Portillo accuses Blair of euro-vote arrogance

fields.headline: Portillo accuses Blair of euro-vote arrogance
fields.trailText: The prime minister was yesterday accused of arrogance when it was revealed he is privately optimistic that his leadership can persuade the British to join a single currency after the election.
fields.body:
The prime minister was yesterday accused of arrogance when it was revealed he is privately optimistic that his leadership can persuade the British to join a single currency after the election.

In a previously unpublished part of an interview with the author Robert Harris, published by the US magazine Talk, Tony Blair dismissed suggestions that it was getting too late to turn around public hostility.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, told the BBC's Breakfast With Frost programme: "The prime minister has taken a very important new step revealing that he believes it would be easy to persuade the British public to go into the euro, that all he has to do is give a bit of leadership and we are going to follow. I think he overestimates, in a rather arrogant way, his own ability to lead people."

Mr Portillo said the Conservatives would argue that such a move would have to be regarded as permanent and irretrievable.

In the interview Mr Blair was asked whether it was not too late to turn round public opinion on the euro. "I don't, as a matter of fact, accept this. If we decided to make a recommendation to people, the whole dynamics of the argument would change." People "do respond to political leaders who know what they want to do," he said.

Other ministers also believe public opinion is volatile. They claim the recent job losses caused by the high pound reveal the dangers of Britain remaining outside the euro indefinitely.

The existence of the unused section of the interview was first revealed by the monthly magazine Prospect, which reported that Mr Harris was upset by its exclusion.

In the short term the government is becoming increasingly concerned that the Franco-German alliance will use the French presidency in the second half of this year to win agreement that some countries within the EU should be allowed to cooperate more closely than others.

webTitle: Nation in waiting Row over delay in debt relief for Uganda

fields.headline: Nation in waiting Row over delay in debt relief for Uganda
fields.trailText: Debt campaigners yesterday accused western governments of political interference in a global plan to cancel the loans of some of the world's poorest countries after it emerged that western creditors have postponed hearing the Ugandan government's case for a debt write-down.
fields.body:
Debt campaigners yesterday accused western governments of political interference in a global plan to cancel the loans of some of the world's poorest countries after it emerged that western creditors have postponed hearing the Ugandan government's case for a debt write-down.

The Paris Club of 20 creditor nations announced last week it would not be considering Uganda at its meeting this month. Around 10% of its $3.2bn foreign debts are owed to Paris Club nations. The group rarely explains its actions, but sources at the World Bank say concerns about clashes between Ugandan and Rwandan troups in the Democratic Republic of Congo are behind the decision.

"I have heard the donors expressed concern about the situation between Uganda and Rwanda," said Robert Blake, the World Bank's chief economist in Kampala. Provided it met conditions such as spending on education (see above) attached to debt write-off, Uganda was to be the first poor nation to be given new assistance towards reducing debt since the G7 promised speedier and more generous relief for the poor in Cologne last September.

Ann Pettifor, director of the Jubilee 2000 coalition, which backs an independent international arbitration process to resolve the debt crisis, described the decision as outrageous. "Uganda is the first and only country to get debt relief since the promises of Cologne," she said. "It's clear creditors should not be given the responsibility to cancel debt because they simply cannot bring themselves to do it. We need an independent process."

fields.headline: Emails
fields.standfirst:
Newspapers challenge widening of police, security agency powersFreedom of information: special report
David Shayler's website
fields.trailText: The Guardian and the Observer will tomorrow challenge in the high court an order made by an Old Bailey judge to hand over any emails or notes the newspapers may possess relating to the MI5 renegade David Shayler.
fields.body:
The Guardian and the Observer will tomorrow challenge in the high court an order made by an Old Bailey judge to hand over any emails or notes the newspapers may possess relating to the MI5 renegade David Shayler.

The ruling demonstrates the wide discretion the courts have to accommodate the demands of the police and security and intelligence agencies.

Judge Martin Stephens made the order under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act which gives judges the authority to decide what is in the "public interest".

The judge made passing reference to the right to "freedom of expression" in the European convention on human rights - which from October will be part of English law.

He stressed, however, that the convention allowed restrictions to this right "in the interests of national security" - a concept before which the courts invariably genuflect.

Government agencies will soon get a new weapon in their armoury allowing them to intercept and seize information, including that held by journalists.

The regulation of investigatory powers bill extends existing law, which is limited to post and telephones, by enabling the police and other agencies to apply to cabinet ministers for warrants to intercept all forms of telecommunications.

These include documents and pictures distributed electronically, emails, and lists of websites contacted and email addresses - the equivalent to getting access to a log of telephone calls.

MI5 is reported to be building a new £25m surveillance system, codenamed GTAC - the government technical assistance centre - to monitor emails and other internet messages sent and received in Britain.

Caspar Bowden, director of the Foundation for Information Policy Research, said: "With this facility, the government can track every website that a person visits, without a warrant, giving rise to a culture of suspicion by association."

Though information obtained by interception would be inadmissible as evidence in court, the police or security and intelligence agencies - or any government department - could use intercepts for covert fishing expeditions.

The point about intercepts - unlike orders under the act which can be challenged in the courts - is that the holder of the information is unaware it is being done.

Lawyers say that the bill has enormous implications for journalists and others since they would not be able to guarantee the confidentiality of the information on their computers, including information supplied by their sources.

webTitle: Mowlam move to seize profits of crime

fields.headline: Mowlam move to seize profits of crime
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the minister for the Cabinet Office, will today try to seize back the law and order agenda from the Conservatives by announcing sweeping new powers to seize the assets of criminals.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the minister for the Cabinet Office, will today try to seize back the law and order agenda from the Conservatives by announcing sweeping new powers to seize the assets of criminals.

She will also propose a national agency to coordinate the seizures and end drug-related money laundering.

The proposals were first considered by the Home Office organised crime directorate in November 1998, but have now been developed by the Cabinet Office think tank, the performance and innovation unit.

After a month in which the government has been on the back foot on crime, Ms Mowlam, in a speech today, will say: "Why should millions of law-abiding people work hard for a living while a few criminals live a life of luxury built on the misery of others? Arresting and convicting criminals is not enough - we must also take away their profits.

"In every court case we should be looking to confiscate the unlawful assets that have built up. That should be the norm, not the exception."

She will also tell the courts that they must use their existing powers more to confiscate assets and make sure money is collected where confiscation orders are made.

Proposing to put new powers in place "as soon as possible", she will also reveal that the government is planning "a new national agency staffed by top quality financial investigators to maximise the revenues seized".

She will also promise "tough new measures against money laundering and wider laws to ensure that income from all crimes - not just drug trafficking - can be seized."

The courts already have powers to confiscate the proceeds of crime by means of a criminal confiscation order. Even before proceedings begin, the prosecutor can obtain an order from the high court to freeze property, pending the making and enforcement of a criminal confiscation order.

However, the Home Office crime directorate has acknowledged that these orders "have not been as successful as originally anticipated".

The number of drug traffickers subject to confiscation orders rose from around 3,000 in each of the years 1987 to 1991 to only just over 7,000 in 1996. At the same time the total amount ordered to be confiscated rose from £1m in 1987 to only just over £10m in 1996.

Even worse, the Home Office acknowledges, the amounts actually raised have remained stuck at £5m per year.

Between 1987 and 1996 only 157 drug trafficking confiscation orders for over £100,000 were made, even though there had been over 45,000 convictions for supply of drugs.

Separately, customs officers have powers to forfeit or seize money if they suspect it represents the proceeds of drug trafficking, or is intended for use in drug trafficking.

Ms Mowlam will strengthen these powers to allow seizure in non-drug trafficking cases, claiming the current restriction is an unfortunate anomaly. The government plan would permit the seizure of cash not just at the point of import or export of cash, but at any point at which it is found and suspected of being crime-related.

The police have also been seeking new powers to investigate and restrain the suspected criminal source of money "where there is strong circumstantial evidence that that property is the proceeds of crime".

The think tank report, which will lead to a white paper and legislation this autumn, will recommend that the burden of proof required to seize the suspected profits of crime should be reduced from the criminal to the civil level. Police would have to make a case that goods had been acquired illegally on the "balance of probabilities" rather than the higher standard of "beyond reasonable doubt".

The proposed "national confiscation agency" would ensure there was a single body dedicated to seizing criminal assets. At present the serious fraud office and crown prosecution service have too many other responsibilities. It is possible the agency will be funded partly by the proceeds.

It would employ lawyers, forensic accountants, and financial and criminal investigators. It would oversee civil forfeiture, enforce criminal confiscation orders and work with law enforcement agencies.

Proposing to put new powers in place "as soon as possible", she will also reveal that the government is planning "a new national agency staffed by top quality financial investigators to maximise the revenues seized". She will also promise "tough new measures against money laundering and wider laws to ensure that income from all crimes - not just drug trafficking - can be seized." The courts already have powers to confiscate the proceeds of crime by means of a criminal confiscation order. Even before proceedings begin, the prosecutor can obtain an order from the high court to freeze property, pending the making and enforcement of a criminal confiscation order. However, the Home Office crime directorate has acknowledged that these orders "have not been as successful as originally anticipated". The number of drug traffickers subject to confiscation orders rose from around 3,000 in each of the years 1987 to 1991 to only just over 7,000 in 1996. At the same time the total amount ordered to be confiscated rose from £1m in 1987 to only just over £10m in 1996. Even worse, the Home Office acknowledges, the amounts actually raised have remained stuck at £5m per year. Between 1987 and 1996 only 157 drug trafficking confiscation orders for over £100,000 were made, even though there had been over 45,000 convictions for supply of drugs. Separately, customs officers have powers to forfeit or seize money if they suspect it represents the proceeds of drug trafficking, or is intended for use in drug trafficking. Ms Mowlam will strengthen these powers to allow seizure in non-drug trafficking cases, claiming the current restriction is an unfortunate anomaly. The government plan would permit the seizure of cash not just at the point of import or export of cash, but at any point at which it is found and suspected of being crime-related. The police have also been seeking new powers to investigate and restrain the suspected criminal source of money "where there is strong circumstantial evidence that that property is the proceeds of crime". Police would have to make a case that goods had been acquired illegally on the "balance of probabilities" rather than the higher standard of "beyond reasonable doubt". It would employ lawyers, forensic accountants, and financial and criminal investigators. It would oversee civil forfeiture, enforce criminal confiscation orders and work with law enforcement agencies.

webTitle: Gun lobby to spend $10m fighting Gore

fields.headline: Gun lobby to spend $10m fighting Gore
fields.standfirst:
NRA sounds US election battle cry

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Led by Charlton Heston brandishing a musket, the National Rifle Association (NRA) declared political war on Al Gore's presidential candidacy yesterday, pledging to throw at least $10m (£6.7m) into the fight to get the pro-gun Republican George W Bush elected to the White House on November 7.
fields.body:
Led by Charlton Heston brandishing a musket, the National Rifle Association (NRA) declared political war on Al Gore's presidential candidacy yesterday, pledging to throw at least $10m (£6.7m) into the fight to get the pro-gun Republican George W Bush elected to the White House on November 7.

More than 20,000 members of America's most powerful single-issue lobbying group gathered for their annual convention in Charlotte, North Carolina, during the weekend, where they heard speech after speech warning that Mr Gore's election would lead first to gun registration and ultimately to gun confiscation of the kind seen in Britain and Australia in recent years.

"Our gun rights are truly in peril," announced Mr Heston, the association's president, in his opening address. "When the sun comes up on November 8, who wins the election will determine our freedoms into the next century."

As he reached the climax of his address, the veteran Hollywood actor lifted a replica musket from the American Revolutionary era above his head and invoked one of the NRA's most widely repeated slogans: "I'll give up my gun when you take it from my cold, dead hands."

"As we set out this year to defeat the divisive forces that would take freedom away," Mr Heston intoned, "I want to say those words again for everyone within the sound of my voice to hear and to heed, and especially for you, Mr Gore: 'From my cold, dead hands'."

Other speakers also repeatedly targeted Mr Gore. If the vice-president is elected, the NRA vice-president, Kayne Robinson, said, the right to bear arms as defined in the second amendment to the US constitution "will not be safe".

It was Mr Robinson who was caught on video in February claiming that the NRA enjoys "unbelievably friendly relations" with Mr Bush, and who said that the Texas governor would be "a president where we work out of their office".

Mr Bush has been a strong ally of the NRA in his years as governor of Texas. He has signed bills to allow Texans to carry concealed weapons and to prevent cities and towns from bringing class-action lawsuits against the gun industry.

The NRA's executive vice-president, Wayne LaPierre, told the convention that last weekend's Washington Million Mom March, attended by 750,000 gun-reform supporters, "wasn't a grassroots rally but a Gore campaign rally scripted and coached by the White House".

Mr Bush was not mentioned by name in the NRA leaders' speeches, but there is not an iota of uncertainty as to where the gun lobby's political loyalties lie in this year's elections; it has already spent 10 times as much money in support of Republican candidates as it has on Democrats.

The NRA's strongly assertive tone underlines the determination - as well as the muscle - which it will bring to bear in this year's elections, in which it is certain to be the heaviest-spending single pressure group on the side of Mr Bush and the Republicans.

Gun use and the death penalty are casting a shadow over US claims to moral leadership in the world, the American ambassador to France warned yesterday.

Ambassador Felix Rohatyn told Newsweek magazine that he had not realised how important the issue was in Europe until he arrived in Paris in 1997. The US should not bend to the criticisms of its capital punishment policy but it "should explore changes in our approach to criminal punishment that reflect our basic values", Mr Rohatyn said.

webTitle: Trimble puts job on line with faith in IRA arms offer

fields.headline: Trimble puts job on line with faith in IRA arms offer
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, yesterday declared he believed the IRA's offer to put its arms beyond use meant its 30-year war was over, so clarifying the battleground for the soul of unionism in a make-or-break week for the Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, yesterday declared he believed the IRA's offer to put its arms beyond use meant its 30-year war was over, so clarifying the battleground for the soul of unionism in a make-or-break week for the Northern Ireland peace process.

Mr Trimble's comments, in the Irish edition of the Sunday Times, put his political career on the line. They make inevitable his resignation if the Ulster Unionist council refuses to back his plea next Saturday to return to government with Sinn Fein.

Anti-agreement Ulster Unionists were aghast. But they also felt it offered them something to aim at, with the middle third of the 860-strong council likely to seal the vote.

Mr Trimble noted that the IRA had said it would put arms beyond use, rather than that it could do so. He also highlighted a key section of the IRA's statement in which it said it wanted the full implementation of the Good Friday agreement "in which republicans and unionists can as equals pursue their respective political objectives peacefully".

Mr Trimble, surprising and infuriating anti-agreement unionists, said: "Viewing unionists as equals, with equal rights to a political identity, is another first for the IRA, but the most significant part of this sentence is the IRA statement of intent to pursue its aims peacefully. This is an important step forward. It means to me that the IRA campaign is finally over."

Mr Trimble added: "No longer will people have to suffer the shock of death in the family, or living with permanent injuries inflicted deliberately, or the torment of worrying that such unspeakable things could happen to their families."

He understood scepticism about returning again to the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein, but said republicans had to be put to the test.

He said he would walk away from devolved government if the IRA failed to honour its commitments, outlined in a statement 16 days ago. It offered to allow outside inspectors regularly to inspect some of its secured arms dumps.

"The IRA wished the restoration of the devolved government to be permanent," he said. "I wish the same, but inclusive government can be permanent for us only when decommissioning is demonstrably permanent for them.

"If they let us down, we can walk. Moreover, the secretary of state has specifically retained his power of suspension despite strong pressure to give it up."

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, appeared to deal the Good Friday agreement a blow yesterday when he confirmed he would be unable to recommend to republicans that they join the police service outlined in the policing bill. He is unhappy that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, has appeared to promise that the RUC's name will live on in amended legislation.

But Mr Adams was addressing a republican parade in west Belfast. It was expected Sinn Fein would take that position, even if Chris Patten's reforms had been implemented in full.

Some Ulster Unionists believe Mr Adams's comments might help Mr Trimble. One suggested it proved Mr Trimble had won the battle over saving the RUC's integrity.

webTitle: Fear for British aid worker missing in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Fear for British aid worker missing in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: A British aid worker is missing in Sierra Leone, the Foreign Office confirmed yesterday, adding to the number of foreigners and peacekeepers believed to be held captive by the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF).
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
A British aid worker is missing in Sierra Leone, the Foreign Office confirmed yesterday, adding to the number of foreigners and peacekeepers believed to be held captive by the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF).

Alan Smith, 55, has not been seen since May 9, when he was spotted near Songo, 25 miles inland from the capital and later the scene of intense fighting.

In all, 334 UN peacekeepers are being held hostage by the rebels. The UN had hoped to use the captured RUF chief, Foday Sankoh, as a bargaining chip, but the Sierra Leonean government has rejected the RUFs demand for Mr Sankoh's release and said it will probably try him for murder, and this has stalled the peacekeepers' release.

The police, British forces, including members of the SAS, and the UN have all been asked to look out for the Birmingham engineer. The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said there was considerable anxiety about his fate.

"We have been trying hard to locate him. That effort continues, but obviously it is a matter of great anxiety to us," he said.

The Foreign Office has not said which aid agency Mr Smith works for, but he is believed to have been delivering second-hand computers to a local education charity. The FO said six or seven Sierra Leonean nationals working with him were also missing.

In a televised address, President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah said Mr Sankoh was being investigated for the suspected murder of 20 unarmed demonstrators outside his house a fortnight ago, and for treasonably plotting a coup. The rebel leader has been in police "protective custody with additional security provided by British forces since his capture last week.

In an attempt to separate him from the RUF, Mr Tejan Kabbah appealed to other rebel leaders to give up fighting and open talks, adding: "Those found wanting will be prosecuted."

Mr Hoon said that while it was up to the Sierra Leonean authorities to decide Mr Sankoh's fate, he should not be allowed to take his place in government agreed in last July's much-violated peace accords.

"Obviously we would be concerned that he should no longer have any kind of an influence over Sierra Leone. He was the one who broke the peace accord, he's responsible for the recent upsurge in violence," Mr Hoon said.

Sierra Leonean government forces have kept up the pressure on the RUF by pushing it further from Freetown. Yesterday it was massing at Magbelli Bridge, a strategic crossing 45 miles north-east of the capital, for an assault toward the town of Lunsar. Its capture would open the road to the rebel headquarters at Makeni.

British officers coordinating the military strategy say there has been a transformation in the Sierra Leonean army, including a marked improvement in discipline and coordination and strengthened supply lines. The Kamajor militia and other loyal forces have been put in army uniform and brought under its command.

As government troops push forward, the SAS and UN are moving up behind to secure the captured territory and ensure that the rebels do not launch an attack in the rear. Although the British troops officially do not have a combat role, the SAS in particular is close to the frontline. Yesterday it had two jeeps full of its soldiers three miles from the fighting.

The offensive and Mr Sankoh's arrest have apparently slowed down the release of UN hostages held by the RUF. The vice-chief of Kenya's general staff, Daniel Opande, said he believed his men might be used to try to win Mr Sankoh's freedom.

"Without [Sankoh's arrest] this thing would have been completed by now," he said.

Among the hostages is a British observer, Major Andy Harrison, trapped with Indian peacekeepers in the RUF stronghold of Kailahun but not believed to be in immediate danger.

fields.headline: Building blocks
fields.standfirst:
Lord Rogers is losing patience: his recommendations on urban renewal are being sidelined by the Treasury. Time to see Tony Blair

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The patience of New Labour's favourite architect finally snapped this week. Lord Rogers of Riverside may live and work on fashionable Thames-side, above a famous cafe co-run by his wife, but he has a passion for improving the country outside - from depressed inner-London boroughs to run-down northern cities.
fields.body:
The patience of New Labour's favourite architect finally snapped this week. Lord Rogers of Riverside may live and work on fashionable Thames-side, above a famous cafe co-run by his wife, but he has a passion for improving the country outside - from depressed inner-London boroughs to run-down northern cities.

That is why the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, with the blessing of Downing Street, gave him the task of chairing an urban task force shortly after Labour came to power. Its mission was to "identify causes of urban decline in England and recommend practical solutions to bring people back into our cities".

After 12 months' study at home and abroad, the 13-strong task force made a string of recommendations last June. With English cities performing well below continental counterparts in the European wealth league, the report called for a national crusade to improve the quality of urban life, create more jobs and recycle an estimated 1.3m urban buildings lying empty. Crucially, ministers were urged to provide a range of fiscal incentives for developers and local councils in special urban priority areas, or low-tax zones, to encourage inner-city regeneration. John Prescott, sitting alongside the architect, appeared enthusiastic.

But with warm words and little else, Lord Rogers soon became restless. At the turn of the year, he accused the government of being "disappointingly negative" about his key proposals - namely a call for much more urban cash. This week, he publicly told ministers he was not happy and is seeking a meeting with Tony Blair.

The architect made clear that the government had to move "faster and further" on the urban front. More controversially, he urged ministers to divert Whitehall funds from rich parts of England to poor cities in order to relieve "stressed urban areas".

Significantly, Lord Rogers and his team have made clear they are not attacking Mr Prescott. Rather, they have decided that the only way to influence government is to go over the head of the deputy prime minister and appeal directly to the Treasury. This, in short, is a plea to Gordon Brown for what Rogers calls "significant extra public resources" in the three-year spending review. It is also a challenge to Downing Street that tough political choices cannot be avoided if new life is to be breathed into cities, which also happen to be at the centre of Labour's old, disaffected heartlands.

The report pulls no punches. It accuses government departments of working at cross-purposes rather than pursuing the "cross-cutting" initiatives necessary for Whitehall to pull together and deliver the urban renaissance. While this is seen as a swipe at the Department of Trade and Industry's obsession with hi-tech "clusters" in the countryside - around Cambridge and along the M4 corridor, for instance - Lord Rogers also believes that the Department for Education and Employment has to play a more central role alongside Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR).

Significantly, the task force is now pressing for a single public service agreement - an essential performance measure in the spending review process - to halt the drift from cities. This, it suggests, should be used to measure whether improving the quality of life with a better environment, more imaginative building designs and better public services, can eventually lead to re-population.

But the key to delivering Lord Rogers' vision lies in manipulating the tax system, US-style, with a string of incentives and capital allowances to encourage developers into inner-cities. The chancellor, preparing to launch his own urban initiative in July, does not appear keen. In the Budget, he rejected Mr Prescott's call to harmonise VAT between new building - zero-rated - and conversions or improvements, which attract the full 17.5% rate. An across-the-board zero rate would clearly make conversion of 1.3m empty buildings a more attractive proposition.

In addition, Lord Rogers favoured taxing empty sites to penalise developers holding onto vacant land in anticipation of future gains. His report last year also suggested that councils should be allowed to retain the extra cash generated from business rates on new developments in designated urban priority areas (these rates are handed to the DETR and redistributed nationally). The idea is that the proceeds would then be recycled into the management and maintenance. Developers could also benefit from a capital allowances. But sources say the Treasury is sceptical.

Perhaps to stem any criticism, Gordon Brown is planning to bring a small army of American urban entrepreneurs to Britain early in July for a national conference on regeneration. After meeting ministers in London, the idea is that they will fan out to study depressed cities, and offer suggestions on redevelopment. Unless the Treasury responds to Lord Rogers, the plan could be high risk; developers in American cities invariably benefit from huge tax incentives, which make the British measures under discussion paltry by comparison.

But Lord Rogers has not given up hope. One task force member said that while members were frustrated, they still had expectations that the government would deliver. "But it is clear that the urban agenda has not yet occupied the centre ground of government thinking", he lamented. "It has to be part of the mainstream, or it is nowhere."

 Peter Hetherington is our regional affairs correspondent

 peter.hetherington@theguardian.com
