webTitle: Rubble women defy Russians in Grozny

fields.headline: Rubble women defy Russians in Grozny
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: In a city of ruins and Russian checkpoints, Koka Isayeva is seeking solace in trowelling bricks and mortar. Aloft a ladder at Grozny railway station where the trains do not run, she has enlisted with an army of Chechen war widows slapping cement onto salvaged bricks, painstakingly putting the bombed-out station back together.
fields.body:
In a city of ruins and Russian checkpoints, Koka Isayeva is seeking solace in trowelling bricks and mortar. Aloft a ladder at Grozny railway station where the trains do not run, she has enlisted with an army of Chechen war widows slapping cement onto salvaged bricks, painstakingly putting the bombed-out station back together.

It is a labour of love amid the hatred of war and occupation. The railway project is an attempt by the women, most of whom have lost sons and husbands, to find distraction from their grief simply by being together and doing something.

"My husband is dead. They killed my two sons. I raised my family and now it's gone. What am I supposed to do?" Mrs Isayeva wails. She is 57, but she looks more than 70.

Her tears turn to anger as she surveys the Russian Rambos, in bandanas and armed to the teeth, swaggering around their armoured cars, wary of the bowed but unbroken women of Grozny.

"Look at them, they're proud of themselves," hisses Mrs Isayeva. "They call themselves liberators, but they're occupiers."

The railway work is the only rebuilding evident in Grozny three months after the Russians vanquished the city by grinding it into dust. The project seems an absurdity in this landscape of devastation.

However, like the '"Trümmerfrauen" or "rubble women" of Berlin after the second world war, the Muslim women of Grozny, in headscarves and billowing skirts, are making a start in rebuilding their city.

They get no help from the thousands of Russian troops who are barely controlling the Chechen capital.

"They give us no money, no materials," says Malika Bisayeva, another woman working at the railway station. "They won't let you live. We just can't live with these Russians. But we were in the cellars for four months and we've got to start somewhere."

The only other recovery work that seems to be going on is the grim business of retrieval and reburial of corpses. A crew of 36 Russians and Chechens working for the Russian authorities combs the city daily, digging up the dead from what were cellars or courtyards or gardens and taking them to cemeteries.

On average, more than 20 corpses are dug up every day from their makeshift graves or from where they were killed. The exhumation squads have reburied more than 1,200 dead, almost all civilians.

The Russians have stated baldly that Grozny is not worth recovering and their reconstruction efforts are directed not at the city, but at the sprawling military base of Khankala, south of Grozny, which is the headquarters for the permanent deployment of more than 20,000 troops.

Meanwhile, the Russian troops in the capital are busy plundering, according to the Russian-appointed mayor, Supyan Mokhchayev. He claims that billions of roubles worth of assets have been looted from destroyed power stations and industrial plants. The conquerors of Grozny are now laying mines to deter further theft.

"New minelaying has been started in a city just cleared of mines and other ordnance. It's a paradox, but there's no other option," he said. "Grozny is now being mined again by the new authorities."

To travel north from Khankala, through the outskirts of Grozny, into the centre and on to the Staropromyslovsky district where an impromptu Chechen bazaar has sprung up is to witness destruction on an epic scale. Not one building has been spared.

"What do you expect? I know of a unit of 80 of our guys and only 12 of them survived the fight for Grozny," says Yury Vasin, a spokesman for Russia's justice ministry. "I've just seen Grozny for the first time and, to be honest, I thought the damage would be worse. I thought there wouldn't be a stone left standing."

What is left standing is uninhabitable. Twenty-foot bomb craters pock the roads. Bridges and tunnels are collapsed. High-rise blocks of flats have concertinaed into heaps of mangled masonry and metal. Charred shells of older, once elegant buildings are sprouting weeds and saplings. Hovels are being patched together out of the debris and scrawled signs have been placed on them proclaiming "We live here."

The totality of the destruction takes the breath away. On a bright spring day, there is a cruel beauty to the ruins of Grozny. Bizarre, dream-like images burn themselves on the memory - four elderly blind men tiptoeing through the debris, holding hands and clutching sticks; two peasant women embraceing silently on a sunny street, tears streaming down their faces; a middle-aged woman suddenly running after a western reporter, pleading as she throws a folded scrap of paper for him to catch.

It reads: "They've been holding my son illegally for four months. Akhmed Arbiyevich, born 1976. They took him away and won't let him go."

"There's no money, no work, no water, no electricity, no prospects," says Ruslan Khatuyev, a 25-year-old Chechen man lingering at the bazaar where country women are selling garlic bulbs, radishes, parsley, and tomatoes. "No nothing."

The mayor maintains there are now 100,000 people in a city that once was home to four times that number. But the true figure can only be a quarter of the mayor's estimate and most of them are still living in blasted basements.

And beneath the Russian swagger, the troops are on edge. The violence is unremitting, the bitterness festers. Firefights erupt every night as the rebel gunmen infiltrate to stage hit-and-run attacks before melting back into the maze of ruins.

"The high intensity of firing at federal forces in Grozny suggests that the militants have started implementing orders to intensify subversive and terrorist activity," the Russian military has admitted.

"They call it liberated Grozny, but there's no freedom, only taunting," says Raisa Nakhamadova, 62, who has lost two sons.

"Every night, from dusk till dawn, the firing never stops," says Mrs Isayeva. "Russian soldiers came around drunk at 11pm the other night. They shot the neighbours, Maleyka and Hasan. They're in hospital. What about their three kids?"

webTitle: Why four is the new three

fields.headline: Why four is the new three
fields.standfirst:
In the 60s it was excessive, in the 70s it was frivolous, and by the 90s, it was completely beyond the pale. But now, says Maureen Freely , the four-child family is making a comeback. And not just because of Tony and Cherie

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: In the 60s it was excessive, in the 70s it was frivolous, and by the 90s, it was completely beyond the pale. But now, says  Maureen Freely  , the four-child family is making a comeback. And not just because of Tony and Cherie
fields.body:
They were all the rage after the second world war. After all, the Queen had four children, so why shouldn't everyone else? But by the 60s, four began to look a little excessive. By the 70s, it was definitely frivolous. And by the 90s, it was unwise even to utter the F word in public. There was always one person who would have one drink too many and then tell you a thing or two about the population explosion.

The scare statistics varied but the moral of the lecture was always the same: socially responsible parents stopped at "replacement level".

There was a lingering sympathy for those who went on to have third children because their first two were the same sex. But if you already had a boy and a girl, you could expect to raise eyebrows. If you went for a fourth, the very first set of raised eyebrows would belong to the family planning nurse.

As a rule, she would begin with the question: "Are you Catholic?" If you made the mistake of saying, as I did, "Yes, but not practising", you then got a friendly chat about the merits of the more "reliable" forms of birth control. The most reliable being, ahem, sterilisation. That was their view, anyway. My own view is that the most effective form of birth control is house-hunting. Or trying to find a car that's big enough to hold a family of six. Or maybe just looking at the prices. Trying to get sympathy for your predicament - that worked wonders, too. If you so much as mentioned that you would have to be a millionaire to afford a house with enough bedrooms, then someone would say: "Well, you must have realised this would be a problem when you let yourself into this."

But now attitudes are beginning to shift again. And it's not entirely due to the Blair baby.

Our birth rate is sinking. Not as fast as it is in other parts of Europe - but the decline is steady and unlikely to reverse itself if present conditions persist. The decline is partly due to the fact that more and more people are choosing to remain childless, and partly to the fact that those who do have families have strong economic reasons to stop at two. But add up all these sensible choices and what you get is a rather serious problem in the long term. In the decades to come, we will have an ever smaller pool of working-age adults, and they will have to support an ever larger pool of pensioners.

The solutions proposed so far by policy wonks are all rather dramatic. The easiest thing would be to accept that we cannot support our ageing population at the levels considered normal today. But this is not likely to be much of an election-winner, as most people would not want to vote for a policy that condemned them to poverty in old age. However, they are not likely to relish the three other proposed solutions either. One tack would be to increase taxes. Another would be to increase immigration. The gentlest option - as some European countries have already decided - would be to bring the birth rate back above replacement level again. In other words, make it just a bit easier for people to have more children. It is against this backdrop that four-child families begin to look not so ridiculous, and even socially useful.

If they also look a little exotic, it is not just because they are rare. It is also because they tend to be departures from the original idea. Given the various pressures to keep families small, there are almost always extenuating circumstances. The plan was for three children, and the fourth was a surprise. Or the plan was to have two children, but after getting divorced, the father went on to have a second family. Or after stopping at two, and going back into full-time work, the mother got fed up with it all and went home to shock the neighbours by having another two after an eight, nine, 10-year gap.

Or they never made a plan at all, because they didn't believe life should be like that. Boris Johnson of the Spectator and the publisher of Condé Nast, Nicholas Coleridge, fall into this category, as do so many of the people you see reclining on their priceless sofas in Hello magazine. But even in the more modest categories, there's always a story, and the stories always have a tinge of glamour and romance attached to them, if only because the parents in question are refusing to listen to their bank managers and are following their passions instead.

This does not always lead to domestic bliss, and let's not mention the money side right now because it gives me a headache. That said, choosing to have a fourth child was the best reckless decision I ever made.

I am still not sure it's quite fashionable enough to blab about those extenuating circumstances. But I'll say this much. There's a buzz in a house that has four children in it that you don't get if you stop at two or three. It comes, I think, from the number of relationships that are going on at the same time. If you include two parents in the equation, the total is 15: five plus four plus three plus two plus one. Because each child has such a distinct personality and interacts in such a different way with each of the other children, you never quite know what's going to happen next. The idea that you can shape your children in your image goes right out the window.

Children in families of four enjoy a privacy and a freedom of movement that children in smaller families rarely get to know. They can be sure their parents will be too busy to be keeping them under constant sur veillance, or at least too tired to intervene in every last negotiation. And if they do get in trouble, they know it is only a matter of time before one of the other children becomes number one object of family shame.

When I talk to people who grew up in four-children families in the 50s, they always mention how much they enjoyed being in houses where there were twice as many children as adults. It felt like the right balance of power. And they liked the variety of ages. First and second-born children recall the pleasure of being older brothers and sisters. The younger ones talk about seeing their older siblings as gods. There is always an exception - the one who played that cruel trick on you when you were six, or the little brat who took your best shoes out to jump in the puddles and whose name will always be mud. But as a rule, sibling rivalries seem to have less of a sting to them than they do in smaller families. Because even if you hate the very sight of the other child, at least you don't have to spend your whole life eyeball to eyeball. There's always someone else to talk to, so conflicts are never quite as intense. The same rule applies to parents. It was very comforting, for example, having two little ones around when my older children became teenagers. I cannot claim that I was not a nervous wreck, but I know I would have been even more hysterical and clingy if they had been leaving me to an empty house.

And when I argued with my teenagers, it didn't hit me as hard as it might have done, because in the next room there were these two little children who still liked and admired me and were longing to climb on to my lap. Talking at their level for hours on end was a pleasure not a drain, because I knew that once they were in bed I could go back to the teenagers and have an almost adult conversation. Or ask them to babysit, and go out to see a movie.

My relationships with my children now that I have four of them are also less Significant than they were when I had one, two, and three. A friend of mine who also has four children says it's because you "don't quite have all your eggs in one basket". You might still be trying to live out your fantasies through them, but that still means fewer fantasies per child. You also have a much stronger sense of each child's personality. Now that you have learned from experience that not all girls are alike, and that boys vary in temperament just as much, you are much quicker to pick up on and appreciate the differences. And what a comfort it is to put all your experience to good use. In families where there are only two, closely spaced children, you are forever learning about a certain age only to have to throw all your hard-won wisdom away as you race to learn about the next age. If you have four children, you know that anything you learn with your older children will help you later on with the younger ones.

So in almost every way, life in a four-child family is more relaxed than it is in a smaller family. But here we come to the down side, aka the end of the month. It is incredibly expensive to keep four children in shoes, let alone anything else. I don't think I'll itemise the bills, because (as people are always reminding me), I'm the one who got myself into this and so I'm the one who's going to have to pay for it. Maybe in a few years, when we've all seen enough pictures of the new improved Blair family, people will start viewing the F word in a more favourable light. Maybe we'll even get letters from the Queen congratulating us for following so bravely in her footsteps. Maybe we'll see new policies coming in, offering incentives for people who would like four to be the new three. But until that day arrives, the four-child family will continue to be a luxury that only the very rich and reckless can afford.

fields.headline: Ethiopia pushes deep into Eritrea
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: The Ethiopian army continued its lightning offensive deep inside Eritrea yesterday, threatening its neighbour's capital, Asmara.
fields.body:
The Ethiopian army continued its lightning offensive deep inside Eritrea yesterday, threatening its neighbour's capital, Asmara.

Ethiopia took the Eritrean town of Om Hajer, on the borders of Ethiopia and Sudan, in a move designed to protect the western flank of its army, a government official said.

Addis Ababa also claimed it had carried out bombing raids near the strategic town of Mendefera, the capture of which would allow Ethiopia to make a direct assault on Asmara. And, while one Addis Ababa official insisted that Ethiopia had no intention of taking Asmara, another refused to rule out such a move.

Ethiopia's rapid advance is causing concern in Asmara where the US yesterday ordered the evacuation of non-essential embassy staff and the Foreign Office advised British citizens to leave.

Retreating Eritrean forces are trying to slow the advance by blowing up bridges and laying landmines, but Ethiopian troops are within 60 miles of Asmara.

"We just don't know quite what the Ethiopians have planned next. Asmara would be an option but a very difficult one," said a military analyst in Addis Ababa.

A successful attack on Asmara would almost certainly lead to the overthrow of the Eritrean president, Isaias Afewerki, who Ethiopia says is entirely to blame for the war which began two years ago when Eritrea invaded large parts of northern Ethiopia.

Hundreds of thousands of Eritreans have been displaced by Ethiopia's advance and are reportedly in dire need of assistance. The UN World Food Programme is already feeding 300,000 Eritreans threatened by drought.

Hundreds of thousands of Eritreans have been displaced by Ethiopia's advance and are reportedly in dire need of assistance. The UN World Food Programme is already feeding 300,000 Eritreans threatened by drought.

fields.headline: 'Real New Yorker' challenges Hillary
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Rick Lazio began his whirlwind transformation from relative political obscurity to national prominence at the weekend as the Republican party's new standard-bearer battled to establish himself as a credible rival to Hillary Clinton in the New York Senate election.
fields.body:
Rick Lazio began his whirlwind transformation from relative political obscurity to national prominence at the weekend as the Republican party's new standard-bearer battled to establish himself as a credible rival to Hillary Clinton in the New York Senate election.

Just hours after New York City's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, threw the November contest wide open by withdrawing because of his recently diagnosed prostate cancer, Mr Lazio went on a whistlestop tour of the television studios and embarked on a four-city swing through the state in an attempt to overcome Mrs Clinton's surge in the opinion polls.

The scale of the task facing Mr Lazio, a 42-year-old congressman from Long Island, was underlined by a poll showing Mrs Clinton has jumped into a 14-point lead following Mr Giuliani's withdrawal.

Mr Giuliani and Mrs Clinton were neck and neck in the polls, but the new survey of likely New York state voters, published in the New York Post, shows Mrs Clinton with 46% support, Mr Lazio on 32% and 17% undecided.

Mr Lazio began his campaign by stressing what he hopes will be a key advantage over Mrs Clinton, the fact that he has spent all his life in New York, has a New York-born wife Patricia, and sends his two daughters to New York schools.

"You can tell from my accent that I am a lifelong New Yorker," Mr Lazio said at a rally on Saturday. "I didn't need an exploratory committee to help me figure out where I wanted to live".

Describing himself as "a centrist, a mainstream Republican", Mr Lazio says he is right-of-centre on tax and budget issues and "realistic" on social policies. He has records of support for abortion rights and for moderate gun control - measures which are indispensable for Republicans running for state-wide office in New York.

Mr Lazio made it clear yesterday that he intends to attack Mrs Clinton more forcefully than Mr Giuliani has. Describing his rival as "far left" and "extreme", Mr Lazio said she offers "the big government ideology that crippled New York in the 1980s".

"She is no more a New Democrat than she is a New Yorker," Mr Lazio said.

Mr Lazio signed up Mike Murphy, formerly the campaign strategist for Senator John McCain's presidential bid, to run his campaign. Mr Murphy's expertise in persuading non-Republican voters to back a Republican candidate could be a vital asset in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than a million.

fields.headline: Peace talks called off
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Hours after a Jewish toddler was badly burnt by a petrol bomb, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday lost patience with eight consecutive days of rioting in the West Bank and Gaza and ordered his negotiators to return from peace talks in Stockholm.
fields.body:
Hours after a Jewish toddler was badly burnt by a petrol bomb, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday lost patience with eight consecutive days of rioting in the West Bank and Gaza and ordered his negotiators to return from peace talks in Stockholm.

The severity of Mr Barak's response, amid the violence in Palestinian-controlled areas and heavy fighting in south Lebanon, deepened the sense that events may be spinning out of control.

Mr Barak is openly frustrated with the failure of the Palestinian Authority to rein in the protesters in the areas it controls - including the policemen who fired live rounds at Israeli soldiers twice in the last week.

Earlier yesterday, he demanded that the Palestinian Authority take forceful steps to end the unrest - the worst since 1996 - and took the unusual step of banning Israelis and foreign tourists from Palestinian-controlled areas.

With a two-year-old Israeli girl on life support in a Jerusalem hospital after the car in which she was travelling was attacked outside the town of Jericho, Mr Barak may feel that he cannot be seen to be discussing a peace settlement with the Palestinians that would involve concessions on territory, and on prisoners - the protesters' main demand.

Mr Barak told his weekly cabinet meeting yesterday that the transfer of Abu Dis and other villages near Jerusalem was on hold until Mr Arafat could promise there would be no further violence. On Saturday night he cancelled a summit meeting in Washington.

Yesterday Hizbullah guerrillas in southern Lebanon used mortars and machine guns against an Israeli post near the Golan Heights. Israeli Radio said the attack was believed to be related to Lebanon's demand that Israel withdraw from the Sheba'a farms at the foot of Mount Hermon during its unilateral withdrawal.

The prime minister's office summoned its two negotiators from the unofficial talks in Stockholm "in light of the situation in the [Palestinian] territories", and to update them on conversations Mr Barak has held in recent days with world leaders.

During the past week of unrest, in which five Palestinians were killed and hundreds were wounded, Israel has accused Mr Arafat of stoking protests to force concessions on territory before September, the deadline for a final peace settlement.

In turn, Palestinian leaders say Israel has inflamed the protesters by using live ammunition, and by threatening to use attack helicopters.

However, the protests are also driven by a campaign for the release of around 1,650 political prisoners, still being held in Israeli jails after nearly seven years of negotiations. More than 1,000 have been on hunger strike, led by 60 inmates at the Hadarim jail.

The Hadarim inmates, who have subsisted on small cups of milk and soup since May 1, plan to intensify their protest later this month with an all-out hunger strike.

All the prisoners at Hadarim belong to Palestinian organisations opposed to the peace process, presenting a challenge to Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation, which wants to be seen as leading the protests. Yesterday, Fatah called for five days of peaceful protests on the prisoners' behalf.

webTitle: Leo brings pangs of old labour

fields.headline: Leo brings pangs of old labour
fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: First Tony confessed to a church congregation that he was feeling a little tired, then Cherie issued a statement saying that she, too, was "tired but full of joy".
fields.body:
First Tony confessed to a church congregation that he was feeling a little tired, then Cherie issued a statement saying that she, too, was "tired but full of joy".

One day after the arrival of Leo Blair, the prime minister and his wife quietly retreated to Downing Street's inner sanctum to recover from a 12-hour labour and an unsettled first night.

Yesterday they remembered what a difficult, draining business having a baby can be.

While the world's media waited for the first photographic glimpse of the "lovely little kid" - as his father called him - Mrs Blair said in a statement that it was so long since the birth of her other three children she had forgotten "quite what an ordeal those last few hours of labour can be".

After thanking the midwives, doctors and other staff at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital, where the birth took place, she added: "Now that Leo is here, I am very tired but full of joy. Tony and the children are a real help and all of us are really touched by the flowers, messages and presents, not just from friends and colleagues but, perhaps above all, from people we have never met."

Her husband, who went to Westminister Cathedral with their three other children, Euan, 16, Nicky, 14, and Kathryn, 12, looked weary after the baby's first night at Downing Street. He told fellow worshippers: "It definitely wasn't a quiet night."

Mrs Blair, 45, gave birth to her fourth child at 12.25am on Saturday morning. The 3.06kg (6lb 12oz) boy, the first child born to a serving prime minister for 150 years, is named after Mr Blair's father.

A spokesman said the family spent a quiet afternoon at Downing Street with their new arrival yesterday, and that the atmosphere was "relaxed and happy".

A group of students visiting from Nebraska, USA, who were given a rare tour of Number 10, said they had seen "lots of cuddly toys" lying around.

The house was also filled with flowers and messages of congratulation from round the world: greetings came from the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh, the Tory leader William Hague and his wife Ffion, Hillary Clinton, and the Russian president Vladimir Putin and his wife Lyudmila.

The cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, a close friend of the Blairs, said: "The reality of yesterday was a mother and father wreathed in grins because they had a baby."

He told the BBC's Breakfast With Frost: "The most important thing which happened as far as the Blairs are concerned is that they are relieved and delighted that Leo has come and is safe. Obviously these things are attended by great anxiety but, at the end, great happiness."

Mr Blair has promised to reduce his commitments so that he can spend as much time as possible with Leo, but will not take formal paternity leave.

Leo is expected to be baptised at a Roman Catholic church in Mr Blair's Sedgefield, Co Durham, constituency.

fields.headline: Blow to anti-hunt campaigners
fields.standfirst:
Burns Inquiry homepage
The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The campaign to ban fox-hunting will be delivered a severe blow when an official inquiry reveals that there is no conclusive evidence to show that foxes suffer physical pain and terror when being pursued by a pack of dogs.
fields.body:
The campaign to ban fox-hunting will be delivered a severe blow when an official inquiry reveals that there is no conclusive evidence to show that foxes suffer physical pain and terror when being pursued by a pack of dogs.

But opponents of hunting will seize on other conclusions in the Burns inquiry report, including research that shows farmers massively overestimate the size of the fox population and the danger it poses to livestock.

The Burns inquiry is due to publish its findings in the next few weeks amid signs that it will offer a range of options, including a limited or outright ban.

The inquiry, chaired by Sir Terry Burns, the former Treasury permanent secretary, was set up by the home secretary, Jack Straw, with the stated aim of trying to remove some of the emotional heat and increase informed debate about fox-hunting. The research acknowledges that foxes suffer a high heart rate during a chase and are not always cleanly killed by hounds dislocating the neck, as claimed by supporters of hunting.

It has also concluded that the impact of hunting with hounds on fox culling in lowland areas is "extremely small" and that removing hunting with hounds "has very little long term effect on the pervading population trend".

By contrast, a ban on hunting with dogs in upland areas could have "a profound effect" since the majority of foxes there have been killed using dogs.

Critics claimed the inquiry was established to make it less likely that legislation banning fox-hunting could be implemented before the general election.

The government has promised to offer "reasonable parliamentary time, if necessary", and drafting assistance for a private member's bill banning fox-hunting.

It has also promised a free vote, ensuring that the measure will be passed in the Labour-dominated Commons, but probably delayed in the Lords.

A paper commissioned by the inquiry from Professor Patrick Bateson on the welfare implications of hunting foxes finds that although body temperature of foxes rise during a chase - sometimes lasting longer 30 minutes - there is no final evidence that it produces permanent damage. But a post-mortem study of foxes shows that some are probably injured before the kill.

The research more conlusively rejects the use of terriers to dig out foxes, saying the cornered fox can reasonably be compared with a fox in a box trap, and demonstrates a pronounced stress.

The study also states: "No scientific evidence exists on whether shooting is a more humane way of killing foxes since little is known of the accuracy of shooting and the rates of wounding. Common sense suggests that the wounding rate of a smaller and primarily nocturnal species will be higher than than the 2.4% of wounded deer that are known to escape."

The inquiry has found in separate research that a comparatively small number of jobs would be lost as a result of the closure of the hunts, ranging from 666 to 4,633. It also points out that employment in the rural communities has increased by nearly 600,000 over the past 20 years.

A report commissioned by the inquiry from three universities on management of the fox population and its predatory status concludes: "Despite the widespread belief that foxes are serious predators of livestock, there is evidence to suggest their importance is generally overestimated and that in fact they are responsible for only a minor percentage of losses."

For instance the study has found only 3% of lost lambs can be attributed to foxes, compared with 18% claimed by farmers.

The research also suggests famers massively over-estimate the size of the fox population. It suggests there are fewer than 240,000 adult foxes at the start of the breeding season, of which the vast majority are shot, killed on roads or trapped. Fewer than 15,000 are killed by foxhounds, by one estimate.

fields.headline: Symbolic vow to ditch N-weapons
fields.standfirst: 'Big 5' make symbolic vow to ditch nuclear arsenals
fields.trailText: The five official nuclear powers, including Britain, have made an "unequivocal" commitment to eliminate their atomic arsenals, in a move which while largely symbolic was yesterday hailed as a landmark in the cause of a nuclear-free world.
fields.body:
The five official nuclear powers, including Britain, have made an "unequivocal" commitment to eliminate their atomic arsenals, in a move which while largely symbolic was yesterday hailed as a landmark in the cause of a nuclear-free world.

The pledge, contained in a document agreed by rare consensus between 187 countries after a month of negotiation at a UN conference in New York, goes significantly further than non-nuclear powers and arms control groups had expected.

The non-proliferation treaty review conference also singled out Israel, which is estimated to have up to 200 undeclared nuclear weapons, for not signing the treaty.

The treaty agreed to further cuts in the number of tactical nuclear weapons, more openness by the nuclear powers about arsenals, a moratorium on nuclear tests, unilateral reductions in nuclear arsenals, a reduction in the number of warheads on hair-trigger alert, and nuclear-free zones in the Middle East and South Asia.

Kofi Annan, UN secretary general, called it "a significant step forward in humanity's pursuit of a world free of nuclear dangers". Antonio de Icaza, the Mexican representative speaking for the New Agenda Coalition - including countries which have abandoned nuclear ambitions - described the agreement as "a landmark on which to build a nuclear weapons-free world".

However, the importance of the commitment, which sets no timescale for nuclear disarmament, was played down by some anti-nuclear groups, notably CND and Greenpeace, and by the British government.

"There's no specific timetable agreed and obviously it is dependent on every other nuclear weapons state agreeing the same and taking appropriate action," said Geff Hoon, the defence secretary.

"What we have agreed together with the United States is that in principle we would like to see the end to nuclear weapons", he told BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme. He added: "I think realistically it's unlikely to lead to action tomorrow, next week or next month." He hoped nuclear weapons would be a thing of the past during his lifetime.

"But it is dependent on all the countries with nuclear weapons and access to that very dangerous technology [that they should] agree upon and take action to bring about their elimination," he said.

Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, said in a statement: "We now look forward to translating this agreement into concrete international progress."

fields.headline: Dr Shyam Singha
fields.trailText: Shyam Singha, who in the terms of his religiious beliefs "left his body" at the age of 79, was a leading pioneer in natural health therapies, an influential teacher and lecturer, the founder of the first British School of Acupuncture and a doctor at the Natural Therapies Centre in Suffolk.
fields.body:
Shyam Singha, who in the terms of his religiious beliefs "left his body" at the age of 79, was a leading pioneer in natural health therapies, an influential teacher and lecturer, the founder of the first British School of Acupuncture and a doctor at the Natural Therapies Centre in Suffolk.

Born in Kashmir, Singha went to university in Patna, where he gained a BSc in aeronautical engineering. After service in the Indian air force, he came to England in 1953 where he studied at the college of naturopathy and osteopathy. It was here that his interest in the curative effects of acupuncture and alternative therapies grew, and he went on to Hong Kong, where he trained as an acupuncturist and became a member of the Chinese Acupuncture Association.

In the 1970s, therapies such as acupuncture and homeopathy were actually illegal in many parts of the west, but Singha's credo was always to treat the patient, not the disease, and he was enormously successful with more than 37,000 patients. He worked in surgeries in London and Suffolk and lectured, gave workshops and ran clinics in Europe and America. The author of The Secrets of Natural Health (1997), he was an inspiring teacher. Among his pupils was Harvard-trained Dr James Gordon, who went on to serve with the National Institute of Health and became the founder of the Mind/Body Centre in Washington DC, as well as setting up the annual Comprehensive Cancer Care Conference.

I first met Singha in 1971 when I went to him for acupuncture to see if the treatment, as rumoured, could help my hearing. To my astonishment, my hearing improved, at times so dramatically that I could set aside my hearing aids. With a long history of audiograms and other tests, I used these techniques to monitor the efficiency of the acupuncture treatment. As a result I became intensely interested in Singha's work, and for a time accompanied him at his workshops and clinics across the world.

A man of immense intelligence, humour and courage, he did not sell salvation and he did not suffer fools, but if you were in trouble, or genuinely wanting to change your life, then he would help. There is no doubt that it is through his influence and teaching that today acupuncture is now considered a commonplace therapy for a broad range of ailments and that there are many excellent doctors, trained in the disciplines of both the west and east.

Singha is survived by his mother, his wife Pauline, their two daughters and a son, and his son and daughter from his first marriage to Ruth Mary Elizabeth, who predeceased him.

Ian Fenton writes: Shyam Singha lived and healed with the underlying belief that what was once naturally healthy could be restored to health by natural means. The Secrets of Natural Health includes the natural food and cooking skills which were an important part of Shyam's healing technique, as was his lifelong practice of meditation, which he also taught to others. The method he taught was a meditation of love, as much his tool for healing as any material substance. It was not sentimental love, but the detached love of the master. Shyam Sunder Singha, doctor, teacher and healer, born August 2 1920; died April 30 2000

fields.headline: Local government
fields.standfirst:
Culture of secrecy in town hall cabinet system

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Culture of secrecy in town hall cabinet system.
fields.body:
For some it was a storm in a plant pot. But for others a £3m scheme to freshen up flower beds and improve street cleaning struck at the very heart of local democracy in Newcastle upon Tyne.

Nigel Todd, 20 years a Labour councillor in the city, says he was outraged by the determination of party colleagues to surround the modest venture with secrecy.

"In the past it would have gone to a committee and you would see what the order of priorities was in distributing the money around the city. Now there's no way of knowing how that is being undertaken."

Mr Todd says the scheme, parochial yet important to thousands of council taxpayers, was approved in private because Labour-run Newcastle, like scores of councils around the country, scrapped its old committee structure in favour of a cabinet system. This usually means press and public are excluded from meetings where key issues are debated.

Local newspapers, like Newcastle's Evening Chronicle, were so outraged by the bureaucratic attack on hard-won freedom of information rights that they launched "open them up" campaigns, occasionally with success.

Alison Hastings, the Chronicle's editor, said: "These cab inets make it easier for councillors to approve things because they are not seeing the effect their decisions are having on the electorate and that is plain wrong. Democratically, it is very bad if voters are unable to go along and show their strength of feeling to this inner sanctum that was making far-reaching decisions involving an awful lot of money."

The Chronicle's campaign hit home. Tony Flynn, the council leader, said: "Presentationally, it looked as if we were being secretive, although that was not the case."

Newcastle has finally bowed to pressure. It will follow the example of the old committee system and open the next cabinet meeting to the press and the public after six months of secret meetings.

The Campaign for Freedom of Information says an increasing number of town halls are taking key decisions in private. A new local government bill now going through parliament only requires council cabinets to publish important papers after decisions have been taken - leaving people little or no time to object to contentious issues. Unlike previous legislation, which underpinned open committee meetings, there is no requirement for cabinets to meet in public.

But Labour's national executive has little sympathy with critics in the council chamber and in the local press. In a recent circular to all Labour council groups, it claims current campaigns against a cabinet system are "naive, misinformed or mischievous".

webTitle: Middle England calls for better childcare

fields.headline: Middle England calls for better childcare
fields.trailText: Three-quarters of working mothers believe they have too little access to affordable childcare, according to a poll published today at the start of national childcare week.
fields.body:
Three-quarters of working mothers believe they have too little access to affordable childcare, according to a poll published today at the start of national childcare week.

The Mori poll for the pressure group Daycare Trust also reveals that just over two-thirds of parents with school age children regard affordable childcare as essential in enabling women to return to work.

Middle England voters are even more likely than those in the lower socio-economic groups to put the issue first, with 71% of ABC1s saying care they can afford is the key issue.

Almost half of parents believe employers do not support mothers, according to the survey, with around the same number saying that a supportive employer is a primary factor in helping women return to the workplace.

Better-off parents, in particular, want to see the government ensuring that employers offer more flexible working to mothers returning from maternity leave.

The poll comes as ministers are acknowledging that initial moves to improve childcare have led to growing momentum for better and cheaper facilities.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is considering multi-million pound bids from education ministers in advance of the comprehensive spending review in July, to plug yawning gaps in care for the youngest children, aged up to three.

The birth of Tony and Cherie Blair's fourth child will focus yet more attention on childcare dilemmas.

Margaret Hodge, the minister responsible for childcare and early years education, said: "We can never go as fast as everybody would like, but the key is to get a solid structure in place to make sure all children are given a decent start in life."

webTitle: Four threats to the public's right to know

fields.headline: Four threats to the public's right to know
fields.standfirst:
Bills going through parliament will hinder watchdog role of press and bolster state secrecy

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Bills going through parliament will hinder watchdog role of press and bolster state secrecy.
fields.body:
Who first exposed the scandal of the high death rate of babies with heart defects in Bristol? Who warned that cows with BSE could pose a threat to humans, when the government was categorically denying there was any risk? In both cases, the early warnings came from the media.

A probing, questioning press is the citizen's prime safeguard against an officialdom whose natural reaction is to try to hush things up. Britain's culture of secrecy is buttressed by harsh libel laws and weak rights of access to official information.

The freedom of information bill, now going through parliament, gives fewer rights to official information than those enjoyed by citizens of the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the Irish Republic. In some respects, the rights are weaker than those under the last Tory government's open government code.

But three other bills well on their way to enactment with much less media attention also threaten the public's right to know or the ability of journalists to perform their watchdog role: the local government bill, the terrorism bill, and the regulation of investigatory powers bill.

The freedom of information bill has drawn criticism from MPs and peers of all parties, yet ministers have made minimal concessions and the bill is progressing through parliament in essence unchanged. There are blanket exemptions for whole categories of information.

Not only are sensitive policy discussions excluded - a standard exemption under FOI legislation worldwide - but also the factual information on which policy decisions are based, which other governments make available to their citizens. Scientific advice, on BSE for example, opinion polls, and submissions by lobbyists would all be exempt.

Where information was exempt, the new information commissioner would be able to order disclosure in the public interest, but a minister would be able to veto the order.

Under a late concession, the veto would have to be exercised by a cabinet minister. But under Ireland's 1997 Freedom of Information Act, the information commissioner can compel disclosure on public interest grounds and cannot be overruled by ministers.

The FOI bill covers local authorities, NHS trusts, quangos and a wide range of public bodies as well as government departments. Information gathered through investigations is exempt, even if the investigation is over and prosecutions finished. That rules out much information about safety hazards, including the Paddington rail crash, deaths on building sites, and data falsification by BNFL- the type of information which has proved a powerful tool in the US for holding careless companies to account. Police investigations are exempt too, despite the Macpherson report's recommendation that the police should be fully accountable under freedom of information laws.

Another clause exempts "commercially confidential" information - the excuse already used by the government to deny the Consumers' Association information on pension and endowment misselling. A catch-all clause, which applies to public bodies as well as government departments, allows disclosure to be refused if "in the reasonable opinion of a qualified person" - a minister or official - it would "prejudice the effective conduct of public affairs".

The local government bill will take away existing rights to information about local authority decision-making. Now, most important council decisions are taken at open meet ings of the council or its committees, with council papers available beforehand. Under the bill, most decisions will be taken by the mayor or leader, individual councillors with executive powers, or a cabinet of councillors.

Cabinets will be able to sit in secret and only have to publish their decisions once taken. Councils will be able to take decisions about housing, social services, and education in much greater secrecy. People will lose their existing rights to know, which apply only where meetings are open. They will have no right to know what decisions are about to be taken or to see reports and official papers in advance.

The terrorism bill puts journalists in danger of arrest, search and questioning, and having material seized if they cover the activities not only of organisations most people would regard as terrorist, but also campaigning bodies, protesters and even workers involved in industrial disputes. The bill widens the definition of terrorism from political causes to include religious or ideological causes, and the definition of violence to include violent action against property as well as people. Poll tax demonstrators, road protesters or groups taking action against GM crops would come within the ambit of the bill.

It would become a crime not to report suspicions about certain terrorist activities, but the definition of terrorism is so wide that journalists could find themselves expected to inform on a large range of campaigning organisations or activities.

Photographers and cameramen in Northern Ireland who cover assemblies and funerals could be forced to hand over film. The bill makes it a criminal offence to collect information likely to be useful to a terrorist - which could include politicians' home addresses.

The regulation of investigatory powers bill will jeopardise journalists' sources and confidential information. The bill will allow the state to intercept email and telephone communications across private networks, and force the decoding of scrambled information, for the purposes of detecting crime, preventing disorder, for public safety, protecting public health, and even "in the interests of the economic well-being of the United Kingdom".

Law enforcement agencies would be able to force individuals to hand over encryption keys and passwords needed to decode encrypted data, and those individuals would be barred from telling anyone else, including an employer, about the demand. Those who lose or forget their password would risk a jail sentence of up to two years unless they could prove that it was forgotten or lost.

The four bills add up to a legislative programme which, says the Society of Editors, "will erode current safeguards, extend state powers, outlaw legitimate journalistic investigation and bolster state secrecy".

fields.headline: Russian focus for bank chief
fields.standfirst: Warning to Putin as EBRD seeks reforms
fields.trailText: The French treasury director, civil servant Jean Lemierre, who will today be voted in as next president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is expected to put Russia at the top of his agenda.
fields.body:
The French treasury director, civil servant Jean Lemierre, who will today be voted in as next president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is expected to put Russia at the top of his agenda.

The decision to appoint him will be taken by the bank's governors at the annual meeting in Riga, but Mr Lemierre's appointment has been regarded as a foregone conclusion since he won the backing of the EU countries last month.

Mr Lemierre will be the third Frenchman to hold the bank's presidency since it was set up in 1991. He takes over from Germany's Horst Köhler - the only non-Frenchman to hold the top EBRD job - following the latter's appointment as head of the International Monetary Fund.

Mr Lemierre, regarded as one of France's top economic civil servants, will take over at the EBRD at a critical time.

The bank is facing a series of challenges, from rebuilding its operations in Russia after running up provisions of more than €500m (£295m) in the wake of the country's financial crisis in 1998 to making more money available to economies which have been slower to reform than EU membership front runners such as Poland, Hungary and the Czech republic. The bank is also facing the tricky question of aid for the Ukraine in exchange for the closure of the nuclear power station at Chernobyl.

Mr Lemierre will also have to work out the bank's relations with other lenders such as the European Investment Bank, which has a mandate to help countries in their run-up to joining the EU, and the World Bank, which is involved in helping to rebuild war-torn economies in the Balkans.

But Mr Lemierre shrugs off questions about overlapping operations. fields.headline: One down, one to go
fields.standfirst:
Hillary Clinton faces a new challenger

Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: The departure from the fray of Rudy Giuliani, the tough-talking, crime-busting mayor of New York, should be good news for Hillary Clinton, the hard-hitting, precedent-setting wife of America's soon to be ex-president.
fields.body:
The departure from the fray of Rudy Giuliani, the tough-talking, crime-busting mayor of New York, should be good news for Hillary Clinton, the hard-hitting, precedent-setting wife of America's soon to be ex-president.

Mr Giuliani dropped out of the race for a US senate seat at the weekend because a) he has been diagnosed with prostate cancer and b) his marriage has broken up amid highly scandalous recrimination. This dramatic denouement was greeted with almost universal gloom by New Yorkers who enjoy a good old Madison Square Garden-style punch-up and had been promised the political fight of the century. The First Lady was quick to wish her floored opponent a speedy recovery (after the bell). Then she carried on campaigning, the instant frontrunner in a contest which until now has been too close to call. They call it the luck of the Clintons.

All the same, Democratic party celebrations may be seriously premature. Like the Zulus at Isandlwana, no sooner is one Republican down than another rises in his place. New York congressman Rick Lazio, complete with "Born Here; Raised Here" posters, jokes about "limousine liberals" and a reputation for rough-house, has moved swiftly to fill the breach. An Italian-American, Mr Lazio, aged 42, fancies himself (he has, as they say, movie-star looks) and his chances.

More even than Mr Giuliani, he will try to make Mrs Clinton (and her husband, whom he voted to impeach) the big issue, backed by nationwide cash from Clinton-haters; he will hammer away at her out-of-state origins; and he will exploit the ambivalence about her candidacy expressed by key voter groups, including the Jewish community, white males, and suburban voters. Mr Lazio is no better known in upstate New York than he is in Yorkshire. But the first post-Giuliani poll shows the Republican already attracting 32% support (to Mrs Clinton's 46%). Not bad after two days on the stump. This one ain't over yet. No, ma'am.

webTitle: Happy drug Prozac can bring on impulse to suicide, study says

fields.headline: Happy drug Prozac can bring on impulse to suicide, study says
fields.standfirst: As best-selling pill is prescribed by GPs for ever more sufferers from mild depression, research brings disturbing evidence to light
fields.trailText: Alarming evidence from a new British study shows that the Prozac class of antidepressants can make healthy men, women and children with no history of depression feel suicidal.
fields.body:
Alarming evidence from a new British study shows that the Prozac class of antidepressants can make healthy men, women and children with no history of depression feel suicidal.

The research undermines the claims of Eli Lilly, makers of Prozac, that people who kill themselves while on the tablets do so because of their depression, and that the disease, not the drug, is to blame for their suicide.

Its findings are particularly worrying because of the increasing numbers of people, including children, who are being given the drugs by their GP for mild depression, and who are not seriously clinically ill.

Prozac, the wonder pill of the 1980s and 1990s, became the biggest drug company blockbuster of all time, prescribed to more than 38m people around the world. It became a metaphor for late 20th century life and a cult in its own right, enshrined in a book called Prozac Nation.

What began as a medicine for the clinically depressed has been transformed by use and demand into a pill for minor ills.

But while the happy drug works for many people, in a significant number it can take them to the edge of despair. The study, conducted by David Healy, director of the North Wales Department of Psychological Medicine, reveals the real dangers for some of the SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), as Prozac and its imitators are called.

Nightmare

It found that two out of 20 healthy volunteers on an antidepressant in the Prozac class called Lustral (or Zoloft in the USA) became dangerously suicidal, compared with none of them when they were put on an antidepressant of a different class called reboxetine.

One 30-year-old woman who took part had a nightmare about having her throat slit after one week and by the end of a fortnight, was suicidal. "She felt hopeless and alone. It seemed that all she could do was to follow a thought that had been planted in her brain from some alien force. She suddenly decided she should go and throw herself in front of a car, that this was the only answer.

"It was as if there was nothing out there apart from the car, which she was going to throw herself under. She didn't think of her partner or child," says the study, published in the journal Primary Care Psychiatry.

Later she completed a diary entry, describing herself as jumpy, anxious and suspicious. "Her mind was racing and spiralling out of control. Then it went blank except for the clear thought that she must kill herself violently by throwing herself beneath a car or a train."

Dr Healy says the results of the research should be a warning to GPs prescribing any SSRIs. "They may not all be equally the same," he told the Guardian. "But the risk holds for the whole of the group. Generally the findings would indicate that women and children and those who are least ill may be most at risk."

All the drugs have been licensed as both safe and efficacious on the basis of data from clinical trials. But Dr Healy believes that there are serious problems with the reporting of side-effects in these trials, and that this has allowed drugs to be handed out to millions around the globe without their true risks being understood.

Volunteers taking part in the early trials were never asked whether they experienced any suicidal feelings or the restless agitation which can be the precursor of a suicide attempt. If patients in later trials said they felt suicidal, it was recorded as part of their depression.

Dr Healey has written to the Medicines Control Agency, which licences medicines in the UK, expressing his concern and pointing out that he believes patients who today become suicidal on SSRIs are in a state of "legal jeopardy".

Firms are using data from trials that were not designed to look at suicidality to prove that their drugs could not have caused it. Until the system for reporting side-effects is changed, he questions whether anybody should take part in clinical trials.

The new study's findings have emerged at a time of acute embarrassment for Eli Lilly. Its patent on Prozac (fluoxetine), is soon to expire, but it recently bought the licence for a second version of the drug, called R-fluoxetine. The patent for the new drug, it has just been revealed in the US, states that R-fluoxetine is improvement on Prozac specifically as it is less likely to cause "suicidal thoughts and self-mutilation".

Eli Lilly argues that the patent was filed by the American scientist Martin Teicher and the company Sepracor which devised the new drug.

Mr Teicher, in 1990, was the first to warn that patients on Prozac were becoming suicidal, but Eli Lilly has always dismissed his study on the basis that those patients were suffering chronic depression.

Dr Healy, the UK's leading historian of antidepressant medication who has given evidence against Lilly in litigation in the US, has frequently taken issue with the major study commissioned by the company to persuade the US Food and Drugs Administration that Prozac carried no suicide risk.

Dr Healy has argued there has never been a prospective study and that the retrospective 1991 Beasley study, as it is known, included only a small selection of the trials that had taken place on Prozac.

An internal memo released by Eli Lilly during recent litigation appears to support Healy's argument.

In one of a series of memos, dated August 27, 1990, a UK-based clinician tells Eli Lilly management in Indianapolis that critics will be suspicious of the fact that not all the trials were included and concludes that it gives "the impression that the question of whether fluoxetine provokes suicidal thoughts or not has not been properly considered."

'Killing herself appeared irresistible'

Case A: 30-year-old woman
After a few days on sertraline, she experienced agitation and anxiety, racing thoughts and restlessness, says the study. "Over the first weekend she had a nightmare about having her throat slit so that it gaped open and she imagined she bled to death in the bed." Other versions of the nightmare recurred during the next two nights.

At the start of week two, she remained restless, withdrawn and preoccupied. By Wednesday she was tearful and did not seem herself. "She described swings of emotion, with misery predominating but she was not depressed.

"She was advised to stop taking the drug and agreed to do so. She did not stop. In retrospect, it was almost as if she could not stop herself from taking the tablets."

On Thursday, the study monitors stopped her medication but the effects persisted. "That night she was seriously suicidal... On the Friday she telephoned early in the morning, distressed and tearful after the previous night. Her conversation was garbled. She described almost going out and killing herself."

She described feeling hopeless and alone and becoming obsessed with the idea of throwing herself under a car or perhaps a train.

"This clear thought appeared irresistible and its appearance seemed to put an end to the anxiety. It was trance-like and only broken by a telephone call, which came when she was about to act on the basis of this idea." She remains very disturbed by what happened.

Case B: 28-year-old woman
Within a few days she noticed she had become snappy and more assertive but she was liable to mood swings from cheerfulness to withdrawal. She also reported feeling restless.

She described finding herself in a state where she did not think through the consequences of what she did or said. She did not appear to feel afraid.

Driving home in a car with her mother, she saw a group of teenage boys beside the road who were making obscene gestures. She stopped the car in the middle of moving traffic, went over to them and grabbed one of them, telling him if he did anything like that again she would 'deck' him." Her mother reported that she was extremely frightened.

On two consecutive nights, "while awake or lucidly dreaming" she spent a long period lying in her bed fantasising about hanging herself from a beam across the bedroom ceiling.

She was aware that these thoughts were accompanied by an abnormal lack of concern as to whether her partner, mother or any others might find her.

She is not aware of having comparable thoughts before. The reason she did nothing, she explained afterwards, was because she was a coward and had a vestigial concern about being found by her son. The episode repeated itself the following night.

"There was a strong feeling that while on the drug that in some way she was being controlled and that suicide might happen."

webTitle: Firework safety law foiled by pro-hunt plot

fields.headline: Firework safety law foiled by pro-hunt plot
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Legislation that would have protected thousands of people and animals from firework injuries was blocked by David Maclean, a former Tory Home Office minister, in order to punish Labour MPs who had supported a ban on fox hunting, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Legislation that would have protected thousands of people and animals from firework injuries was blocked by David Maclean, a former Tory Home Office minister, in order to punish Labour MPs who had supported a ban on fox hunting, it emerged yesterday.

A confidential letter written by the former minister and obtained by the Guardian reveals that he orchestrated a plot to wreck the fireworks bill - introduced by Linda Gilroy, Labour MP for Plymouth, Sutton - with Lord Kimball, the deputy chairman of the Countryside Alliance.

The bill, which had the support of the fireworks industry, the police, fire services and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (Rospa), would have introduced new controls over people responsible for public displays and a training programme for people handling fireworks.

It would also have allowed imported fireworks to be traced in Britain and would have empowered Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, to introduce emergency safety regulations to respond to events such as last week's fatal firework warehouse fire in the Netherlands.

In a letter marked "confidential - hunting bill - remaining parliamentary tactics", Mr Maclean, the MP for Penrith and the Border, disclosed his hatred of the fireworks legislation.

"I do not want the fireworks bill to be enacted," it said. "That is nothing to do with hunting tactics, but it is because I think it is a thoroughly bad bill, full of Henry VIII clauses [the powers given to ministers to introduce regulations by order] and, since the government are desperately keen on it, this must be one of the bills they do not get, as punishment for letting their backbenchers play around with hunting."

He goes on: "We will block everything else in the Commons listed for July 3 [the day the fireworks bill was due to be debated] and I think if the government only get seven reasonably small private members bills this session, they might begin to realise the consequences of their supporters toying with anti-hunting bills."

He tells Lord Kimball: "How you deal with fireworks [the bill] is up to you; I am happy for it to die in the Lords or come back to us behind two or three other bills so that we run out of time for it in Commons consideration of Lords' amendments."

Later, he adds: "I know you will suitably hold up fireworks."

The disclosure of the confidential letter yesterday shocked the bill's original promoter, Ms Gilroy, other Labour MPs and the firework industry.

They admitted yesterday they had no idea that Mr Maclean and Lord Kimball had orchestrated the blocking of the bill in July 1998.

Mr Maclean, who was present during the proceedings that "talked out" the fireworks bill, played only a minor role with one intervention. The main MPs against the measure were Eric Forth, the Tory MP for Bromley, who opposes all private legislation; Edward Leigh, the Tory MP for Gainsborough; and Tim Collins, the Tory MP for Westmorland.

Because the hunting bill was behind the firework bill when it reached the Commons, it never got debated and therefore collapsed.

Richard Burden, Labour MP for Birmingham, Northfield, said last night: "Given that this bill would have helped to reduce serious injuries among children and animals... I find [the blocking of] this bill, to help people who chase foxes, was nothing less than contemptible."

John Woodhead, who helps lobby for change in the industry, said: "If this bill had become law it would certainly help ministers now to deal with any regulation changes that might be necessary after the disastrous fireworks warehouse explosion in Holland.

"Last year serious injuries from fireworks rose again - and this bill would have helped keep them down."

Ms Gilroy said: "I would not believe that a former Home Office minister would stoop to such tactics. It is the unacceptable face of public schoolboy games played to protect blood sports."

The Guardian twice tried to contact Mr Maclean, but he was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Guerrilla artists make a splash at Tate Modern

fields.headline: Guerrilla artists make a splash at Tate Modern
fields.trailText: The new home of British modern art, Tate Modern, was yesterday targeted by a pair of "guerrilla artists" who claimed to have urinated on an 80-year-old work by Marcel Duchamp.
fields.body:
The new home of British modern art, Tate Modern, was yesterday targeted by a pair of "guerrilla artists" who claimed to have urinated on an 80-year-old work by Marcel Duchamp.

Yuan Cai and JJ Xi last made the news when they stripped and jumped on Tracey Emin's Turner Prize nominated Bed in October 1999.

Appropriately, the work involved yesterday, entitled Fountain, is in fact a urinal. The pair claimed that the purpose of their action was to "celebrate the spirit of modern art".

A spokeswoman at the Tate Modern's information desk said she had no knowledge of the incident.

But Katie Hill, spokeswoman for the two artists, said she had photographs and a video to prove their claims.

The men said that they walked into the room which contained Duchamp's Fountain, lowered their trousers, urinated, and left.

Bemused onlookers in the room applauded, thinking that they had just seen an officially planned performance. The artists claim that after their performance, which lasted about a minute, the Tate closed the room to the public but made no attempt to apprehend them.

"There were no security guards and they just got away with doing it," Ms Hill said.

The men, who both live in London, said they targeted the piece by the French modern artist because it was itself the centre of controversy when it was first exhibited in 1917.

fields.headline: Crane collapse
fields.standfirst: Three workmen die in tangle of steel
fields.trailText: Three workmen were killed yesterday when a crane snapped in half and its giant steel arm and cabin crashed 135 metres to the ground near Canary Wharf tower, London.
fields.body:
Three workmen were killed yesterday when a crane snapped in half and its giant steel arm and cabin crashed 135 metres to the ground near Canary Wharf tower, London.

One man was in the cabin and the other two were on a platform outside. They were extending the arm when the accident happened just after 4pm. They had not been named last night.

As the structure crashed to the ground it collided with a second, smaller crane, which was unoccupied.

Three workman on the ground suffered minor injuries from the falling debris, and were treated mainly for shock, firefighters said.

Investigators from the health and safety executive went to the scene, where the men had been involved in building a new headquarters for the HSBC bank.

A witness, Nigel Beswetherick, 29, had been working in Canary Wharf tower at the time.

He said: "I heard this really loud noise like steel being snapped or broken. I looked out of the window and saw the top half of the crane snapped off and falling through the air.

"I didn't see the workmen at the time, but I had seen them earlier on.

"When it hit the ground it sounded like a bomb going off. I was in a state of shock, just wondering if there had been anybody on it or anybody underneath."

Other workers leaving the building said the spot where the crane arm had fallen would during a weekday have been bustling with people.

Yesterday evening police were clearing onlookers and cordoning off the area where the remains of the crane arm, a smashed tangle of red painted steel, lay sprawled across a normally busy thoroughfare.

The tower of the crane remained standing exactly as it had been before the accident.

Firefighters said the scene was being preserved intact for investigators.

Assistant Divisional Officer Dave Hoxey, of the London Fire Brigade, speaking at the scene, confirmed that three men had died and that their relatives had been informed.

fields.headline: Change of heart
fields.standfirst:
Richard Stone, an adviser on the Lawrence inquiry, on a rethinking of double jeopardy

Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Tory politicians and some media are suddenly demanding that the Stephen Lawrence inquiry's recommendation on double jeopardy must be implemented at once. Yet these same people made virulent attacks on this recommendation when our report was launched a year ago.
fields.body:
Tory politicians and some media are suddenly demanding that the Stephen Lawrence inquiry's recommendation on double jeopardy must be implemented at once. Yet these same people made virulent attacks on this recommendation when our report was launched a year ago.

Of the 70 recommendations we made in the Lawrence report, 63 were firm statements, beginning: "We recommend that..." The recommendation on double jeopardy is one of seven that start "We recommend that consideration be given to..." This one goes on: "to the Court of Appeal being given power to permit prosecution after acquittal where fresh and viable evidence is presented". We had no doubt about the 63 firm recommendations. On prosecution after acquittal, our recommendation is tentative. This is because Sir William Macpherson, the former High Court judge who chaired the inquiry, was well aware of the long-standing rule in English law that after acquittal there should be no risk of people being hounded by the threat of further charges for the same offence.

However, we could not ignore the situation left at the end of our inquiry. It seems very possible that one at least of the three men acquitted of Lawrence's murder is the murderer. His freedom can be attributed to the collective failure of the Metropolitan Police murder investigation. We could anticipate the likelihood of fresh evidence appearing that was strong enough to secure a conviction.

We could not ignore the gross injustice of leaving him beyond the law. Take the case of the black doctor Joan Francisco. During the original investigation into her murder, police overlooked a small spot of blood on her red jumper. Her family thought her former boyfriend was the killer, but there was insufficient evidence to justify his prosecution. A second police investigation a year later found the spot and DNA testing matched it to her ex-boyfriend. He was convicted of the murder. Had he been prosecuted after the first investigation, he would have been acquitted. It seems unthinkable that he could not have been re-tried after the blood was found.

Our tentative recommendation recognises the difficulties in changing a long-established right under English law. However, the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, implemented our recommendation swiftly by referring it to the Law Commission. To our critics' surprise, the Commission suggested the law be changed in line with our recommendation. This is now out for consultation. What is likely to happen is that, in carefully selected cases and on one occasion only, the High Court will be able to refer cases like this for re-trial. There will be a right of appeal for the previously acquitted person.

Why the unreasoning dismissal of the whole Stephen Lawrence inquiry, based on one or two tentative recommendations arising from the special facts we faced? Many have good reason to feel defensive about the conclusions we drew from the evidence presented to us. Could it be that underpinning the attacks was an unwillingness to address institutional racism? Was it really the inquiry which caused the recent loss of morale within the police and a loss of trust by the public in the police? Or was it the facts of the Lawrence police investigation which six years later were laid bare for the public to see?

Most people who read and saw in the media what we heard and saw recognised that two serious injustices were done to Neville and Doreen Lawrence. The appalling racist murder of their son was one. The collective failure of the police to investigate the murder professionally was the other.

Both injustices are connected to the fact that the family is black. This connection is the first step in understanding what institutional racism means. It is to the Lawrences' credit that they have educated the British public to recognise this.

fields.headline: Baby talk
fields.standfirst:
Waxing lyrical about Blair the Younger

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: He did not need to stand on the Downing Street pavement and, like a predecessor in very different circumstances, invite the nation to "rejoice". We were all already delighted. The Blair birth was one of those unalloyed good news stories that pleased people up and down the country and made them happy for mother, new son Leo, and family.
fields.body:
He did not need to stand on the Downing Street pavement and, like a predecessor in very different circumstances, invite the nation to "rejoice". We were all already delighted. The Blair birth was one of those unalloyed good news stories that pleased people up and down the country and made them happy for mother, new son Leo, and family.

So far a balance has been struck between the Blairs' legitimate demand for privacy and the public's desire to know (and see). Alastair Campbell realises the media beast has to be fed and much cooing over baby pictures can be expected when he presents the opportunity. The prime minister walks a fine line. Leading a government deemed too clever by half on the publicity and image front, he knows that if he is seen to be cashing in on the genuine feelings of goodwill generated by the arrival of his new son, he will be blamed. Number 10, the soap, may get good viewing figures, but it is instructive how little Mrs Blair's pregnancy has insulated Labour, or Mr Blair's personal ratings, from loss.

No amount of public appreciation of her qualities (as woman, lawyer and mother) or his infectious love and enthusiasm will stop the ordinary operations of political opinion-forming, hospital waiting lists, school roofs and all. In the era of Lord John Russell, the last prime minister known to have fathered a child while in office, the personal and the political did meet, but only occasionally. Now, it is going to be very hard not to look to Blair family circumstances for evidence on a number of hot policy topics, especially the protection and support offered by the state to mothers and the obligations of employers to female (and male) staff with children.

Occupying Number 10 is a one-off and it would be unfair to generalise. But the birth does focus attention on the balance between work and "life" and what the state should do to regulate employment. The third way has, until now, too often been the free market liberal way, implying that the employer's right to squeeze family life was a necessary condition of prosperity. The economy will collapse - so the government seems to say - if the European Union parental leave directive is allowed to apply now to parents with young children. As Cherie Booth QC said last week, arguing the TUC's case, that is a nonsense. The father of her son, gazing fondly at him, may reflect that his wife's view is also profoundly civilised.
