webTitle: Social care: rescuing a tainted service

fields.headline: Social care: rescuing a tainted service
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Labour should propose to abolish social workers. The idea would win easy headlines and pander to popular prejudice, but also make much sense.
fields.body:
Labour should propose to abolish social workers. The idea would win easy headlines and pander to popular prejudice, but also make much sense.

Rightly or wrongly, the term "social worker" is irredeemably tainted. Associated with political correctness, the failings of municipal socialism and 20 years of care scandals, it is a real deterrent to recruitment into the social care sector. By redefining and renaming the role, the profession could make a fresh start.

The move should be coupled with the extension of care management - as designed for work with elderly people - into children's services. Vulnerable children would in effect have a personal champion, holding a budget and able to commission the services best suited for the individual. For "interfering social worker", read "enabling care manager."

Elsewhere, Labour should drop its resistance to the creation in England of a children's commissioner. Wales is going ahead with the idea, as recommended by the Waterhouse inquiry into abuse in children's homes in north Wales. Ministers have failed to make a convincing case for not following suit.

Giving children their own ombudsman would be a popular and low cost measure, as experience in other countries suggests. It would also draw a welcome line under the horrors of the past.

fields.headline: Enough already
fields.standfirst:
'Woman has baby' rates, as a non-story, along with 'man has sex with wife'. Why should the Blairs be different?

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: 'Woman has baby' rates, as a non-story, along with 'man has sex with wife'. Why should the Blairs be different?
fields.body:
Haven't you been longing to see the first picture? Baby Leo, that is, the first infant born to a serving prime minister since the 19th century. Is that Tony's nose? Cherie's mouth? The Blairs' fourth child has arrived to instant celebrity, with the world's media falling over each other to get that must-have first shot.

For the moment, pop stars and footballers can take a back seat. Yesterday's Sunday Mirror led the pack, devoting 13 pages to its "souvenir edition" - pretty impressive for a human being whose biography, to date, would barely fill the back of a postcard. But the really big question, the one nobody is supposed to ask at a moment like this, is why it merits the kind of coverage which used to be reserved for winning a war or a change of government.

Lots of people may have warmed to the prime minister over the weekend, as he stood outside No 10 with an unforced smile on his face for the first time in months. Yet until very recently, the birth of a child was a private event, a cause for celebration for friends and immediate family but of little interest to the rest of the world.

Royal babies were different, marked by official announcements, but at least they had some constitutional significance. Leo Blair doesn't. Nor does the Blairs' style of parenting have implications for other working mothers and fathers. The prime minister's family is unlike anyone else's; in a country with an increasingly presidential style of government, and with British troops deployed in half a dozen trouble spots, Blair was always unlikely to take full parental leave.

By the same token, his wife was never going to experience the kind of care most of us get from the NHS: cancelled appointments, lost notes, doctors in too much of a hurry to explain what's going on. The myth that there is an ordinary family living in Downing Street is just that - a myth. This is not entirely the Blairs' fault, and they have been at pains to protect their privacy, complaining to the Press Complaints Commission when they think journalists have gone too far.

But they have also blurred the boundaries. Blair revealed on Saturday that he had already changed his first nappy, a detail seized on by reporters intent on portraying the prime minister as an ordinary bloke. The couple have posed with their other children for a Christmas card and even, on one notable occasion, allowed the Downing Street press office to issue a statement about Cherie Blair's weight. In a recent interview with an American magazine, Blair himself divulged his reaction when his wife told him about her latest pregnancy. These are intensely private matters, which is the line Cherie Blair took earlier this year when she sought a draconian ex parte injunction to prevent publication of innocuous details of life in Downing Street which came from her children's former nanny.

Like all celebrities, the Blairs are happy to invade their own privacy when it suits them. Even the fact that Blair has started to wear reading glasses was revealed in an interview with a women's magazine, providing a fascinating glimpse of the kind of discussions which apparently go on in Downing Street. Should we send more troops to Sierra Leone? Should we give the story about Tony's specs to the Sun or Woman's Own?

Now there is Leo, an absolute gift in PR terms. No doubt the Blairs will walk a fine line, trying to avoid accusations of exploitation. Plenty of people noted cynically that news of the pregnancy just happened to leak last autumn in a week when New Labour was getting a terrible press over its handling of Ken Livingstone's attempt to get on the shortlist of candidates for London mayor. But no one should be surprised if the prime minister's popularity, which has dropped alarmingly from Millbank's point of view, bounces back in the next few weeks.

In fact, the Blairs don't need to do anything much but sit out the media frenzy. "Woman has baby" surely rates, as a non-story, with "man has sex with wife". But it is a wonderful excuse for self-regarding columnists to regale us with their experience of having a baby in their 40s, basking in reflected glory. "One of the Blairs' old friends, who also became a father again at 47, offers a few words of advice", the Mail on Sunday boasted yesterday.

Only a culture obsessed with famous people, simultaneously convinced they are just like us and almost mystically different, could get into such a state about something as ordinary as Leo Blair's birth. Or do we? My guess is that millions of readers would be quite content with a one-paragraph announcement, and they are probably the same people who observed with bewilderment the public outpouring of grief in the week of Princess Diana's funeral.

Tabloid culture, which is the natural constituency of celebrity human interest stories, is only one face of modern Britain. It is brash, noisy and ubiquitous, making many of us feel like strangers in our own country. But I'm certain that millions of voters would much rather know when we are going to see real improvements in the NHS than yesterday's hot topic of speculation, the identity of Leo Blair's godparents.

 comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Scrabbling for slogans
fields.trailText: I once worked out, not entirely facetiously, that there are 16 basic propositions which define the law's and the courts' approach to criminals. I say propositions, but some are little more than slogans. Every so often, prime ministers, home secretaries and their shadows dip into this bag of strategies and emerge with what they then describe as a "policy".
fields.body:
I once worked out, not entirely facetiously, that there are 16 basic propositions which define the law's and the courts' approach to criminals. I say propositions, but some are little more than slogans. Every so often, prime ministers, home secretaries and their shadows dip into this bag of strategies and emerge with what they then describe as a "policy".

It's important to understand that the permutations that come out of the bag are purely random, like Scrabble tiles. Recently, for instance, Jack Straw pulled out of the lucky dip "short, sharp shock" (an old favourite) and "prison for repeat offenders, however slight their crimes", to add to his "more tagging" and "life imprisonment means life".

Mr Hague and Ms Widdecombe have just drawn "double jeopardy", "appeals against lenient sentences" and "lock up more children". (They already have "honesty in sentencing".) Luckily for all their electoral chances, there haven't been any recent "long, languid let-offs" (the opposite of short, sharp shocks) or "non-custodial sentences work".

The points I want to make - which will save you hours of unnecessary reading - are that a) there is no such thing as new penal policy, and b) there is no such thing as successful penal policy.

One aspect of Jack Straw's vision deserves further analysis - his plan to appoint prisoners who would only visit their prisons occasionally (under the scheme called PIE - part-time incarceration experience). Mr Straw believes that those picked for PIE should go to jail during office hours, so that they can keep in touch with their families.

On the contrary, says Ms Widdecombe, they must be imprisoned at night, so that they can have day jobs that earn them money, otherwise they'd just go out robbing and thieving. The flaw in the Widdecombe plan is that it doesn't leave much time for the offender to be with his loved ones, whereas the Straw formula evokes a vision of a happy home around the fireside, which, however, would lack a fire, due to poverty.

May I suggest a Third Way? Prisoners would attend their jails twice a day - at breakfast time (the petit déjeuner stretch, as it's known in our penal establishments) and again for the Late Afternoon Tea Hour. In between they'd work, and at night they'd go home. At two hours a day, it would, unfortunately, take 12 years to work off a 12-month sentence (OK, six years with remission) but, hey, we really need to get crime under control. The alternative is to have "hot cells", occupied by happily married cons during the day and by single, separated and unloved criminals by night.

I just thought you ought to know how much you've been missing by not being a clever, young solicitor. A survey by the magazine Legal Business found that at least a dozen American law firms in London are paying newly qualified lawyers, just out of their training, more than £78,000 a year starting salaries. Some are in the £100,000 range. This is for someone who may be only 24 years old.

By contrast, the top City of London firms tend to pay in the £42,000 area. So is there a flow of bright young talent to the American firms? And how. I say propositions, but some are little more than slogans. Every so often, prime ministers, home secretaries and their shadows dip into this bag of strategies and emerge with what they then describe as a "policy". It's important to understand that the permutations that come out of the bag are purely random, like Scrabble tiles. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: When someone asked Franz Berwald about his profession he was told "I'm a glassblower". Up to a point. Berwald also ran a sawmill, practised orthopaedics, worked as a publisher and pioneered physiotherapy. Earlier he had been an orchestral violinist, and is now featured as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3).
fields.body:
When someone asked Franz Berwald about his profession he was told "I'm a glassblower". Up to a point. Berwald also ran a sawmill, practised orthopaedics, worked as a publisher and pioneered physiotherapy. Earlier he had been an orchestral violinist, and is now featured as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3). Though regarded nowadays as Sweden's foremost 19th- century Romantic, his countrymen managed to ignore his musical output for most of his life. Donald Macleod sets the record straight.

It's 100 years since the Cambridge zoologist William Bateson rediscovered the work on heredity done by an obscure Moravian monk. Gregor Mendel's 44-page account of painstakingly cross-breeding peas had been published in a learned journal 35 years earlier - and then forgotten. In the Book Of The Week: A Monk And Two Peas (9.45am, Radio 4) Robin Marantz Henig unravels the experiments which led on to the human genome project. Liza Ross and Michael Williams are the readers.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Sarah Jessica Parker in Flight Of The Navigator (Randal Kleiser, 1986)
fields.body:
Sarah Jessica Parker in Flight Of The Navigator (Randal Kleiser, 1986)

Who? Parker, the equine star of TV show Sex And The City, started acting young. In fact, her first gig was playing Annie in the original Broadway show. Her film work hasn't all been particularly inspiring (The First Wives Club, Hocus Pocus) but she's worked with Tim Burton on Ed Wood and Mars Attacks! and appears in David Mamet's forthcoming State And Main. She dated Robert Downey Jr for seven years, but is now married to Matthew Broderick, who she recently starred with in a Broadway revival of How To Succeed In Business Without Really Trying.

The role: Carolyn McAdams, a remarkably perky NASA assistant, who looks after David Freeman (Joey Cramer), a 12-year-old boy who vanished for eight years and then turned up again, still 12 years old. He's been on an intergalactic space mission, but you try telling that to Mom and Pop.

Best line: To David, when he's first brought to NASA's headquarters: "So, who did you murder to get put here in maximum security?"

Cringe factor: Middling. The hideous 80s hairdo might be somewhat regrettable for someone who now has such a high-fashion "look".

Other wannabes: Child actor Joey Cramer appeared as Young Broud in The Clan Of The Cave Bear in 1986 but hasn't acted since. And the voice of the robot, while credited to Paul Mall, is actually Paul (Pee Wee Herman) Reubens.

Critical Judgement: The ever-ebullient Leonard Maltin said it was "Yet another film featuring a youthful hero and a cute robot; adequate entertainment for kids."

Also not starring in: TV show Square Pegs in 1982, and as Rusty in 1984's Footloose.

Flight Of The Navigator, Sci-Fi, Sun May 28, 2pm

fields.headline: See no evil
fields.trailText: Apart from tuning in to Question Time and switching to ITV at 10pm in order to get upset at News At Ten not being there, politicians tend to make a point of being too busy to watch television. But they will be scrabbling for cassettes of Brits (Wednesday, 9.30pm, BBC2), the high-class series - reported by Peter Taylor, produced by Sam Collyns - which completes, after Provos and Loyalists, a documentary trilogy about paramilitary and military operations in Ulster during the Troubles.
fields.body:
Apart from tuning in to Question Time and switching to ITV at 10pm in order to get upset at News At Ten not being there, politicians tend to make a point of being too busy to watch television. But they will be scrabbling for cassettes of Brits (Wednesday, 9.30pm, BBC2), the high-class series - reported by Peter Taylor, produced by Sam Collyns - which completes, after Provos and Loyalists, a documentary trilogy about paramilitary and military operations in Ulster during the Troubles.

This week's second episode is the most important and contentious journalistically - investigating whether a shoot-to-kill policy was used against the IRA - and, for that reason, has not been released for preview. But although the power of this series is its verbal revelations, there's an intriguing visual aspect for the student of television.

Whereas print journalism can give anonymity to sources very easily - so easily that the person quoted may in some cases not even exist - TV, a medium dominated by the facial close-up, needs to be more inventive in disguising speakers.

In the first phase of television journalism, anonymous witnesses were simply unlit, uttering their dangerous phrases from the dark part of the room or studio. A later variation (still in use) was to shoot the back of their heads: a phrase imbued with nervous irony for gangsters and terrorists fearing retaliation. Technical advances brought the faces of shimmering patchwork squares known as pixillation.

All these techniques are distracting: our expectation in conversation is to see the lips and eyes of the speaker. In Brits, producer Collyns impressively turns journalistic necessity to artistic advantage by using tight close-ups of the eyes and mouths of his unknown soldiers so that - not inappropriately for an Irish series - the effect is of a Samuel Beckett play. It's the least important aspect of the series, but indicates that it understands the cruel new rule of current affairs television: the interest and attention of the audience can't be assumed.

webTitle: Why the real Gordon Brown should stand up

fields.headline: Why the real Gordon Brown should stand up
fields.standfirst:
Debate Robin Marris

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago I attended a lecture by Gordon Brown - an apparently detailed account of his philosophy and policies. Yet for all practical purposes this speech does not exist.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago I attended a lecture by Gordon Brown - an apparently detailed account of his philosophy and policies. Yet for all practical purposes this speech does not exist.

Although a thousand people were present it is unlikely that many will remember the salient points from the six-page document because they were not given a copy. You can get it from the Treasury website, but how many will do that? As for the press, there were the usual leaks plus a full copy on the day.

The results were derisory. If the Guardian made any mention of the lecture, I missed it. The Financial Times was concerned only with points of interest to the City; the Times only in interpreting the chancellor's Delphic remarks about the exchange rate; the Telegraph did not report it but ran a leader saying that at last Mr Brown had flown his true colours - a skull and crossbones for the middle classes.

The document was marked, "check on delivery", but where will a future historian find the fact that the speaker, departing from his text, said: "Full employment is now within our grasp"? Or that "in the past 20 years, unemployment has been the primary cause of poverty in Britain today"? Or that he implied that the child poverty that exists today was directly caused by the Tories?

The chancellor wants to halve child poverty in 10 years and eliminate it in 20. Since children mostly live in families, reducing child poverty means much the same thing as reducing general poverty.

So here we have a finance minister apparently undertaking to roll back the last 20 years of social history and attempt to restore a golden age of full employment, low inflation, rising productivity and a steadily increased share of the national income going to the lowest income groups.

How could such a pronouncement sink without trace? The culprit is the prophet. His 3,500 closely reasoned words contain no summary. It is also full of pink herrings - pink, not red, because they are not so much diversionary as distracting.

On the first page, for instance, he speaks only of high rather than full employment and then only in the context of his familiar precondition, namely low inflation.

Many commentators are writing on the theme of New Labour's lack of courage in its convictions. It seems to fear that those convictions are election losers. But the critics say that the true election loser may be that attitude itself.

Yet in truth, whether he himself fully understands it, Mr Brown's core philosophy is quite clear, and runs as follows: "Contrary to the beliefs of old socialists the capitalist system has proved a remarkable en gine of production, innovation and growth. Left to itself, however, the system has two crippling defects: it cannot maintain full employment and it often creates monopoly rather than competition.

"Consequently the system cannot sustain an acceptable balance between the economic interests of the successful or fortunate members of society, on the one hand, and the less advantaged on the other. Therefore, in one way or another, the government must intervene. The debate is not about ends, but means."

Thus Mr Brown is implying that the essential task of government is to seek powerful methods of correcting the system's defects without throwing away the baby with the bath water, that is, without destroying business incentives.

That is actually all inherently radical. On one side it implicitly denies the rhetoric of the old left, who tended to speak as if the bath water contained no baby at all. On the other, it explicitly denies the ideological non-interventionism of Mrs Thatcher's alleged gurus, such as Friedrich A von Hayek.

If it is what Gordon Brown believes, why not say so? More precisely, why does he not set out his positive framework first, letting the detail follow?

If he did, the detailed policies also described in his lecture would fall into place, look and be impressive, and do much to restore respect and enthusiasm for New Labour over the political spectrum.

Robin Marris is emeritus professor of economics at Birkbeck College

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Strangers On A Train
fields.body:
Strangers On A Train

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1951)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Black-hearted thriller, with Hitchcock's tongue even more firmly in cheek than usual. Part-written by Raymond Chandler from the novel by Patricia Highsmith, the story has tennis player Guy (Farley Granger) meeting apparently sane Bruno, who suggests a murder swap: he will top Guy's troublesome wife if Guy will reciprocate in the case of his father, the logic being that the police will never trace the killers. Some wonderfully wry scenes, including one of Hitch's nastiest murders - at the fairground.

The Killer Elite

(1975, Sam Peckinpah)

9pm, Carlton Cinema

Thinly veiled portrait of the CIA's dirty-tricks department, with James Caan double-crossed and nearly paralysed in the first five minutes. Recuperating with the help of a friendly nurse and some rooftop kung fu, he's back in the game, looking for revenge. A paranoid tale that entertains while never really breaking into a sweat.

Copycat

(Jon Amiel, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Another addition to the now-passé serial-killer strand but with a neat twist... the devious culprit imitates the modus operandi of people like the Boston Strangler. Paired against him are Sigourney Weaver as a criminal psychologist traumatised after surviving an attack, and smart cop Holly Hunter. Well acted, nasty but very effective tale.

Event Horizon

(Paul Anderson, 1997)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

It's 2047, and a little band of spacepeople are investigating starship Event Horizon, which has suddenly reappeared after seven years. The ship, they discover, has been to hell and back, and brought something devilish with it. Starts out quite intriguingly, with performers such as Captain Laurence Fishburne, intense Doctor Sam Neill and Joely Richardson beefing up what becomes pure hokum, a sci-fi movie drifting in the void somewhere between Solaris and Lost In Space.

fields.headline: Poetry in motion
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: The sinking feeling that usually accompanies documentaries about gifted disabled children was entirely absent from Tito's Story (BBC1, Sunday), a hardnosed and utterly disarming study of autism.
fields.body:
The sinking feeling that usually accompanies documentaries about gifted disabled children was entirely absent from Tito's Story (BBC1, Sunday), a hardnosed and utterly disarming study of autism. Eleven-year-old Tito lives in Bangalore and spends much of his time in a rigorous programme of education with his mother Soma, the very embodiment of tough love. She gets him to his desk every morning, puts him through his academic paces and battles with his inability to concentrate - then, lessons over, she takes him out on pleasure trips that more closely resemble military exercises. It works, though; instead of sitting in his room unable to communicate, like many autistic children, Tito writes articulate and occasionally profound poetry, showing verbal skills far greater than the average 11-year-old.

Chris Terrill's film followed Tito and Soma through the weeks preceding a trip to London at the invitation of the National Autistic Society. Tito, in full hyper mode, caused havoc at school. Eventually, in a three-way interview with Terrill and a therapist, with Soma "translating" his garbled words where necessary, Tito blurted out the root of his anxiety. "Will the audience laugh at me? Do I look mad?" The answer, of course, was no - by this time Terrill's methods had taken us to the heart of Tito's world, and we could ignore the surface twitches and see, instead, an intelligence of seemingly unlimited potential.

Terrill is a clever operator; whatever his subject (HMS Brilliant, Soho Stories) he uses minimal technical resources to get close to the core in double-quick time. While so many documentaries substitute flashy effects for insight, Terrill's low-tech approach focuses relentlessly on the human experience. And in Tito, as in previous productions, he struck gold. The psychiatrists at the National Autistic Society, professional sceptics to a woman, sat in awe as Tito riffed through a few spontaneous poems and then casually demonstrated his understanding of words like "marsupial", "geriatric" and "prestigious". By the time his attention ran out and he went haring off to the kitchen to play with the light switches, the experts were staring in slack-jawed disbelief at this prodigy, struggling to reconcile Tito's typically autistic behaviour with his profound verbal insights.

Art Malik intoned Tito's poems with a suitable degree of artlessness, but it was Tito himself who stole the show. Driving into London in a taxi, he asked the driver: "Where are your cows?" After his triumphant demonstration to the doctors, he announced: "I deserve a biscuit." In the hands of a lesser director, this might have been mawkish fare, but Terrill kept sentiment at bay and chose merely to observe. It was more than enough.

Technique sadly interposed itself between viewer and subject in BBC2's Saturday night offering, Arena: The Veil . What set out to be an exploration of Muslim women and their attitude towards "hijab", the covering of the head and face, lost itself in a welter of visual trickery. Film was seen spooling through edit suites, video footage was reshot in close-up to fragment the image. Perhaps this was meant to make a point about an image-obsessed media, or perhaps something entirely different. Perhaps the producer was just obsessed by the edit suite.

This was a shame, because the subject of hijab is intriguing to Muslim and non-Muslim viewers alike, arousing puzzlement and passion in equal measure. The thoughts of young Muslim women who had chosen to wear the veil hinted at a vast range of hidden experience, ranging from religious mysticism to downright fear. "You have to protect yourself - the more I cover myself, the less fear I feel," said the voice-over, collated from interviews with a number of subjects who declined, for obvious reasons, to appear on TV. Western women were dismissed as "slaves to their lust - kidding themselves that they are free"; more insightful was the description of concerned non-Muslims who "in their eagerness to free us... become our oppressors". An east London minicab driver recounted a wry story of local women who get into the car in full hijab, then, on their way up west, remove the veil, light up a fag and start putting on make-up. Another anecdote recounted the horror of westernised Muslim parents when their daughter took up hijab, an interesting variation on the old "you're not going out dressed like that" chestnut. "But Mum, it's just a bit of cloth!" replied the daughter, true to the script.

What set out to be an exploration of Muslim women and their attitude towards "hijab", the covering of the head and face, lost itself in a welter of visual trickery. Film was seen spooling through edit suites, video footage was reshot in close-up to fragment the image. Perhaps this was meant to make a point about an image-obsessed media, or perhaps something entirely different. Perhaps the producer was just obsessed by the edit suite. This was a shame, because the subject of hijab is intriguing to Muslim and non-Muslim viewers alike, arousing puzzlement and passion in equal measure. The thoughts of young Muslim women who had chosen to wear the veil hinted at a vast range of hidden experience, ranging from religious mysticism to downright fear. "You have to protect yourself - the more I cover myself, the less fear I feel," said the voice-over, collated from interviews with a number of subjects who declined, for obvious reasons, to appear on TV. Western women were dismissed as "slaves to their lust - kidding themselves that they are free"; more insightful was the description of concerned non-Muslims who "in their eagerness to free us... become our oppressors". An east London minicab driver recounted a wry story of local women who get into the car in full hijab, then, on their way up west, remove the veil, light up a fag and start putting on make-up. Another anecdote recounted the horror of westernised Muslim parents when their daughter took up hijab, an interesting variation on the old "you're not going out dressed like that" chestnut. "But Mum, it's just a bit of cloth!" replied the daughter, true to the script.

fields.headline: You the jury
fields.standfirst: Tonight, viewers are being asked to vote on whether the pilot episode of ITV's new romantic comedy should become a series. What's the verdict going to be?
fields.trailText: Tonight, viewers are being asked to vote on whether the pilot episode of ITV's new romantic comedy should become a series. What's the verdict going to be?
fields.body:
One of the pleasures frequently predicted for viewers of the future is self-scheduling. We will download the programmes from a central tape-base.

Gerald Kaufman will be able to have his News At Ten again. If you think there should be a Saturday edition of Coronation Street, there can be.

But, whether or not we will all one day be schedulers, it's increasingly the case that viewers are commissioners. Although a few shows are still permitted second series, whatever the viewers thought - BBC1's Harbour Lights, ITV's Bob Martin, the latter more deservedly - the scale of the audience now usually decides the fate of shows. Like crowds at a gladiatorial contest, viewers will decide if a series survives.

An unusually blatant invitation to be a commissioning editor for a day comes with I Saw You (Tonight, 10pm, ITV). This one-off comedy-romance is openly advertised as a pilot episode. Light a large cigar, divert all calls and sit back to decide if we're going to commit to this for spring 2001.

We're inevitably interested in the track record of the people who made this. I Saw You comes from the makers of Cold Feet, the middle-class ensemble piece which is the nearest our television has come to emulating the American series thirtysomething.

I Saw You, though, is a lighter piece about two people who are hopeless romantically trying to become hopelessly romantic with each other.

Ben (Paul Rhys) is an optician. He is given this profession because the basic joke is that he never really sees what's going on. In the opening sequence, he prepares a champagne marriage proposal to his girlfriend which she interrupts by telling him she's leaving for someone else. In an amusing spin on the popular theory that a man's car is an extension of his penis, Ben doesn't have one. He has failed the driving test 12 times.

Ben's other running gag is concussion. Being treated in hospital after one bang to the head, Ben briefly sees a knock-out beautiful woman and advertises in a dating magazine for her to contact him. But, amnesia being a side-effect of concussion, Ben has forgotten that he blacked out twice, and the ministering angel who answers the ad belongs to the second neurological episode. She is Grace Bingley, a single mother almost as socially maladept as Ben, played by Fay Ripley, the spiky, whiny-voiced Karen from Cold Feet. Grace's defining characteristic is that she says cutting and frightening things which she then reveals to have been a joke.

Efficiently but predictably, the scene is set for a comedy of clumsy courtship. There is one very good post-sex joke, although it owes a lot to Four Weddings And A Funeral. The couple's go-between is Ben's driving instructor Frank (Jeff Rawle) and the episode concludes with a farce sequence involving Grace on a bicycle and Ben taking his 13th driving test.

Much of this is smartly done and the Bristol setting is well presented.

But we know - even as our cigar trembles with occasional merriment - that it isn't enough for a pilot to convince for 50 minutes. Does it, as we say in the industry, have legs? As with any comedy about maladroit lovers, the risk is that the recurring stupidities given to the characters make them irritating rather than distinctive. For all the efforts of Rhys and Ripley to charm, this too often feels like moody wimp meets dippy whinger.

And a pilot should be like a child. Part of what makes you smile now is the possibility of what they'll become. This is the biggest problem with I Saw You. Series about dysfunctional lovers have worked in the past - the sitcom Just Good Friends and two Judi Dench series, A Fine Romance and As Time Goes By - but the will-they-won't-they? plotline is restrictive for a scriptwriter. The couple simply have the same misunderstandings and identical reunions in various rooms using vaguely different phrases.

Influenced by the multi-strand narratives of novels and movies, contemporary television viewers demand more plot and complications: happy couples contrasted with unhappy ones, the private counterpointed by the public. The stand-out drama series of recent years about relationships - This Life, Cold Feet, Queer As Folk, Hearts And Bones - have been ensemble pieces, offering the restless viewer a choice of people and themes.

In contrast, the most recent ITV will-they-won't-they? show - Reach For The Moon - had to be rescheduled to later because of poor ratings. These pieces about two characters trying to haul their emotional baggage on to the same carousel work best as self-contained movies: Sleepless In Seattle, One Fine Day. The tension of romantic wariness only sustains one episode.

It's mainly for this reason that I personally will not be commissioning a series of I Saw You. It should be refiled in the tape library under that face-saving phrase for a failed pilot: Comedy Special.

But I'm a semi-professional in these matters, and the real decision will be made tonight by moguls and impressarios on sofas across Britain. We are all commissioners now.

fields.headline: Marriage of inconvenience
fields.standfirst: Glyndebourne is set for an overhaul under its new regime. Not before time, says  Andrew Clements  , after seeing a lacklustre Figaro open the season
fields.trailText: Glyndebourne is set for an overhaul under its new regime. Not before time, says Andrew Clements , after seeing a lacklustre Figaro open the season
fields.body:
In the efficient, unsensational way in which things are run at Glyndebourne, the old order has passed on. Last April Nicholas Snowman succeeded Anthony Whitworth-Jones as general director, while at the end of last year's festival George Christie handed the chairmanship of the festival to his son Gus. The current season, which opened on Saturday with a new production of Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro, is the last that will involve Andrew Davis as music director and Graham Vick as director of productions.

Snowman and the younger Christie have plans. No replacements for Vick and Davis have yet been announced, and it seems there will be no overall directorial control. Snowman is intent on expanding the repertory, promising to test the capacity of the house with Verdi's Otello and Wagner's Tristan, and to bring more new works into the repertory. Birtwistle's The Last Supper will appear on the tour in the autumn, and for the main festival next year commissions from Peter Eotvos and Thomas Adès are under way, while there will be cycles of early German romantic opera and Monteverdi.

We're promised more of Peter Sellars, but the bulk of the new shows will be entrusted to a nicely contrasted trio of young directors: Richard Jones, Christoph Loy and David McVicar. Instead of a production style defined by one person, as for the past decade, there will be a richer mix. This Figaro shows that it is just about time for those changes. Glyndebourne badly needs new theatrical blood.

With the new Mozarts this season (Don Giovanni follows in July), Davis and Vick complete the trilogy of the Da Ponte operas they began in 1998 with Cosi Fan Tutte, an appropriate way to end their partnership in a house that has always prided itself on its Mozart. But there is little pride to be gained from the new show. On the first night Davis conducted the score rather lumpishly (why has Glyndebourne returned to performing Mozart with a modern orchestra - the London Philharmonic - rather than period instruments?). And if the Cosi was a dull, unperceptive affair, the Figaro continues in the same vein, with a staging that is low on humour, sex and politics.

Richard Hudson's basic set from 1998 - off-white walls and old-fashioned radiators, like a trendy loft conversion - returns, with the specifics of Almaviva's castle suggested by gilded chairs, gauze-panel walls and cut-out doorways, so every entrance is visually anticipated. Apart from a baffling array of cardboard boxes, first impressions are of calm elegance, but with such a monochrome setting the characters need to supply some vitality - and they just don't, though there are two fine performances, one of them life-saving as far as the evening is concerned.

Peter Mattei's Figaro is the star of the evening. Handsome, commanding and vocally expert, he is a natural stage creature; his arias in the first and fourth acts are the moments when the performance really takes wing. But he is surrounded by very average contributions. Christiane Oelze is miscast as Susanna: all she can offer is pert prissiness that is neither physically nor vocally seductive. One wonders why the Count should bother with her, but he is portrayed by Mariusz Kwiecen as a bully with no charm in his manner or his singing. Maria Costanza Nocentini's Countess is striking to behold, rather wan to hear, while Marina Comparato's Cherubino rushes around like a hamster on heat. There are perfectly proficient but utterly conventional depictions of Bartolo and Basilio from Andrew Shore and Ryland Davies, but a fine, glamorous Marcellina from Diana Montague.

In a better production Mattei and Montague would prosper; here the odds are stacked against them. With the surtitles anticipating every joke, and the stage invention contrived and unengaging, there are too few natural laughs, too little real emotion.

In rep till August 7. Box office: 01273 813813.

fields.headline: Easy rider
fields.standfirst: Bizet's sultry cigarette girl is now a garage hand.  Judith Mackrell checks out AMP's new Car Man
fields.trailText: Adventures in Motion Pictures became famous as the dance group who turned Swan Lake into a ballet for the boys. So it comes as no surprise that their latest show The Car Man (directed and choreographed, as always, by Matthew Bourne) involves yet another classic (Bizet's opera Carmen) in yet another drastic change of sex.
fields.body:
Adventures in Motion Pictures became famous as the dance group who turned Swan Lake into a ballet for the boys. So it comes as no surprise that their latest show The Car Man (directed and choreographed, as always, by Matthew Bourne) involves yet another classic (Bizet's opera Carmen) in yet another drastic change of sex.

Instead of being set around a cigarette factory in 19th-century Spain, the story has been relocated to a garage in small town America circa 1960. This means that in place of Bizet's original chorus of feisty, flirty factory girls Bourne has a group of muscled grease monkeys, and instead of a gypsy seductress as the mainspring of the action there is a charismatic drifter called Luca.

But even though Bourne uses Bizet as a starting point (Rodion Shchredin's Carmen Suite intercut with new music by Terry Davies), his staging involves much more than a simple flipping of gender and place. The Car Man's story of cuckoldry, murder and erotic treachery may contain powerful echoes of Carmen, but these collide with resonances from many other sources, including Greek tragedy, Bourne's own Swan lake and Hollywood film noir (hence the dreadful pun of the subtitle: "Auto-erotic Thriller).

This new plot is much too good to give away, but its sharp changes of emotional gear build to a rare edge-of-the-seat urgency. It's also peopled with characters of winning interest and complexity. All this is presented through a body language so bright with wit and so fraught with emotional subtext that it's hard to believe not a line of dialogue has been uttered.

Part of the production credit must go to designer Lez Brotherston, whose recreation of 60s America is so visceral you can almost feel the heat that has the dancers languid with sweat or twitching with sexual energy. Bourne plugs into the macho charge of this scenery with choreography that's especially good for the men. Their group dances are animated with a vernacular wit and pulse. The pivotal duets, violent and erotic, are even better, and bring out performances so intense you sometimes want to look away.

Alan Vincent as Luca is a fine dancer but he brings with him a sense of past history, a patina of grit that has nothing to do with the dance studio. Will Kemp as the frail victimised Angelo dances even better, yet his rarefied moves reveal with startling clarity how this preppy introvert unravels into emotional chaos. Scott Ambler's cuckolded husband, a comic gem of farting, shambling horror, tips just the wrong side of caricature, but the single serious flaw in this otherwise magnificent show is the choreography for the women. Though Michela Meazza as the errant wife looks rivetingly like a white trash version of Sophia Loren, her dance sequences, like those of her wide-eyed, romantic sister, appear girlish and gawky, as if the anatomy of female desire isn't quite in Bourne's range.

But AMP's shows have a good habit of growing and changing when they're out on the road, and The Car Man has a long tour before its London premiere in September. Since it's already so full of dramatic and choreographic juice, it's very likely going to run and run.

The Car Man is at Sheffield Lyceum (0114-249 6000) from Tuesday.

webTitle: 'I now have nine weeks to prepare three pieces I've hardly seen before'

fields.headline: 'I now have nine weeks to prepare three pieces I've hardly seen before'
fields.standfirst: Saxophonist  Simon Cosgrove describes how he reached the finals of the BBC Young Musician of the Year contest
fields.trailText: Saxophonist Simon Cosgrove describes how he reached the finals of the BBC Young Musician of the Year contest
fields.body:
Tonight the BBC will begin broadcasting the finals of the Young Musician of the Year competition. From an original 600 entrants, all under the age of 19, only 25 musicians remain, competing for one of five places in the final concert on Saturday. The winner will receive £2,000 and go on to represent Britain in the Eurovision Young Musician in two weeks' time.

The players who made it to the finals (divided into the categories brass, keyboard, woodwind, percussion and strings) represent some of the very best young musicians in the UK. Apart from fulfilling the basic requirements, such as having passed their Associated Board Grade 8 examination, they have already triumphed in regional auditions, regional finals and national semi-finals - a process that started a year ago. Simon Cosgrove, a saxophonist and A-level student from Pontefract, West Yorkshire, tells how he made it to the national finals, which were recorded by the BBC in February.

May 13, 1999

It was exciting to see the first BBC envelope slip through the letterbox this morning. It was only to let me know that my first round audition is on July 7, but now I know everything is officially underway.

I have to send off a confirmation slip by June 5, otherwise I "risk losing" my audition date. I've already made one such mistake: when entering the competition, I forgot to enclose a copy of my Grade 8 certificate and had to sweet-talk the postman into letting me retrieve the application.

I wasn't even sure whether to enter the competition: a background more in jazz than classical music and no specialist music education didn't seem the ideal cocktail for a competition of such classical prestige. Still, programming was fun. For the first round (a local audition at Leeds University), I've tried to strike a balance between French classical, contemporary and jazz music. Richard Ingham was a great help in that respect - it's great to have a teacher who is not just a sax specialist but also a vigilant and wise competition programmer.

June 5

Had a call from the BBC this morning wondering if I still wanted my audition as I hadn't returned my slip in time - oops. I assured them it would be in the post in minutes, so that wasn't a huge problem, just a bit embarrassing. Meanwhile, practice for July 7 beckons.

July 7

Today was quite an experience. I found communicating my music to a panel of three much more draining and intense than to an audience of thousands who don't have copies of my scores and the eyes of an eagle. It was also strange meeting other competitors in the waiting-room - it felt more like a dentist's surgery than preparation for a competition whose ethos is to give young musicians the chance to perform and be heard. Still, I had my chauffeur and two bodyguards to fuel my enthusiasm, aka my dad and two accompanists (it's hard to find one who is prepared to play both classical and jazz!), and the audition - 15 minutes' worth of music - went well. Perhaps not as well as it might, but the experience was invaluable

July 26

The practice must have paid off because I'm through to the regional finals. I'll have to up my usual practice schedule of about 40 minutes every other day quite a bit. Musically, I'm going for a similar format as round one, although this time I'm including a sprinkling of Baroque to make the blend of genres even more eclectic.

September 23

I was pleased with my performance at Manchester today, especially in view of the difficulties I had finding an accompanist. My usual accompanist had other commitments, so I had to call on good friend and proficient pianist Sam Breuning to fill his shoes. He rose to the challenge well and we were able to nail the pieces, pulling off a successful performance. I reached the regional finals of the competition when I entered in 1997, but I didn't get any further. Nor do I expect to this time, although the experience and determination is always there. It would be nice if I could reach the so-called "safety net", a pool stage in which a few of those who didn't make it straight through to the national semi-finals are re-judged using a tape of their performance. I'll just have to wait and see.

October 2

Ambition achieved - I've reached the safety net!

November 1

It's getting better - I've been picked up from the "safety net" and have reached the national semi-finals, which places me in the top 12 woodwind players in the competition. I've slacked off a bit, but practice will have to take top priority now. I have until December 23 to decide on a programme for the semi-finals. At least I don't have the added worry of finding another accompanist - Chris Ross, provided by the BBC, seems the obvious choice for me.

Over the last few months, because I have had to try out so many pieces (you can only repeat one piece throughout the competition) my knowledge of the repertoire has grown. I also have a deeper understanding of conventional musical forms and how they can be presented.

December 23

Success! I have a place in the finals of what is perhaps the most prestigious competition for young musicians in the UK. Today was drawn-out. I arrived at the Royal Northern College of Music in Manchester at 10 this morning, but wasn't on stage until 9.15pm, which was draining. Still, the weeks of endless practice obviously worked and I'm now facing a guaranteed TV appearance and an all-new finals programme.

A lot of my presuppositions were shattered today, too. I found the BBC Young Musicians team to be incredibly friendly and helpful, and Chris Ross was fantastic. I expected a man who had toured the world more times than I'd washed the dishes at home to be quite eccentric and almost hostile, but he was amazing - musically, and in the way he made me feel at ease while offering constructive criticism.

Programming music for this stage was a feat in itself. I must have spent hours on the phone to my teacher and to the BBC office deciding, then changing, deciding, then changing... I had almost run out of repertoire - suitable saxophone pieces are harder to find than, say, piano pieces - so having to decide on material for the semis and the finals was difficult.

Support from family, friends and teachers has been second to none, while being a comprehensive 6th form college student with no real musical history in the family has generated interest locally. Not going to a private music school does have its drawbacks (such as having to use the freezing college sports hall to produce a makeshift concert hall acoustic), but reaching this far in the competition makes me feel more privileged and determined to succeed.

I now have nine weeks to prepare three pieces that I've hardly seen before, so I'll be practising like mad - two-and-a-half hours' a day is the plan. In fact, the next two months will be incredibly busy - I have a trip to New Orleans with the Doncaster Jazz Orchestra in two weeks plus mock A-levels the week after.

February 24, 2000

Only a matter of hours now until I'm on stage in front of television cameras and an audience of hundreds. The last few weeks have been hectic but rewarding. I've been at the RNCM today having rehearsals with Chris Ross, as well as TV interviews. It sounds daunting, but the BBC Young Musicians team have been incredibly considerate, as has the camera crew. Taking part in this competition has been an experience I'll never forget. Even though I've been privileged enough to reach the finals, I've learned that success doesn't mean winning - in this case it means maturing as a musician and being prepared to communicate your work to an audience in such a way that they are grasped and moved by your playing.

fields.bodyText: Tonight the BBC will begin broadcasting the finals of the Young Musician of the Year competition. From an original 600 entrants, all under the age of 19, only 25 musicians remain, competing for one of five places in the final concert on Saturday. The winner will receive £2,000 and go on to represent Britain in the Eurovision Young Musician in two weeks' time. The players who made it to the finals (divided into the categories brass, keyboard, woodwind, percussion and strings) represent some of the very best young musicians in the UK. Apart from fulfilling the basic requirements, such as having passed their Associated Board Grade 8 examination, they have already triumphed in regional auditions, regional finals and national semi-finals - a process that started a year ago. Simon Cosgrove, a saxophonist and A-level student from Pontefract, West Yorkshire, tells how he made it to the national finals, which were recorded by the BBC in February. May 13, 1999 It was exciting to see the first BBC envelope slip through the letterbox this morning. It was only to let me know that my first round audition is on July 7, but now I know everything is officially underway. I have to send off a confirmation slip by June 5, otherwise I "risk losing" my audition date. I've already made one such mistake: when entering the competition, I forgot to enclose a copy of my Grade 8 certificate and had to sweet-talk the postman into letting me retrieve the application. I wasn't even sure whether to enter the competition: a background more in jazz than classical music and no specialist music education didn't seem the ideal cocktail for a competition of such classical prestige. Still, programming was fun. For the first round (a local audition at Leeds University), I've tried to strike a balance between French classical, contemporary and jazz music. Richard Ingham was a great help in that respect - it's great to have a teacher who is not just a sax specialist but also a vigilant and wise competition programmer. June 5 Had a call from the BBC this morning wondering if I still wanted my audition as I hadn't returned my slip in time - oops. I assured them it would be in the post in minutes, so that wasn't a huge problem, just a bit embarrassing. Meanwhile, practice for July 7 beckons. July 7 Today was quite an experience. I found communicating my music to a panel of three much more draining and intense than to an audience of thousands who don't have copies of my scores and the eyes of an eagle. It was also strange meeting other competitors in the waiting-room - it felt more like a dentist's surgery than preparation for a competition whose ethos is to give young musicians the chance to perform and be heard. Still, I had my chauffeur and two bodyguards to fuel my enthusiasm, aka my dad and two accompanists (it's hard to find one who is prepared to play both classical and jazz!), and the audition - 15 minutes' worth of music - went well. Perhaps not as well as it might, but the experience was invaluable July 26 The practice must have paid off because I'm through to the regional finals. I'll have to up my usual practice schedule of about 40 minutes every other day quite a bit. Musically, I'm going for a similar format as round one, although this time I'm including a sprinkling of Baroque to make the blend of genres even more eclectic. September 23 I was pleased with my performance at Manchester today, especially in view of the difficulties I had finding an accompanist. My usual accompanist had other commitments, so I had to call on good friend and proficient pianist Sam Breuning to fill his shoes. He rose to the challenge well and we were able to nail the pieces, pulling off a successful performance. I reached the regional finals of the competition when I entered in 1997, but I didn't get any further. Nor do I expect to this time, although the experience and determination is always there. It would be nice if I could reach the so-called "safety net", a pool stage in which a few of those who didn't make it straight through to the national semi-finals are re-judged using a tape of their performance. I'll just have to wait and see. October 2 Ambition achieved - I've reached the safety net! I've slacked off a bit, but practice will have to take top priority now. I have until December 23 to decide on a programme for the semi-finals. At least I don't have the added worry of finding another accompanist - Chris Ross, provided by the BBC, seems the obvious choice for me. Over the last few months, because I have had to try out so many pieces (you can only repeat one piece throughout the competition) my knowledge of the repertoire has grown. I also have a deeper understanding of conventional musical forms and how they can be presented. December 23 Success! I have a place in the finals of what is perhaps the most prestigious competition for young musicians in the UK. Today was drawn-out. fields.headline: Guilty until proven innocent
fields.standfirst: Mohammed Patel spent three years in prison for a drug crime. Ten years on, the CPS has conceded that there wasn't a scrap of evidence against him.  Bob Woffinden  reports
fields.trailText: Mohammed Patel spent three years in prison for a drug crime. Ten years on, the CPS has conceded that there wasn't a scrap of evidence against him.  Bob Woffinden  reports
fields.body:
Mohammed Patel's life changed for ever on Sunday, January 18 1987, the day he was ferrying children to his six-year-old daughter's birthday party. Arriving at a house in Rainham, Essex, to pick up two children, he found himself in the middle of a drugs raid.

The police had just found about £1m worth of heroin. They told Patel to send the children home by minicab. They strip-searched him, and took him to be questioned at Romford police station.

Patel stood trial at Snaresbrook Crown Court and was given a four-year prison sentence. His life was in ruins; his promising career as a banker in the City of London was over. This month the Crown finally conceded that there wasn't a scrap of evidence against him.

"When you look at the case in detail," explained his solicitor, Jane Hickman, "you can see that Mr Patel has been let down by every part of the criminal justice system."

Patel, 44, came to this country in 1977 from India and enthusiastically adopted the ways of his host country. He became westernised in every way, and even passed the Lord Tebbit nationality test: he supported England at cricket.

He joined the Muslim Commercial Bank, won a series of rapid promotions and became the bank's accountant. The bank depended on Asian businessmen, and staff were instructed to foster social contacts - which explained Patel's arrival at the house of Mohamedali Ramjanali, later sentenced to 16 years for possessing heroin with intent to supply.

Patel was charged with leaking information prejudicial to their inquiry into the drugs case, suggesting that he had enabled the drug dealers to protect their assets. There were two strands of evidence against him. The first concerned supposed admissions he had made during two interviews. There was no record of the first interview, although there was an ostensibly contemporaneous record of the second.

The second strand of evidence only emerged at trial, when the investigating officer told the jury that "certain inquiries we did make in Lisbon reflected directly communication being made from London by Mr Patel".

This evidence, however damaging, was vague, but it was put in more concrete terms by the judge. In his summing-up, he said that "the investigation had in fact been compromised by information being leaked from London". This embellishment was itself further embellished at appeal by the then Lord Chief Justice, Lord Lane, who commented that the investigation had been "grossly compromised" by the leak.

After his release in 1990, Patel dedicated himself to getting his conviction quashed. He had first been refused permission to appeal in March 1988. In February 1989, a full three-judge court turned down his appeal, but neither Patel nor his lawyers had been informed about the hearing. The appeal was heard again in March 1990, and again turned down.

Hickman's concern was twofold: that her client had been convicted on spurious evidence; and that his barrister had failed to challenge the admissibility of the interviews, and had told Patel he could not criticise the police. Although Patel's instructions throughout were that the police had fabricated the interviews, the barrister told his client to say in the witness box that he "couldn't remember" the key questions and answers, seriously weakening Patel's credibility.

Hickman obtained the records of the second interview and sent them for electrostatic document analysis (ESDA) tests. These proved that, at the critical point, the pages had been re-written, supporting Patel's claims that the self-incriminating remarks were fabricated.

But the Crown Prosecution Service refused to release documents indicating Patel had leaked information, claiming they were protected by public interest immunity (PII) certificates. In June 1993, Hickman urged the Home Secretary, Kenneth Clarke, to refer the case to appeal. The Home Office asked the Police Complaints Authority to supervise an investigation into the case. Its report was delivered in May 1996. Hickman sent a fresh submission to the Home Secretary - by then Michael Howard - and the case was referred to appeal in November 1996.

Innumerable delays followed before the case was finally listed for hearing this month. Forty-eight hours before the hearing on May 11, the CPS finally threw in the towel. They conceded that the judge in his summing-up had misreported what the police officer said, and that what the police officer had said wasn't true. The information that had supposedly been covered by PII for at least the previous eight years simply didn't exist.

"The Crown were prepared to concede that there was no evidence of money movements, that there was no evidence at all of leaking, and that there had been tampering with the interviews," said Hickman. "If they were prepared to concede all that now, why did we have to wait all these years?"

Patel wept quietly in court as his conviction was quashed. "They can't give him back his career, or the 13 years he's lost, or his peace of mind," said Hickman. "I don't know how you can ever compensate anybody for all that."

fields.headline: The man who sculpts buildings
fields.standfirst: Frank Gehry has won the Gold Medal for Architecture - and quite right too, says  Jonathan Glancey  : the man's a genius of design
fields.trailText: Frank Gehry has won the Gold Medal for Architecture - and quite right too, says Jonathan Glancey : the man's a genius of design
fields.body:
Here are some statistics. Approximately 1.3m people visited the Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao in its first year (1997-98) and about 1.1m in its second. Of these, 70 per cent said they came to see the building rather than the art it houses, although this doesn't mean they didn't ultimately enjoy what they saw inside. Between 15 and 16 per cent said they had never visited a museum before - which must be some sort of proof of the magnetic pull of the museum Frank Gehry designed for the Guggenheim and for the Basque capital.

Bilbao has a population of 375,000. If Tate Modern was to woo an equivalent number of visitors proportionate to the population of London, that figure would be in the order of 22m a year. By any measure - numbers, aesthetics, cultural and economic impact on Bilbao, sheer "wow! factor" - the Guggenheim has been a rip-roaring success. Many cities would like a Gehry Guggenheim of their own, not least New York, for which the architect launched an even more radical design for another outpost of the expanding Guggenheim empire a couple of months back.

The Toronto-born architect is on a roll. And now he has won the Royal Gold Medal for Architecture, a gift awarded on behalf of the Queen by the Royal Institute of British Architecture, and still, despite the big bucks attached to newer international prizes, the most prestigious of its kind. The citation reads: "No one who believes in the power of architecture as a creative and artistic force can deny the contribution which has already been made by this master architect who, at the age of 71, is still at the height of his powers as a designer."

He is currently planning or building the Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, the Maggie Jencks memorial cancer care centre, Dundee, and Manhattan's second, if putative, Guggenheim. Each will be a fully operational building and yet each is also a highly striking and idiosyncratic sculpture. Architects working in this way have been rare and not always successful. Quirky buildings are often just that: oddballs, curios, rococo fantasmagoria that quickly pall and become labelled, at best, as the work of wilful eccentrics.

Gehry shares a part of the terrain occupied in the past century by the likes of Antoni Gaudi (the patron saint of Barcelona in all but name, but even that may not be far off), Frank Lloyd Wright (architect of the existing Guggenheim Museum, New York), Le Corbusier in his late, raw concrete days - Gehry was influenced by Corbu's sublime pilgrimage chapel at Ronchamp - and in the work of younger talents such as Daniel Libeskind's Jewish Museum in Berlin last year and Zaha Hadid's forthcoming Museum of Contemporary Art in Rome.

Gehry is not a man to follow conventional wisdom and enjoys talking out of turn. It is fun to hear a great architect tell us that, "Palladio faced a fork in the road, and he took the wrong turn." Could he mean Andrea Palladio, maestro of imposed and superimposed geometry and probably the most influential architect of all time? Sure, says Gehry: "He should have recognised that there's chaos; he should have gone ahead and done what Borromoni did. He would have been a pioneer."

What Francesco Borromoni did was to twist, turn, push, pull and stretch every sinew of the corpus of classical architecture until he had transformed it into something as extraordinary, inimitable and as apparently chaotic as the supra-Baroque church of San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane in Rome. Gehry has done to modern architecture what Borromini did to classical. But he didn't escape from what he saw as the constraints of classical modernism. His way to international fame in the 70s was along the wibbly-wobbly road of post-modernism, mapped out by Robert Venturi in his book Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture and recorded so cleverly by Gehry's own chum Charles Jencks in The Language of Post-Modern Architecture.

Where post-modernism led to a truly complex and contradictory pot-pourri, Gehry created a language of his own, richer yet more lucid with every new project. He is, says his friend Kurt W Forster of the Getty Research Centre, "a player whose desire for acceptance is forever in conflict with his drive for distinction". And in that gap lurks genius.

Like many architectural geniuses, Gehry found conventional study problematic. He didn't get on at graduate school at Harvard, finding it pretentious and doctrinaire. He left to work with various practices in Los Angeles and Paris before building his own famous deconstructed, ragamuffin house in Santa Monica (1977-78) and teaming up with Claes Oldenburg and Richard Serra, among other big-spirited artists. He also began to draw fish, design buildings that looked like fish, and aim at what he sees as the perfection of the fish. This is where Gehry's work needs to be assessed by a psychoanalyst rather than a critic.

But don't be put off by the fishing expedition: you only need to look at the Bilbao Guggenheim, with its titanium scales and long waggling tail to see, if not understand, how Gehry's obsession with fish has led to an architecture everyone is drawn to, as they are by the sight of exotic fish in a brightly lit aquarium. The Fishdance restaurant in Kobe, Japan (1986-87) is just that: a 70ft chain-link mesh fish dances on its tail next to the main building.

Gehry's buildings became increasingly innovative as he gained confidence in the 80s. The Vitra International Design Museum, Weil-am-Rheim, Germany (1987-89) was the first of the real swooping, roller coaster designs that have become the architect's trademark. The Guggenheim followed (1991-97). There have been many others - among at least 250 projects altogether - wrapped around, before, after and in between.

Then there's the furniture, notably the super-curvy bentwood chairs for Knoll and the cardboard stuff for Vitra. There's the Condé Nast cafeteria, New York, the projected city gate entrance to Venice beside the airport, and now the breathtaking Experience Museum Project (1996-2000), nearly complete alongside the Space Needle in downtown Seattle, a music centre shaped loosely in the guise of a shattered Fender Stratocaster and dedicated mostly to the Strat-licks and memory of the late Jimi Hendrix.

Gehry's achievement is a great one. He has given us playful, powerful, memorable and enjoyable buildings that weave together history, popular culture, the obsessions of contemporary art and a belief he shares with the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer, who won the Gold Medal in 1997, that "architecture must be constant invention". He has - most difficult of all for architects - invented a language unmistakeably his own. Solid gold.

fields.headline: Born on the 20th of May
fields.standfirst: Around 2,000 women had babies in Britain on the same day as Cherie Booth. Here, the mothers of 10 of them tell  Joanna Moorhead  how their births went, and of their hopes for the future. The Guardian will be following the fortunes of these families in the months and years to come    2. Conor O'Pants :
fields.trailText: Around 2,000 women had babies in Britain on the same day as Cherie Booth. Here, the mothers of 10 of them tell  Joanna Moorhead  how their births went, and of their hopes for the future. The Guardian will be following the fortunes of these families in the months and years to come
fields.body:
1: Baby McCabe
Born: 6.36am.

Parents: Joanne McCabe and Ian Macmillan, both 29, from Glasgow. They already have a two-year-old son, Cameron. Joanne is a finance assistant with a housing association, and Ian works for a distillery.

At: Royal Maternity Hospital Glasgow.

Care: It's a crowded site, but the new hospital is due to open next year. Like most women in Britain, Joanne had shared care, seeing her GP and a community midwife at alternate check-ups.

The birth: Joanne's pregnancy was straightforward, but as she has rhesus negative blood she was in a "high risk" group. Her waters broke on Friday at 8pm and she went straight to the hospital. The baby was born 10 hours later by ventouse. Joanne expects to have four months' maternity leave, as she did with her son after his birth.

Hopes for the future: "I just hope she has a happy life."
2: Bethany Elliot

Born: 2.05am.

Parents: Claire and Stuart Elliott, both police officers. Claire is 27, Stuart is 33, and they live in a large three-bedroomed flat in Bexley.

At: Queen Mary's hospital, Sidcup.

Care: 1968-built hospital with a large maternity unit - 3,800 deliveries a year. Forward-looking approach - midwives don't wear uniforms. Home births are on the increase, and the caesarean section rate is around 25%.

The birth: "It was really hard work, but it all went very well. I already knew both Deirdre, my main midwife, and Barbara, the student midwife - that helped such a lot. I've got an old back injury, so I wanted to deliver standing up to put less pressure on it, and they gave me lots of help to achieve that. I've had lots of help with breastfeeding and several midwives I saw antenatally have popped in to see us."

Hopes for the future: "I just want her to be happy and healthy and to enjoy every moment of what's ahead."

3: Jessica Rose Thompson

Born: 1.12am.

Parents: Kathryne Garett, 24, legal secretary, and partner Calvin Thompson, 24, an alarm engineer, already have one daughter, Ellie-May, two.

At: Kingston Hospital, Surrey

Type of maternity care: Births at Kingston have increased dramatically over the past few years, and the hospital now has 4,800 deliveries annually. The maternity unit, built in 1995, has state-of-the-art LDRP rooms (labour, delivery, recovery, postpartum) - you stay in the same room for your labour, delivery and aftercare, although Kingston is so popular that it's often not possible to stay put after the birth and you're moved to another single room with its own en-suite bathroom. Hopes for the future: "I want her to have the best education going. I want her to enjoy the things she does, like my little girl Ellie does already."

Born: 7.10am.

Parents: Efi Bile, 26, originally from West Africa, is a business studies

student, as is husband Elie Fofala, 28. They live in New Cross.

At: Guy's and St Thomas' Hospital, London.

Care: If Cherie had chosen her nearest hospital, it would have been St Thomas', opposite the Houses of Parliament on London's south bank. St Thomas' and Guy's hospitals merged in 1993, and around 5,500 babies are born there each year. Work is about to start on a brand new maternity unit.

The birth: "It was a very easy labour. I arrived at 5.30am and the baby was born less than two hours later. I hadn't met the midwife who delivered Adam but it didn't matter. He's gorgeous and he looks just like his dad."

5: Layna Smyth

Born: 12.33am.

Parents: Antoinette Morelli, 24, a drama student at Queen's University in

Belfast; Colin Smyth, 32, works for BT. Live on the Lisburn Road in Belfast. "We hadn't intended starting a family yet, but we're delighted."

At: Royal Maternity Hospital, Belfast.

Care: At 30%, the caesarean rate is well above average, as is the induction rate of 38%.

The birth: Antoinette was taken in on Friday morning for an induction. "The baby was due 11 days ago, so they thought they needed to give me a move on. It seemed a long labour but I had a brilliant midwife - I'd never met her before, but she was fantastic. It was a forceps birth, so she's a bit swollen today, but it's going down and she's got a mass of hair like me."

Hopes for the future: "Just to be holding my baby in my arms is enough for me. I just want to give her the best."

6: Joshua Bracewell

Born: 9.38am.

Parents: Helen Bracewell, 24, a travel agent, Stuart Parkin, 25, a car salesman. Couple live in a rented flat in the village of Thaxted outside Cambridge. Both sets of grandparents live nearby.

At: The Rosie Maternity Hospital at Addenbrooke's in Cambridge.

Care: The unit delivers around 5,000 babies a year. Care is community-based. Home birth rate hovers around 2%, which is national average.

The birth: "I was looked after by the same midwife through my pregnancy at my GP's surgery, which was great - and I'll see her again once I'm home. I'd never met the midwife who delivered Joshua, but I don't think that mattered - she was brilliant."

Hopes for the future: "I want to be able to provide for him, and to give him a safe and happy upbringing. We're just hoping we'll be able to afford to buy our own house so we get a garden for him to run around in."

7: Scott Lee Rosser

Born: 11.50am.

Parents: Sarah Charles, 18, and Mark Rosser, 36. Both unemployed, Sarah recently finished a nursery nursing course. Live in a flat on a council estate.

Born at: Newport Hospital, Gwent.

Type of maternity care: Sarah had shared care, seeing her doctor and a midwife at his surgery. She also had check-ups at the hospital itself.

How the birth went: "I was on the pill so finding myself pregnant was a big shock - especially for Mark, as he's already got two childen. Once I got over it and told my mum and everyone, though, I got quite excited. I can't remember meeting the midwife before the birth, but it didn't make a lot of difference. I went into labour during the night on Friday, and at 5am Iwent over to my mum's. She and Mark both came with me to the hospital, but there they said I was only in the early stages. They sent mum and Mark home and I had a little nap. Then I woke up with this awful pain and they called them back in quick. Scott was born soon afterwards. When the baby was born he had the cord wrapped round his neck but they dealt with it really quickly and with no panic at all. Now I'm in a nice four-bedded ward now with Scott and it's very pleasant: I've got a lovely view from my window. 8: Jack Picton

Born: 4.57am.

Parents: Maxine Picton, 33, a TV cabinet packer. Partner Tony Wilkinson, 46, a textile mill worker. Maxine lives with her mum in Ovenden, a former council estate outside Halifax town centre.

At: Halifax General Hospital.

Care: During her pregnancy Maxine saw a community midwife at her GP's surgery, and also attended the hospital antenatal clinic.

The Halifax General is a large, Victorian hospital and 2,500 babies are born there each year.

High point: its a midwife-run GP unit - "the next best thing to having a baby at home" - where women can have natural deliveries in a low-tech environment.

Low point: an old Victorian site, though it's about to be redeveloped.

The birth: "I'd never met the midwife who delivered Jack, but she was fine. They've treated me well, I've been OK. Getting pregnant was a shock - we weren't planning a baby, but once we knew, I got used to the idea."

Hopes for the future: "I've been brought up well - I've never been in trouble with the police or been on drugs or anything like that. I'm going to do the same for Jack, I'll make a good job of it."

9: Emily Rose Hale

Born: 7.58am.

Parents: Sheila Hale, 35, a school cook, and husband Graeme. Sheila already has a 12-year-old daughter, Leanne, and a 14-year-old son, Christopher. But Emily is a first baby for Graeme, and he's "over the moon".

At: Weston General, Weston super Mare.

Care: The Weston is a small unit, with just 400 deliveries a year. There are no facilities for caesareans, so only takes "low risk" mothers. Around 2% of those are born at home. It offers aromatherapy in pregnancy and birth as well as the now almost standard birthing pool.

The birth: "It was a long labour, which was quite a surprise because with Leanne I was only in labour for three hours. It's 12 years since I last had a baby, and also like her I had a long labour - it started around 11.30pm on Friday night."

Hopes for the future: "We'd just like her to be healthy and happy."

10: Alexander FitzGerald

Born: 5.30pm.

Parents: Lauren, 29, and Patrick, 34, FitzGerald. Both Australians who came to live in London last year - she's a commercial lawyer, he's an IT consultant. Just moved (on Friday!) into a flat in Blackheath.

At: Greenwich Hospital, with the help of independent midwife Dorothy Norris.

Care: There are around 50 independent midwives in the UK. They commit themselves to be with you at the birth.

The birth: Lauren was three weeks overdue, so the baby was induced. "Dorothy stayed with us throughout," says Patrick. "When things didn't quite go to plan, we had to make quick decisions about an assisted delivery - Alexander was born using forceps - and it was invaluable having someone we knew we could trust ."

Hopes for the future: "A happy upbringing, a good education, and the fulfilment of his potential."
