webTitle: Greek church at war over plans to change ID cards

fields.headline: Greek church at war over plans to change ID cards
fields.trailText: Proposals to make Greeks more European by removing their religious affiliation from state identity cards have ignited the fury of the country's Orthodox church.
fields.body:
Proposals to make Greeks more European by removing their religious affiliation from state identity cards have ignited the fury of the country's Orthodox church.

The plans have been dimissed by clerics as nothing short of a sinister plot to rid Greeks of their innate Orthodox faith.

"Our faith is the foundation of our identity," said Archbishop Christodoulos, the church's flamboyant leader. "These changes are being put forward by neo-intellectuals who want to attack us like rabid dogs and tear at our flesh."

Greece, the only Orthodox EU member state, has come under growing pressure from Brussels to update its identity cards. The country's cherished tradition of stipulating religious beliefs on nearly all official documents is seen by many to discriminate against Jews, Catholics and Muslims.

Human rights groups frequently complain about the absence of religious minorities from prominent positions in the military and in politics.

Last week an independent commission, created to revamp privacy protection laws, fuelled the row further by declaring that in addition to religious affiliation, Greeks should no longer include their occupation, nationality or spouse's name on ID cards.

Constantine Dafermos, head of the commission, said: "Religious beliefs and professions can change at any time and so cannot be regarded as proof of identity. The government has pledged to uphold our decision."

The justice minister, Michalis Stathopoulos, has made no secret of the fact that he sees the row over ID cards as just the beginning of a battle to separate the state from religion. "Those who don't like these measures can go before the council of state [the highest adminstrative court]. We are going to move forward. Greece is a European country."

But faced with the prospect of thousands of religious zealots taking to the streets, the government yesterday sought to play down the row - although it ruled out holding a referendum on the issue.

Memories are still fresh of the protests triggered by the state's abortive attempts to tax ecclesiastical property in the 1980s. For weeks, hundreds of thousands of protesters marched through Athens in a show of hostility that had some commentators predicting civil war.

fields.headline: Male belly-dancing sets Turkey aquiver
fields.trailText: When darkness falls over the Bosphorus, veils are adjusted and sequins shimmer. Belly-dancing has been part of Istanbul's night life for centuries, but beyond the traditional tourist haunts things are not quite what they seem.
fields.body:
When darkness falls over the Bosphorus, veils are adjusted and sequins shimmer. Belly-dancing has been part of Istanbul's night life for centuries, but beyond the traditional tourist haunts things are not quite what they seem.

Women still rule the roost, but some nightclubs are now striking an unusual blow for sexual equality - male belly-dancing is all the rage, and business is booming.

At a club on the Asian shores of the Bosphorus, Evrim Sultan was preparing for his performance. He started belly-dancing nine years ago, and now makes a living from it.

"I just love to dance," he said. "I plan to keep doing this for as long as possible."

Evrim said his family were not too keen on his chosen career at first but once they saw him on local television and in a music video, they changed their tune. He has only one rule - no all-male audiences.

Evrin's agent, Erol, estimates that there are now about 20 men making a living from belly-dancing. Istanbul is their biggest market, but they occasionally go to the capital, Ankara, or to the resorts along the Mediterranean coast.

"I think there will be more male belly-dancers soon," said Erol. "This is an art form, and once we join the European Union it will be more open, just like everything else".

Many conservative Turks, however, are not happy about the trend. In February, police had to rescue a 19-year-old whose father held him captive for three days to prevent him belly-dancing at nightclubs.

In a city where millions of migrants from the countryside have brought conservative attitudes in recent years, such opposition is not surprising.

But male belly-dancing has a long history, partly because of Islamic sensibilities. In Ottoman times, men covered their faces with veils and danced for the Sultan because Muslim women were barred from performing.

"It was against the rules - among both Turks and Arabs," Evrim said. "So it used to be the men who were the belly-dancers - they were called koceks . I just do the same job in a more modern way".His performance certainly went down a storm with his audience. Young and old were dancing on the tables, stomping and shouting into the early hours.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Kidnap victim crucified
A kidnap victim was found by a passing motorist doused in petrol and nailed to an improvised crucifix near farmland in Hayes, north London, early yesterday. The 20-year-old man, who told detectives that he was abducted in the street, was being treated at an undisclosed hospital. His injuries are not thought to be life threatening and Scotland Yard said it did not know of any motive.
fields.body:
Kidnap victim crucified
A kidnap victim was found by a passing motorist doused in petrol and nailed to an improvised crucifix near farmland in Hayes, north London, early yesterday. The 20-year-old man, who told detectives that he was abducted in the street, was being treated at an undisclosed hospital. His injuries are not thought to be life threatening and Scotland Yard said it did not know of any motive.

Boy's organs save lives
The organs of 12-year-old James Gregory, who died after being knocked down by a bus in March, have been used to save the lives of four other children. Debbie Gregory, 39, of Plymouth, said her son had filled in a donor card when he was 10. His heart and lungs had been given to a 12-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis, his liver went to a baby and his kidneys to two boys, aged 15 and four.

New tests on IRA's Deal bomb
Police are to use new forensic techniques on the remains of the 15lb IRA bomb which killed 11 Royal Marine bandsmen in an attack at the Royal Marine school of music in Deal, Kent, in September 1989. No-one was ever prosecuted for planting the bomb, which went off while the band practised and also injured 60 bandsmen.

webTitle: Animal activists suspected of blast attack at meat firm

fields.headline: Animal activists suspected of blast attack at meat firm
fields.trailText: Animal Liberation Front activists are believed to have been responsible for an explosion at a meat packing firm in Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
Animal Liberation Front activists are believed to have been responsible for an explosion at a meat packing firm in Oxfordshire.

Army bomb disposal experts were called to Mutchmeats Limited, in Witney, Oxfordshire, early yesterday after an incendiary device ignited under a refrigeration lorry.

Nine similar devices were found attached to other vehicles in the compound and were made safe.

Robin Webb, spokesman for the ALF, said he was "absolutely confident" the group was responsible for the attack. "Because of security concerns individuals are unlikely to identify themselves to me but this attack bears all the hallmarks of the ALF. The meat packing industry is one of the largest areas of animal abuse."

He said the meat industry would continue to be a target as long as it "continues to practise cruelty".

The largest sustained campaign by the ALF saw more than 100 lorries attacked in 1991-92 at an estimated cost to the industry of £5.5m. Mr Webb claimed knock-on invisible costs of increased insurance premiums and higher security bills cut into the industry's profitability.

The Home Office played down fears that yesterday's incident heralded the start of a similar campaign, but said it would request a report from Thames Valley police.

The anti-terrorism bill before parliament redefines terrorism to include any group that uses violence or the threat of violence for the purposes of coercion.

webTitle: New agency to confiscate wealthy criminals' assets

fields.headline: New agency to confiscate wealthy criminals' assets
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the minister for the Cabinet Office, will today try to seize back the law and order agenda from the Conservatives by announcing sweeping new powers to seize the assets of criminals. She will also propose a national agency to co-ordinate the seizures and end drug-related money laundering.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the minister for the Cabinet Office, will today try to seize back the law and order agenda from the Conservatives by announcing sweeping new powers to seize the assets of criminals. She will also propose a national agency to co-ordinate the seizures and end drug-related money laundering.

The proposals were first considered by the Home Office organised crime directorate in November 1998, but have now been developed by the Cabinet Office thinktank, the performance and innovation unit.

After a month in which the government has been on the back foot on crime, Ms Mowlam, in a speech today, will say: "Why should millions of law-abiding people work hard for a living whilst a few criminals live a life of luxury built on the misery of others? Arresting and convicting criminals is not enough - we must also take away their profits.

"In every court case we should be looking to confiscate the unlawful assets that have built up. That should be the norm, not the exception."

She will also tell the courts that they must use their existing powers more to confiscate assets and make sure money is collected where confiscation orders are made.

Proposing to put new powers in place "as soon as possible", she will also reveal that the government is planning "a new national agency staffed by top quality financial investigators to maximise the revenues seized".

She will also promise "tough new measures against money laundering and wider laws to ensure that income from all crimes - not just drug trafficking - can be seized."

The courts already have powers to confiscate the proceeds of crime by means of a criminal confiscation order. Even before proceedings begin, the prosecutor can obtain an order to freeze property, pending the making and enforcement of a criminal confiscation order.

However, the Home Office crime directorate has ac knowledged that these orders "have not been as successful as originally anticipated".

The number of drug traffickers subject to confiscation orders rose from around 3,000 in each of the years 1987 to 1991 to only just over 7,000 in 1996. At the same time the total amount ordered to be confiscated rose from £1m in 1987 to only just over £10m in 1996.

Even worse, the Home Office acknowledges, the amounts actually raised have remained stuck at £5m per year.

Between 1987 and 1996 only 157 drug trafficking confiscation orders for over £100,000 were made, even though there had been over 45,000 convictions for supply of drugs.

Separately, customs officers have powers to forfeit or seize money if they suspect it represents the proceeds of drug trafficking, or is intended for use in drug trafficking.

Ms Mowlam will strengthen these powers to allow seizure in non-drug trafficking cases, claiming the current restriction is an unfortunate anomaly. The government plan would permit the seizure of cash not just at the point of imort or export of cash, but at any point at which it is found and suspected of being crime-related.

The police have also been seeking new powers to investigate and restrain the suspected criminal source of money "where there is strong circumstantial evidence that that property is the proceeds of crime".

The thinktank report, which will lead to a white paper and legislation this autumn, will recommend that the burden of proof required to seize the suspected profits of crime should be reduced from the criminal to the civil level. Police would have to make a case that goods had been acquired illegally on the "balance of probabilities" rather than the higher standard of "beyond reasonable doubt".

The proposed "national confiscation agency" would ensure there was a single body dedicated to seizing criminal assets. At present the serious fraud office and crown prosecution service have too many other responsibilities. It is possible the agency will be funded in part from the proceeds of seizures.

webTitle: Case of restored panel spices row over Rubens

fields.headline: Case of restored panel spices row over Rubens
fields.standfirst: Art Review
fields.trailText: It has all the ingredients of a delicious art mystery; involving one of the world's most valuable paintings, the reputation of an old master, and claims of a cover-up at the National Gallery.
fields.body:
It has all the ingredients of a delicious art mystery; involving one of the world's most valuable paintings, the reputation of an old master, and claims of a cover-up at the National Gallery.

An article in the respected Art Review, which claims that the National Gallery altered the back of the 17th century painting of Rubens's Samson and Delilah to conceal that it is not the work of the great Flemish artist, has spiced up a row which has simmered for over a decade.

If true, it would mean the Old Testament scene - valued at an estimated £40m - was painted by one of his pupils, and its worth could be as little as £1m.

The new evidence is presented by Michael Daley, director of ArtWatch UK, a fake-hunter and long-standing critic of the work, in tomorrow's edition of the art journal.

Samson and Delilah has hung in the National Gallery since it was bought for £2.5m in 1980, then the second highest price paid for a work of art. The gallery, which has always stood by its authenticity, yesterday dismissed the latest allegations as "extraordinary".

The painting is notable because one of Samson's feet is chopped off at the picture's edge, which experts say indicates a fake. Detractors also say that while Rubens's colouring tends to be subtle, the snipping of Samson's locks is portrayed in garish hues.

If Rubens was not the artist, a likely candidate is Jacob Jordaens, a pupil and collaborator. It was common for 17th century painters to have pupils paint for them. It is estimated that as many as half the paintings of the time were produced in this way.

The new claims arise after Mr Daley was given permission by the gallery to search through its files on the painting. His attack focuses on the blockboard backing to the work. At some point in the 20th century the original oak panel on to which Samson and Delilah was painted was planed down to a thickness of 3mm and glued on to the blockboard.

Mr Daley claims that a document in the Samson archive which describes it as being on a panel and in excellent condition in 1930 shows that the planing must have happened after that date.

If the picture was planed recently, Mr Daley argues, why was such a major restoration not documented and why were photographs not taken of the original back before the alteration?

He suggests the work was done to conceal evidence of the painting's true origin, such as the panelmaker's mark. They entered common usage only in 1617, while Samson and Delilah is dated to 1609-10.

Mr Daley has even claimed, again based on letters found in the dossier, that the planing was done by the National Gallery itself.

He said: "The letters show there is no window of opportunity for anybody else to have undertaken such a major treatment before 1982, when it was withdrawn for restoration. That was the first time it was withdrawn for a long period."

Jean Liddiard, the National Gallery's head of press, said at the weekend: "We have absolutely no doubts about the authenticity of the picture and nor do most experts on Rubens. Tests by a timber expert have confirmed that the blockboard predates 1960, most likely originating in the 1930s."

She said the planing had taken place at that time, when the painting was in private hands, and it was common practice.

fields.headline: Buckled bridge
fields.standfirst: Up to 100 injured after walkway collapses at US stock car track
fields.trailText: A concrete walkway spanning a four-lane motorway collapsed yesterday, injuring more than 90 people - at least 13 critically - as they left a stock car race meeting in Concord, North Carolina.
fields.byline: Jenna Fryer in Concord, North Carolina
fields.body:
A concrete walkway spanning a four-lane motorway collapsed yesterday, injuring more than 90 people - at least 13 critically - as they left a stock car race meeting in Concord, North Carolina.

A nine-metre (30ft) section of the bridge, which connects the track to a car park, snapped in half and fell about five metres on to the south-bound lanes of the motorway, which was empty at the time.

Several victims were airlifted to hospitals in Concord and nearby Charlotte with injuries ranging from bruises and broken bones to head and spinal injuries, hospital officials said.

"The predominant injuries are orthopaedic injuries," said Carol Lovin, a spokeswoman for Northeast Medical Centre in Concord said of the 50 casualties brought to her hospital. "We've had numerous fractures ... We've had head injuries, we've had spinal cord injuries."

"We felt something like an earthquake," Kevin Sanders said. "We were all scared for our lives."
AP

fields.headline: Reform vote in Tehran overturned
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Iran's parliamentary election - applauded by the west as the closest the country has come to democracy - has been tainted by the decision of a supervisory board at the weekend to throw out a quarter of the votes cast in Tehran.
fields.body:
Iran's parliamentary election - applauded by the west as the closest the country has come to democracy - has been tainted by the decision of a supervisory board at the weekend to throw out a quarter of the votes cast in Tehran.

Conservatives on the Guardian Council invalidated 726,000 votes in the capital from the February 18 polls, and apparently rejigged the order of the winners.

Former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was said to be in 30th place after preliminary results were released, was now in 20th place for 30 seats from Tehran.

Rasoul Montajabnia, a pro-reform cleric who was in 27th place before being pushed into a run-off by the recent announcement, accused the Guardians of rigging the results to secure places for some of their loyalists.

"The action of the Guardian Council was the worst in 21 years. They have behaved in the worst manner toward the votes and the people," said Mr Montajabnia.

"The changes made in the list and the election and the elevation [of one candidate] from 30th to 20th cannot be the result of a recount but more a result of miracles inside the ballot boxes," he said.

The deputy interior minister, Mostafa Tajzadeh, a supporter of the progressive president, Mohammad Khatami, yesterday accused the Guardians of concealing the results. He pointed out that they had declared the election fair and then proceeded to conduct three recounts of the votes. The interior ministry was responsible for holding the election.

The results of the latest vote recount will not change the fact that reformers are now the biggest single bloc in the new 290-seat parliament, due to meet on Saturday. But the cancellation of one quarter of the votes in Tehran, Iran's political centre, has clouded the previously emphatic verdict of the election.

Since the election, the conservative establishment has used its power to dilute the gains reformers could have made as a result of the poll. Many reformist journalists have been imprisoned and the conservative-dominated judiciary has closed 17 progressive newspapers and journals, the strongest political weapon at the reformers' disposal.

The Guardian Council had recounted the votes three times and refused to make public the results for Tehran - they were eventually announced on Saturday, only after an order from Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

In the months while the recounting was conducted, reformist politicians and commentators accused the Guardians of tampering with the results to ensure a place for Mr Rafsanjani, whose presidency ushered in conservative social policies. There had been some speculation that he would drop out entirely to avoid the embarrassment of his miserable finish.

But Mr Rafsanjani still holds great power over the law of the land. He heads the expediency council, a body appointed by Ayatollah Khamenei which is empowered to rule on disputed legislation passed by parliament. Although reformers may have the biggest bloc of seats in parliament, Mr Rafsanjani still has the last word.

fields.headline: ... with two sides to it
fields.trailText: Your report presented a distorted and alarmist interpretation of the article in the Washington Post, upon which it was based. The government, which is finalising its future statutory waste management strategy, has taken rigorous steps through the Environment Agency in recent years to assess the threat from dioxins and to reduce their incidence. This industry has consistently worked within - and often out-performed - the emission limits set by the agency.
fields.body:
Your report presented a distorted and alarmist interpretation of the article in the Washington Post, upon which it was based. The government, which is finalising its future statutory waste management strategy, has taken rigorous steps through the Environment Agency in recent years to assess the threat from dioxins and to reduce their incidence. This industry has consistently worked within - and often out-performed - the emission limits set by the agency.

Incineration, with energy recovery, has been identified by a range of independent and reputable bodies, including the Environment Agency and the Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution, as the "best practicable environmental option" for some waste streams. Incineration produces just a tiny proportion of UK emissions of dioxins. Michael Meacher told the Commons on January 11 this year that "incinerators now give rise to no more than 4% of total dioxins".

The Washington Post also said: "One source likely to be targeted is uncontrolled residential waste burning, such as burning trash in back yards, particularly in rural areas, EPA briefing papers said. Such burning is 'one of the largest unaddressed dioxin sources and one that could have a disproportionately large contribution to the food supply'." In the UK it is generally considered Guy Fawkes celebrations are a significant contributor of dioxins. Will you be calling for the banning of the bonfire night activities?

Without the contribution of a planned and regulated programme of development of new energy from waste plants, working alongside initiatives to massively increase recycling and composting, the UK stands no chance of meeting its obligations under the EU landfill directive.
Dr Stuart McLanaghan
Director, Energy from Waste Association

fields.trailText: The decision by the five permanent members of the United Nations security council to strengthen their commitment to the elimination of nuclear weapons is, on the face of it, a welcome step. Britain joined the US, Russia, China and France in making an "unequivocal undertaking" to accomplish the destruction of its nuclear arsenal. This marks a move forward from the nuclear powers' previous position, namely that abolition of such weapons was an "ultimate goal". fields.body:
The decision by the five permanent members of the United Nations security council to strengthen their commitment to the elimination of nuclear weapons is, on the face of it, a welcome step. Britain joined the US, Russia, China and France in making an "unequivocal undertaking" to accomplish the destruction of its nuclear arsenal. This marks a move forward from the nuclear powers' previous position, namely that abolition of such weapons was an "ultimate goal". And for the first time in 15 years, all 187 countries attending the month-long review conference in New York of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty (NPT) agreed a disarmament agenda for the next five years.

The agenda will include efforts to cut the number of warheads which are actively deployed, reduce states' reliance on nuclear weapons in their overall defence strategies, and increase the information which is publicly available about existing nuclear stockpiles. Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, was typically enthusiastic, calling the outcome of the meeting "a significant step forward in humanity's pursuit of a more peaceful world". More pragmatically, many countries which have the capability and the technical expertise to acquire nuclear weapons but have so far forsworn them, including Brazil, Egypt, and South Africa, will come away from the review conference with renewed confidence that the acknowledged nuclear states appear serious about disarmament.

Beyond the conference's headline achievements, however, many worrying concerns remain, and there will be disappointment that tougher and more imaginative measures were not adopted. The meeting was forced to skirt round the United States' continuing refusal to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, which sets an appalling example to oth ers like India and Pakistan (which have refused to sign the NPT). Likewise, the impact on non-proliferation efforts of US attempts to renegotiate its anti-ballistic missile treaty with Russia is likely to be very negative. China is among several countries which have warned that America's linked development of a national missile defence (NMD) system, designed to intercept nuclear missiles, is potentially deeply destabilising. China knows this better than most since it is currently the most active manufacturer of long- range, nuclear-capable missiles. If Beijing concludes that NMD will significantly reduce its offensive capability, it is likely to build even more nukes.

Although Russia recently ratified the Start II arms reduction accord with the US, President Vladimir Putin has increased, rather than reduced, the importance of nuclear weapons in his country's defence planning. And while the meeting, under Arab pressure, singled out nuclear-armed Israel - another NPT refusenik which rejects international inspections - for direct criticism, its strictures carry no actual force and are unlikely to bring changes in Israeli policy without much tougher external pressure.

Indeed, the fundamental drawback of the new NPT agenda is that while it enunciates objectives more clearly, it remains vague about the (purely voluntary) means of achieving them, setting out no timetables or penalties. A more visionary, more persuasive approach would be for all the known nuclear powers, including Britain, to launch, right now, an unconditional, multilateral arms reduction process. Such exemplary action would do much to halt the spread of these evil weapons to developing countries and "rogue" states alike. The Big Five all say they are willing, in theory. They should get on with it.

fields.headline: Waste is a burning issue
fields.trailText: Congratulations on your coverage (Incinerator cancer threat revealed, May 18). However, an important additional point is that incineration of waste encourages the continued manufacture of those products which themselves lead to dioxin formation. For example dioxin formation occurs when PVC is manufactured and again if it is involved in combustion, as in house fires.
fields.body:
Congratulations on your coverage (Incinerator cancer threat revealed, May 18). However, an important additional point is that incineration of waste encourages the continued manufacture of those products which themselves lead to dioxin formation. For example dioxin formation occurs when PVC is manufactured and again if it is involved in combustion, as in house fires.

The organisations most interested in lobbying in favour of waste incineration are the ones that produce the toxic problems. They know better than most that if the disposal route of incineration is closed, the spotlight will inevitably turn to them and pressure will mount for the elimination of their products. This would be a sensible "front-end" solution, as there are more environmentally neutral alternatives for almost all organochlorine products.

Dr Vyvyan Howard
University of Liverpool
c.v.howard@liv.ac.uk

 The cancer threat will not have been news to the US government. Both the US and UK governments are major players in the UN convention on persistent organic pollutants which already recognises this group of substances as being among the 12 "most toxic chemicals known to man". Dioxins are known hormone disrupting chemicals which can accumulate in the body. Exposure to dioxins and dioxin-like substances has been linked to IQ deficiencies and to effects on co-ordination development in children. They are also implicated in reproductive problems and weakened immune systems in people and wildlife.

In light of the EPA report, and the additional threat of cancer, government, industry and retailers should phase out the use of substances which release dioxins when not properly disposed of. The government must also reconsider plans to build more incinerators and instead invest in more environmentally sound methods of waste disposal, ending the gamble being played with public health.

Chloe Webster
Toxics policy officer, WWF-UK

 If we are really concerned about incineration, we should be putting pressure on manufacturers not to overpackage goods. Marks and Spencers are selling ladies' panties enclosed in a thick plastic wallet which would be good for at least five years of constant use, but which are destined solely to be dumped in the bin.

Leslie Wilson
Reading

 For years the Cooperative Bank has been drawing attention to the link between dioxins and a range of health problems. Unfortunately, the Advertising Standards Authority, following a complaint from the British Plastics Federation, has ruled we should not use the phrase "the evidence is frightening" whilst conducting the debate as this would be "unduly alarmist". With the EPA set to announce that people on normal diets have a one in 100 chance of contracting cancer as a result of dioxins contamination of the environment, can we now consider the evidence as frightening?

Paul Monaghan Ecology unit manager Cooperative Bank

 The UK recycles 8% of all household waste, compared to Switzerland's 52%. The UK has 3.5m tonnes of waste paper available for recovery. The disposal cost is £175m, but it could produce recycled paper products worth in excess of £2.2bn. This is not money that should be allowed to go up in smoke.

Andy Moore Community Recycling Network

 Archie Norman says "Labour have failed to stem the growth of waste in this country... the government should bin their white paper..." Is this joined-up opposition?

Bob Rotheram Nottingham

fields.headline: Adult view of modern art
fields.trailText:
Is there not another agenda which is important in the "child-friendly art galleries" debate (Letters, May 17)? In my book, "art" is supposed to be challenging, often "difficult", often disturbing. Could it not be that the drive to make galleries and museums "child-friendly" is an integral part of the "dumbing-down" of culture? Should young children be exposed to "adult" concerns with sexuality, violence, philosophy and the very meaning of life and death? I am no apologist for overprotecting children, but when what is suitable for a child begins to determine what can be exhibited for an adult public, isn't it time to worry?

Dr Jan Udris
Hemel Hempstead, Herts
J.Udris@mdx.ac.uk

Much less harmful than a squelchy bottom.

London
simon.gilman@lineone.net

webTitle: Women want an end to yah boo politics

fields.headline: Women want an end to yah boo politics
fields.trailText: I am as frustrated as other colleagues at the lack of substantive reform in the procedures in our parliament (Male members, May 19). To my mind, reducing the time spent on futile adversarial "debate" and improving all-party scrutiny of government bills would be of much greater relevance to our democracy then nine-to-five (or seven) working for MPs. As an MP with family life based in my constituency, such working arrangement would be of little benefit. The pressure on my time, responding not only to the demands of Westminster but also those of my constituents, is such that I am regularly in the my office after the house has risen.
fields.body:
I am as frustrated as other colleagues at the lack of substantive reform in the procedures in our parliament (Male members, May 19). To my mind, reducing the time spent on futile adversarial "debate" and improving all-party scrutiny of government bills would be of much greater relevance to our democracy then nine-to-five (or seven) working for MPs. As an MP with family life based in my constituency, such working arrangement would be of little benefit. The pressure on my time, responding not only to the demands of Westminster but also those of my constituents, is such that I am regularly in the my office after the house has risen.

MPs need to be able to compartmentalise their lives between work and home. For me, a three-day London-based working week with recesses to coincide with school holidays would be best.

With its huge majority, the government should also be able to introduce more sensible timetabling of bills, but it is open to accusations of undemocratic practice if there is no reform of the way legislative committees operate. These should operate more like select committees, encouraging genuine debate about whether government proposals will result in the benefits claimed. Appointments to such committees should be taken independently of the whipping system.

Dr Lynne Jones MP

 The picture presented by Oona King and Lucy Ward of the continuing resistance to women as equals in politics makes depressing reading. In the Welsh Assembly the impact of 42% women on the time given to issues that matter to women and the treatment of equality is visible. But political habits die hard, and when the temperature rises, the point-scoring, scalp-taking and Westminster yah boo still masquerades as serious politics.

Until equal representation is accepted as the democratic right of half the population to be heard and to influence decision-making, it seems we will continue to need positive action mechanisms to get women picked by their parties. The first Labour selections indicate that attitudes have not changed enough to value what women can bring to politics.

Val Feld
Welsh Assembly Member for Swansea East

fields.headline: US warns on Airbus support
fields.standfirst: Airbus
fields.trailText: The prospect of renewed trade tensions between Europe and the US increased last night after a senior American official said the Clinton administration was keeping the development of the A3XX super jumbo under close scrutiny.
fields.body:
The prospect of renewed trade tensions between Europe and the US increased last night after a senior American official said the Clinton administration was keeping the development of the A3XX super jumbo under close scrutiny.

The new aircraft is being developed by Europe's Airbus Industrie group and if the project gets the go-ahead it will be the first challenge to arch-rival Boeing's 747 aircraft.

Last night US trade representative Charlene Barshefsky said Airbus's plans to finance development were being looked at "very, very closely" by the White House.

"Airbus, which would be making this new jumbo liner, is not an infant company. This is not a new industry in Europe. Airbus has garnered about 50% of the new orders last year, they're shooting for 60% this year," she said.

"They ought to be able to do that [development] without government involvement, without preferential financing financing from the member-state governments."

Launch aid for previous Airbus models has caused friction between the US and Europe in the past.

Airbus is the only rival to Boeing in the market for wide-bodied jets and the US company has argued that government launch aid has given its European rival an unfair advantage. The consortium includes British Aerospace, as well as French, German and Spanish companies.

That argument has been countered by European assertions that Boeing gets help for its development programmes through defence contracts.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.body:
Observer

Tesco , Britain's biggest food retailer, is poised to close up to 10 of its Metro convenience stores, apparently after poor financial performance. The group has already ordered the closure of two of its 41 town centre shops, in Leicester and Southend. Its Bristol store is thought to be next.

Ford is set to buy the four-wheel-drive manufacturer Land Rover this week, despite last minute wrangles over price. The US carmaker is likely to switch at least half of Land Rover's component purchasing to the continent and America over the next two years.

Sunday Times

Britain's top cable company, NTL , is a serious contender to buy Freeserve, the internet company which has been put up for sale.

A £15bn sale of the former Mannesmann fixed-line telephone operations is being considered by Vodafone AirTouch .

The Phoenix consortium is close to buying Rover's Powertrain engine and gearbox business from BMW for a nominal £10.

Sunday Telegraph

Blue Circle Industries is considering a merger with an American cement group following its successful defence of a hostile bid from Lafarge . The company held merger talks with Southdown , America's second largest cement producer, last year but they broke down. Last week the Blue Circle board discussed reopening talks later this year.

Don Cruickshank , chairman of the London stock exchange , is to launch a charm offensive to head off mounting opposition to the exchange's merger with Deutsche Börse .

Antfactory , an internet investment company set up by an alliance of former investment bankers, private equity investors and technologists, is in talks about a float that should value the business at up to $1bn.

Sunday Business

Phoenix , the consortium which took control of Rover from BMW two weeks ago, may ditch the Rover marque in two years' time. Sources say it is considering production of new models under the MG badge.

BT is planning to spend up to £5bn to bolster its position in mainland European markets. By far the biggest deal on the horizon will be the acquisition of Viag's 45% stake in German joint venture Viag Interkom.

Mail on Sunday

Planet Hollywood chain founder Robert Earl has turned to a younger generation of celebrities to help revamp the restaurant group's image. Chart-topping band 'N Sync have put money into the chain. Britney Spears and the Backstreet Boys are also thought to be investors.

British Airway boss Rod Eddington is on course for his first industrial test of strength as employees seem certain to reject a 1.4% pay offer. BA this week reports its worst ever figures.

IoS

The Football League , which represents the 74 clubs outside England's Premier League, has entered talks with leading broadcasters about television deals which could be worth as much as £450m.

webTitle: SFO to extradite Regan on £2.4m theft charge

fields.headline: SFO to extradite Regan on £2.4m theft charge
fields.trailText: The serious fraud office yesterday confirmed that it had decided to extradite Andrew Regan, the Monaco-based businessman best known for his abortive £1.3bn bid for the Co-op in 1997.
fields.body:
The serious fraud office yesterday confirmed that it had decided to extradite Andrew Regan, the Monaco-based businessman best known for his abortive £1.3bn bid for the Co-op in 1997.

An SFO spokesman said Mr Regan and his lawyers had been told that the extradition was going ahead but was unable to confirm reports that Mr Regan had agreed to return to Britain next week to meet investigators.

A warrant was issued in October for the arrest of Mr Regan for alleged theft of £2.4m from Hobson, a company he owned in the mid-1990s. Hobson bought the CWS Food Manufacturing Group for £104m in 1994 and the SFO is investigating an agreement extending the company's deal to supply the Co-op with its range of own-brand products.

In September, two senior CWS executives, Allan Green and David Chambers, were charged with corruption; they are alleged to have received £1m each.

Paul Thomas, a solicitor who had acted for Hobson, was charged with aiding, abetting, counselling and procuring the executives to commit the alleged offence.

City sources said that if Mr Regan had agreed a voluntary return to Britain, he would almost certainly have made arrangements with the SFO enabling him to return to his family and businesses in Monaco in the event of his arrest. He has not been charged.

fields.headline: Changing rooms
fields.standfirst: Two hotel groups plan restructuring
fields.trailText: Britain's hotel industry could be on the brink of radical change with two leading chains set to change hands, according to reports yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's hotel industry could be on the brink of radical change with two leading chains set to change hands, according to reports yesterday.

Whitbread is said to be lining up a £400m acquisition of De Vere hotels, including the Grand in Brighton (pictured) and the Belfry near Sutton Coldfield, while Granada is tipped to sell its Posthouse chain to win shareholder support for its planned merger with Compass.

The City is expecting Whitbread to sell its brewing business to Interbrew, possibly this week, and then acquire the De Vere hotels operation, which is seen as a good fit.

De Vere is what remains of the Greenalls group following the latter's £1.14bn sale of its pubs and restaurants to Scottish & Newcastle at the end of last year. As well as the hotels business, De Vere has a health and fitness business which would fit well with Whitbread's David Lloyd leisure division.

According to reports yesterday, Granada is lining up the £1bn-plus sale of the Posthouse chain, which includes 80 three-star hotels, in order to counter City scepticism about the merger with Compass.

Under the terms of the deal announced last week, Granada and Compass would combine and then Granada's media business would be split off. That would leave it free to pursue its own ambitions, widely expected to be a bid for United News & Media or Carlton Communications.

But the deal has been criticised as being the cause of the diversification of Compass - which is the world's biggest catering business.

webTitle: M&S investors expect 50% cut in dividend

fields.headline: M&S investors expect 50% cut in dividend
fields.trailText: The City is bracing itself for a cut in the dividend payout from Marks & Spencer when the stores group announces its annual results tomorrow. Reports over the weekend suggested that the dividend could be cut by as much as half, which would save the company about £140m.
fields.body:
The City is bracing itself for a cut in the dividend payout from Marks & Spencer when the stores group announces its annual results tomorrow. Reports over the weekend suggested that the dividend could be cut by as much as half, which would save the company about £140m.

However, a spokeswoman for M&S dismissed the reports as "speculative" and said that a decision would not be taken until a board meeting this evening chaired by the company's new executive chairman, Luc Vandevelde.

Mr Vandevelde, who took over three months ago, is expected to outline a revival plan in his statement accompany ing tomorrow's results. Analysts expect M&S's profits before tax to fall from £546m last year to between £450m and £475m this time.

The blow to investors could be lessened by the City's reaction to the drastic action being taken by the company.

M&S has been perceived in the City as being without a recovery strategy but tough action from Mr Vandevelde could give its price a boost.

It is not expected that M&S will announce any boardroom changes - although it is understood several directors could be leaving this year following boardroom disputes.

Despite poor clothing sales M&S was last week named high street fashion retailer of the year at an event organised by Prima magazine.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rabbatts heads wired Whitehall
fields.body:
Rabbatts heads wired Whitehall

Heather Rabbatts, former chief executive of Lambeth council, is to head a new company designed to link people with the government through the internet.

Impower will look at providing links with all areas of government, including paying parking fines and council tax. It will also aid the flow of information between government departments and the business community.

Bourse merger may be delayed

The German bourse faced pressure at the weekend to delay the decision on its planned merger with the London stock exchange and rework some details of the deal to save it from collapse. After some Deutsche Börse supervisory board members and regional government and central bank officials voiced reservations about parts of the plan, speculation mounted that the decision might be postponed.

Union seeks target shift

The Transport and General Workers Union yesterday called for changes to the Bank of England's 2.5% inflation target to help manufacturing but made clear it remained opposed to early entry into the euro.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Syrian Ex-PM commits suicide
The former Syrian prime minister, Mahmoud al-Zuabi committed suicide yesterday a week after his properties and assets were frozen pending the outcome of his trial on corruption charges, political sources said.
fields.body:
Syrian Ex-PM commits suicide
The former Syrian prime minister, Mahmoud al-Zuabi committed suicide yesterday a week after his properties and assets were frozen pending the outcome of his trial on corruption charges, political sources said.

They said Zuabi, 65, who was prime minister from 1987 until his resignation in March, shot himself at his home on the outskirts of Damascus and died shortly afterwards in hospital. Reuters, Damascus

Fastest ascent of Everest
A Nepalese sherpa has set a record for the fastest ascent of Mount Everest by climbing to the top of the world's highest mountain in 15 hours and 56 minutes, according to Nepal's tourism ministry.

Babu Chiri Sherpa, 34, who reached the 8,850-metre summit more than four hours faster than the previous record-holder, used no artificial oxygen and was joined by his brother Dawa on the last part of his climb. Reuters, Kathmandu

Robber wields slippery snake
A robber held up a shocked attendant at a petrol station in the southern city of Melbourne yesterday by brandishing a one-metre python at the employee, according to Australian police.

After selecting some magazines and a drink, the man waved the reptile above his head "in a menacing way" and left without paying, a police spokesman said. AP, Melbourne

Haider meets Gadafy
Jörg Haider, until recently the head of Austria's far-right Freedom party, confirmed yesterday that he had recently visited the Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy, a move criticised by the Austrian opposition.

Mr Haider evidently made the trip on May 9 with a bank director who wanted to do business in Libya, but one Social Democrat described his trip as "highly dubious" and requiring a maximum of clarification. AP, Vienna

fields.headline: New Media diary
fields.trailText: • If you want to create an overnight publishing sensation on the net, the answer seems to be boys, boys, boys and their toys. And what better team to do it than Johnny Vaughan, ex-Loaded ed James Brown, now chief executive of his own publishing company, and Piers Adam, nightclub owner and friend of It girls and rich boys for more than 15 years? All three have been connected in a project (codenamed "the shed") which Adam and his business partner Nicholas Green hope will become the ultimate online club or lifestyle portal for guys. Clubs, babe magnets, gangsta movies, football, champers, VIP gold card- what more could a chap want? But Adam's publicist is shifty: "There is something in the offing: a portal with e-commerce, but things are at such an early stage." Brown is equally cagey: "nothing has been decided yet . . . Johnny's having talks with a lot of people." A call back to Adam soon puts us in our place. "Look, there really is no story yet but call back in a couple of weeks and we'll give you the exclusive." Ahem.

There were mews of delight at Condé Nast last week where the rumour was circulating that Jane Procter, the dreaded former editor of Tatler, was going to be "phased out" of the editorship of her own project Peoplenews.com and replaced by Catherine Ostler, former Weekend editor on the Times. Before the Persian hairs get too thick on the ground, Peoplenews have put the kibosh on the vicious gossip: "Jane is and always has been editor-in-chief - it's just that she's been involved in a hands-on way recently with hiring. Catherine was always going to come on board as UK editor," says a spokesperson, adding archly, "We know where that rumour came from, but it's ridiculous." There you have it.

A total revamp is planned for August and the department is looking at bringing in such exotic services as video streaming through their site and a mobile news service by the end of the year. Online editor Andy Bull confirms, "The site is creaky and old-fashioned and we don't know much about our readers at the moment. We are looking to adjust it to suit their needs."

First Tuesday, the new media boozing and schmoozing club, is seeking £15m for its first-round funding in order to expand its services across 24 countries. Having established the world's most high-profile networking network, it is now looking to reap benefits by becoming a co-investor in all future deals brokered through them (taking a cut of around 2%).

7#149; Food and drink website foodoo.com has signed up celebrity chefs and cookery writers in return for equity. They include Gordon Ramsay, Gary Rhodes, Sophie Grigson, Antony Worrall-Thompson and Ken Hom.

fields.headline: Digital diva's big night
fields.standfirst: Forget the Oscars, the hottest ticket in town is the Webby awards.  Hari Kunzru on the Hollywood-style ceremony honouring the superstars of new media
fields.trailText: A procession of fabulously dressed people files up the red-carpeted stairs into the auditorium. They are mobbed by screaming fans and flashbulb- popping paparazzi, while policemen redirect traffic and a line of limousines queues to disgorge passengers into the waiting crowd. So far, so typical of any US media awards ceremony - except for a few telling details. This is San Francisco, not New York or Los Angeles.
fields.body:
A procession of fabulously dressed people files up the red-carpeted stairs into the auditorium. They are mobbed by screaming fans and flashbulb- popping paparazzi, while policemen redirect traffic and a line of limousines queues to disgorge passengers into the waiting crowd. So far, so typical of any US media awards ceremony - except for a few telling details. This is San Francisco, not New York or Los Angeles.

If you look closely at the crowd, there are people dressed as spacemen and angels and Mexican beans mixed in with the Gucci-clad VIPs. At least half the photographers (and the loudest fans) are dressed in 40s outfits, giving a surreal performance-art aspect to the event, while suspended from the facade of the auditorium, people in red Lycra bodysuits are performing a kind of mid-air abseiling dance. Most tellingly, the people filing in, the superstars who are the focus of all the palaver, are not actors or musicians but new media entrepreneurs. They are fit and tanned, and positively reek of money. Suddenly, cliches about geeks and ponytails seem old-fashioned.

This is the scene outside last week's 2000 Webby awards which had a modest start four years ago in a North Beach nightclub, but now looks set to become the index of success in the global new media scene. Since it started in 1997, the Webbies has grown to eclipse its many rivals, most of which have little profile or credibility, even within the online community. A few weeks ago the Cool Site of the Year awards the longest established web awards ceremony, and a recognised name among old-school netheads, went off without causing so much as a ripple. By contrast, the Webbies is fast becoming an institution. The city's flamboyant mayor, Willie Brown, addressed the audience of 2,500, saying that, thanks to them, "this city has become the centre of the world," a sentiment predictably enough greeted with a huge cheer.

However, the Webbies phenomenon is not only the product of the West Coast's talent for self-congratulation. Even the traditional East-West rivalry hasn't prevented the New York Times from telling its readers to "forget the Oscars, here come the Webbies", while Entertainment Weekly writes drily that the awards "have grown in significance as fast as your PC has aged." Perhaps the most telling index of the ceremony's success is that given by www.sfgirl.com, a site which lists the almost indecent number of dot.com schmoozing parties in the Bay area, along with tips on how to crash them. The post-Webbies bash was rated as the hot ticket of the year, especially for those determined party girls in search of a net-millionaire husband.

The Webbies' founder, self-described "digital diva" Tiffany Shlain, describes the awards' mission as "objectively honouring excellence." To this end she has established the wonderfully pompous sounding International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences, which includes a host of big name judges, such as Simpsons creator Matt Groening on humour, David Bowie on music and Francis Ford Coppola on film.

Though the IADAS works with all the seriousness of the Oscar Academy, the Webbies' success can be ascribed less to its exertions - and its sometimes wayward choice of winners - than to Shlain's own drive and larger-than-life personality. Though the ceremony was compered by actor Alan Cumming, and awards were presented by Tina Brown and Sandra Bernhard, no one attending was left in any doubt that they were at Tiffany's show. "My inspiration this year" she bubbled in her welcoming speech, "was HG Wells's The Time Machine", before outlining her theory of how the net has "collapsed space and time and seems to allow us to experience everything all at once."

Her showmanship and eye for catchy presentational techniques have given the Webbies a number of instant "traditions," such as the 40s paparazzi, the ceremony's trademark five-word acceptance speeches, and the "nominees altar" in the foyer, a voodoo-esque concoction of vegetables, 8-balls, SF paperbacks and lucky dice that delighted San Francisco traditionalists, and baffled newcomers.

The photogenic Shlain acts as a figurehead for the awards, tirelessly promoting them through appearances on TV and in print. As a result her creation is now backed by international media group IDG, whose core business is print publishing, including the popular "for dummies" series of technology primers.

This year's Webbies appeared to mark a watershed in the convergence of "old" and "new" media. Produced with a level of glitz hitherto unseen at online gatherings, they are attracting as much attention from the worlds of mainstream music, film, TV and print media as from the dot.com business and hacker communities. Many of the winners straddle both worlds. MSNBC the quintessential broadcast-interactive collaboration between Microsoft and the NBC network, won in the TV category, while the travel award went to www.outsidemag.com the online presence of the popular US print publication.

John Battelle, founder of weekly dot.com industry bible The Standard believes that we are moving into an era when the distinctions no longer apply. "I don't see any difference any more. This year for the first time there are websites doing numbers bigger than broadcast TV ratings. It's all just media now. It's the same business."

The sharp-eyed gaggle of online marketeers will have noted the Webby recognition of several strong internet-based media brands which started up in the old-fashioned shoe string manner. Webzine the Onion won in the humour category, while the news award went to Jim Romanesko's industry gossip site Media News which is fast becoming a must-read for journalists on both sides of the Atlantic. These sites have gained preeminence through word of mouth, building communities of users from the ground up rather than relying on the huge marketing spends with which many venture capital-financed dot.com start-ups try to establish themselves.

However far the web has travelled on the road to mainstream media convergence, it still has one foot in traditional online culture, and the rules of the game are different. As a result "old" media enterprises such as film and TV are having to place representatives in the Bay area, in order to participate in the networking frenzy and keep up with accelerating technological and cultural trends.

Lucian James, a development producer with LA-based TV production company World of Wonder, recently relocated to San Francisco to develop WoW's new media operations. "Really there is no option. It's ironic. The whole point of the internet is that it's supposed be global. But somehow San Francisco is still ground zero." Battelle agrees. "This world is extraordinarily tied by personal relationships - that's why the geographic region is so important, and why people are prepared to pay $100 per square foot for real estate. They want to be within a stone's throw of everyone else."

The Webbies are now established as an integral part of this networking scene, focusing attention in a culture where attention is a primary currency, as well as giving something for start-up chief executives to brag about at parties. James believes they serve a useful purpose. "Winning a Webby is one of the best ways of raising your site out of the white noise of the rest of the internet."

However, some old-school netheads disagree. Rob "Commander Taco" Malda, who set up tech-discussion community Slashdot, which was nominated in two categories, didn't bother leaving Michigan to attend. "I'm pretty oblivious to stuff outside things that matter to me," he emails. "Web awards really don't. Ya know I've got a couple of trophies sitting on my desk from a few other awards, but they don't really matter. I've also got a folder full of cool email that readers sent me. That matters a lot more then a cheesy piece of plastic."

Despite such occasional voices of dissent, the consensus of opinion is that the Webbies are here to stay, and that next year's event will be even glitzier than this. At the after-awards party, as trays of sushi circulate and winners are mobbed by people thrusting business cards at them, net celebrity Mahir is surrounded by fans of his I Kiss You site, while the creator of controversial music-sharing software Napster is being interviewed by a TV crew as the team behind film winners Atom Films describe their plans for online commissioning and sales to studio executives from LA.

At the bar I overhear the editor of Nerve which won in the print and zines category, being schmoozed by an attractive woman in a clinging evening gown. "You must be so proud," she purrs, flashing him a smile full of dot.com promise. "Could I touch it?" He holds out his award for her to stroke. It's all a long way from geeky kids in bedrooms.

Even the traditional East-West rivalry hasn't prevented the New York Times from telling its readers to "forget the Oscars, here come the Webbies", while Entertainment Weekly writes drily that the awards "have grown in significance as fast as your PC has aged." Perhaps the most telling index of the ceremony's success is that given by www.sfgirl.com, a site which lists the almost indecent number of dot.com schmoozing parties in the Bay area, along with tips on how to crash them. The post-Webbies bash was rated as the hot ticket of the year, especially for those determined party girls in search of a net-millionaire husband. The Webbies' founder, self-described "digital diva" Tiffany Shlain, describes the awards' mission as "objectively honouring excellence." To this end she has established the wonderfully pompous sounding International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences, which includes a host of big name judges, such as Simpsons creator Matt Groening on humour, David Bowie on music and Francis Ford Coppola on film. Though the IADAS works with all the seriousness of the Oscar Academy, the Webbies' success can be ascribed less to its exertions - and its sometimes wayward choice of winners - than to Shlain's own drive and larger-than-life personality. Though the ceremony was compered by actor Alan Cumming, and awards were presented by Tina Brown and Sandra Bernhard, no one attending was left in any doubt that they were at Tiffany's show. "My inspiration this year" she bubbled in her welcoming speech, "was HG Wells's The Time Machine", before outlining her theory of how the net has "collapsed space and time and seems to allow us to experience everything all at once." Her showmanship and eye for catchy presentational techniques have given the Webbies a number of instant "traditions," such as the 40s paparazzi, the ceremony's trademark five-word acceptance speeches, and the "nominees altar" in the foyer, a voodoo-esque concoction of vegetables, 8-balls, SF paperbacks and lucky dice that delighted San Francisco traditionalists, and baffled newcomers. The photogenic Shlain acts as a figurehead for the awards, tirelessly promoting them through appearances on TV and in print. As a result her creation is now backed by international media group IDG, whose core business is print publishing, including the popular "for dummies" series of technology primers. This year's Webbies appeared to mark a watershed in the convergence of "old" and "new" media. Produced with a level of glitz hitherto unseen at online gatherings, they are attracting as much attention from the worlds of mainstream music, film, TV and print media as from the dot.com business and hacker communities. Many of the winners straddle both worlds. MSNBC the quintessential broadcast-interactive collaboration between Microsoft and the NBC network, won in the TV category, while the travel award went to www.outsidemag.com the online presence of the popular US print publication. John Battelle, founder of weekly dot.com industry bible The Standard believes that we are moving into an era when the distinctions no longer apply. "I don't see any difference any more. This year for the first time there are websites doing numbers bigger than broadcast TV ratings. It's all just media now. It's the same business." The sharp-eyed gaggle of online marketeers will have noted the Webby recognition of several strong internet-based media brands which started up in the old-fashioned shoe string manner. Webzine the Onion won in the humour category, while the news award went to Jim Romanesko's industry gossip site Media News which is fast becoming a must-read for journalists on both sides of the Atlantic. These sites have gained preeminence through word of mouth, building communities of users from the ground up rather than relying on the huge marketing spends with which many venture capital-financed dot.com start-ups try to establish themselves. However far the web has travelled on the road to mainstream media convergence, it still has one foot in traditional online culture, and the rules of the game are different. As a result "old" media enterprises such as film and TV are having to place representatives in the Bay area, in order to participate in the networking frenzy and keep up with accelerating technological and cultural trends. Lucian James, a development producer with LA-based TV production company World of Wonder, recently relocated to San Francisco to develop WoW's new media operations. "Really there is no option. It's ironic. The whole point of the internet is that it's supposed be global. But somehow San Francisco is still ground zero." Battelle agrees. "This world is extraordinarily tied by personal relationships - that's why the geographic region is so important, and why people are prepared to pay $100 per square foot for real estate. They want to be within a stone's throw of everyone else." The Webbies are now established as an integral part of this networking scene, focusing attention in a culture where attention is a primary currency, as well as giving something for start-up chief executives to brag about at parties. James believes they serve a useful purpose. "Winning a Webby is one of the best ways of raising your site out of the white noise of the rest of the internet." However, some old-school netheads disagree. Rob "Commander Taco" Malda, who set up tech-discussion community Slashdot, which was nominated in two categories, didn't bother leaving Michigan to attend. "I'm pretty oblivious to stuff outside things that matter to me," he emails. "Web awards really don't. Ya know I've got a couple of trophies sitting on my desk from a few other awards, but they don't really matter. I've also got a folder full of cool email that readers sent me. That matters a lot more then a cheesy piece of plastic." Despite such occasional voices of dissent, the consensus of opinion is that the Webbies are here to stay, and that next year's event will be even glitzier than this. At the after-awards party, as trays of sushi circulate and winners are mobbed by people thrusting business cards at them, net celebrity Mahir is surrounded by fans of his I Kiss You site, while the creator of controversial music-sharing software Napster is being interviewed by a TV crew as the team behind film winners Atom Films describe their plans for online commissioning and sales to studio executives from LA. At the bar I overhear the editor of Nerve which won in the print and zines category, being schmoozed by an attractive woman in a clinging evening gown. "You must be so proud," she purrs, flashing him a smile full of dot.com promise. "Could I touch it?" He holds out his award for her to stroke. It's all a long way from geeky kids in bedrooms.

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Jon Bains
fields.trailText: Age? 28.
fields.body:
Age? 28.

Who is he? Chairman and co-founder of lateral.net, a three-year-old web strategy, design and production company that comes up with ideas for building brands online. Before, he had a company called Obsolete and was a music journalist, DJ and graphic designer.

What's the clever idea? "Basically on all web servers there is a page you can modify which is the error page. These are very unused as media essentially, but a lot of people see them. So why not give people a bit of a surprise instead of a standard you-haven't-found-what-you're-looking-for message? They'll get a Levi's- branded picture which says things like, Chill Out, You're Looking For Things Too Quickly, that sort of thing. You click on it and it takes you to the microsite we've built www.yahoo.se/latera.

What's the thinking behind it? "For the launch of Levi's Engineered Jeans - a big new product - we wanted to do something completely different and unexpected again. And the whole thing about the jeans is that they have a twist on the leg, so we thought we'd do an online campaign with a twist, which is you never actually see it unless you find an error page. So we bought all the error pages across Europe for Yahoo! - every time anybody gets an error, they get a little Levi's message."

How does it work? "It's really simple. You've gone to Yahoo, don't find what you're looking for and it comes up with an error page. On the page, at least two-thirds of the screen is covered with a Levi's picture which, when clicked, takes you through to a "microsite" which pops up windows that allow you to navigate and find out about the products. It's a mad, bizarre website that gives users information about Levi's Engineered Jeans and a very cool online experience. It makes people think about Levis and we achieved our targets quicker than expected."

Possible shortcomings? "I'd have liked to have seen it go on more sites, but Yahoo were the only people who had pan-European spread, so we could get into all the countries we wanted. Also, people might not necessarily go through the whole experience, but that's fine because all we really want is for them to get a bit of a quick hit."

What's next? "Immediately afterwards we did the Stellas [online movie ratings]. We were trying to come up with some way to get Stella's association with film across the internet. We negotiated a deal which basically took the voting from the Guardian, Empire, Popcorn and other sites and aggregated them into one web rating system - the Stellas - so you have the actual review and also the Stella rating. Useful and a clever use of media and hopefully next year we'll do an awards ceremony. We've also just launched the website for Honest, Dave Stewart's film, and are about to launch the site for Nick Park's Chicken Run."

webTitle: Desktop icons No 20: The business card

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 20: The business card
fields.trailText: Wall Street in the 80s. A group of stockbrokers sit round a conference table. Slowly, one lays a small, off-white card on the highly polished wood. His colleagues nod in admiration. "Good colouring," says one. "That's bone. And the lettering is Silian Grail."
fields.body:
Wall Street in the 80s. A group of stockbrokers sit round a conference table. Slowly, one lays a small, off-white card on the highly polished wood. His colleagues nod in admiration. "Good colouring," says one. "That's bone. And the lettering is Silian Grail."

Someone else takes out a card. "Eggshell, with Roman." The first man smiles bitterly. "Nice".

A third broker produces a card. "Raised lettering, pale nimbus." "Impressive."

"Let's see Paul's card." The room falls silent as the third broker draws out the card of an absent colleague. The first broker's face creases in horror. "Oh my God. It even has a watermark."

The trumping of Patrick Bateman's business card by his colleagues in the recent film American Psycho is an indicator of just how important a small rectangular card can be in the world of business. Most of us, when faced with the challenge of defining ourselves in a space just 3in x 2in, plump for the conventional plain white card option. That could be your first professional mistake.

According to business card guru (yes, there are such people) Lynella Grant, business cards are "silent ambassadors . . . the handshake you leave behind". So you'd better make it a firm one.

Business cards are the descendents of the calling cards that genteel ladies started carrying in France in the early 1800s and which quickly spread across Europe and the US. In those days, even which corner was dog-eared mattered: a folded top right corner meant congratulations, a lower right fold expressed sympathy.

Philadelphia business card enthusiast (yes, they exist too) Ken Erdman has preserved many such relics in his museum dedicated to the card, as well as others crafted from glass, leather, and even china. Bateman and his buddies would be green with envy. Though you can be sure that these days they would all be carrying nothing less impressive than the new tiny CD-rom cards, carrying up to 32MB of information on a little rectangular piece of plastic.

fields.headline: Land girl
fields.standfirst: A background in banking might not seem ideal for a PA on a farm, but Tracey Abell reckons it is her strongest asset.  Hilary Whitney  reports
fields.trailText: The traditional image of the farmer out on the land from morning till night is outdated. Increasing bureaucracy may mean the average farmer struggling in an office with a mountain of paperwork. One way to ensure everything runs smoothly is to employ a secretary who is not only highly organised but is keyed into the ever-changing regulations with which farmers must keep step. A good farm secretary will be able to identify these changes immediately and deal with the paperwork accordingly.
fields.body:
The traditional image of the farmer out on the land from morning till night is outdated. Increasing bureaucracy may mean the average farmer struggling in an office with a mountain of paperwork. One way to ensure everything runs smoothly is to employ a secretary who is not only highly organised but is keyed into the ever-changing regulations with which farmers must keep step. A good farm secretary will be able to identify these changes immediately and deal with the paperwork accordingly.

Tracey Abell is certainly that. In order to encourage farm secretaries to keep up to date, the Institute of Agricultural Secretaries and Administrators (IAgSA) introduced a professional development scheme and launched an award to recognise outstanding achievement. And Abell, 44, was the inaugural winner.

Her tasks are daunting. Abell is responsible for the administration of four farms including her own family's 880 acres in Linstead Magna in Suffolk. "One of the most important parts of this job is being able to advise the farmers," she says. "They are kept very busy with the practical side of running a farm, so it's up to their secretaries to inform them about new legislation."

Far from being a country girl, Abell grew up in Harlow, Essex, and, despite being terrified of numbers, her first job was working for a bank. After a year, however, her confidence had grown and she realised she enjoyed working with figures and had a real aptitude for organising accounts. It is precisely this banking background, Abell believes, that has given her the edge in a job where a high level of numeracy is essential.

She never planned to work on a farm. "I've always loved riding and wherever I've lived I've usually helped people out with their horses. One day, someone said to me, 'Oh, you work in a bank, do you think you could do my books for me?' I thoroughly enjoyed it and began to wonder if it would be possible to do something like that for a living."

Eventually she enrolled on a full-time course at Brooksby agricultural college in Leicestershire. "At the end of the year I qualified for the national certificate of farm secretaries. In addition to the usual secretarial skills, we learnt about crop-growing, looking after animals and farm legislation. This was a fantastic grounding and meant that when we got our first jobs we weren't completely clueless about farming."

Since leaving college Abell has married a farmer and thrives on working for the family farm plus those of three neighbours. "It can get hectic but I'm a very methodical worker and I'm pretty good at juggling. All the farms are very different - for example, our farm has a dairy herd and another I work for has pigs. I enjoy being involved with different enterprises."

She visits two of the farms that she administers on a quarterly basis to ensure the books are up-to-date, and to do the VAT returns. At the end of the accounting year, which is different for every farm, she summarises the accounts before they are sent off to the accountants. "I try to make sure that I've made everything as straightforward as possible. It makes more sense for me to spend a lot of time on the accounts because I'm cheaper to pay than the accountants. I actually received a letter from our accountants that said that I was saving the farm a lot of money because I presented everything so clearly." One of the farms is on the coast and also operates as a bed and breakfast business. "I really enjoy going there. I'm given a lovely meal and we have quite a chat. It's very sociable!"

Nevertheless, being a farm secretary can be quite isolating. "Some secretaries are just given a pile of work and are left to get on with it. I don't mind that, but it is quite nice to have someone else around every now and then. Every Friday I go to a farm where the farmer usually works in the office with me - he likes to keep an overview of the administration. That's an extremely busy job because in addition to looking after his farm he is also the master of the local hunt and there's a huge amount of paperwork involved with fox-hunting. He is also the trustee of the family estate - there's never a dull moment. I often end up having to bring work home and I can be up until the early hours of the morning trying to get something finished for a deadline."

IAgSA is trying to encourage farmers to employ properly qualified farm secretaries. "Farming today is all about rules and regulations. Understandably most farmers find that very frustrating, but I think more of them are beginning to realise that a good farm secretary can take most of the bureaucracy off their hands and leave them free to do what they are really interested in."

webTitle: Hague plans direct funding for schools

fields.headline: Hague plans direct funding for schools
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague wants to bypass local education authorities (LEAs) and fund schools directly, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague wants to bypass local education authorities (LEAs) and fund schools directly, it was reported today.

Under his proposals, headteachers would be responsible for hiring private-sector services and distributing the school's budget. The plans extend the Conservatives' 80s policy of allowing schools to opt out of local authority control and gain grant-maintained (GM) status.

If the policy were implemented, hundreds of administrative staff would lose their jobs and headteachers' workloads would increase substantially.

Although Labour has begun to privatise a number of "failing" local education authorities - notably Islington and Hackney - in a drive to increase efficiency and raise standards, Mr Hague's proposals would mean that centrally funded LEAs no longer provided services free of charge to individual schools. Instead, private-sector companies could bid for them. The Tory leader believes that money spent bolstering the administrative costs of LEAs would be better spent on books and equipment.

He also wants to reduce the compulsory elements of the national curriculum and allow heads to determine pay structures in their own schools, a move which is certain to anger teaching unions. According to today's reports, Mr Hague's thinking has been influenced by a tour of New York schools.

A Conservative source was quoted as saying: "Blair knows the direction in which policy should be heading, but he is afraid to take on the educational establishment. We're not afraid... We are planning the greatest steps towards diversity and autonomy the state education system has ever seen."

Under Labour, "superheads" have been allocated to severely underperforming schools and given a greater degree of autonomy in an effort to turn around their schools. However, the high-profile resignations of three "superheads" in recent months - most recently Torsten Freidag of the Islington Arts and Media School in north London - have led to criticism of the scheme. Nonetheless, the government announced last week that it would extend the number of organisations who were eligible to bid for education services to include companies such as the Group 4 consortium.

 In another development, A-level exams may move to April if an inquiry into the reorganisation of the school year recommends the change.

LEAs already have the power to alter the pattern of the school year, and most universities favour the move, which would allow candidates to apply for places once they knew their results. At the moment, offers are conditional and are made chiefly on the basis of predicted A-level grades.

Shifting exams to April would probably create a five-term year. Students would spend their fourth term taking exams and the fifth on work experience or pre-university courses.

However, a senior government source suggested yesterday that any changes would only take place in the long term. "Quite honestly, we have got enough on our plate at the moment without undertaking this sort of change and upheaval," he said.
